question: When considering an Application for Listing, what actions may the Regulator take regarding admission of Securities to the Official List, and how does the authority under section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR relate to the circumstance-based power described in subsection (2)?
gold_answer: The Regulator has power to manage outcomes at the listing stage by either declining the Application for Listing or controlling the terms on which Securities are admitted to the Official List through conditions or restrictions, including later changing or removing those conditions or restrictions. [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] In addition, section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR specifically supports the Regulator’s ability to impose conditions or restrictions on admission to the Official List and to vary or withdraw them, which aligns with (and is reflected in) the same set of actions described for admission decisions in the listing context. [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226] The circumstance-based framing in the listing provision means these actions (refusal, or the imposition/variation/withdrawal of conditions or restrictions) are exercisable in the circumstances identified in subsection (2), rather than as an unqualified discretion. [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] Practically, this links the FSMR section 52(1)(b) authority over admission conditions to the listing decision pathway that also includes the option to refuse the Application for Listing, with both sets of actions operating within the subsection (2) circumstances. [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226] [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b]

question: If the Regulator is looking at an Application for Listing, what can it do (including refusing the application), and how does section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR fit with the rule that these actions are only available in the circumstances in subsection (2)?
gold_answer: For an Application for Listing, the Regulator can choose to refuse the Application for Listing, or it can allow admission of Securities to the Official List but attach conditions or restrictions to that admission. [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] If conditions or restrictions are used, the Regulator can also later change them or remove them entirely (vary or withdraw them). [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] Section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR provides the underlying authority for the admission-related part of this: it expressly allows the Regulator to impose conditions or restrictions on admission of Securities to the Official List and to vary or withdraw those conditions or restrictions. [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226] The listing provision adds an important boundary: the Regulator’s ability to refuse the application or to impose/vary/withdraw admission conditions is stated to apply in the circumstances specified in subsection (2). [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] Taken together, section 52(1)(b) explains the scope of the admission-condition tools, while the listing provision ties both refusal and those tools to the subsection (2) circumstances. [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226] [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b]

question: For a Reporting Entity, how do the section 82 FSMR obligation to appoint an auditor and the requirement that the auditor be appointed in accordance with Part 15 and any Rules made for that Part operate together when making the appointment?
gold_answer: A Reporting Entity must ensure it has an auditor and that the appointment is made through the specific framework referenced for auditor appointments. [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] The baseline obligation is that the Reporting Entity is required to appoint an auditor under section 82 of the FSMR, so the entity cannot omit making an appointment. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] In addition, the appointment is not merely a general designation; it must be carried out in accordance with Part 15 and any Rules made for the purposes of that Part, meaning the Reporting Entity must follow that Part 15/Rules pathway when appointing the auditor. [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] Read together, section 82 establishes the duty to appoint, while the Part 15 and related Rules condition specifies the required method or procedural basis for how the auditor is appointed. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] Accordingly, compliance requires both (i) making an auditor appointment and (ii) ensuring that appointment is made under the Part 15 and Rules framework, rather than outside it. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb]

question: If a Reporting Entity needs to appoint an auditor, what does it have to do, and what process does it have to follow, based on section 82 of the FSMR and the Part 15/Rules requirement?
gold_answer: A Reporting Entity must both appoint an auditor and make that appointment using the specific appointment framework referenced for financial reports. [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] Section 82 of the FSMR creates the requirement for a Reporting Entity to appoint an auditor, so the entity has a clear duty to make an appointment rather than leaving the role unfilled. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] The financial reports provision adds that the Reporting Entity must have an auditor appointed in accordance with Part 15 and any Rules made for the purposes of that Part, so the appointment must be done through that Part 15 and Rules route. [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] Putting these together, the “what” is appointing an auditor (the obligation), and the “how” is that the appointment must be made in line with Part 15 and any Rules made for that Part (the required basis for the appointment). [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] This means a Reporting Entity should treat Part 15 and its Rules as the governing process for fulfilling the section 82 appointment duty. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb]

question: Where an Applicant/Authorised Person seeks FSRA approval for its FSP to cover a Regulated Activity in relation to both conventional assets (e.g., Securities or Derivatives) and Spot Commodities, how should the fee outcome be determined if the Regulator considers it fair and reasonable to reduce, waive or refund fees in that particular case?
gold_answer: If an Applicant/Authorised Person will undertake a Regulated Activity involving conventional assets in addition to Spot Commodities, it must seek approval from the FSRA for its FSP to permit it to carry out its Regulated Activity in relation to both asset types. [#SRC:e801f4a4-1a6e-4c91-92d6-724eec350cc0] In that dual-asset scenario, the fee outcome is not automatically cumulative across the conventional and Spot Commodity-related Regulated Activities where the FSRA exercises discretion to reduce or waive a fee, taking into account the high fees already imposed on Applicants/Authorised Persons conducting Regulated Activities using Spot Commodities. [#SRC:e801f4a4-1a6e-4c91-92d6-724eec350cc0] This aligns with the Regulator’s broader power to reduce, waive, or refund all or part of any fee (including supplementary or late payment fees) at any time, provided it considers that doing so would be fair and reasonable in the circumstances of the particular case. [#TGT:0caa9f08-40e5-42b7-9cef-4148ae1dc036] Accordingly, when the Regulator reaches a fairness-and-reasonableness view for the specific case, it may implement that relief in a way that prevents fees from stacking cumulatively across the two asset types, rather than charging full fees for both without adjustment. [#SRC:e801f4a4-1a6e-4c91-92d6-724eec350cc0] [#TGT:0caa9f08-40e5-42b7-9cef-4148ae1dc036]

question: If an Applicant/Authorised Person wants its FSP to cover Regulated Activities for both Spot Commodities and conventional assets (like Securities or Derivatives), can the Regulator lower or waive fees so they don’t add up twice, and when can it do that?
gold_answer: Yes, in the situation where an Applicant/Authorised Person will be undertaking a Regulated Activity involving conventional assets in addition to Spot Commodities, it needs FSRA approval for its FSP to allow it to conduct the Regulated Activity for both asset types. [#SRC:e801f4a4-1a6e-4c91-92d6-724eec350cc0] When fees are being considered for those conventional and Spot Commodity-related Regulated Activities, the fees may be treated as not cumulative if the FSRA uses its discretion to reduce or waive a fee, particularly in light of the high fees already imposed on Applicants/Authorised Persons conducting Regulated Activities using Spot Commodities. [#SRC:e801f4a4-1a6e-4c91-92d6-724eec350cc0] Separately, the Regulator has a general ability to reduce, waive, or refund all or part of any fee (including supplementary or late payment fees) at any time, as long as it considers that doing so would be fair and reasonable in the circumstances of the particular case. [#TGT:0caa9f08-40e5-42b7-9cef-4148ae1dc036] Putting these together, the Regulator can apply that fairness-based relief in a way that avoids fees stacking up across both asset types when the case circumstances justify it. [#SRC:e801f4a4-1a6e-4c91-92d6-724eec350cc0] [#TGT:0caa9f08-40e5-42b7-9cef-4148ae1dc036]

question: When deciding whether to revoke a Recognition Order, how does the Regulator distinguish between using its power to give directions to secure compliance with the Recognition Requirements (including directions that may require premises access or suspension of activities) and proceeding to revocation, and what specific circumstances trigger the revocation approach?
gold_answer: The Regulator may use directions to require a Recognised Body to take specified steps to secure compliance with the Recognition Requirements, but it will usually consider revoking a Recognition Order where a direction is not suitable or the Recognised Body’s position warrants revocation. [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500] In particular, revocation is typically considered if the Recognised Body is failing or has failed to meet one or more Recognition Requirements and that failure has or will have serious consequences. [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a] Revocation is also the usual approach where it would not be possible for the Recognised Body to comply with a direction given under the Regulator’s direction power, or where (for another reason) it would not be appropriate for the Regulator to give such a direction. [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a] By contrast, where directions are used, the specified steps can include granting the Regulator access to the Recognised Body’s premises to inspect the premises or documents there, and requiring suspension of the carrying on of any activity for the period stated in the direction. [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500] Separately, revocation is usually considered if the Recognised Body has not carried on the business of a Recognised Body during the 12 months starting on the day the Recognition Order took effect, or has not carried on that business at any time during the six months ending on the day the Recognition Order is revoked. [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a]

question: If a Recognised Body is not meeting the Recognition Requirements, when would the Regulator tell it to take steps (like letting the Regulator inspect its premises or pausing activities) instead of moving to revoke the Recognition Order, and what time-based business inactivity situations can also lead to revocation?
gold_answer: The Regulator can direct a Recognised Body to take specified steps to secure compliance with the Recognition Requirements, but it will usually consider revoking the Recognition Order in defined situations where directions are not enough or not suitable. [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500] Directions can require practical measures such as giving the Regulator access to the Recognised Body’s premises to inspect the premises or documents there, and suspending the carrying on of any activity for a period set out in the direction. [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500] However, revocation is usually considered if the Recognised Body is failing or has failed to satisfy one or more Recognition Requirements and that failure has or will have serious consequences. [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a] Revocation is also usually considered if it would not be possible for the Recognised Body to comply with a direction, or if (for some other reason) it would not be appropriate for the Regulator to give a direction. [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a] In addition, the Regulator will usually consider revocation where the Recognised Body has not carried on the business of a Recognised Body during the 12 months beginning when the Recognition Order took effect, or where it has not carried on that business at any time during the six months ending on the day the Recognition Order is revoked. [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a]

question: Where an Issuer makes an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM and has published a Prospectus, what must the Issuer (or the person responsible for the issue of the Prospectus) do if, after the Prospectus is issued, a significant change occurs or a material mistake/inaccuracy or significant new matter arises, and what baseline prospectus requirement anchors this obligation?
gold_answer: In this scenario, the Issuer’s baseline obligation is to publish a Prospectus when it wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] Once that Prospectus has been issued, if at any time afterward there is a significant change in information, a material mistake or inaccuracy affecting a matter in the Prospectus, or a significant new matter arises, the Issuer or the person responsible for issuing the Prospectus must issue a supplementary prospectus. [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] The supplementary prospectus must (i) set out details of the relevant change, mistake, inaccuracy, or new matter, and (ii) meet the requirements referenced in section 62(1). [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] The timing trigger is explicitly “after the issue of a Prospectus” and applies whenever the specified events occur, meaning the duty is ongoing for the period after issuance rather than limited to a single update point. [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] This supplementary-prospectus duty is therefore an extension of the initial prospectus publication requirement that applies to Offers of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd]

question: If an Issuer is offering Securities to the public in or from ADGM and has already put out a Prospectus, what should happen if something important changes or a big error is found after the Prospectus is issued, and how does this connect to the original need to publish a Prospectus?
gold_answer: For an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, the Issuer is expected to publish a Prospectus as part of the applicable requirements for such offers. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] After that Prospectus has been issued, the rules then require an additional step if certain events occur: if at any time there is a significant change, or a material mistake or inaccuracy affecting something in the Prospectus, or a significant new matter arises, the Issuer (or the person responsible for issuing the Prospectus) must produce a supplementary prospectus. [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] That supplementary prospectus has two core content/compliance elements: it must describe the relevant change, mistake, inaccuracy, or new matter, and it must comply with the requirements in section 62(1). [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] The link between the two texts is that the supplementary prospectus obligation only makes sense once the Issuer has already met the initial prospectus publication requirement for the public offer in or from ADGM. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] The trigger is explicitly tied to the period after the Prospectus is issued, and it applies whenever the specified kinds of developments occur. [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c]

question: When a Petroleum Reporting Entity has new material estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves that have not previously been disclosed, what is the required disclosure timing and what specific content elements must be included in that disclosure (including how it should address prior disclosures)?
gold_answer: A Petroleum Reporting Entity must make an immediate disclosure when it has new material estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves that have not previously been disclosed. [#TGT:1d41da19-7d47-42e7-baf3-28af0f6c1c12] When making that disclosure under Rule 12.6.1, it must also ensure the disclosure includes specific supporting information that explains the basis for the new estimates and how they differ from what was previously reported. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] In practice, the disclosure should cover all of the following elements: - Identify the types of permits or licences the Petroleum Reporting Entity holds that relate to the estimates being disclosed. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] - Explain the new data and information that underpins the new material estimates. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] - Explain how that new data and information has affected the estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Resources (including Petroleum Reserves). [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] - Describe any changes or additions to information previously disclosed for Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources, and Petroleum Reserves by reference to the specified prior-disclosure categories. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] This combines the timing trigger (immediate disclosure of new material estimates) with the minimum content needed to make that disclosure complete. [#TGT:1d41da19-7d47-42e7-baf3-28af0f6c1c12] [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704]

question: If a Petroleum Reporting Entity comes up with new material estimates for Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources, or Petroleum Reserves that it has never disclosed before, how fast does it need to disclose them, and what details must it include about licences, the new data, and what changed compared with earlier disclosures?
gold_answer: The Petroleum Reporting Entity must disclose the new material estimates immediately when they have not previously been disclosed. [#TGT:1d41da19-7d47-42e7-baf3-28af0f6c1c12] When it makes that disclosure under Rule 12.6.1, it must also include enough detail to show what the estimates relate to and why they changed. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] The disclosure needs to include, at a minimum: - The types of permits or licences the Petroleum Reporting Entity holds that relate to the estimates. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] - A clear explanation of the new data and information. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] - An explanation of how the new data and information affected the estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources, or Petroleum Resources (which includes Petroleum Reserves). [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] - Any changes or additions to what it previously disclosed for Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources, and Petroleum Reserves, using the listed prior-disclosure groupings. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] So the rule is both “disclose right away” and “include the specified supporting explanations and updates to earlier information.” [#TGT:1d41da19-7d47-42e7-baf3-28af0f6c1c12] [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704]

question: For a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity preparing its quarterly report, what information must the report contain (including any consolidated-basis requirement and the 12‑month reserves/resources disclosure cross-reference), and by when after quarter-end must the report required by Rule 12.13.1 be disclosed?
gold_answer: A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity must both (i) include specified content in its quarterly report for each quarter of its financial year and (ii) disclose the Rule 12.13.1 report within a defined post‑quarter deadline. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] [#SRC:380ff25a-7805-4020-9f40-da991f91eab1] The quarterly report must cover the Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity and all controlled entities, prepared on a consolidated basis where applicable. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] It must include: details of Petroleum-related activities for Exploration (or a statement of no Exploration activity) and for production and development (or a statement of no mining production and development activity); a summary of expenditure incurred for Exploration and for production and development; Petroleum Tenements held at quarter-end with location and percentage interest (including beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements); and Petroleum Tenements (including those beneficial interests) acquired or disposed of during the quarter with their location. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] In addition, at least once every 12 months the report must address the Summary of Reserves and Resources required by Rule 12.14.1 unless that summary is included in the annual report, and it must state when the previous and upcoming disclosures of that summary were and are to be made. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] The Rule 12.13.1 quarterly report must be disclosed no later than one month after the end of the quarter. [#SRC:380ff25a-7805-4020-9f40-da991f91eab1]

question: What does a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity have to put in its quarterly report (including what to say if there were no activities and what to cover about controlled entities), and how soon after the quarter ends does it have to disclose the Rule 12.13.1 report?
gold_answer: A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity’s quarterly report has two linked requirements: it must include specific Petroleum-related information for the quarter (with a consolidated scope where relevant), and it must be disclosed within a set time after the quarter ends. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] [#SRC:380ff25a-7805-4020-9f40-da991f91eab1] On content, the report is for each quarter of the financial year and must cover the Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity and all controlled entities, using a consolidated basis if applicable. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] It must describe activities relating to Petroleum Exploration (or clearly state there were no Exploration activities) and production and development (or state there were no mining production and development activities). [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] It also must summarize expenditure for Exploration and for production and development, list Petroleum Tenements held at quarter-end with location and percentage interest (including beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements), and identify Petroleum Tenements acquired or disposed of during the quarter (including those beneficial interests) with their location. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] Separately, the report must address the Summary of Reserves and Resources at least once every 12 months unless included in the annual report, and it must indicate when the prior and next such disclosures were and are due. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] The Rule 12.13.1 report must be disclosed no later than one month after the end of the quarter. [#SRC:380ff25a-7805-4020-9f40-da991f91eab1]

question: When the Listing Authority concludes, after an enquiry into a complaint or allegation, that the information is accurate, constitutes Inside Information, and is not covered by the Rule 7.2.2 disclosure exemption, how should the Listing Authority proceed under Rule 7.2.1, and what specific confirmations and timing details would an ‘aware letter’ typically require from the Reporting Entity if the information should have been Disclosed earlier?
gold_answer: Where the Listing Authority’s enquiry leads it to decide the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and does not fall within the Rule 7.2.2 exemption from disclosure, it will require the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter under Rule 7.2.1. [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944] If the Listing Authority considers the information should have been Disclosed earlier, it may issue an ‘aware letter’ as a follow-on step. [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944] In that aware letter, the Listing Authority would typically (a) identify the information at issue and state the relevant date it was Disclosed, and then (b) ask the Reporting Entity to address whether it considers the information to be Inside Information, using the reasonable-person/price-effect framing described in the template. [#TGT:f221a729-4fb2-4eca-bb45-6c892c667a28] If the Reporting Entity answers that it is Inside Information, the letter generally seeks timing and context: when the Reporting Entity first became aware of it, including the time and circumstances of becoming aware of the key contents. [#TGT:f221a729-4fb2-4eca-bb45-6c892c667a28] It also asks why the Reporting Entity did not Disclose earlier or request a Trading Halt or Suspension earlier, with specific commentary on Rule 7.2.1, and requests confirmation of compliance with the Markets Rules, particularly Rule 7.2.1. [#TGT:f221a729-4fb2-4eca-bb45-6c892c667a28]

question: If the Listing Authority checks a complaint and decides the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not exempt under Rule 7.2.2, what does it ask the Reporting Entity to do under Rule 7.2.1, and what kinds of questions would an ‘aware letter’ ask if the Listing Authority thinks the information should have been Disclosed earlier?
gold_answer: If the Listing Authority’s enquiry results in a view that the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not within the Rule 7.2.2 exemption from disclosure, it will ask the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter under Rule 7.2.1. [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944] When the Listing Authority also believes the information should have been Disclosed earlier, it may escalate by issuing an ‘aware letter’ (or taking other action), which is used to probe the Reporting Entity’s handling and timing of disclosure. [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944] An aware letter generally follows a standard template that first identifies the information and notes the date it was Disclosed. [#TGT:f221a729-4fb2-4eca-bb45-6c892c667a28] It then asks whether the Reporting Entity considers that information to be Inside Information, described as information a reasonable person would expect to significantly affect the price of the Listed Entity’s Securities. [#TGT:f221a729-4fb2-4eca-bb45-6c892c667a28] If the Reporting Entity says “yes,” the letter typically asks when it first became aware of the Inside Information (including time and circumstances) and why it did not Disclose earlier or request a Trading Halt or Suspension earlier, with specific comments on Rule 7.2.1. [#TGT:f221a729-4fb2-4eca-bb45-6c892c667a28] If the Reporting Entity says “no,” it must explain the basis for that view and confirm compliance with the Markets Rules, especially Rule 7.2.1. [#TGT:f221a729-4fb2-4eca-bb45-6c892c667a28]

question: Where the Regulator considers a name issue under Section 117 of FSMR, how does the Regulator’s power to make a direction apply across (i) a Fund, (ii) a Sub-Fund, and (iii) a class of Units in a Fund, and what specific action may the Regulator require and from whom when the name is undesirable, misleading, or conflicts with another name?
gold_answer: If the Regulator forms the view that a relevant name is undesirable, misleading, or conflicts with a name used by another product, the Regulator has power to issue a direction under Section 117 of FSMR covering not only a Fund and a Sub-Fund but also a class of Units in a Fund. [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295] When exercising that power in relation to a Fund or a Sub Fund, the Regulator may require a concrete remedial step: it may direct the Fund Manager to change the name of the Fund or the Sub Fund. [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff] The triggering conditions align across both passages: the Regulator’s assessment (including where the name conflicts with another Fund/Sub-Fund name, or is undesirable or misleading) is the basis for intervention. [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff] The scope of what can be assessed for undesirability, misleading character, or conflict is broader in that it expressly includes a class of Units in a Fund in addition to Funds and Sub-Funds. [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295] Accordingly, compliance planning should treat the Fund Manager as the directed party for Fund/Sub Fund name changes, while recognizing that the Regulator’s naming-direction power extends to class-of-Units naming issues as well. [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff] [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295]

question: If the Regulator thinks a name is confusing or clashes with another name, what kinds of names can it step in on (Fund, Sub-Fund, or class of Units), and who can it tell to change the name?
gold_answer: When the Regulator believes a name is undesirable, misleading, or conflicts with a name used by another Fund, Sub-Fund, or class of Units, it has the power to make a direction under Section 117 of FSMR. [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295] The set of names that can trigger this power includes the name of a Fund, a Sub-Fund, and also a class of Units in a Fund, so the Regulator’s concern is not limited to only the top-level Fund name. [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295] If the issue relates to the name of a Fund or a Sub Fund, the Regulator can require a specific fix by directing the Fund Manager to change that name. [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff] This means the decision point is the Regulator’s opinion about conflict, undesirability, or misleading character, and the operational obligation (for Fund/Sub Fund names) falls on the Fund Manager to implement the change when directed. [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff] Taken together, you should treat naming reviews as covering Fund/Sub-Fund/class-of-Units names, and be ready for a direction that specifically instructs the Fund Manager to rename a Fund or Sub Fund. [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295] [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff]

question: For a Third Party Provider entering into a Governing Contract with a Customer, what information must be included in the Governing Contract (absent a written agreement otherwise), and by what point must that Rule 20.2.2 information be provided so the Customer is not bound before receiving it?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider must ensure the Customer receives the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 before the Customer becomes bound by the Governing Contract. [#SRC:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8] Unless the Third Party Provider and their Customer have otherwise agreed in writing, that Rule 20.2.2 information is the set of items that the Governing Contract itself is required to contain. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] In practice, this means the contract must include, at a minimum, identifying and regulatory details about the Third Party Provider (including its name, ADGM office contact details, and the name of its Regulator and Financial Service Permission details), and operational details about the Third Party Services (including service characteristics, what customer information/identifier is needed for a Third Party Transaction, consent process, time of receipt of a Third Party Transaction, maximum service time, and any usage limits). [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] It must also cover charges and (where relevant) exchange rates and Reference Exchange Rates mechanics, agreed communication methods and frequencies (including what Customer information is transferred to the Customer’s Financial Institution), safeguards/corrective measures (including notification periods for unauthorised or incorrect Third Party Transactions and relevant liability/refund conditions), change/termination terms, and redress provisions. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] The timing requirement is that this information must be provided before the Customer is bound, even if information may also be provided during the period of the Governing Contract. [#SRC:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8]

question: If a Third Party Provider is about to sign a Governing Contract with a Customer, what details have to be in the contract (unless they both agree something else in writing), and when does the Customer need to get that information so they are not bound too early?
gold_answer: The Customer must be given the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 before the Customer is bound by the Governing Contract. [#SRC:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8] Unless the Third Party Provider and their Customer agree otherwise in writing, the Governing Contract must itself contain that information, so providing the contract with the required content is the normal way to meet the pre-binding delivery requirement. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] The required contract content includes: who the Third Party Provider is (its name, its ADGM office address/contact details, and its Regulator and Financial Service Permission details); what the Third Party Services are (main characteristics, what customer information/unique identifier is needed for a Third Party Transaction, how consent is given, when a Third Party Transaction is treated as received, maximum service time, and any usage limits); and what it costs (all charges and, where relevant, exchange rate details including Reference Exchange Rates and how changes apply if agreed). [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] It also must explain communications (including technical requirements and what Customer information is transferred to the Customer’s Financial Institution), safeguards and corrective measures (including how/when to notify unauthorised or incorrect Third Party Transactions and liability/refund conditions), how changes and termination work, and redress options. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] Even though information can be provided during the period of the Governing Contract, the key timing point is that the Customer must receive it before being bound. [#SRC:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure that does not follow a non-mandatory requirement in a Mining Reporting Standard (for example, a non-mandatory item in Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code), what must the Mining Reporting Entity include in the disclosure, and how does this relate to the Regulator’s expectation of compliance under Rule 11.2.1(1) and the explanation approach referenced in Rule 11.2.2?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is expected to comply fully with non-mandatory requirements in a Mining Reporting Standard, but if it does not, it must transparently explain the departure within the disclosure itself. [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124] Specifically, where a disclosure does not meet a non-mandatory requirement in the relevant Mining Reporting Standard, the Mining Reporting Entity must include a statement in that disclosure describing both how the disclosure differs and why it differs from the non-mandatory requirement. [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f] This disclosure-level statement operationalizes the Regulator’s expectation that non-mandatory requirements are followed unless the entity explains non-compliance, including in relation to non-mandatory items such as those found in Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code. [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124] In practical terms, the Mining Reporting Entity should (i) identify the specific non-mandatory requirement it did not meet, (ii) describe the nature of the difference, and (iii) provide the reason for that difference, all within the disclosure. [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f] This approach aligns with the referenced expectation to explain non-compliance in accordance with Rule 11.2.2 when non-mandatory requirements are not followed. [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure doesn’t follow a non-mandatory part of a Mining Reporting Standard (like something in Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code), what exactly has to be written in the disclosure, and how does that fit with the Regulator’s expectation to comply or explain under Rule 11.2.1(1) and Rule 11.2.2?
gold_answer: If a Mining Reporting Entity does not follow a non-mandatory requirement in a Mining Reporting Standard, it still needs to address that gap directly and clearly in the disclosure. [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124] The disclosure must contain a statement that explains both (1) how the disclosure is different from the non-mandatory requirement and (2) why it is different. [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f] This is consistent with the Regulator’s stated expectation that the Mining Reporting Entity should fully comply with non-mandatory requirements (including examples such as Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code) unless it provides an explanation of non-compliance. [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124] In other words, the “comply or explain” idea is implemented by requiring the explanation to be included inside the disclosure whenever the non-mandatory requirement is not met. [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f] This also matches the reference to explaining non-compliance in accordance with Rule 11.2.2 when the entity does not follow non-mandatory requirements. [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124]

question: For a Listed Entity that has only partially adopted the best practice standards in APP 4, what specific disclosures must appear in its annual financial report, and how does that annual reporting obligation align with the Regulator’s expectation for disclosure in the Prospectus and thereafter under Rule 9.2.10, including the consequence of inaccurate or false representations?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity that has only partially adopted APP 4 must make a structured set of disclosures in its annual financial report, and those disclosures should be consistent with the Regulator’s expectation that the same type of explanation and alternative measures be disclosed in the Prospectus and then continued thereafter under Rule 9.2.10. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] [#SRC:ff5bac8d-3dc7-46dd-a9ce-b0c32a42422e] Specifically, the annual financial report must (i) state whether the APP 4 best practice standards (the Corporate Governance Principles) have been adopted, and (ii) where adoption is partial, explain why full adoption did not occur and describe what actions (if any) were taken to achieve compliance to the extent of the gap. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] In addition, Directors must provide an opinion on whether the Listed Entity’s Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, supported by information and assumptions and including qualifications if needed. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] In parallel, where a Reporting Entity does not adopt APP 4 (or does so only partially), the Regulator expects the reasons and any alternative measures adopted to achieve the intended outcomes to be disclosed in the Prospectus and thereafter pursuant to Rule 9.2.10. [#SRC:ff5bac8d-3dc7-46dd-a9ce-b0c32a42422e] Any inaccurate or false representations in these disclosures can result in civil liability under section 70 of the FSMR. [#SRC:ff5bac8d-3dc7-46dd-a9ce-b0c32a42422e]

question: If a Listed Entity hasn’t fully followed APP 4, what does it need to say in its annual financial report, and what extra disclosure does the Regulator expect in the Prospectus and later under Rule 9.2.10—and what happens if the statements are inaccurate or false?
gold_answer: When a Listed Entity has not fully adopted APP 4, its annual financial report must clearly report both the status of adoption and the reasons and steps taken, and this should sit alongside the Regulator’s expectation that similar explanations and alternative measures are disclosed in the Prospectus and then continued under Rule 9.2.10. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] [#SRC:ff5bac8d-3dc7-46dd-a9ce-b0c32a42422e] In the annual financial report, the Listed Entity must state whether it has adopted the APP 4 best practice standards (the Corporate Governance Principles). [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] If adoption is not full (including partial adoption), it must explain why and describe what actions, if any, it has taken to achieve compliance to the extent the standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] The report must also include a statement by Directors on whether, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance, supported by information and assumptions and with qualifications if necessary. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] Separately, where a Reporting Entity does not adopt APP 4 or does so only partially, the Regulator expects the reasons and any alternative measures adopted to achieve the intended outcomes to be disclosed in the Prospectus and thereafter under Rule 9.2.10. [#SRC:ff5bac8d-3dc7-46dd-a9ce-b0c32a42422e] If the disclosures contain inaccurate or false representations, civil liability may be imposed under section 70 of the FSMR. [#SRC:ff5bac8d-3dc7-46dd-a9ce-b0c32a42422e]

question: For an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, how should the Resolution Pack requirement to include the master list of all Client Accounts be satisfied in terms of the specific data fields that must appear on that master list?
gold_answer: To satisfy the Resolution Pack requirement for an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, the master list of all Client Accounts must be included in the Resolution Pack and must be maintained with the specific account details prescribed for that master list. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d] The Resolution Pack scope expressly includes the master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments, so the pack should contain the master list(s) that the Authorised Person maintains for those Client Accounts. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] In maintaining that master list, the Authorised Person must ensure it details, for each Client Account, the account name, account number, and where the account is located. [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d] It must also identify the bank and include the bank’s address and contact information, and it must record the account’s terms and conditions. [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d] Finally, the master list must show whether each account is open or closed and the date it was opened or closed, so that the Resolution Pack contains a complete and status-aware inventory of Client Accounts. [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d]

question: When putting together the Resolution Pack, what information has to be on the master list of all Client Accounts that the Authorised Person must keep?
gold_answer: The Resolution Pack must include the master list (or master lists) of all Client Accounts, and that list must be kept with the specific details required for each account. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d] The Resolution Pack requirement applies to an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business and explicitly calls for master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments, so the pack should contain the maintained master list covering those Client Accounts. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] The master list itself must include, for every Client Account, the account’s name and number and where the account is held (its location). [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d] It also has to identify the bank and provide the bank’s address and contact details, and it must capture the account’s terms and conditions. [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d] In addition, the list must show whether the account is open or closed and record the opening date or closure date, so the Resolution Pack includes an up-to-date view of each Client Account’s status. [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d]

question: When the Regulator issues a written collateral notice to a Captive Insurer requiring assets to be made available, how is the maximum value of those assets capped by reference to the “lower of” test, and how is the Rule 10.3.2(4) amount determined for (i) a Captive Cell of a Captive Insurer which is a Cell Company and (ii) a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company?
gold_answer: A collateral notice can require a Captive Insurer to make available assets, but the value of assets that can be required is capped at the lower of (1) any amount stated in the notice and (2) the amount calculated under Rule 10.3.2(4), with the asset value determined under Chapter 6. [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7] To apply that cap, the Rule 10.3.2(4) amount depends on the Captive Insurer’s structure and the relevant business segment. [#SRC:9585f95e-ae97-44a1-966f-ec94cc458c39] For the Rule 10.3.2(4) limb of the “lower of” test: - For a Captive Cell of a Captive Insurer which is a Cell Company, the amount is the sum of (i) the Insurance Liabilities attributable to that Captive Cell and (ii) the Minimum Cellular Capital Requirement applicable to that Captive Cell. [#SRC:9585f95e-ae97-44a1-966f-ec94cc458c39] - For a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company, the amount is the sum of (i) the Captive Insurer’s Insurance Liabilities and (ii) the Captive Insurer’s minimum capital requirement as provided for in Rule 2.2. [#SRC:9585f95e-ae97-44a1-966f-ec94cc458c39] Accordingly, the collateral notice cannot require assets (valued under Chapter 6) above whichever is lower: the notice-stated amount (if any) or the applicable Rule 10.3.2(4) calculation for the relevant case. [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7]

question: If the Regulator sends a collateral notice to a Captive Insurer, what is the limit on how much asset value can be required, and how do you work out that limit for a Long-Term Insurance Fund using the Rule 10.3.2(4) calculation?
gold_answer: A collateral notice can require a Captive Insurer to make assets available, but the required asset value (as valued under Chapter 6) is limited to the lower of (i) any amount written into the notice and (ii) the amount calculated under Rule 10.3.2(4). [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7] This means you must compute the Rule 10.3.2(4) amount for the relevant case and then compare it to any figure specified in the notice to identify the binding cap. [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7] For a Long-Term Insurance Fund, the Rule 10.3.2(4) amount is calculated as the sum of two components, subject to the stated cross-references in that rule: (1) the Insurance Liabilities attributable to that Long-Term Insurance Fund and (2) the Minimum Fund Capital Requirement applicable to that Long-Term Insurance Fund. [#SRC:9585f95e-ae97-44a1-966f-ec94cc458c39] Once that sum is determined, it becomes the Rule 10.3.2(4) comparator in the “lower of” test used to cap the collateral notice requirement. [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7] In practice, the maximum asset value that can be required is whichever is lower: the notice amount (if any) or the Long-Term Insurance Fund sum described above. [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7]

question: When a Prospectus has been filed with the Regulator and is intended to be treated as an “Approved Prospectus” for the purposes of subsection (1), what specific approval action must the Regulator take, and how does that action apply where the Prospectus comprises multiple documents under the Rules-based approval concept?
gold_answer: A filed Prospectus is treated as an “Approved Prospectus” only when the Regulator has taken an affirmative approval step, not merely because it has been filed. Under the Regulations’ framing, a Prospectus qualifies as an Approved Prospectus if it is approved by the Regulator in line with the requirements prescribed in the Rules, and references to a Prospectus in the Regulations are generally to an Approved Prospectus unless context indicates otherwise. [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1] In addition, for the filing to result in an Approved Prospectus for the stated statutory purpose, the Regulator must issue the Applicant a notice that states the Regulator’s approval. [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e] That notice must cover the Prospectus (or, where applicable, the Supplementary Prospectus). [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e] Where the Prospectus consists of multiple documents, the notice must expressly approve all of those multiple documents, aligning the practical evidence of approval (the notice) with the Rules-based approval concept used to define an Approved Prospectus. [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e] [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1]

question: If someone says a Prospectus is “approved” just because it was filed with the Regulator, what extra step is needed for it to count as an Approved Prospectus, and what changes if the Prospectus is made up of multiple documents?
gold_answer: Filing a Prospectus with the Regulator, by itself, does not make it an Approved Prospectus; an additional approval step is required. Specifically, the Regulator must issue the Applicant a notice that states the Regulator’s approval of the Prospectus (or, if relevant, the Supplementary Prospectus). [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e] This notice-based approval is the concrete action that turns a filed document into an approved one for the stated statutory purpose. [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e] Separately, the Regulations explain that a Prospectus is an Approved Prospectus when it is approved by the Regulator in accordance with the requirements prescribed in the Rules, and that when the Regulations refer to a “Prospectus” they generally mean an Approved Prospectus unless the context requires otherwise. [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1] If the Prospectus is made up of multiple documents, the Regulator’s notice must cover approval of all the multiple documents, not just one part, so that the approval aligns with how the Prospectus is constituted. [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e]

question: When an Authorised Person is establishing and maintaining systems and controls to deter/prevent and report suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes, how should it reflect best practices given the evolving nature of Financial Crime, and what concrete measures are indicated as examples for those systems and controls?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must have effective systems and controls that both (i) deter and prevent suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes against the Authorised Person and its Customers and (ii) enable reporting of suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes to the relevant authorities. [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] In establishing the systems and controls required for this purpose, the Authorised Person should also observe best practices, explicitly recognizing that Financial Crime evolves and that controls should be designed with that changing risk in mind. [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7] Practically, this means the required fraud/Financial Crime framework should be implemented and maintained in a way that can support both prevention/deterrence and reporting outcomes, while incorporating concrete control features that are identified as examples of best practice. [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7] Examples of such best-practice measures include using secure authentication, deploying biometrics, and monitoring customer behaviour metrics within anti-fraud and anti-Financial Crime systems and controls. [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7] Taken together, the obligation to establish and maintain effective systems and controls is met not only by having controls in place for deterrence/prevention and reporting, but by building them using these kinds of evolving best-practice techniques. [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7]

question: If an Authorised Person needs controls to stop fraud and other Financial Crimes and to report suspected cases, what best-practice features should it consider adding to those controls because Financial Crime keeps changing?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person is required to set up and keep effective systems and controls that do two things: help deter and prevent suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes against the Authorised Person and its Customers, and support reporting suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes to the relevant authorities. [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] When putting those systems and controls in place, the Authorised Person should also follow best practices, specifically because Financial Crime is evolving and controls should be designed with that changing threat in mind. [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7] In other words, the required fraud/Financial Crime controls should not be static; they should be built and maintained in a way that supports prevention/deterrence and reporting while using practical techniques that are identified as best-practice examples. [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7] The examples given of such best-practice techniques are incorporating secure authentication, using biometrics, and monitoring customer behaviour metrics as part of anti-fraud and anti-Financial Crime systems and controls. [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7] Using these features helps align the way the controls are established with the obligation to maintain effective controls for both stopping suspected misconduct and reporting it. [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7]

question: For an Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager of an ADGM Green Portfolio, how should the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement be applied across different portions of Eligible Green Portfolio Assets when some assets are aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy under Rule 3.8.4(a) and other assets are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark under Rule 3.8.4(b)?
gold_answer: The Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement applies only to the portion of Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy under Rule 3.8.4(a), and it does not apply to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark under Rule 3.8.4(b). [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e] [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86] In practice, the Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager must segment the portfolio by these Rule 3.8.4 categories so the attestation scope is limited to the taxonomy-aligned portion and excludes the EU Paris Aligned Benchmark-tracking portion. [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e] [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86] For the in-scope portion, the Investment Manager must appoint a third party to attest to compliance with the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually. [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e] Conversely, where Eligible Green Portfolio Assets fall within the EU Paris Aligned Benchmark condition described in Rule 3.8.4(b), Rule 3.8.6 provides that the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to those assets, so they should not be included in the third-party attestation coverage. [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86]

question: If an ADGM Green Portfolio has (1) assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy under Rule 3.8.4(a) and (2) assets that track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark under Rule 3.8.4(b), which part needs the third-party attestation and how often must it be done?
gold_answer: Only the portion of Eligible Green Portfolio Assets invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy under Rule 3.8.4(a) is subject to the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement, while the portion included in or otherwise tracking an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark under Rule 3.8.4(b) is excluded from that requirement. [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e] [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86] For the in-scope (taxonomy-aligned) portion, the Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager of an ADGM Green Portfolio must appoint a third party to attest to compliance with the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement. [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e] The attestation must be maintained on an ongoing basis and performed at least annually for that in-scope portion. [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e] By contrast, Rule 3.8.6 states that the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark in accordance with Rule 3.8.4(b), so those assets should not be counted when determining what the third party must attest to. [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86] This means the Investment Manager should apply the attestation only to the taxonomy-aligned slice and exclude the benchmark-tracking slice. [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e] [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86]

question: When a person is making an Offer of a Unit, how do the Chapter-level non-application provisions interact with the Rulebook’s chapter 4 Prospectus content and structure requirements for Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds, and where are the applicable Prospectus requirements instead located?
gold_answer: For an Offer involving Units, the combined effect is that the Chapter’s provisions (and Rules made for that Chapter) do not apply to the person making the Offer, and the Rulebook’s chapter 4 Prospectus content and structure requirements are also not applicable to Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds. [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a] [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] In this context, the Rulebook makes a specific carve-out for Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds by stating that chapter 4 Prospectus requirements (including content and structure) do not apply to those Prospectuses. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] Instead, the Prospectus requirements that do apply to an Offer of Units of Funds are located in the Fund Rules, which are identified as the source of applicable Prospectus requirements for such Offers. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] This allocation is reinforced by the statement that Section 57(1) of FSMR disapplies chapter 4 of the Rulebook to Fund Prospectuses, aligning the Rulebook’s chapter 4 non-application for Units of Funds with the broader non-application framework for the Chapter in relation to making an Offer of a Unit. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a]

question: If someone is making an Offer of a Unit, do the rules in this Chapter apply to them, and if the Offer is for Units of Funds, where do they find the Prospectus requirements instead of chapter 4 of the Rulebook?
gold_answer: A person making an Offer of a Unit is not subject to the provisions in this Chapter or the Rules made for the purposes of this Chapter in relation to that activity. [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a] Separately, when the Prospectus relates to Units of Funds, the Rulebook’s chapter 4 Prospectus requirements—covering content and structure—do not apply to those Prospectuses. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] Putting these together for an Offer that involves Units of Funds, you should not look to chapter 4 of the Rulebook for the Prospectus content/structure requirements, because that chapter is expressly stated not to apply to Fund Prospectuses. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] Instead, the Prospectus requirements that apply to an Offer of Units of Funds are found in the Fund Rules, which are identified as the applicable source for such Offers. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] This approach is consistent with the statement that Section 57(1) of FSMR disapplies chapter 4 of the Rulebook to Fund Prospectuses, reinforcing that chapter 4 is not the governing Prospectus framework for Units of Funds even though the Chapter itself is also stated not to apply to a person in relation to making an Offer of a Unit. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a]

question: When an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and is measuring E for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure, how should the firm determine which collateral-recognition approach is permitted, including the distinction between exposures determined under Rule 4.9.15 and whether the SFT sits in the Trading Book or Non Trading Book?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral for an SFT only in the circumstances and using the methods specified for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures, and the permitted method depends on both how the exposure is determined and which book the SFT is in. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] Where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure for an SFT is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 and the Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral, the firm may recognise the effect of that collateral by applying the framework set out in Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] In addition, for any SFT in the Non Trading Book, the firm must choose either the FCSA or the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral, apply that single chosen approach consistently across the entire Non Trading Book, and avoid mixing the two approaches. [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412] By contrast, for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT in the Trading Book, the firm is restricted to using only the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral. [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412]

question: If an Authorised Person has eligible financial Collateral for an SFT, what are the allowed ways to reflect that collateral when measuring E for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure, and how do the rules change depending on whether the SFT is in the Non Trading Book or Trading Book and whether the exposure is determined under Rule 4.9.15?
gold_answer: To reflect eligible financial Collateral in E for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure from an SFT, the Authorised Person must follow both the rule that permits collateral recognition for exposures determined under Rule 4.9.15 and the book-based limits on which approach can be used. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] If the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 and the firm has taken eligible financial Collateral, the firm may recognise the effect of that collateral by applying Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] Separately, for any SFT in the Non Trading Book, the firm must pick either the FCSA or the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral, use that one approach for the entire Non Trading Book, and not combine both approaches. [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412] For a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure from an SFT in the Trading Book, the firm is limited to using only the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral. [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412]

question: When an Authorised Person chooses to reduce the value of its Exposures using one or more of the credit risk mitigation methods listed for this Section, what policy documentation is required specifically in relation to using exclusions in Rule 4.15.12, and how does that documentation obligation relate to the discretionary nature of those exposure reductions?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that elects to reduce the value of its Exposures using the credit risk mitigation recognition options in this Section must also have documented policy coverage for its use of any exclusions in Rule 4.15.12. [#SRC:5a4ad383-0e7b-476f-84ee-d6bce45b2270] This documentation requirement applies in addition to (and is not replaced by) the fact that the Section allows the Authorised Person, at its discretion, to reduce Exposure values using one or more specified methods. [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3] In practice, this means: - The Authorised Person may choose whether to reduce Exposures and may do so via specific provisions, netting (if Section 4.13 conditions are met), eligible Collateral (meeting Section 4.13 requirements), eligible guarantees (as permitted under Section 4.13.9), qualifying Credit Derivatives (included in Rule 4.13.11 and meeting that Section’s conditions), or securitisation transfers (if Section 4.14 conditions are met). [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3] - Separately, it must document its policy for using any exclusions in Rule 4.15.12, so that any reliance on those exclusions is governed by an established internal policy. [#SRC:5a4ad383-0e7b-476f-84ee-d6bce45b2270] Accordingly, discretion to apply the listed reduction techniques does not remove the need for a documented exclusions policy where Rule 4.15.12 exclusions are used. [#SRC:5a4ad383-0e7b-476f-84ee-d6bce45b2270] [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3]

question: If an Authorised Person decides to lower the value of its Exposures using things like Collateral, netting, guarantees, Credit Derivatives, or securitisation, what written policy does it need to have about using exclusions in Rule 4.15.12?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person chooses to reduce the value of its Exposures using the credit risk mitigation recognition options available in this Section, it must also ensure it has documented its policy for using any exclusions in Rule 4.15.12. [#SRC:5a4ad383-0e7b-476f-84ee-d6bce45b2270] The need for a documented exclusions policy sits alongside the Section’s statement that the Authorised Person may, at its discretion, reduce Exposure values using one or more specified mechanisms. [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3] Concretely: - The Section permits discretionary reductions by, among other methods, applying specific provisions (that are not general provisions/reserves), netting claims and liabilities to a Counterparty if Section 4.13 conditions are met, recognising qualifying Collateral under the FCSA/FCCA approaches subject to Section 4.13 requirements, using eligible guarantees under Section 4.13.9, recognising qualifying Credit Derivatives included in Rule 4.13.11 if the transaction meets that Section’s conditions, and recognising securitisation transfers if Section 4.14 conditions are met. [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3] - Independently of which of those methods it uses, the Authorised Person must document its policy for the use of any exclusions in Rule 4.15.12. [#SRC:5a4ad383-0e7b-476f-84ee-d6bce45b2270] So, whenever exclusions in Rule 4.15.12 are used in this context, they must be supported by a documented policy, even though the Exposure reductions themselves are discretionary. [#SRC:5a4ad383-0e7b-476f-84ee-d6bce45b2270] [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3]

question: When a Fund Manager appoints an auditor to audit a Fund’s financial statements under IAASB standards, what specific statements must the Fund Manager ensure the Auditor includes in the resulting Fund Auditor’s Report, including any points that apply at Fund or Sub-Fund level for the annual accounting period?
gold_answer: A Fund Manager must both (i) formally instruct its auditor in writing to perform the audit under the relevant IAASB standards and to produce a Fund Auditor’s Report, and (ii) when procuring that report, ensure the Auditor’s report contains the required set of statements about the financial statements and related matters. [#SRC:8949f938-33e5-4393-a256-021917125579] Specifically, the Fund Manager must ensure the Auditor states whether the financial statements were properly prepared using the financial reporting standards the Fund has adopted under FUNDS, and whether they present a true and fair view of the Fund’s financial position. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce] That true-and-fair assessment must cover net income and net gains or losses of the Fund Property (or, where relevant, the Fund Property attributable to the Sub-Fund) for the annual accounting period, and the financial position of the Fund or Sub-Fund at the end of that period. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce] The report must also address whether proper accounting records have not been kept or whether the statements fail to agree with records/returns or fail to comply with applicable reporting standards, confirm whether the Auditor received all necessary information and explanations, and state whether the Directors’ report or Fund Manager’s report is consistent with the financial statements, plus any other matter required by FUNDS. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce]

question: If a Fund Manager tells its auditor in writing to audit the Fund’s financial statements using IAASB standards, what does the Fund Manager then need to make sure the auditor actually says in the Fund Auditor’s Report (including anything that can be about a Sub-Fund and the annual accounting period)?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager’s responsibilities span both the engagement step and the content-control step: it must give a written requirement to its auditor to carry out an audit of the Fund’s financial statements under the relevant IAASB standards and to produce a Fund Auditor’s Report on those audited statements. [#SRC:8949f938-33e5-4393-a256-021917125579] After that, when arranging for the report to be produced, the Fund Manager must ensure the Auditor includes specific statements in the Fund Auditor’s Report. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce] These include whether the financial statements were properly prepared using the financial reporting standards the Fund adopted under FUNDS, and whether the statements give a true and fair view of the Fund’s financial position. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce] The true-and-fair view must cover net income and net gains or losses of the Fund Property (or, if applicable, the Fund Property attributable to the Sub-Fund) for the annual accounting period, and the financial position of the Fund or Sub-Fund at the end of that period. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce] The Auditor must also state if proper accounting records have not been kept or if the statements do not match records/returns or do not comply with applicable reporting standards, confirm whether it received all needed information and explanations, address consistency of the Directors’ report or Fund Manager’s report with the financial statements, and include any other matter required by FUNDS. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure under Rule 11.9.1 that includes forecast financial information, how should it handle material economic assumptions it considers commercially sensitive, and what additional disclosure is required about the Production Target—particularly in light of the caution about when it is difficult to justify commercial sensitivity?
gold_answer: In a Rule 11.9.1 disclosure containing forecast financial information, a Mining Reporting Entity must provide all material economic assumptions it used, and it must also disclose any other material assumptions applied. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity treats the material economic assumptions as commercially sensitive, it still must include a clear statement that it considers them commercially sensitive and explain the methodology it used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] That sensitivity position should be taken carefully: it is specifically cautioned that where the Mining Reporting Entity has not yet entered into commercially sensitive contracts underpinning assumptions such as commodity price, capital expenditure, or operational expenditure, it would be difficult to conclude that information about those assumptions is commercially sensitive. [#TGT:3b4ca4c9-5690-4bae-8c30-3d06642d6e95] Separately from assumptions, the disclosure must identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, and it must include all information required for that Production Target (including the information contained in Rule 11.8.3). [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity says its economic assumptions are “commercially sensitive” in a Rule 11.9.1 forecast disclosure, what must it still explain, and when might it be hard to justify calling those assumptions sensitive? Also, what must it disclose about the Production Target used for the forecast?
gold_answer: Even where a Mining Reporting Entity believes its material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it must still include the material economic assumptions used for the forecast financial information and provide a statement that it considers them commercially sensitive together with an explanation of the methodology used to determine those assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] It must also disclose all other material assumptions used in preparing the forecast financial information. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] However, the Mining Reporting Entity should be cautious about asserting sensitivity where it is not warranted: if it has not yet entered into any commercially sensitive contracts that underpin assumptions such as commodity price, capital expenditure, or operational expenditure, it would be difficult to form a view that information about those assumptions is commercially sensitive. [#TGT:3b4ca4c9-5690-4bae-8c30-3d06642d6e95] In addition to assumptions, the disclosure must state the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, and it must include all information required for that Production Target (including the information contained in Rule 11.8.3). [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]

question: When applying Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6 to a reverse repurchase agreement, how should the firm determine the exposure amount (E) using the reverse repo formula, and what methodology must it use to calculate the market value (MV) inputs for both the Securities and any Collateral?
gold_answer: For a reverse repurchase agreement assessed under Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6, the exposure amount (E) is determined by taking the amount paid (or Collateral given) and subtracting the market value (MV) of the Securities received. [#TGT:4262e773-aad2-4422-b6b3-fea38fd9d619] To apply that formula correctly, the MV of Securities and the value of Collateral used as inputs must be calculated using the credit risk mitigation (CRM) provisions specified in Section 4.13, because Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6 require those MV and collateral values to be computed in accordance with that CRM methodology. [#SRC:379a83c2-96da-4b2a-acea-f8779444878d] In practice, this means the firm should (i) identify the relevant reverse repurchase agreement components (amount paid or Collateral given, and the Securities received), (ii) compute the MV of the Securities received using the Section 4.13 CRM approach, and (iii) compute the value of any Collateral (including Collateral given, where relevant to the reverse repo inputs) using the same Section 4.13 CRM approach, before inserting those values into the E calculation. [#SRC:379a83c2-96da-4b2a-acea-f8779444878d] This linkage ensures the reverse repo exposure formula uses MV and collateral values that are consistent with the required CRM calculation basis for Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6. [#TGT:4262e773-aad2-4422-b6b3-fea38fd9d619]

question: If you are working out E for a reverse repurchase agreement, what numbers do you subtract and, when you need the MV of the Securities and the value of Collateral for Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6, where do you get the method for calculating those values?
gold_answer: To calculate E for a reverse repurchase agreement, you start with the amount paid (or the Collateral given) and then subtract the MV of the Securities received. [#TGT:4262e773-aad2-4422-b6b3-fea38fd9d619] However, you cannot choose any ad hoc approach for those MV and collateral figures when the calculation is being done under Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6. [#SRC:379a83c2-96da-4b2a-acea-f8779444878d] Instead, the MV of Securities and the value of Collateral that feed into the reverse repo E formula must be calculated using the CRM provisions in Section 4.13, because Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6 specify that those values should be calculated in accordance with that Section 4.13 CRM framework. [#SRC:379a83c2-96da-4b2a-acea-f8779444878d] Put together, the steps are: (1) identify the amount paid or Collateral given and the Securities received for the reverse repurchase agreement, (2) calculate the MV of the Securities and the value of any Collateral using Section 4.13’s CRM provisions, and (3) plug those results into the E equation by subtracting the MV of the Securities received from the amount paid or Collateral given. [#TGT:4262e773-aad2-4422-b6b3-fea38fd9d619]

question: How would the Regulator assess whether a trader’s conduct in a crude oil contract—rapidly accumulating more than 90% of the physical inventory, not offering to lend it back at a reasonable commercial rate, and then unwinding in the final settlement window at rapidly increasing prices—amounts to Behaviour that secures an abnormal or artificial price level, given the requirement that the transactions or orders be otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices?
gold_answer: The described crude oil scenario can be assessed as potentially abusive where the trading strategy both creates an abnormal price outcome and is carried out through transactions or orders that are not for legitimate reasons and not in line with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market.
