question: If an Authorised Person is allowed (by its Financial Service Permission) to hold Client Money while doing Investment Business, what report has to go to the Regulator every year, and what does the Auditor have to say in it at the date of the audited statement of financial position?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business has a Financial Service Permission that allows it to hold Client Money, it must arrange for a Client Money Auditor’s Report to be submitted to the Regulator each year. [#SRC:c42abaa9-4c93-4d5b-b989-aa4ec57cf600] When the Authorised Person procures that report, it must ensure the Auditor includes specific statements measured as at the date the Authorised Person’s audited statement of financial position was prepared. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] At that financial-position date, the Auditor must state the amount of Client Money the Authorised Person was holding and controlling in line with COBS Chapter 14. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] The Auditor must also state whether the Authorised Person maintained systems and controls throughout the year to comply with COBS Chapter 14, and whether those controls keep Client Money identifiable and secure at all times. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] In addition, the Auditor must address whether any COBS Chapter 14 requirements were not met and whether Client Money was pooled in a single client Account or segregated into Client Accounts for individual Clients in accordance with COBS Chapter 14. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] Finally, the Auditor must confirm receiving necessary information and explanations for the report to the Regulator and, if applicable, note any material reconciliation discrepancies. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17]

question: For an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, which MIR Chapter 5 rules must be complied with, and how does COBS Rule 17.7.4 affect the application of those MIR notification and information requirements to MTFs using Virtual Assets (including the linkage to paragraph 29 of the Guidance on additional Accepted Virtual Assets)?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets is required to comply with specified MIR Chapter 5 requirements, and COBS Rule 17.7.4 clarifies that certain Recognised Investment Exchange-style notification and information requirements apply to MTFs using Virtual Assets as additional requirements. [#TGT:7404ef72-3a2f-4c07-a166-0dfd8a480e8d] [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8] Concretely, the MIR Chapter 5 obligations for such an Authorised Person include compliance with Rules 5.1–5.3 and Rule 5.4.1, but only in the circumstances identified in the listed Items (including Items 19, 20, 24(a) and (b), 27, 28, 32, 33, 35, 37–41, 43, 45–50, 52–55, and 57–62). [#TGT:7404ef72-3a2f-4c07-a166-0dfd8a480e8d] In addition, COBS Rule 17.7.4 specifies that certain notification requirements that are applicable to Recognised Investment Exchanges under MIR Rules 5.1 and 5.3, and certain information requirements under MIR Rule 5.4.1, also apply to MTFs (using Virtual Assets), and it characterises these as additional requirements for MTFs using Virtual Assets. [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8] Finally, beyond those COBS-applied requirements, MTFs using Virtual Assets must also comply with any other applicable notification requirements, including those described in paragraph 29 of the Guidance regarding the use of additional Accepted Virtual Assets. [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8]

question: If an Authorised Person runs an MTF for Virtual Assets, what MIR Chapter 5 rules do they have to follow, and what extra point does COBS Rule 17.7.4 make about notifications/information and paragraph 29 on additional Accepted Virtual Assets?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets must follow certain MIR Chapter 5 rules, and COBS Rule 17.7.4 adds that specific notification and information requirements (originally framed for Recognised Investment Exchanges) also apply to MTFs using Virtual Assets as additional requirements. [#TGT:7404ef72-3a2f-4c07-a166-0dfd8a480e8d] [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8] From the MIR side, the required rules are: (a) Rules 5.1–5.3; and (b) Rule 5.4.1, but only when the circumstances match the specific Items listed (including Items 19, 20, 24(a) and (b), 27, 28, 32, 33, 35, 37–41, 43, 45–50, 52–55, and 57–62). [#TGT:7404ef72-3a2f-4c07-a166-0dfd8a480e8d] From the COBS/GUIDANCE side, COBS Rule 17.7.4 states that certain notification requirements under MIR Rules 5.1 and 5.3 and certain information requirements under MIR Rule 5.4.1 that apply to Recognised Investment Exchanges are also applied to MTFs (using Virtual Assets), and it describes these as additional requirements for MTFs using Virtual Assets. [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8] It also indicates that MTFs using Virtual Assets must comply with any other applicable notification requirements, including those referenced in paragraph 29 of the Guidance about using additional Accepted Virtual Assets. [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure under Rule 11.9.1 that includes forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, how should it structure the required assumptions and Production Target content so that the overall disclosure also meets the “fair and balanced” representation expectation for information drawn from a separate report annexed under Rule 11.6.2, without attempting to summarise the entire annexure?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity should present the Rule 11.9.1 forecast-financial-information package (assumptions plus the underlying Production Target) in a way that remains fair and balanced when read alongside the separate report that must be annexed, while avoiding an unnecessary full summary of that annexure. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:b8cb4fdb-f627-43ae-90bf-801a549f8d63] Specifically, the disclosure must include all material economic assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, and it must also include all other material assumptions used. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions commercially sensitive, it must say so and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In addition, the disclosure must include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including all information required by Rule 11.8.3. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] To align this with the Rule 11.6.1 “fair and balanced” expectation, the information included in the disclosure should fairly reflect the information in the separate report prepared under Rule 11.6.2 (annexed to the disclosure), but the FSRA expects only material information needed to understand the estimates of Mineral Resources in that separate report—where that material information is not already in the body of the disclosure—to be included, rather than a comprehensive summary. [#TGT:b8cb4fdb-f627-43ae-90bf-801a549f8d63]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity is putting forecast financial information in its disclosure and that forecast comes from a Production Target, what must it say about its assumptions and the Production Target, and how does that fit with the FSRA’s expectation that the disclosure should be fair and balanced compared with the separate report that is attached as an annexure?
gold_answer: The disclosure needs to include a complete set of required assumption and Production Target information for the forecast, and it should be presented in a way that is fair and balanced when compared with the attached separate report, without trying to restate everything in that report. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:b8cb4fdb-f627-43ae-90bf-801a549f8d63] For the forecast financial information, the Mining Reporting Entity must include all material economic assumptions used to determine the forecast and also include all other material assumptions used. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If it believes the material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it must state that and explain the methodology it used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] It must also include the Production Target that the forecast is based on, and that Production Target must include all information required by Rule 11.8.3. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] Separately, where the disclosure includes information that comes from the separate report prepared under Rule 11.6.2 (which must be attached as an annexure), the information in the disclosure must be a fair and balanced representation of that report; however, the FSRA does not expect a full summary, only the material information needed to understand the estimates of Mineral Resources in the separate report that is not already in the body of the disclosure. [#TGT:b8cb4fdb-f627-43ae-90bf-801a549f8d63]

question: When the Prospectus relating to a Passported Fund has been amended or replaced, what must the Fund Manager submit to the Regulator in its notification, and what form and timing constraints apply (including any outer deadline once it becomes aware)?
gold_answer: When the Prospectus relating to a Passported Fund is amended or replaced, the Fund Manager must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable, and in any case no later than seven days after it becomes aware of the event. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] The notification must be made in the prescribed form that the Regulator may direct from time to time. [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f] At a minimum, the notification must include reasonable detail describing the event. [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f] In addition, where the Prospectus has been amended or replaced, the notification must be accompanied by a copy of the new Prospectus, so the Regulator receives the updated disclosure document alongside the event description. [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f] This Prospectus-change trigger is expressly listed as a notifiable material event for a Passported Fund, and the seven-day outer limit applies once the Fund Manager becomes aware. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] Accordingly, compliance requires both meeting the timing requirement for Passported Fund material events and ensuring the submission package satisfies the minimum content and form requirements for the notification. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f]

question: If a Passported Fund’s Fund Manager becomes aware that the Prospectus has been amended or replaced, how quickly does it have to tell the Regulator, and what information and documents must be included with that notice?
gold_answer: If the Prospectus relating to a Passported Fund is amended or replaced, the Fund Manager must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable, and it must do so no later than seven days after it becomes aware of the change. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] The notice must be submitted in the prescribed form that the Regulator directs from time to time, so the Fund Manager should follow the Regulator’s current format instructions. [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f] The notice also has minimum content requirements: it must include reasonable detail about the event, explaining what happened and why it is being reported. [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f] Because the event is specifically a Prospectus amendment or replacement, the notice must also be accompanied by a copy of the new Prospectus, not just a description of the change. [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f] This combination of timing (as soon as practicable and within seven days of awareness) and submission package (prescribed form, reasonable detail, and the new Prospectus) is what completes the notification for this Passported Fund event. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f]

question: Where a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a Rule 11.8.2 disclosure that complied with the detailed content requirements for Production Targets, under what conditions may a later disclosure about the same Production Target omit the Rule 11.8.2 content items (including the required prominent cautionary statements for Inferred Mineral Resources and/or an Exploration Target), and what specific confirmations or cross-references must the later disclosure still include?
gold_answer: A subsequent disclosure about a Production Target can omit the detailed Rule 11.8.2 content (such as the material assumptions, proportion breakdowns, and the specified prominent cautionary statements) only if it is explicitly tied back to an earlier Rule 11.8.2 disclosure that already contained those required items and was compliant. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] To rely on that streamlined approach, the later disclosure must (i) point readers to the earlier compliant disclosure, and (ii) include a confirmation that the material assumptions used in the initial disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] In addition, the later disclosure must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, aligned to the specific statement required for that scenario in the Rule 11.8.2 content list. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] Similarly, if the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, the later disclosure must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement aligned to the Exploration Target warning specified in the Rule 11.8.2 requirements. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity already made a full Rule 11.8.2 Production Target disclosure, when can it make a later update without repeating all the details (like the assumptions and the split between Ore Reserves/Mineral Resources/Exploration Target), and what must it still say if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or partly based on an Exploration Target?
gold_answer: A later disclosure about a Production Target does not have to repeat all the detailed Rule 11.8.2 information (for example, the material economic assumptions and other material assumptions, whether forecast commodity prices were used on reasonable grounds, and the proportions sourced from Ore Reserves, Mineral Resources, Inferred Mineral Resources, and any Exploration Target) if it properly relies on an earlier Rule 11.8.2 disclosure that already included those items and was compliant. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] To do that, the later disclosure must refer back to the earlier compliant disclosure and must also confirm that the material assumptions from the initial disclosure still apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] Even when the later disclosure is streamlined, it still needs to include specific prominent warnings in certain cases: if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the later disclosure must include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement matching the required Inferred Mineral Resources warning for that scenario. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] If the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, the later disclosure must include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement matching the required Exploration Target warning. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]

question: When seeking to have an investment treated as a Security for an Offer of Digital Securities to the public, what specific submission does the FSRA indicate it will review as key to deciding whether it can use its deeming power, and how does that relate to the Regulator’s ability to deem a non-Security to be a Security by written notice (including any conditions)?
gold_answer: For an Offer of Digital Securities to the public, the FSRA indicates that the information required to be submitted as part of a Securities Note is the key material it will review when considering whether to use its power to deem a Security. [#SRC:b77f9697-b690-4a8b-9139-913a81e95aed] This links directly to the Regulator’s power to deem an investment that is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and the Rules, which must be exercised by written notice and may be made subject to terms and conditions the Regulator considers appropriate. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] In practical compliance terms, the Securities Note functions as the evidentiary package the FSRA expects to assess before it can decide whether to issue such a written notice deeming treatment. [#SRC:b77f9697-b690-4a8b-9139-913a81e95aed] If the Securities Note information is not available or is not completed appropriately, the FSRA states it is most likely not in a position to utilise its deeming power, meaning the written-notice deeming outcome (and any associated terms and conditions) is unlikely to be available. [#SRC:b77f9697-b690-4a8b-9139-913a81e95aed] [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]

question: If you want the Regulator to treat something that is not a Security as a Security, what document information does the FSRA say it needs for an Offer of Digital Securities, and what form can the Regulator use to do the deeming (and with what kind of extra conditions)?
gold_answer: To support deeming treatment in the context of an Offer of Digital Securities to the public, the FSRA says the information that must be submitted as part of a Securities Note is the key information it will review when deciding whether it can use its deeming power. [#SRC:b77f9697-b690-4a8b-9139-913a81e95aed] The Regulator’s deeming power itself includes the ability to treat an investment that is not a Security as a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and the Rules made under them, and it does this by issuing a written notice. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] The same written notice can be made subject to whatever terms and conditions the Regulator considers appropriate, so the deeming outcome is not necessarily unconditional. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] The FSRA also warns that if the Securities Note information is missing or not properly completed, it is most likely that the FSRA will not be able to use its deeming power at all, which would prevent reaching the written-notice stage. [#SRC:b77f9697-b690-4a8b-9139-913a81e95aed] Taken together, this means completing the Securities Note information is a practical prerequisite for the FSRA to be able to consider issuing a written notice that deems the investment to be a Security (potentially with conditions). [#SRC:b77f9697-b690-4a8b-9139-913a81e95aed] [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]

question: When applying the Chapter’s requirement to recognise and measure an Insurer’s assets and liabilities using the basis of accounting referenced in Rule 5.3.2, which accounting standards must the Insurer adopt for the purposes of Rule 5.3.1, and how does that differ for a Takaful Insurer versus any other Insurer?
gold_answer: An Insurer must recognise and measure its assets and liabilities using the basis of accounting specified in Rule 5.3.2, unless the Chapter itself states an alternative approach. [#TGT:35397bd0-0c01-4dec-8eba-1b904df8b4d4] For the purposes of Rule 5.3.1, the Insurer’s adopted basis of accounting depends on whether it is a Takaful Insurer or not. [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0] Specifically, if the Insurer is a Takaful Insurer, it must use the standards issued by the Accounting and Auditing Organisation for Islamic Financial Institutions as its basis of accounting. [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0] If the Insurer is not a Takaful Insurer, it must instead use International Financial Reporting Standards as its basis of accounting. [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0] In practical compliance terms, the Chapter’s recognition and measurement requirement operates by tying the accounting treatment of assets and liabilities to the Rule 5.3.2 basis, while Rule 5.3.1 clarifies which accounting framework the Insurer must adopt depending on its type. [#TGT:35397bd0-0c01-4dec-8eba-1b904df8b4d4] [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0]

question: If an Insurer is measuring and recording its assets and liabilities under the Chapter using the basis of accounting in Rule 5.3.2, what accounting standards does it have to use for Rule 5.3.1 if it is (1) a Takaful Insurer or (2) not a Takaful Insurer?
gold_answer: For an Insurer’s assets and liabilities, the Chapter requires recognition and measurement to follow the basis of accounting set out in Rule 5.3.2, unless the Chapter says otherwise. [#TGT:35397bd0-0c01-4dec-8eba-1b904df8b4d4] Separately, for the purposes of Rule 5.3.1, the Insurer must choose its basis of accounting by reference to what type of Insurer it is. [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0] If the Insurer is a Takaful Insurer, the required basis of accounting is the standards of the Accounting and Auditing Organisation for Islamic Financial Institutions. [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0] If the Insurer is any other type (i.e., not a Takaful Insurer), the required basis of accounting is International Financial Reporting Standards. [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0] Putting these together, the Chapter’s rule on how to recognise and measure assets and liabilities points you to the Rule 5.3.2 basis, and Rule 5.3.1 tells you which accounting framework that basis must be built on depending on whether the Insurer is Takaful or not. [#TGT:35397bd0-0c01-4dec-8eba-1b904df8b4d4] [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0]

question: When an Authorised Person prepares or publishes Investment Research and identifies an actual or potential conflict of interest, what form and level of detail must any conflict disclosure have so that the relevant Client can make an informed decision in the context of the service?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that prepares or publishes Investment Research must have adequate procedures and controls for that activity, and this sits alongside its obligation to take reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest and then prevent or manage them. [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759] Where the Authorised Person makes a conflicts disclosure under Rule 3.3.23 in connection with the service in which the conflict arises, that disclosure must be delivered in a durable medium and must contain enough information for the Client to make an informed decision. [#TGT:448d19a7-728b-491f-9eb2-284dc92112e9] In practice, this means the Authorised Person should (i) identify the conflict as part of its conflicts process and address it through prevention or management measures, and (ii) if disclosure is used, ensure the disclosure is appropriately communicated and sufficiently detailed for the particular Client. [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759] The required level of detail is not fixed; it must be assessed by reference to the nature of the Client and must be framed so the Client can decide, on an informed basis, whether to proceed with the relevant service notwithstanding the conflict. [#TGT:448d19a7-728b-491f-9eb2-284dc92112e9]

question: If an Authorised Person is writing or publishing Investment Research and there is a conflict of interest, what do they need to do about the conflict, and how must any disclosure be given to the Client?
gold_answer: For Investment Research, the Authorised Person must have adequate procedures and controls in place, and it must also take reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest and then prevent or manage them. [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759] If the conflict is addressed through a disclosure made under Rule 3.3.23, the disclosure has two key requirements: it must be provided in a durable medium, and it must give enough detail for the Client to make an informed decision about the service in which the conflict arises. [#TGT:448d19a7-728b-491f-9eb2-284dc92112e9] Putting these together, the Authorised Person should ensure its Investment Research controls and its conflicts process work in tandem: the conflicts process should surface the conflict and drive prevention/management actions, while any disclosure used should be communicated in the required format and tailored in detail to the nature of the Client. [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759] The disclosure’s detail must be sufficient for that specific Client to understand the conflict in the context of the relevant service and decide whether to proceed. [#TGT:448d19a7-728b-491f-9eb2-284dc92112e9]

question: Where an Offer in or from the ADGM is structured so that different tranches rely on different prescribed Exempt Offer circumstances (e.g., one tranche directed at no more than 50 Persons in a 12-month period and another tranche meeting a $100,000 minimum consideration threshold), under what condition can the Offer still be treated as an Exempt Offer notwithstanding that it falls partly within more than one circumstance?
gold_answer: An Offer can continue to be treated as an Exempt Offer even if it is split across multiple prescribed Exempt Offer circumstances, provided that every part of the Offer is covered by at least one of those circumstances. [#SRC:93a2a61f-b4c9-4b29-bec3-d7bdd00541c0] In applying that principle, the relevant “circumstances” are those prescribed by the Regulator for section 61(3)(a) of the FSMR, including (among others) an Offer in or from the ADGM directed at no more than 50 Persons in any 12-month period (with specified exclusions for certain Professional Clients), and an Offer where the total consideration paid by a Person is at least $100,000 (or equivalent). [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] Practically, this means you may rely on different prescribed circumstances for different portions of the same overall Offer (for example, a limited-number-of-persons limb for one portion and a minimum-consideration limb for another), but you must check that there is no residual portion that falls outside all prescribed circumstances. [#SRC:93a2a61f-b4c9-4b29-bec3-d7bdd00541c0] If any part of the Offer is not within at least one prescribed circumstance, the condition for maintaining Exempt Offer status is not met. [#SRC:93a2a61f-b4c9-4b29-bec3-d7bdd00541c0]

question: If an Offer is made partly to or directed at only Professional Clients and partly through a Private Financing Platform to no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients or Market Counterparties, how should Exempt Offer status be assessed when the Offer falls within more than one prescribed circumstance?
gold_answer: You assess Exempt Offer status by confirming that, although the Offer may fall in whole or in part within more than one prescribed circumstance, all parts of the Offer are covered by at least one prescribed circumstance. [#SRC:93a2a61f-b4c9-4b29-bec3-d7bdd00541c0] The prescribed circumstances include an Offer made to or directed at only Professional Clients, and (other than in relation to Debentures and Sukuk) an Offer in or from the ADGM directed at no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients or Market Counterparties where the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] Accordingly, it is permissible for one portion of the Offer to rely on the “only Professional Clients” circumstance while another portion relies on the “Private Financing Platform/MTF with up to 200 non-Professional Clients/non-Market Counterparties” circumstance, so long as there is no portion of the Offer that is outside all prescribed circumstances. [#SRC:93a2a61f-b4c9-4b29-bec3-d7bdd00541c0] This requires mapping each tranche or distribution channel to at least one prescribed circumstance and ensuring the platform-based limb is not used for Debentures or Sukuk. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] If every part is covered, the Offer remains an Exempt Offer despite the overlap. [#SRC:93a2a61f-b4c9-4b29-bec3-d7bdd00541c0]

question: Where an MTF admits to trading Securities offered by way of an Exempt Offer under MKT Rule 4.3.1 (13), how should the operator align its platform-specific systems and controls (including identifying offerees and limiting non-Professional Client participation) with the broader Rule 3.9.1 admission-to-trading framework that requires clear, transparent Business Rules and fair, orderly and efficient trading?
gold_answer: An MTF admitting Securities from an Exempt Offer under MKT Rule 4.3.1 (13) must implement platform-level systems and controls that both (i) enforce the Exempt Offer-specific constraints and (ii) support compliance with the admission-to-trading requirements referenced through Rule 3.9.1. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] Concretely, the MTF must ensure it admits only Securities from Exempt Offers made on its own platform, can identify the Persons to whom the Exempt Offer was made, and restrict trading so that no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients can trade those Securities. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] In parallel, because the MTF must comply with MIR rule 3.9.1 (Admission to trading) as applicable for the relevant Securities, the admission approach should be reflected in clear and transparent Business Rules and should ensure the admitted instruments are capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner. [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215] Operationally, this means the Exempt Offer gating (platform-only admission, offeree identification, and the 200-person non-Professional Client cap) should be embedded into the admission process and rule set used to meet Rule 3.9.1 expectations on transparency and orderly trading. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215]

question: For Securities admitted to trading on an MTF under an Exempt Offer, what combined arrangements are required to ensure users can access information (including Offer documents and Inside Information) while also meeting the Recognised Investment Exchange obligation to assist users in obtaining access to information made public under disclosure obligations?
gold_answer: When Securities from an Exempt Offer are admitted to trading on an MTF, the operator must put in place information-access arrangements that satisfy both the Exempt Offer-specific requirement to provide market users with relevant inside and offer-related materials and the broader obligation to help users access information made public under disclosure obligations. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215] On the Exempt Offer side, the MTF must have effective systems and controls that allow users of its market to obtain Inside Information, and this expressly includes any Offer documents prepared under MKT Rule 4.3.5 that are relevant to the Securities. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] Separately, the Recognised Investment Exchange framework for admission to trading requires maintaining arrangements to assist users of a market it operates to obtain access to information that is made public under its disclosure obligations. [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215] Read together, the practical expectation is that the MTF’s user-access mechanisms should cover (i) the Inside Information and Exempt Offer documentation relevant to the admitted Securities and (ii) the channels or processes by which users can obtain information that has been made public under the applicable disclosure obligations. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215] This combined approach ensures the information-access control is not limited to offer materials but also supports the broader disclosure-information access objective for market users. [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215]

question: For a Third Party Provider’s Governing Contract, how should the contract’s required exchange-rate disclosures and any agreed approach to changing exchange rates be structured so that the provider can apply exchange-rate changes immediately and without notice only in the permitted cases?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider should draft the Governing Contract so that (i) it includes the required baseline disclosures on exchange rates and (ii) it only permits immediate, no-notice exchange-rate changes in the limited situations allowed. The contract must, where relevant, state the exchange rates to be applied or, if Reference Exchange Rates are used, explain how the relevant date is determined for those Reference Exchange Rates. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] Where relevant and if agreed, it must also address how changes in Reference Exchange Rates will be applied and what information will be provided in relation to those changes. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] Against that disclosure framework, immediate application without notice is only appropriate where the Governing Contract expressly grants that right and the exchange-rate changes are based on Reference Exchange Rate information that has already been provided to the Customer in accordance with Rule 20.2.2, or where the change is more favourable to the Customer. [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2] In practice, this means the contract’s “changes” provisions should be aligned with its exchange-rate/Reference Exchange Rate disclosures so the no-notice mechanism is not broader than these two permitted cases. [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2] [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]

question: If a Third Party Provider wants to change exchange rates right away without telling the Customer first, what must be written into the Governing Contract about exchange rates and Reference Exchange Rates, and when is the “no notice” change allowed?
gold_answer: The Governing Contract should both explain the exchange-rate basis up front and narrowly define when an exchange-rate change can happen immediately without notice. Where relevant, the contract must include details of the exchange rates to be applied, or—if Reference Exchange Rates will be used—the method for calculating the relevant date used to determine those Reference Exchange Rates. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] Where relevant and if agreed, it must also cover how changes in Reference Exchange Rates will be applied and the information requirements tied to those changes. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] Even with those disclosures, an immediate, no-notice exchange-rate change is only allowed in two cases: (1) the Governing Contract includes an agreed right to do so and the change is based on Reference Exchange Rate information that has already been provided to the Customer in line with Rule 20.2.2; or (2) the change is more favourable to the Customer. [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2] So the contract needs both the required exchange-rate/Reference Exchange Rate information and a tightly scoped “immediate change” clause that matches these permitted triggers. [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2] [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]

question: How do the Regulations’ general prohibition on making an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market (and on having Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange) interact with the Regulator’s power under section 59(c) of the FSMR to prescribe certain communications as Exempt Communications, and what is the compliance consequence for those prescribed communications?
gold_answer: Communications that the Regulator prescribes as Exempt Communications are treated as outside the regulatory concept that triggers the general prohibition on making an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or having Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange. [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f] The Regulations state that a person must not make an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market and must not have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, unless an exception applies under the Regulations. [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a] Under section 59(c) of the FSMR, the Regulator can designate certain communications as Exempt Communications, and those communications are not subject to the prohibition in section 58(1) of the FSMR because they fall outside the definition of an “Offer of Securities” in section 59 of the FSMR. [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f] As a result, where a communication has been prescribed by the Regulator as an Exempt Communication, it does not constitute an Offer of Securities for these purposes, so the Regulations’ prohibition framed around making an “Offer of Securities” in the Abu Dhabi Global Market is not engaged by that communication. [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f] [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a]

question: If someone is worried that a message they send could count as an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market, what changes if the Regulator has prescribed that kind of message as an Exempt Communication under section 59(c) of the FSMR, given the Regulations’ ban on making an Offer of Securities (and on admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange)?
gold_answer: If the Regulator has prescribed the message as an Exempt Communication, the message is treated as not being an “Offer of Securities,” which means the Regulations’ ban that is triggered by making an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market is not activated by that message. [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f] The Regulations set a general rule that a person must not make an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market and must not have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, unless an exception applies under the Regulations. [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a] Separately, the Regulator has power under section 59(c) of the FSMR to prescribe certain communications as Exempt Communications, and those prescribed communications are not subject to the prohibition in section 58(1) of the FSMR because they fall outside the definition of an “Offer of Securities” in section 59 of the FSMR. [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f] Putting these together, the key compliance consequence is that a prescribed Exempt Communication is not treated as an Offer of Securities, so the specific prohibition in the Regulations that is framed around making an “Offer of Securities” in the Abu Dhabi Global Market does not apply to that communication. [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f] [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a]

question: When an Authorised Person calculates its Leverage Ratio using the prescribed methodology, what specific components must be included in the Capital Measure, and how does that Capital Measure relate to the Exposure Measure in the ratio?
gold_answer: In calculating the Leverage Ratio, an Authorised Person must use a Capital Measure that is its Tier 1 Capital, and that Tier 1 Capital must be built up as the sum of two specified components. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] Specifically, Tier 1 capital is determined by adding together Common Equity Tier 1 capital (CET1 Capital) and Additional Tier 1 capital (AT1 Capital). [#TGT:a2ce8a2e-9188-4d44-8582-42abbadc4f11] The Leverage Ratio itself is then computed by dividing this Capital Measure (i.e., Tier 1 Capital as just described) by the Exposure Measure. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] The Exposure Measure is not a capital component; it is the value of the Authorised Person’s Exposures, and it must be calculated under the specified exposure rules referenced for that purpose. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] Accordingly, the numerator of the ratio is Tier 1 Capital (CET1 Capital plus AT1 Capital), while the denominator is the Exposure Measure derived from the Authorised Person’s Exposures. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] [#TGT:a2ce8a2e-9188-4d44-8582-42abbadc4f11]

question: If you’re working out an Authorised Person’s Leverage Ratio, what do you add up to get the Tier 1 Capital used in the Capital Measure, and what do you divide it by?
gold_answer: To calculate an Authorised Person’s Leverage Ratio, you start by identifying the Capital Measure and the Exposure Measure and then apply the required division. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] The Capital Measure is the Authorised Person’s Tier 1 Capital, and Tier 1 capital must be calculated as the total of Common Equity Tier 1 capital (CET1 Capital) plus Additional Tier 1 capital (AT1 Capital). [#TGT:a2ce8a2e-9188-4d44-8582-42abbadc4f11] Once you have that Tier 1 Capital amount, you use it as the numerator in the Leverage Ratio formula. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] You then divide it by the Exposure Measure, which is defined as the value of the Authorised Person’s Exposures calculated under the specified exposure calculation rules referenced for that purpose. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] In other words, the ratio is Tier 1 Capital (made up of CET1 Capital and AT1 Capital) divided by the Exposure Measure (the value of Exposures). [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] [#TGT:a2ce8a2e-9188-4d44-8582-42abbadc4f11]

question: Where a person has failed to comply with a requirement under Part 17 of FSMR and is certified in default, what must the Court of First Instance be satisfied about before it may treat the Defaulter as if in contempt, and who else may be dealt with in that way if the Defaulter is a Body Corporate?
gold_answer: If a person fails to comply with a requirement under Part 17 of FSMR and is certified in default, the Court of First Instance may only proceed to treat the Defaulter as if in contempt once it is satisfied of the relevant non-compliance condition described for that step. [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf] Specifically, the Court must be satisfied that the Defaulter failed to comply with the requirement without reasonable excuse before it may deal with the Defaulter as if he were in contempt. [#TGT:91865998-c73a-45ec-8cec-23c36750808a] In addition, when the Defaulter is a Body Corporate, the Court’s contempt-style treatment may extend beyond the entity itself to include any Director or other Officer of that Body Corporate. [#TGT:91865998-c73a-45ec-8cec-23c36750808a] Separately from the Court’s contempt-style handling, the same failure to comply with Part 17 requirements may also expose the person to being found to have committed a contravention of FSMR. [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf] These consequences operate on the basis of the failure to comply with the Part 17 requirement and the Court’s satisfaction as to the absence of reasonable excuse for the contempt-style response. [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf] [#TGT:91865998-c73a-45ec-8cec-23c36750808a]

question: If someone doesn’t follow a requirement under Part 17 of FSMR and gets certified in default, what does the Court of First Instance need to believe before treating them like they’re in contempt, and if the Defaulter is a Body Corporate, who else can the Court treat that way?
gold_answer: When a person does not comply with a requirement under Part 17 of FSMR, that person can be certified in default and then may face Court of First Instance action that treats them as if they were in contempt of court. [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf] For the Court to take that contempt-style step, it is not enough that there was non-compliance; the Court must be satisfied that the Defaulter failed to comply without reasonable excuse. [#TGT:91865998-c73a-45ec-8cec-23c36750808a] If the Defaulter is a Body Corporate, the Court’s ability to deal with parties as if in contempt can also reach individuals connected to the company—namely any Director or other Officer—rather than being limited to the corporate entity alone. [#TGT:91865998-c73a-45ec-8cec-23c36750808a] In parallel with the Court’s contempt-style handling, the same failure to comply with a Part 17 requirement may also result in the person being found to have committed a contravention of FSMR. [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf] Taken together, the process links certification in default for Part 17 non-compliance with a Court assessment focused on whether there was a reasonable excuse, and it clarifies who may be dealt with when the Defaulter is a Body Corporate. [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf] [#TGT:91865998-c73a-45ec-8cec-23c36750808a]

question: For a Petroleum Reporting Entity preparing a Summary of Reserves and Resources, when must it include the MKT Form 12-1 table and what is the relevant “as of” date constraint, and how does this change if the entity is required to file SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports annually with the SEC?
gold_answer: A Petroleum Reporting Entity generally must include, within its Summary of Reserves and Resources, a table using the MKT Form 12-1 format, and that table must be prepared “as of” a date that is no earlier than one month before the Summary of Reserves and Resources is disclosed. [#SRC:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] However, if the Petroleum Reporting Entity is required to file SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports annually with the SEC, it is not required to comply with Rule 12.14.1, which is the rule that imposes the MKT Form 12-1 table requirement and its timing condition. [#TGT:b249219a-57ec-4b15-be46-58475357c6c1] In practical terms, the compliance outcome depends on whether the entity falls into that SEC annual filing category: if it does not, it must include the MKT Form 12-1 table and ensure the “as of” date is within the one-month window before disclosure; if it does, the entity is exempt from the Rule 12.14.1 obligation and therefore does not have to meet that table-inclusion requirement or its associated “as of” date constraint under that rule. [#SRC:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] [#TGT:b249219a-57ec-4b15-be46-58475357c6c1]

question: If a Petroleum Reporting Entity is putting together its Summary of Reserves and Resources, what table does it normally need to add and how recent must the table’s “as of” date be, and does that still apply if it files SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports every year?
gold_answer: Normally, a Petroleum Reporting Entity must add a table to its Summary of Reserves and Resources using the MKT Form 12-1 format. [#SRC:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] The table must be dated “as of” a point in time that is not more than one month before the Summary of Reserves and Resources is disclosed, meaning the “as of” date cannot be earlier than one month prior to that disclosure. [#SRC:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] But this requirement does not apply in the same way to every Petroleum Reporting Entity: if the entity is required to file SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports annually with the SEC, it does not have to comply with Rule 12.14.1. [#TGT:b249219a-57ec-4b15-be46-58475357c6c1] Because the MKT Form 12-1 table and its one-month “as of” date condition are part of Rule 12.14.1, an entity in that SEC annual filing category is not required to follow that table-and-date requirement under Rule 12.14.1, while an entity outside that category must follow it when preparing the Summary of Reserves and Resources. [#SRC:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] [#TGT:b249219a-57ec-4b15-be46-58475357c6c1]

question: When the Regulator receives a request from a Host Regulator to conduct an on-site inspection relating to a Passported Fund, how should the Regulator determine whether it must permit and accompany the inspection versus when it may refuse to cooperate, particularly where enforcement action or judicial proceedings exist for the same conduct and the same Persons?
gold_answer: The Regulator’s default position, when it receives a Host Regulator request to carry out an on-site inspection connected to a Passported Fund, is to allow the inspection to proceed and to accompany the Host Regulator during the on-site visit. [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6] However, the Regulator may decline to act on a Host Regulator’s cooperation request for an inspection if specific parallel actions already exist concerning the same conduct and the same Persons. [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c] In practice, the Regulator should (i) confirm that the request is for an on-site inspection and that it is in relation to a Passported Fund, because that is the trigger for the permit-and-accompany approach; and then (ii) assess whether either refusal circumstance applies. [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6] The refusal circumstances are limited to cases where the Regulator has already started or finished enforcement action about the same conduct and the same Persons, or where judicial proceedings have already been started or finished about the same conduct and the same Persons. [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c] If neither of those circumstances applies, the Regulator should permit the inspection and accompany it during the on-site inspection. [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6]

question: If a Host Regulator asks the Regulator to do an on-site inspection about a Passported Fund, what is the normal response, and when is the Regulator allowed to say no because there is already enforcement action or a court case about the same conduct and the same Persons?
gold_answer: Normally, when the Regulator gets a request from a Host Regulator for an on-site inspection that relates to a Passported Fund, the Regulator is expected to allow the inspection and to go along during the on-site inspection. [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6] Even so, the Regulator is permitted to refuse to act on a Host Regulator’s request for cooperation for an inspection if the situation matches one of the listed refusal grounds tied to the same conduct and the same Persons. [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c] To apply this, the Regulator should first check that the request is indeed for an on-site inspection and that it is in relation to a Passported Fund, because that is the scenario where permitting and accompanying the inspection is the baseline expectation. [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6] The Regulator may then refuse if it has already begun or finished enforcement action about the same conduct and the same Persons, or if judicial proceedings have already begun or finished about the same conduct and the same Persons. [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c] If those conditions are not present, the Regulator should proceed by permitting and accompanying the inspection. [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information under Rule 11.9.1 and treats its material economic assumptions as commercially sensitive, what specific statements and explanatory content must it provide, and how does that disclosure need to connect to the Production Target from which the forecast is derived (including the Rule 11.8.3 information)?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity that discloses forecast financial information under Rule 11.9.1 must still provide a complete, investor-understandable explanation of how its forecast is built, even if it treats material economic assumptions as commercially sensitive. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In that scenario, it must (i) identify all material economic assumptions used, and (ii) if it considers those assumptions commercially sensitive, include an explicit statement that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine them. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] Where it relies on the relevant guidance, it must also explain why the information is considered a trade secret or commercially sensitive and disclose enough information—potentially using narrative rather than numbers—to allow investors to understand the methodology used to determine the factors and assumptions and the basis for reporting estimates of Ore Reserves. [#TGT:6435d936-1f1e-44c9-a788-2a4f4de44b80] Separately, the Rule 11.9.1 disclosure must identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived and include all information required by Rule 11.8.3 for that Production Target. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] The commercially sensitive treatment does not remove the need to provide sufficient methodological context for investors, including the basis for Ore Reserves estimates. [#TGT:6435d936-1f1e-44c9-a788-2a4f4de44b80]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity is sharing forecast financial information and says its key economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, what does it still have to tell investors, and what Production Target details must it include with the forecast?
gold_answer: Even if a Mining Reporting Entity says its key economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it still has to give investors enough information to understand how it built the forecast and what it is based on. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] For the forecast disclosure, it must cover the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, including all material economic assumptions and any other material assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If it treats the material economic assumptions as commercially sensitive, it must say so and explain the methodology it used to determine those assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In the commercially sensitive case described for Ore Reserves reporting, it should also explain why the information is considered a trade secret or commercially sensitive and must still disclose sufficient information (which may be narrative rather than numerical) so investors can understand the methodology used to determine the relevant factors and assumptions and the basis for reporting estimates of Ore Reserves. [#TGT:6435d936-1f1e-44c9-a788-2a4f4de44b80] In addition, the forecast disclosure must state the Production Target from which the forecast is derived and include all the information that Rule 11.8.3 requires for that Production Target. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]

question: When an Applicant is seeking admission of Shares to the Official List, how should the Applicant frame its demonstration to the Regulator that it (and any Subsidiaries) has sufficient working capital for its present requirements, including the relevant time horizon the Regulator uses for assessing those present requirements and what must be addressed if working capital is not sufficient?
gold_answer: An Applicant seeking admission of Shares to the Official List must be prepared to satisfy the Regulator that it and any Subsidiaries have enough working capital available for its present requirements, and the Regulator’s benchmark for what counts as “present requirements” is that they are sufficient to support projected normal operations for 12 months starting from the date of admission to the Official List. [#TGT:c5ff4069-f284-4bb2-a504-11cf3694aa2e] [#SRC:b6eba295-6fe5-41d7-9392-46287b03796c] In practice, this means the Applicant’s working-capital case should be framed around a 12-month forward-looking period measured from admission, rather than an undefined or shorter interval. [#SRC:b6eba295-6fe5-41d7-9392-46287b03796c] The Applicant must cover both the Applicant itself and any Subsidiaries in that sufficiency assessment. [#TGT:c5ff4069-f284-4bb2-a504-11cf3694aa2e] If the Applicant cannot demonstrate sufficient working capital for those present requirements, it must instead explain to the Regulator how it proposes to provide the additional working capital needed, which necessarily ties back to meeting the 12-month projected normal operations horizon from admission. [#TGT:c5ff4069-f284-4bb2-a504-11cf3694aa2e] [#SRC:b6eba295-6fe5-41d7-9392-46287b03796c]

question: If a company applies to list Shares, what does it need to show the Regulator about working capital for itself and any Subsidiaries, and over what time period does the Regulator treat “present requirements” as covering from the admission date?
gold_answer: For an Applicant seeking admission of Shares to the Official List, the core requirement is to satisfy the Regulator that the Applicant and any Subsidiaries have sufficient working capital available for the Applicant’s present requirements. [#TGT:c5ff4069-f284-4bb2-a504-11cf3694aa2e] The Regulator’s view of what “present requirements” means is not open-ended: it is treated as being enough to support projected normal operations for a 12-month period starting on the date of admission to the Official List. [#SRC:b6eba295-6fe5-41d7-9392-46287b03796c] Put together, the Applicant’s working-capital showing should be aligned to that 12-month-from-admission horizon and should cover both the Applicant and any Subsidiaries. [#TGT:c5ff4069-f284-4bb2-a504-11cf3694aa2e] [#SRC:b6eba295-6fe5-41d7-9392-46287b03796c] If the Applicant cannot show that working capital is sufficient for those present requirements, it must instead tell the Regulator how it proposes to provide the additional working capital needed, which is the alternative path to addressing the same 12-month operational sufficiency expectation. [#TGT:c5ff4069-f284-4bb2-a504-11cf3694aa2e] [#SRC:b6eba295-6fe5-41d7-9392-46287b03796c]

question: Where a person is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, and an investor who acquired Securities suffers loss from an untrue or misleading statement or a material omission in that Prospectus, what publication-related steps (and timing relative to acquisition) can prevent that person from incurring liability for the loss, including the case where the issue is that an Expert was not competent or did not consent?
gold_answer: A person who is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus can be liable to pay compensation to an acquirer of the relevant Securities for loss or damage caused by an untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus, or by omitting a material matter that was required to be included. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] However, that person does not incur liability for loss in respect of the Securities if, before the Securities were acquired, either (i) a correction was published in a way intended to reach persons likely to acquire those Securities, or (ii) where the statement is of the type attributed to an Expert, the fact that the Expert was not competent or had not consented to inclusion of the attributed statement was published in that same attention-getting manner. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] Alternatively, liability is avoided if the person took all steps that it was reasonable to take to secure that publication and, on reasonable grounds, believed the publication had occurred before the Securities were acquired. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] The key linkage is that the compensation exposure tied to untrue/misleading statements or material omissions is addressed by timely, appropriately targeted publication (or reasonable efforts and belief of publication) occurring before acquisition. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b]

question: If someone is on the list in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, and a buyer of the Securities loses money because the Prospectus had a misleading statement or left out a required material matter, what can that liable person do (and by when) to avoid liability—especially if the problem is about an Expert’s competence or consent?
gold_answer: If a person is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, that person can have to pay compensation to someone who acquired the Securities covered by the Prospectus and suffered loss or damage because the Prospectus contained an untrue or misleading statement or omitted a material matter that was required to be included. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] Even in that setting, the person avoids incurring liability for the loss if, before the Securities were acquired, a correction is published in a way meant to bring it to the attention of people likely to buy those Securities. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] If the issue is a statement attributed to an Expert, the same timing and publication approach can be used by publishing that the Expert was not competent or did not consent to having the attributed statement included in the Prospectus. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] A second route is available: the person can avoid liability if they took all steps that were reasonable to secure that publication and reasonably believed it had happened before the Securities were acquired. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] In short, the compensation risk tied to misleading statements or required omissions is addressed by timely publication (or reasonable efforts and belief of publication) before acquisition. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b]

question: For a Mining Production Reporting Entity preparing its quarterly report, how should it satisfy the requirement to provide the Summary of Reserves and Resources at least once every 12 months, and what date constraint applies to the MKT Form 11-1 table included in that Summary when it is disclosed (including when the Summary is instead included in the annual report)?
gold_answer: A Mining Production Reporting Entity must ensure that, across its quarterly reporting cycle, it provides the Summary of Reserves and Resources at least once in every 12-month period, unless that Summary is instead provided in the Mining Reporting Entity’s annual report. [#SRC:a24b4f51-4c48-4846-bd22-d5f98dbad55b] When the Summary of Reserves and Resources is disclosed (whether via a quarterly report to meet the 12‑month cadence or via inclusion in the annual report), the Mining Reporting Entity’s Summary must contain a table in the format of MKT Form 11-1. [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd] The table must be prepared “as of” a date that is not earlier than one month before the disclosure date of the Summary of Reserves and Resources, meaning the table’s effective date must fall within the month leading up to the Summary’s disclosure. [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd] In addition, the quarterly report must state when the prior disclosure of this 12‑monthly Summary occurred and when the next such disclosure is expected to occur, so readers can track the timing of the required Summary disclosures. [#SRC:a24b4f51-4c48-4846-bd22-d5f98dbad55b]

question: If a Mining Production Reporting Entity is doing its quarterly report and needs to cover the Summary of Reserves and Resources at least once every 12 months (unless it’s in the annual report), what must it say about the timing of the last and next Summary disclosure, and how recent must the date be for the MKT Form 11-1 table inside that Summary?
gold_answer: In the quarterly report, the Mining Production Reporting Entity must manage the Summary of Reserves and Resources on a 12‑month cycle: it must provide that Summary at least once every 12 months unless the Summary is included in the Mining Reporting Entity’s annual report instead. [#SRC:a24b4f51-4c48-4846-bd22-d5f98dbad55b] To make that cycle transparent, the quarterly report must also indicate when the previous disclosure of the required Summary was made and when the next disclosure will be made. [#SRC:a24b4f51-4c48-4846-bd22-d5f98dbad55b] When the Summary of Reserves and Resources is disclosed (whether through the quarterly reporting stream or via the annual report), the Mining Reporting Entity must include a table in the form of MKT Form 11-1 within that Summary. [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd] The “as of” date used for that MKT Form 11-1 table must be no earlier than one month before the Summary is disclosed, so the table’s date must be within the month leading up to the disclosure. [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd]

question: Where a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a disclosure that complied with Rule 11.9.2 and later makes a subsequent disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, under what conditions may the subsequent disclosure omit the Rule 11.9.2 information, and what specific “at least equally prominent, and proximate” cautionary statement(s) must be included if the underlying Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or is based in part on an Exploration Target?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity may leave out the Rule 11.9.2 content in a later disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target only if the later disclosure (i) points back to an earlier disclosure that itself complied with Rule 11.9.2 and (ii) confirms that the material assumptions from that initial disclosure still apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] In addition, the later disclosure must include specific cautionary language, presented at least equally prominently and close to the forecast financial information, when certain Production Target bases apply. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] If the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the required proximate cautionary statement is the one set out for that scenario, warning that geological confidence is low, further work is needed, there is no certainty the Production Target will be met or realised, and that investors should not rely solely on the Production Target when making investment decisions. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] If the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, the required proximate cautionary statement is the one explaining that the Exploration Target is conceptual, exploration is insufficient to determine a Mineral Resource, and there is no certainty further work will result in Mineral Resources or that the Production Target will be realised. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity already made an earlier disclosure that met Rule 11.9.2, what does it need to do in a later announcement with forecast financial information from a Production Target so it can skip repeating the Rule 11.9.2 details, and what warning statement must it put next to the forecast financial information when the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources?
gold_answer: The later announcement can avoid repeating the Rule 11.9.2 information only if it clearly refers back to the earlier disclosure that was compliant with Rule 11.9.2 and includes a confirmation that the material assumptions used in that initial disclosure still apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] Even when that “no repetition” approach is used, the later announcement must still add specific cautionary language in certain cases, and it must be placed at least equally prominently and close to the forecast financial information. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] When the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the required warning is the prescribed statement explaining that the geological confidence for inferred mineral resources is low, that further evaluation and/or exploration is required to establish sufficient confidence, and that there is no certainty the work will lead to indicated mineral resources or that the production target will be realised. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] It must also state that the production target reflects current expectations of future results or events and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]

question: When considering whether to withdraw an Approval for a Controlled Function on the basis that the person is not fit and proper, what specific factors must the Regulator take into account, and how do those factors connect to the particular Controlled Function and the firm’s markets?
gold_answer: If the Regulator is considering withdrawing an Approval given under section 45 because it considers the person is not a fit and proper person to perform the Controlled Function in question, it should ground that assessment in the broader set of relevant matters it uses when deciding whether to exercise its power under section 46 of FSMR. [#TGT:3770f510-3010-431b-9ccf-af63b6825554] In practice, this means the fit-and-proper conclusion for the specific Controlled Function should be informed by multiple, case-specific considerations rather than a single indicator. [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c] In forming its view, the Regulator will have regard to all relevant matters, including: (i) the criteria for assessing the fitness and propriety of an Approved Person (as referenced in GEN 5.2.9 and section 2.3 of GPM); (ii) any offences or findings involving dishonesty, fraud, or a financial crime by the Approved Person; and (iii) whether enforcement action should be taken, or has already been taken, against the Approved Person by the Regulator or other enforcement agencies. [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c] It will also consider contextual factors that link directly to the withdrawal decision for the Controlled Function in question, including the particular Controlled Function the Approved Person is or was performing, the nature and activities of the firm concerned, the markets in which the firm operates, and the severity of the risk the individual poses to consumers and to confidence in the ADGM financial system. [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c] These factors collectively support whether the person should continue to hold the section 45 Approval for that Controlled Function. [#TGT:3770f510-3010-431b-9ccf-af63b6825554]

question: If the Regulator thinks someone is not fit and proper for a specific Controlled Function and may withdraw their Approval, what kinds of things will it look at (for example, crimes, past enforcement, and the firm’s markets) to reach that decision?
gold_answer: Where the Regulator considers that a person is not a fit and proper person to perform the Controlled Function in question, it may withdraw an Approval that was given under section 45. [#TGT:3770f510-3010-431b-9ccf-af63b6825554] To reach that fit-and-proper view for the specific Controlled Function, the Regulator’s approach is to consider all relevant matters it uses when deciding whether to exercise its power under section 46 of FSMR, rather than relying on a single fact in isolation. [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c] In particular, the Regulator will look at a mix of personal conduct, regulatory history, and role/firm context, including: - the criteria for assessing the fitness and propriety of an Approved Person (as referenced in GEN 5.2.9 and section 2.3 of GPM); [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c] - whether the Approved Person has committed offences or has findings involving dishonesty, fraud, or a financial crime; [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c] - whether enforcement action should be taken, or has already been taken, by the Regulator or other enforcement agencies; [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c] - the particular Controlled Function the Approved Person is or was performing, and the nature and activities of the firm concerned, including the markets in which the firm operates; and [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c] - how severe the risk is to consumers and to confidence in the ADGM financial system. [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c] These considerations help the Regulator decide whether the person should continue to hold the section 45 Approval for that Controlled Function. [#TGT:3770f510-3010-431b-9ccf-af63b6825554]

question: When designing the strategy’s system for controlling Liquidity Risk that enables the Authorised Person to implement the requirements in Rule 9.2.6, what specific capabilities and governance/approval features must that system include for the Authorised Person’s Governing Body and senior management, including in relation to limits set under Rule 9.2.7 and operating procedures?
gold_answer: The system for controlling Liquidity Risk that is included in the strategy must be built so it both supports implementation of the requirements in Rule 9.2.6 and contains the specific governance and control features described for the system referenced in Rule 9.2.1(5). [#TGT:5c690bca-7ecd-4950-8e21-6c4cb9357647] In particular, the Authorised Person must ensure the system enables the Authorised Person’s Governing Body and senior management to review whether the Authorised Person is complying with limits that are set in accordance with Rule 9.2.7 and with the relevant operating procedures. [#SRC:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988] The Authorised Person must also ensure the system has appropriate approval processes, limits, and other mechanisms that are designed to provide reasonable assurance that the Authorised Person’s Liquidity Risk management processes are followed in practice. [#SRC:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988] Taken together, this means the strategy-level system is not merely descriptive: it must be capable of enabling implementation of Rule 9.2.6 while also embedding review capability for the Governing Body and senior management and incorporating approvals and control mechanisms tied to the Rule 9.2.7 limit-setting and operating procedures. [#TGT:5c690bca-7ecd-4950-8e21-6c4cb9357647] [#SRC:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988]

question: If the strategy has to include a system for controlling Liquidity Risk so the Authorised Person can carry out Rule 9.2.6, what does that system need to let the Governing Body and senior management do, and what kinds of approval/limit controls must it have (including around limits set under Rule 9.2.7 and operating procedures)?
gold_answer: The strategy must contain a Liquidity Risk control system that enables the Authorised Person to implement the requirements in Rule 9.2.6, and the Authorised Person must ensure that system has the specific review and control features described for the relevant system. [#TGT:5c690bca-7ecd-4950-8e21-6c4cb9357647] The system must allow the Authorised Person’s Governing Body and senior management to review compliance with limits that are set in accordance with Rule 9.2.7 and to review compliance with operating procedures. [#SRC:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988] It must also include appropriate approval processes, limits, and other mechanisms that are designed to give reasonable assurance that the Authorised Person’s Liquidity Risk management processes are actually being followed. [#SRC:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988] In practice, this links the strategy requirement (a system that enables implementation of Rule 9.2.6) with concrete governance expectations: the system must support oversight by the Governing Body and senior management and must embed approvals and control mechanisms aligned to the Rule 9.2.7 limit framework and operating procedures. [#TGT:5c690bca-7ecd-4950-8e21-6c4cb9357647] [#SRC:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988]

question: When an Authorised Person is determining the amount of minority interests of a Subsidiary that is eligible for inclusion in consolidated CET1 Capital, how does the 6.0% CET1 Capital requirement tied to the Subsidiary’s Total Risk Exposure Amount connect to the way Total Risk Exposure Amount must be calculated (including any specified components and adjustments)?
gold_answer: In determining eligible minority interests for inclusion in consolidated CET1 Capital, the Authorised Person must apply a subtraction mechanism that depends on a 6.0% CET1 Capital requirement calculated by reference to the Subsidiary’s Total Risk Exposure Amount, so the Total Risk Exposure Amount must be computed using the required component-sum approach before it can be used in that 6.0% test. [#SRC:dc108b2b-6b01-433d-9e1b-09159c329ab0] Specifically, the eligible amount is derived by taking the minority interests of the Subsidiary and subtracting an amount equal to: (i) a defined CET1 Capital “excess/shortfall” measure for the Subsidiary (CET1 Capital of the Subsidiary minus the lesser of two alternative required CET1 amounts, each built from a 6.0% CET1 requirement plus the Combined Buffer Requirement), multiplied by (ii) the minority-interest percentage of all CET1 instruments plus related retained earnings and share premium accounts. [#SRC:dc108b2b-6b01-433d-9e1b-09159c329ab0] To supply the Total Risk Exposure Amount input to the 6.0% requirement referenced in that minority-interest calculation, the Authorised Person must calculate Total Risk Exposure Amount (after taking into account Rule 3.5.8) as the sum of Credit RWA, and the risk exposure amounts associated with Market Risk, Operational Risk, CVA Risk, and (where applicable) Displaced Commercial Risk (calculated in accordance with IFR Rule 5.4.5). [#TGT:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e]

question: If an Authorised Person is working out how much of a Subsidiary’s minority interests can count in consolidated CET1 Capital, what do they have to calculate about Total Risk Exposure Amount (what it is made up of), and how is that used in the 6.0% CET1 requirement step in the minority-interest formula?
gold_answer: To determine how much of a Subsidiary’s minority interests can be included in consolidated CET1 Capital, the Authorised Person must use a formula that depends on a 6.0% CET1 Capital requirement based on the Subsidiary’s Total Risk Exposure Amount, so the Total Risk Exposure Amount must be calculated in the prescribed way first. [#SRC:dc108b2b-6b01-433d-9e1b-09159c329ab0] The minority-interest amount eligible for inclusion is found by starting with the Subsidiary’s minority interests and subtracting a product: the product is (1) the Subsidiary’s CET1 Capital minus the lesser of two alternative required CET1 amounts (each alternative is the sum of a 6.0% CET1 requirement on Total Risk Exposure Amount and the Combined Buffer Requirement), multiplied by (2) the minority-interest share expressed as a percentage of all CET1 instruments plus related retained earnings and share premium accounts.
