[#SRC:ac70dcf0-7928-4d1c-9561-1b88ff273cb9] [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d] On preparation, the disclosure that contains the statement must be prepared in line with a Mining Reporting Standard and also in line with this chapter. [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d] On Prospectus-specific obligations, the Prospectus must comply with Chapter 4 and, because it contains that kind of statement, it must also comply with Rule 11.2.1. [#SRC:ac70dcf0-7928-4d1c-9561-1b88ff273cb9] In addition, the Prospectus must include details about the Mining Reporting Entity’s policies and practices for operating sustainably, covering (i) its policy on environmental and social issues, (ii) how its business practices affect the environment and the communities where it operates, and (iii) the environmental and social risks it faces. [#SRC:ac70dcf0-7928-4d1c-9561-1b88ff273cb9] In practice, you should ensure the same statement-driven disclosure is both prepared under the Mining Reporting Standard/this chapter framework and accompanied by the Prospectus sustainability disclosures and cross-referenced compliance items. [#SRC:ac70dcf0-7928-4d1c-9561-1b88ff273cb9] [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d]

question: Where a Recognised Clearing House makes provision as allowed under Rule 4.5.8, how must its procedures address (i) the designation and ongoing review of Persons or descriptions of person and (ii) the substantive market-operation risk test that determines whether a Person or description should not be, or should not remain, designated?
gold_answer: A Recognised Clearing House that makes provision as allowed under Rule 4.5.8 must maintain procedures that both manage the designation lifecycle and apply a market-operation impact test to prevent inappropriate designations. [#TGT:242b0395-19a9-4471-85cb-e31dac7eae5d] In particular, the procedures must be adequate to (a) designate the relevant Persons or descriptions of person in respect of whom action may be taken, (b) keep under review which Persons or descriptions should be or remain designated, and (c) withdraw a designation when appropriate. [#TGT:242b0395-19a9-4471-85cb-e31dac7eae5d] Those designation, review, and withdrawal steps must be designed so that a Person is not, or does not remain, designated if that Person’s failure to meet obligations in respect of one or more Market Contracts would adversely affect the operation of the market. [#SRC:55576d4c-9a95-4fb8-8fd6-9462a2a1153b] The same design requirement applies at the category level: a description of persons must not be, or remain, designated if failure by a Person of that description to meet obligations in respect of one or more Market Contracts would affect market operation. [#SRC:55576d4c-9a95-4fb8-8fd6-9462a2a1153b] Accordingly, the ongoing review and any withdrawal decision should be driven by whether the relevant Market Contract obligation failures would impact market operation, ensuring the designation set remains aligned with that risk threshold. [#SRC:55576d4c-9a95-4fb8-8fd6-9462a2a1153b]

question: If the Recognised Clearing House uses the option allowed under Rule 4.5.8, what should its procedures cover for choosing and removing designated Persons (or descriptions of person), and what market-impact check must those procedures be designed to apply about failures to meet obligations under one or more Market Contracts?
gold_answer: When the Recognised Clearing House makes provision as allowed under Rule 4.5.8, it must have procedures that cover the full process for designation and also embed a specific market-impact safeguard. [#TGT:242b0395-19a9-4471-85cb-e31dac7eae5d] On process, the procedures must be adequate for (a) designating the Persons or descriptions of person in respect of whom action may be taken, (b) keeping under review which Persons or descriptions should be or remain designated, and (c) withdrawing a designation. [#TGT:242b0395-19a9-4471-85cb-e31dac7eae5d] On the safeguard, those procedures must be designed so that a Person is not, or does not remain, designated if that Person’s failure to meet obligations in respect of one or more Market Contracts would adversely affect the operation of the market. [#SRC:55576d4c-9a95-4fb8-8fd6-9462a2a1153b] The same design principle applies to a description of persons: it must not be, or remain, designated if failure by a Person within that description to meet obligations in respect of one or more Market Contracts would affect market operation. [#SRC:55576d4c-9a95-4fb8-8fd6-9462a2a1153b] Practically, the review and withdrawal parts of the procedure should be used to ensure designations do not continue where that market-operation impact condition would be met. [#TGT:242b0395-19a9-4471-85cb-e31dac7eae5d]

question: When the Regulator receives the notice referred to in Rule 3.1.2 and is considering whether to send the notice of intent to use passporting procedures to Host Regulator(s) within five Business Days, in what circumstances must it refrain from transmitting the notice under Rule 3.1.4(a), and what downstream steps (including publication and notification) are tied to Host Regulator confirmation if the process proceeds?
gold_answer: The Regulator is required to withhold transmitting a notice under Rule 3.1.4(a) if it concludes either that the Fund Manager or the Private Fund is not compliant with applicable legislation (including these Rules), or that there are reasonable grounds to determine the Fund Manager or the Private Fund may become non-compliant in the future. [#SRC:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c] It must also refrain where it considers doing so is necessary and appropriate to advance one or more of its objectives. [#SRC:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c] If those withholding conditions do not apply and the process proceeds, then within five Business Days after receiving the notice described in Rule 3.1.2 (and subject to Rule 3.1.5), the Regulator must provide notice of its intent to use the passporting procedures to the Host Regulator(s) in each relevant Host Jurisdiction where the Passported Fund is intended to be Promoted. [#TGT:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7] After the relevant Host Regulator(s) confirm their Register of Passported Funds has been updated to include the Passported Fund’s details, the Regulator must then promptly publish the Passported Fund’s details on the Register of Passported Funds and notify the Fund Manager that registration is complete. [#TGT:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7]

question: If the Regulator gets the Rule 3.1.2 notice and would normally tell Host Regulator(s) within five Business Days that it plans to use the passporting procedures, when is it not allowed to send the notice under Rule 3.1.4(a), and what does it have to do after Host Regulator(s) confirm their register is updated?
gold_answer: The Regulator must not transmit a notice under Rule 3.1.4(a) if it thinks the Fund Manager or the Private Fund does not comply with applicable legislation (including these Rules), or if it has reasonable grounds to decide the Fund Manager or the Private Fund may not comply in the future. [#SRC:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c] It also must not transmit that notice if it considers it necessary and appropriate to hold back in order to further one or more of its objectives. [#SRC:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c] If those reasons to hold back do not apply and the process goes ahead, then within five Business Days after receiving the notice mentioned in Rule 3.1.2 (and subject to Rule 3.1.5), the Regulator has to send Host Regulator(s) in the relevant Host Jurisdiction(s) a notice that it intends to use the passporting procedures, for places where the Passported Fund is intended to be Promoted. [#TGT:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7] Once the Host Regulator(s) confirm their Register of Passported Funds has been updated with the Passported Fund’s details, the Regulator must promptly publish those details on the Register of Passported Funds and notify the Fund Manager that registration is complete. [#TGT:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7]

question: When the Regulator is considering granting a waiver from Rule 3.5.1 for an order on a Recognised Investment Exchange market on the basis that it is “large in scale compared with normal market size,” what specific threshold and classification method must be used to determine whether the order qualifies?
gold_answer: To assess whether a waiver from Rule 3.5.1 may be granted on the “large in scale compared with normal market size” basis, the relevant qualifying concept is the category of “orders that are large in scale compared with normal market size” referenced for waivers, which is tied to Rule 3.5.11. [#TGT:aa29640b-f2f9-435b-8e56-31e99fff54e6] For the purpose of applying that large-in-scale concept (in the context referenced by Rule 3.5.7(c)), an order is treated as large in scale if its size is at least the minimum order size specified in Rule 3.5.11. [#SRC:12e55ccd-cd6e-4509-aaf7-b0985942d627] In addition, when determining whether an order is large in scale compared with normal market size, all Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange market must be classified according to their average daily turnover, following Rule 3.5.12. [#SRC:12e55ccd-cd6e-4509-aaf7-b0985942d627] Accordingly, the waiver analysis must combine (i) the Rule 3.5.11 minimum-size threshold with (ii) the required turnover-based classification framework for instruments admitted to trading on the Recognised Investment Exchange market, because the waiver category depends on the “large in scale” determination. [#TGT:aa29640b-f2f9-435b-8e56-31e99fff54e6] [#SRC:12e55ccd-cd6e-4509-aaf7-b0985942d627]

question: If someone wants a waiver from Rule 3.5.1 because an order is “large in scale,” how do you decide if it is big enough, and what extra step applies to Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange market?
gold_answer: A waiver from Rule 3.5.1 can be granted by the Regulator for “orders that are large in scale compared with normal market size,” and that waiver category is linked to Rule 3.5.11. [#TGT:aa29640b-f2f9-435b-8e56-31e99fff54e6] To decide whether an order is large in scale for the relevant large-in-scale concept (referenced for Rule 3.5.7(c)), you treat the order as large in scale when its size is equal to or above the minimum order size set out in Rule 3.5.11. [#SRC:12e55ccd-cd6e-4509-aaf7-b0985942d627] There is also an additional step that applies across the market: for the purpose of making the large-in-scale determination, all Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange market must be classified based on their average daily turnover, using the approach in Rule 3.5.12. [#SRC:12e55ccd-cd6e-4509-aaf7-b0985942d627] Putting these together, you cannot rely only on the waiver label; you must apply the Rule 3.5.11 minimum-size threshold and the turnover-based classification method for instruments admitted to trading on the Recognised Investment Exchange market to support that the order fits the waiver category. [#TGT:aa29640b-f2f9-435b-8e56-31e99fff54e6] [#SRC:12e55ccd-cd6e-4509-aaf7-b0985942d627]

question: When FSRA assesses whether a Spot Commodity Settlement Facility (SCSF) has satisfactory arrangements to secure timely discharge of parties’ rights and liabilities under MIR Rule 4.3.3, how should that assessment be reconciled with the statement that a Recognised Clearing House is not treated as breaching its Recognition Requirement solely because it cannot arrange settlement of a specific transaction?
gold_answer: FSRA’s assessment of an SCSF under MIR Rule 4.3.3 focuses on whether the SCSF has satisfactory arrangements and procedures designed to secure timely discharge of parties’ rights and liabilities, rather than guaranteeing that every individual transaction will in fact settle. [#SRC:b5d36396-57ff-473e-8ff9-0e392516e731] In practice, the SCSF should be able to demonstrate a coherent framework covering (among other things) clearing and settlement rules and practices (including any outsourcing to another Person), trade matching to confirm agreement on trade details, delivery and payment arrangements across relevant jurisdictions, and mechanisms to detect, manage, and respond to settlement failures by a Member (or participant). [#SRC:b5d36396-57ff-473e-8ff9-0e392516e731] That arrangements-based focus aligns with the principle that a Recognised Clearing House is not automatically regarded as non-compliant with its Recognition Requirement merely because it cannot arrange settlement for a particular transaction. [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e] Accordingly, an inability to settle a specific trade should not, by itself, negate an otherwise satisfactory set of default rules, default procedures, monitoring of Members’ settlement performance, and “step-in” arrangements to take action to settle when a Member (or participant) does not. [#SRC:b5d36396-57ff-473e-8ff9-0e392516e731] The key is whether the SCSF’s documented arrangements exist and operate to manage settlement risk and failures, not whether settlement is invariably achievable in every case. [#SRC:b5d36396-57ff-473e-8ff9-0e392516e731][#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e]

question: If an SCSF has procedures to spot and handle a Member (or participant) who does not settle, does one failed trade automatically mean it has not met the standard FSRA looks at under MIR Rule 4.3.3, given the rule about a Recognised Clearing House and a specific transaction not settling?
gold_answer: A single failed trade does not, on its own, determine whether the SCSF meets what FSRA looks for under MIR Rule 4.3.3, because the assessment is about whether the SCSF has satisfactory arrangements to support timely discharge of parties’ rights and liabilities. [#SRC:b5d36396-57ff-473e-8ff9-0e392516e731] FSRA may consider whether the SCSF has practical measures in place such as rules and practices for clearing and settlement (including any arrangements with another Person to provide those services), processes to match trades and confirm the parties agree on trade details, and arrangements for deliveries and payments in all relevant jurisdictions. [#SRC:b5d36396-57ff-473e-8ff9-0e392516e731] FSRA may also look at how the SCSF detects and deals with a Member (or participant) failing to settle, what action it can take to settle a trade when a Member (or participant) does not, how it monitors Members’ settlement performance, and whether it has Default Rules and default procedures. [#SRC:b5d36396-57ff-473e-8ff9-0e392516e731] This arrangements-based approach is consistent with the statement that a Recognised Clearing House is not treated as failing its Recognition Requirement merely because it cannot arrange settlement for a specific transaction. [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e] So, the compliance question is whether the SCSF’s overall framework exists and functions to manage settlement and defaults, not whether every individual transaction always settles. [#SRC:b5d36396-57ff-473e-8ff9-0e392516e731][#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e]

question: When a Relevant Person proposes to rely on a Person in (1) for elements of CDD, how must it determine and evidence that the third party is regulated in a country with AML/TFS rules equivalent to FATF standards, and what immediate CDD-information and document-availability steps must be taken as part of that reliance?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person may rely on a Person in (1) for relevant elements of CDD only if it both (i) meets the operational conditions for third-party reliance and (ii) is satisfied that the third party is regulated and supervised in a country whose AML/TFS regulations are equivalent to FATF standards. [#TGT:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275] To support the equivalence determination, the Relevant Person must take into account a range of jurisdictional indicators, including published mutual evaluations or assessment/follow-up reports by bodies such as FATF, the IMF, the World Bank, the OECD or other International Organisations, as well as whether the jurisdiction is a member of FATF or regional groups (e.g., MENAFATF or the Gulf Co-operation Council). [#SRC:06794d47-81ee-49d0-bf3a-58e87a031da4] It must also consider contextual risk factors like political stability and corruption levels, and any recent criticism (including FATF advisory notices or public assessments by the listed organisations, or reports from relevant NGOs or specialist commercial organisations). [#SRC:06794d47-81ee-49d0-bf3a-58e87a031da4] In parallel, it must immediately obtain the necessary CDD information from the third party and take adequate steps to ensure certified copies of the documents used for the relied-on CDD elements will be available on request without delay. [#TGT:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275] Finally, it must confirm the third party did not use an exception for any CDD element being relied on and that any information relied on is up to date. [#TGT:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275]

question: If a Relevant Person wants to use a Person in (1) to do parts of CDD, what checks does it need to do about the other country’s AML/TFS rules being FATF-equivalent, and what must it get right away from the third party?
gold_answer: The Relevant Person can only rely on a Person in (1) for CDD elements if it satisfies specific reliance conditions and confirms the third party is regulated and supervised for AML/TFS compliance by a Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator or other competent authority in a country whose AML/TFS rules match the FATF Recommendations’ standards. [#TGT:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275] To judge whether that country’s AML/TFS regulations are equivalent to FATF standards, the Relevant Person must consider multiple factors, such as mutual evaluations and assessment or follow-up reports published by FATF and other International Organisations like the IMF, World Bank, or OECD, and whether the country is part of FATF or regional groups such as MENAFATF or the Gulf Co-operation Council. [#SRC:06794d47-81ee-49d0-bf3a-58e87a031da4] It also needs to weigh contextual issues like political stability and corruption, and look for recent criticism (for example FATF advisory notices, public assessments by those organisations, or reports from relevant NGOs or specialist commercial organisations). [#SRC:06794d47-81ee-49d0-bf3a-58e87a031da4] Operationally, it must immediately obtain the necessary CDD information from the third party and take adequate steps to ensure certified copies of the documents used for the relevant CDD work can be provided on request without delay. [#TGT:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275] It must also ensure the third party did not rely on an exception for any CDD element being relied on and that the information is up to date. [#TGT:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275]

question: When the Regulator requests information from a Representative Office that the Representative Office or another member of its Group has already provided to a Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator, how may that information be used in the Regulator’s oversight, and where are further Rules and Guidance identified for obtaining information from the Representative Office’s lead regulator?
gold_answer: When the Regulator asks for information that a Representative Office (or another member of its Group) has already given to a Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator, the Representative Office is required to provide that information to the Regulator. [#TGT:8519a0fd-97e3-4184-8a8f-7807db5de003] Once obtained, the information may be considered by the Regulator in two linked oversight contexts: it may be taken into account as part of the fit and proper test referenced in Chapter 2, and it may also be used in the supervision of the firm (including in a group supervision context). [#SRC:9f4ba591-cf28-4b21-8577-813e8f071050] In addition, where the compliance question involves obtaining information specifically from a Representative Office’s lead regulator (which can be relevant when the information has already been shared with external regulators), the text points to a dedicated location for additional requirements: further Rules and Guidance on obtaining such information are set out in GEN 9.15.3. [#SRC:9f4ba591-cf28-4b21-8577-813e8f071050] Taken together, the obligation is to furnish the requested previously-shared information, and the regulatory consequence is that the Regulator may use it for fit and proper assessment and ongoing supervision, with GEN 9.15.3 identified as the place to look for more detail on lead-regulator information gathering. [#TGT:8519a0fd-97e3-4184-8a8f-7807db5de003] [#SRC:9f4ba591-cf28-4b21-8577-813e8f071050]

question: If the Regulator asks a Representative Office for information that the Representative Office (or another Group member) already gave to a Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator, what does the Representative Office have to do, and what can the Regulator use that information for (including where to find extra guidance about the lead regulator)?
gold_answer: If the Regulator requests it, the Representative Office must give the Regulator the information that it or another member of its Group has already provided to a Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator. [#TGT:8519a0fd-97e3-4184-8a8f-7807db5de003] The same information is not just collected for its own sake: it may be taken into account by the Regulator as part of the fit and proper test described in Chapter 2, and it may also be used in the supervision of the firm, which sits within the stated group supervision context. [#SRC:9f4ba591-cf28-4b21-8577-813e8f071050] If you need to know where the rulebook points you for more detail on getting information from a Representative Office’s lead regulator (a related channel for obtaining regulatory information), the text identifies GEN 9.15.3 as the place where further Rules and Guidance are set out. [#SRC:9f4ba591-cf28-4b21-8577-813e8f071050] So the practical compliance outcome is: provide the requested previously-shared information to the Regulator, and understand it can feed into both fit-and-proper assessment and ongoing supervisory work, with GEN 9.15.3 flagged for additional lead-regulator information-gathering guidance. [#TGT:8519a0fd-97e3-4184-8a8f-7807db5de003] [#SRC:9f4ba591-cf28-4b21-8577-813e8f071050]

question: Where the Customer is not a Natural Person, how may the Customer and the Third Party Provider contractually adjust the application of specific Rules, and how does that interact with the Third Party Provider’s liability to its Customer for charges and interest arising from non-execution, defective execution, or late execution of a Third Party Transaction?
gold_answer: For a Customer that is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider can, by written agreement, disapply a defined set of Rules and can also agree a different time period for certain unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transaction matters; however, the Third Party Provider still bears liability to its Customer for specified financial consequences when it fails to execute, or executes defectively or late, a Third Party Transaction. [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] Specifically, the written agreement mechanism is limited to the Rules listed (including those on charges for information, withdrawal of consent, revocation of a Payment Order, requests for refund, evidence on authentication and execution, and liability for charges), and it also permits the parties to set a different time period for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 20.10.1. [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] Separately, the Third Party Provider is liable to its Customer for any charges for which the Customer is responsible and any interest the Customer must pay when the Third Party Provider’s non-execution, defective execution, or late execution of a Third Party Transaction causes those amounts. [#TGT:e704735d-e9c8-4326-b79a-28e066317151] In practice, any written disapplication of the listed Rules should be assessed against this liability outcome, because the liability statement focuses on the consequence of execution failures (charges and interest) rather than on whether particular Rules have been switched off. [#TGT:e704735d-e9c8-4326-b79a-28e066317151]

question: If the Customer is not a Natural Person, what can the Customer and the Third Party Provider agree to change in writing about which Rules apply (and timing for unauthorised/incorrectly executed Payment Transactions), and what does the Third Party Provider still owe the Customer if a Third Party Transaction is not done, done badly, or done late?
gold_answer: When the Customer is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider may make a written agreement that switches off only certain named Rules, and they may also agree a different time period for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 20.10.1. [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] The Rules that can be disapplied by that written agreement are limited to the specific list provided (covering charges for information, withdrawal of consent, revocation of a Payment Order, requests for refund, evidence on authentication and execution, and liability for charges). [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] Even with such an agreement in place, the Third Party Provider remains liable to its Customer for the financial impact described where the Third Party Provider does not execute a Third Party Transaction, or executes it defectively or late. [#TGT:e704735d-e9c8-4326-b79a-28e066317151] That liability is framed as covering any charges for which the Customer is responsible and any interest the Customer must pay, but only where those amounts arise as a consequence of the Third Party Provider’s non-execution, defective execution, or late execution of the Third Party Transaction. [#TGT:e704735d-e9c8-4326-b79a-28e066317151] Accordingly, the written agreement can adjust the listed Rule-based protections and timing, but it does not remove the stated responsibility for charges and interest caused by execution failures. [#TGT:e704735d-e9c8-4326-b79a-28e066317151]

question: An Issuer plans to admit its Securities to trading on a MTF and wants to run a single fundraising that includes (i) an offer to no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients and (ii) a parallel offer to Professional Clients. Under the described framework, how can the Issuer structure this as Exempt Offers, and what specific Exempt Offer circumstance is not available when relying on additional circumstances alongside the 200-Person MTF route?
gold_answer: The Issuer can structure the fundraising as simultaneous Exempt Offers by combining the specific 200-Person route tied to admission to trading on a MTF with a separate Exempt Offer directed at Professional Clients. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] The 200-Person limb is available where an Exempt Offer is directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients and the Securities are to be admitted to trading on a MTF. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] In parallel, the Issuer may make an Exempt Offer to (or directed at only) Professional Clients, which is a prescribed Exempt Offer circumstance. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] When the Issuer is seeking admission to trading on an MTF using the 200-Person route, it may also rely on one or more other Exempt Offer circumstances, but it cannot rely on the circumstance corresponding to MKT Rule 4.3.1(2). [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] This means the combined structure can use the 200-Person MTF-based Exempt Offer plus the Professional Client-only Exempt Offer, while excluding the specific additional circumstance that is carved out. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]

question: Where an Offer is directed at no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients (and the Securities are offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility), how does this interact with an Issuer’s ability to make a simultaneous Exempt Offer to an unlimited number of Professional Clients when the Securities are to be admitted to trading on a MTF?
gold_answer: An Offer can qualify as an Exempt Offer when it is directed at no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients (or Market Counterparties) and the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] Separately, in the specific scenario where an Issuer is seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF, the framework contemplates an Exempt Offer directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] In that same MTF admission context, the Issuer may run a simultaneous Exempt Offer to an unlimited number of Professional Clients under the Professional Client-only circumstance. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] The linkage is that the 200-Person, non-Professional-Client concept aligns across both passages, while the SOURCE adds the operational structuring point: the Issuer can pair that 200-Person MTF-related Exempt Offer with a parallel Professional Client-only Exempt Offer in the same fundraising. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] The Professional Client-only limb is expressly recognised as an Exempt Offer circumstance, enabling the “unlimited number of Professional Clients” component described for the simultaneous offer. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc]

question: Where an Authorised Person is (i) under Rule 3.11.2 or Rule 3.11.4 and operates as a Cell Company and (ii) also holds a Financial Services Permission to carry on either one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, what annual supervision fees must be paid to the Regulator, and how does the number of Cells affect the total?
gold_answer: In this scenario, the Authorised Person must pay two annual supervision fee components to the Regulator: one tied to operating as a Cell Company and another tied to the specified insurance Regulated Activities carried on as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle. [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b] [#TGT:9240b52a-9167-41c8-a2aa-aba636e47579] For the Cell Company aspect, an Authorised Person under Rule 3.11.2 or Rule 3.11.4 that operates as a Cell Company must pay an additional annual supervision fee of $8,000 for the Cell Company, plus $1,000 for each Cell, so the total increases in direct proportion to the number of Cells. [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b] Separately, if the same Authorised Person has a Financial Services Permission to carry on either one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, it must pay an annual supervision fee of $5,000 covering either or both of those Regulated Activities (i.e., the fee is $5,000 whether it carries on one or both). [#TGT:9240b52a-9167-41c8-a2aa-aba636e47579] Accordingly, the overall annual supervision fees payable are $5,000 plus $8,000 plus $1,000 multiplied by the number of Cells. [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b] [#TGT:9240b52a-9167-41c8-a2aa-aba636e47579]

question: If an Authorised Person runs a Cell Company (under Rule 3.11.2 or Rule 3.11.4) and also has permission to do insurance business as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, what yearly supervision fees does it owe, and what part changes when it adds more Cells?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person owes a combination of annual supervision fees: one fee schedule applies because it operates as a Cell Company under Rule 3.11.2 or Rule 3.11.4, and another fee applies because it has a Financial Services Permission to carry on specified insurance Regulated Activities as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle. [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b] [#TGT:9240b52a-9167-41c8-a2aa-aba636e47579] For the Cell Company part, it must pay an additional annual supervision fee made up of $8,000 for the Cell Company itself plus $1,000 for each Cell, so adding Cells increases the total by $1,000 per added Cell. [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b] For the insurance permission part, if it is permitted to carry on either one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, it must pay $5,000 per year, and that $5,000 applies whether it carries on one or both of those Regulated Activities. [#TGT:9240b52a-9167-41c8-a2aa-aba636e47579] Putting these together, the fixed amounts are $8,000 (Cell Company) and $5,000 (insurance activities), and the variable amount is $1,000 times the number of Cells. [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b] [#TGT:9240b52a-9167-41c8-a2aa-aba636e47579]

question: Under this Part, what conduct is prohibited when a person provides information “in purported compliance,” and how does the non-compliance discussion extend beyond false or misleading information to cover obstruction of investigative powers (including examples)?
gold_answer: A person is prohibited from providing materially false or misleading information when doing so in purported compliance with a requirement imposed under this Part, whether the person does so knowingly or recklessly. [#TGT:77f73737-390b-4344-848c-df4d94932e96] The non-compliance discussion aligns this prohibition with a contravention where a person deliberately or recklessly provides information that is false or misleading in a material particular in purported compliance with a Part 17 requirement. [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23] In addition, the non-compliance discussion makes clear that contraventions are not limited to misinformation: conduct intended to obstruct the exercise of investigative powers “by any means” is also treated as a contravention. [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23] Examples of obstructive conduct include failing to attend at a specified time and place to answer questions, falsifying/concealing/destroying documents, failing to give or produce information or documents specified by us, failing to permit access to premises, and failing to provide assistance in relation to an investigation. [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23] Taken together, the rule on false or misleading information sets the baseline prohibition for purported compliance, while the non-compliance discussion adds that intentional obstruction of investigative activity is separately captured and illustrates what that obstruction can look like in practice. [#TGT:77f73737-390b-4344-848c-df4d94932e96] [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23]

question: If someone is trying to comply with a requirement under this Part, what kinds of false information are they not allowed to give, and what other actions (like blocking an investigation) are treated as non-compliance with examples?
gold_answer: When a person is acting in purported compliance with a requirement imposed under this Part, they must not give information that is false or misleading in a material way if they know it is false or misleading, and they must not do so recklessly either. [#TGT:77f73737-390b-4344-848c-df4d94932e96] The non-compliance discussion describes this same type of behavior as a contravention where a person deliberately or recklessly provides materially false or misleading information in purported compliance with a Part 17 requirement. [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23] It also explains that non-compliance can occur even without false statements: conduct intended to obstruct us in using our investigative powers is also treated as a contravention. [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23] The examples given of obstruction include not showing up at a specified time and place to answer questions, hiding or destroying documents, not providing information or documents specified by us, refusing access to premises, and not giving assistance connected to an investigation. [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23] So, the rule focuses on knowingly or recklessly giving materially false or misleading information in supposed compliance, and the non-compliance discussion adds that actively getting in the way of an investigation is also covered, with concrete examples of what that looks like. [#TGT:77f73737-390b-4344-848c-df4d94932e96] [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23]

question: When a Recognised Investment Exchange is drafting Business Rules to admit Units in an open-ended Collective Investment Fund to trading, how should it operationalise the requirement that instruments be capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner, and which specific fund-related factors must it assess for that purpose?
gold_answer: To admit Units to trading, a Recognised Investment Exchange must have Business Rules that ensure the Units are capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner, and it should implement that standard by embedding an assessment that is tailored to Units in collective investment funds. [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215] For an open-ended Collective Investment Fund, the assessment should cover (and the Business Rules should be designed to take into account) the extent to which the Units are distributed to the public, whether there are appropriate market-making arrangements or, alternatively, whether the Fund Manager provides suitable arrangements for investors to redeem the Units, and whether investors receive sufficient transparency on value through periodic publication of the net asset value. [#SRC:72e47a23-5aa5-4df1-a4d6-2aaf037e9131] In practice, this means the Recognised Investment Exchange should translate the general “fair, orderly and efficient” trading requirement into admission checks or criteria that explicitly test those three open-ended fund elements, rather than treating Units like generic Financial Instruments. [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215] The linkage is that the Business Rules obligation to ensure fair, orderly and efficient trading is met, for Units, by applying the fund-specific factors (distribution, market-making/redemption arrangements, and NAV transparency) when deciding whether to admit the Units. [#SRC:72e47a23-5aa5-4df1-a4d6-2aaf037e9131]

question: If a Recognised Investment Exchange wants to admit Units in a closed-ended Investment Fund to trading, what must its Business Rules achieve, and what closed-ended fund checks should it use to decide whether trading will be fair, orderly and efficient?
gold_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange can admit Financial Instruments to trading only if its Business Rules ensure that instruments admitted to trading are capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner. [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215] For Units in a closed-ended Investment Fund, the way it should judge whether that “fair, orderly and efficient” standard is met is by taking into account two specific fund features: how widely the Units are distributed to the public, and whether the value of the Units is made sufficiently transparent to investors. [#SRC:72e47a23-5aa5-4df1-a4d6-2aaf037e9131] The value-transparency element can be satisfied, for this assessment, either through publication of information about the Fund’s investment strategy or through periodic publication of a net asset value. [#SRC:72e47a23-5aa5-4df1-a4d6-2aaf037e9131] Accordingly, the Business Rules should not just state the general trading-quality requirement; they should be applied through an admission review that explicitly checks those closed-ended fund factors so the Recognised Investment Exchange can conclude the Units will trade fairly, orderly and efficiently on its market. [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215]

question: When an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM and therefore has an obligation to publish a Prospectus under Section 61 of FSMR, what consequence described in the Regulations may apply if the person making the Prospectus Offer fails to publish information they are required to publish, and how is that information published?
gold_answer: For an Issuer making an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, the offer is within the regime where publishing a Prospectus is an identified obligation (including under Section 61 of FSMR). [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] If, in that Prospectus Offer context, the person making the Prospectus Offer does not publish information that they are required to publish by or under the Regulations, the Regulator has a discretionary power to step in and publish the missing required information. [#TGT:cd1d6043-c316-4559-ad75-ad86cdaeaa9f] The mechanism for that intervention is that the Regulator may publish the information using the manner that is prescribed in the Rules, rather than leaving publication solely to the person making the Prospectus Offer. [#TGT:cd1d6043-c316-4559-ad75-ad86cdaeaa9f] This consequence is relevant to the Issuer’s ADGM public offer scenario because the Prospectus publication obligation is part of the requirements applicable to such Offers of Securities (including those under Sections 58 to 71 of FSMR and Chapter 4 of the Markets Rules ("MKT")), and a failure to publish required information can therefore trigger the Regulator’s publication power. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd]

question: If an Issuer is offering Securities to the public in or from ADGM and needs to publish a Prospectus, what can the Regulator do if the person making the Prospectus Offer doesn’t publish required information, and where do the Prospectus obligations come from?
gold_answer: In an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, the applicable requirements include an obligation to publish a Prospectus (including under Section 61 of FSMR), and those offer requirements sit within Sections 58 to 71 of FSMR and Chapter 4 of the Markets Rules ("MKT"). [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] If, in that Prospectus Offer setting, the person making the Prospectus Offer fails to publish information that they are required to publish by or under the Regulations, the Regulator is permitted (but not required) to publish that information instead. [#TGT:cd1d6043-c316-4559-ad75-ad86cdaeaa9f] The Regulations also specify how the Regulator would do this: the Regulator may publish the information in the manner prescribed in the Rules. [#TGT:cd1d6043-c316-4559-ad75-ad86cdaeaa9f] Practically, this means that where the Prospectus-related publication duties apply to the Issuer’s ADGM public offer, a publication failure can lead to the Regulator making the required information public using the Rules-based method. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd]

question: For an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, how should the annual supervision fee amount be determined and paid when the Applicant is seeking to operate an MTF, taking into account that the SOURCE sets the fee “pursuant to FEES Rule 3.17.2” and “payable in accordance with paragraph 1 of the FEES Rulebook,” while the TARGET distinguishes between (i) $15,000 per Regulated Activity and (ii) $60,000 where the Regulated Activity is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility without any additional Regulated Activity?
gold_answer: The annual supervision fee for an Authorised Person carrying on a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets is set at either $15,000 or $60,000, and the correct amount depends on whether the activity is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility and whether it is the only Regulated Activity. [#SRC:9a65518c-820e-4e90-abba-4a05d7c482c0] [#TGT:febdfdb0-1bc0-41ad-a131-4be1812571f8] Where the Applicant is seeking to operate an MTF (in relation to Virtual Assets), the SOURCE identifies a $60,000 annual supervision fee category established under FEES Rule 3.17.2 and payable under paragraph 1 of the FEES Rulebook. [#SRC:9a65518c-820e-4e90-abba-4a05d7c482c0] The TARGET clarifies how that $60,000 category applies in operational terms: the $60,000 amount is used when the Regulated Activity is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility and there is no additional Regulated Activity. [#TGT:febdfdb0-1bc0-41ad-a131-4be1812571f8] If the Authorised Person undertakes Regulated Activities beyond Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility, the TARGET indicates the annual supervision fee is $15,000 for each Regulated Activity, payable to the Regulator in addition to supervision fees due in respect of each Regulated Activity undertaken. [#TGT:febdfdb0-1bc0-41ad-a131-4be1812571f8] Payment is to be made in the manner contemplated by paragraph 1 of the FEES Rulebook as referenced in the SOURCE. [#SRC:9a65518c-820e-4e90-abba-4a05d7c482c0]

question: If an Authorised Person has a Financial Services Permission for Virtual Assets, when do they pay $15,000 and when do they pay $60,000 each year, and how does the SOURCE’s note that the fee is set under FEES Rule 3.17.2 and payable under paragraph 1 of the FEES Rulebook fit with the TARGET’s rule about “Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility without any additional Regulated Activity”?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission to carry on a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets must pay an annual supervision fee that is either $15,000 or $60,000, and the choice depends on the type and combination of Regulated Activities. [#TGT:febdfdb0-1bc0-41ad-a131-4be1812571f8] The SOURCE frames these amounts as the annual supervision fees set under FEES Rule 3.17.2 and indicates they are payable in accordance with paragraph 1 of the FEES Rulebook. [#SRC:9a65518c-820e-4e90-abba-4a05d7c482c0] In practical terms: - Pay $15,000 when the fee is calculated per Regulated Activity, because the TARGET sets $15,000 for each Regulated Activity the Authorised Person undertakes. [#TGT:febdfdb0-1bc0-41ad-a131-4be1812571f8] - Pay $60,000 when the Regulated Activity is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility and it is the only Regulated Activity, which aligns with the SOURCE’s $60,000 category for an Applicant seeking to operate an MTF (in relation to Virtual Assets). [#TGT:febdfdb0-1bc0-41ad-a131-4be1812571f8] [#SRC:9a65518c-820e-4e90-abba-4a05d7c482c0] The payment mechanics are tied to paragraph 1 of the FEES Rulebook as referenced in the SOURCE, while the TARGET explains when each amount applies based on the activity mix. [#SRC:9a65518c-820e-4e90-abba-4a05d7c482c0] [#TGT:febdfdb0-1bc0-41ad-a131-4be1812571f8]

question: When considering whether to modify or waive Rule 2.3.2 for an admission to the Official List, how should the Regulator assess whether investors have the necessary information, specifically in relation to the Applicant’s audited financial statements (including period covered, consolidation, accounting standards, and audit standards)?
gold_answer: The Regulator may modify or waive Rule 2.3.2 only where it considers the change desirable in the interests of investors and is satisfied that investors have enough information to make an informed judgement about the Issuer and the Shares for which admission to the Official List is sought. [#SRC:108a7eb5-7dc8-4146-9fbb-d68fe745ccca] In assessing whether investors have “necessary information” in this context, a central element is whether the Applicant has made available audited financial statements meeting the specified publication/filing and content conditions. [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1] Practically, the information baseline for investor judgement can be evidenced by confirming that the Applicant has published or filed audited accounts that: (i) cover three prior years, or a shorter period that the Regulator accepts; (ii) are consolidated for the Applicant and its subsidiary undertakings; (iii) are prepared under IFRS or other standards acceptable to the Regulator; and (iv) are audited and reported on under IAASB auditing standards or other standards acceptable to the Regulator. [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1] If these audited-account conditions are met (including any Regulator-accepted shorter period or alternative standards), that supports the Regulator’s satisfaction that investors have the necessary information when deciding whether a Rule 2.3.2 modification/waiver is appropriate. [#SRC:108a7eb5-7dc8-4146-9fbb-d68fe745ccca] [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1]

question: If the Regulator is thinking about waiving or changing Rule 2.3.2 for a company seeking admission to the Official List, what audited accounts information should be checked to help show investors can still make an informed judgement about the Issuer and the Shares?
gold_answer: A waiver or change to Rule 2.3.2 is only available where the Regulator thinks doing so is desirable for investors and is satisfied that investors still have enough information to make an informed judgement about the Issuer and the Shares being admitted to the Official List. [#SRC:108a7eb5-7dc8-4146-9fbb-d68fe745ccca] One key way to support that “enough information” test is to confirm the Applicant has made audited financial statements available in the form and scope required for audited accounts. [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1] To do that check, verify the Applicant has published or filed audited accounts that meet all of these points: they cover a prior period of three years (or a shorter period the Regulator accepts); they are consolidated for the Applicant and any subsidiary undertakings; they are prepared under IFRS or another standard the Regulator accepts; and they have been audited and reported on by auditors using IAASB auditing standards (or another standard the Regulator accepts). [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1] If those audited-account conditions are satisfied (including any Regulator-accepted alternatives), that helps demonstrate the investor-information basis the Regulator must be comfortable with before modifying or waiving Rule 2.3.2. [#SRC:108a7eb5-7dc8-4146-9fbb-d68fe745ccca] [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1]

question: When an Authorised Person is identifying which capital instruments can be included in its Available Stable Funding (ASF), how should it treat instruments that qualify as AT1 Capital, including any related Share premium accounts, given the ASF eligibility cross-references and the stated exclusion for certain Tier 2 instruments?
gold_answer: In identifying capital instruments for inclusion in Available Stable Funding (ASF), an Authorised Person must base its selection on whether the relevant capital elements meet the eligibility requirements under Rule 3.10.2, Rule 3.11.2, and Rule 3.12.2, while also applying the explicit exclusion for Tier 2 capital instruments that have a residual maturity of less than one year. [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1] Where the capital element under consideration is AT1 Capital, the composition of AT1 Capital is limited to (i) capital instruments that meet the eligibility criteria in Rule 3.11.3 and (ii) the Share premium accounts that relate to those eligible instruments. [#TGT:1cb9d22d-5506-40d1-92ea-7f84d5e4d10b] Practically, this means the Authorised Person should first determine whether the item is an AT1-eligible instrument under Rule 3.11.3 and identify any associated Share premium accounts, and then assess whether those capital elements fall within the categories of capital elements that are eligible for ASF inclusion by reference to the ASF cross-referenced rules. [#TGT:1cb9d22d-5506-40d1-92ea-7f84d5e4d10b] [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1] The Tier 2 residual-maturity exclusion applies specifically to Tier 2 instruments and therefore does not describe an exclusion for AT1 elements as such; however, the Authorised Person must still apply that Tier 2 filter when any Tier 2 instruments are being considered for ASF. [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1]

question: If you are working out what goes into an Authorised Person’s Available Stable Funding (ASF), and you see AT1 Capital items, what exactly counts as AT1 Capital (including share premium), and what extra ASF screening step must you apply for Tier 2 instruments with short remaining maturity?
gold_answer: To handle AT1 Capital items correctly while building the Available Stable Funding (ASF) set, you need to apply two linked determinations: what counts as AT1 Capital, and what the ASF identification process requires (including a specific Tier 2 exclusion). [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1] AT1 Capital is made up of (a) capital instruments that satisfy the eligibility criteria in Rule 3.11.3 and (b) the Share premium accounts that relate to those eligible instruments. [#TGT:1cb9d22d-5506-40d1-92ea-7f84d5e4d10b] Separately, when an Authorised Person identifies capital instruments to include in ASF, it must do so by considering capital elements that meet the eligibility requirements under Rule 3.10.2, Rule 3.11.2, and Rule 3.12.2. [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1] In that ASF identification step, the Authorised Person must exclude all Tier 2 capital instruments that have a residual maturity of less than one year. [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1] So, you should (i) classify AT1 items as eligible instruments under Rule 3.11.3 plus their related share premium, and (ii) apply the ASF rule set and the Tier 2 short-maturity exclusion when deciding what is included in ASF. [#TGT:1cb9d22d-5506-40d1-92ea-7f84d5e4d10b] [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1]

question: Where an Issuer is seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF and intends to rely on the Exempt Offer circumstance that permits an Offer to no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients, can the Issuer simultaneously structure the same fundraising as an Exempt Offer to an unlimited number of Professional Clients, and what limitation applies to which Exempt Offer circumstances may be combined?
gold_answer: Yes. An Issuer seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF may run a simultaneous Exempt Offer that (i) is directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients and (ii) is also directed to an unlimited number of Professional Clients, provided the Issuer is relying on the relevant Exempt Offer circumstances in combination as permitted. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] The “200 Persons” limb corresponds to the prescribed Exempt Offer circumstance for an Offer in or from the ADGM directed at no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients (and not Market Counterparties), where the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] The “unlimited Professional Clients” limb aligns with the prescribed Exempt Offer circumstance for an Offer made to or directed at only Professional Clients. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] When combining Exempt Offer circumstances for this MTF admission scenario, the Issuer may rely on one or more of the circumstances within the relevant Exempt Offer rule set, but it cannot use the circumstance identified as MKT Rule 4.3.1(2) as part of that combination. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]

question: If an Issuer wants its Securities admitted to trading on an MTF and plans an Exempt Offer to up to 200 people who are not Professional Clients, what extra condition about the offer channel must be met, and can the Issuer also offer to Professional Clients at the same time?
gold_answer: For the “up to 200” route, the offer must fit the circumstance where an Offer in or from the ADGM is directed at no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients (and not Market Counterparties) and the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] In the MTF admission context described, an Issuer can also run a simultaneous Exempt Offer to an unlimited number of Professional Clients alongside the offer to up to 200 non‑Professional Clients. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] The Professional Client leg is consistent with the prescribed Exempt Offer circumstance for an Offer made to or directed at only Professional Clients. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] When structuring the combined approach for admission to trading on an MTF, the Issuer may rely on one or more Exempt Offer circumstances, but there is a specific carve-out: the circumstance identified as MKT Rule 4.3.1(2) cannot be used as part of that combination. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]

question: Where a PFP Operator updates information it has published under Rule 18.5.1 to reflect a material change and provides notice of that change to PFP Clients, what specific records must it retain and for how long, including any related transaction documentation and due diligence materials?
gold_answer: A PFP Operator must both (i) keep its Rule 18.5.1 published information current for material changes and notify PFP Clients of those changes within a reasonable timeframe, and (ii) retain defined records for at least six years that evidence the disclosures and related compliance activity. [#TGT:40149b11-dcb8-48a6-ab09-8d8c37923183] Specifically, because the update and client notice relate to information published under Rule 18.5.1, the Operator must maintain records of all disclosures made under Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2 for a minimum of six years. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] In addition, the Operator must keep, for the same minimum six-year period, documentation exchanged between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect, to the extent such documentation exists in connection with the relevant PFP activity. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] The Operator must also retain records of the due diligence undertaken in accordance with Rule 18.4.1 for at least six years, which supports the integrity of the information being published and updated. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] The timing obligation for notifying PFP Clients is that notice must be provided within a reasonable timeframe after the material change occurs. [#TGT:40149b11-dcb8-48a6-ab09-8d8c37923183]

question: If a PFP Operator makes a material change to the information it publishes under Rule 18.5.1, what does it need to do for PFP Clients, and what records does it have to keep (and for how long) to show it did this and handled the related work?
gold_answer: When there is a material change affecting information published under Rule 18.5.1, the PFP Operator must update that published information so it reflects the change and must give PFP Clients notice of the material change within a reasonable timeframe after the change happens. [#TGT:40149b11-dcb8-48a6-ab09-8d8c37923183] To demonstrate and support this activity, the Operator must keep specified records for a minimum of six years. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] Those records include all disclosures made under Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2, which would cover the disclosures connected to the information being updated and notified. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] The Operator must also retain all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect, where such documentation exists in connection with the relevant transaction activity. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] Finally, it must keep records of the due diligence undertaken in accordance with Rule 18.4.1 for at least six years, as part of the overall record set it is required to maintain. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7]

question: How should a Recognised Body structure its internal compliance arrangements so that its Auditors can meet both (i) the general duty to disclose to the Regulator matters indicating a breach or likely breach of Regulations or Rules and (ii) the Appointed auditor’s duty to communicate information/opinions to the Regulator when specific material-significance or reporting-limitation circumstances arise (including Threshold Conditions/Recognition Requirements and going-concern concerns)?
gold_answer: A Recognised Body should implement internal systems and procedures that both (1) capture and escalate potential non-compliance matters for disclosure to the Regulator and (2) enable its Auditors (including an Appointed auditor) to make the specific communications to the Regulator that are triggered by defined audit-judgment circumstances. [#SRC:80eb597d-32ee-446e-a416-b5777f98698b] In practice, the Recognised Body’s arrangements should be designed so its Auditors can identify and report matters that may indicate a breach/likely breach or failure/likely failure to comply with Regulations or Rules, and so the Recognised Body can support compliance with those notification requirements. [#SRC:80eb597d-32ee-446e-a416-b5777f98698b] Those same arrangements should also ensure the Appointed auditor can communicate to the Regulator information or opinions on the matters referenced in sections 191(3) and 192(3) when the auditor reasonably believes there may have been a contravention that could be materially significant to the Regulator’s use of its powers, or when the information/opinion may be materially significant to whether the person concerned will satisfy Threshold Conditions or (for a Recognised Body) Recognition Requirements. [#TGT:46098015-5ac3-4e30-a252-1dc40ab3f6d6] The procedures should further support communication where the auditor reasonably believes the person concerned may cease to be a going concern, or where the auditor is unable to make required statements in the auditor’s report about preparation of annual accounts/other financial reports or other specified reporting statements. [#TGT:46098015-5ac3-4e30-a252-1dc40ab3f6d6]

question: If an Appointed auditor thinks a company might not be a going concern or can’t make certain statements in the audit report, what does the Recognised Body need to have in place so the auditor can notify the Regulator, and how does that connect to the general rule about telling the Regulator about likely breaches of Regulations or Rules?
gold_answer: The Recognised Body needs systems and procedures that make it possible for its Auditors to comply with notification duties to the Regulator, including situations that arise during audit work. [#SRC:80eb597d-32ee-446e-a416-b5777f98698b] This includes enabling disclosures to the Regulator of any matter that may indicate a breach or likely breach of, or a failure or likely failure to comply with, Regulations or Rules, and ensuring the Recognised Body’s Auditors can meet those notification requirements in practice. [#SRC:80eb597d-32ee-446e-a416-b5777f98698b] In addition, when the auditor is an Appointed auditor, the auditor must communicate to the Regulator information or an opinion on the matters mentioned in sections 191(3) and 192(3) if the auditor reasonably believes the person concerned is not, may not be, or may cease to be, a going concern. [#TGT:46098015-5ac3-4e30-a252-1dc40ab3f6d6] The Appointed auditor must also communicate where the auditor is precluded from stating in the report that the annual accounts (or certain other financial reports) were properly prepared or meet specified reporting statements tied to the Companies Regulations or Rules made under these Regulations. [#TGT:46098015-5ac3-4e30-a252-1dc40ab3f6d6] Putting these together, the Recognised Body’s internal arrangements should support both broad breach/likely-breach disclosures and the more specific audit-triggered communications (going concern and report-statement limitations) so the Regulator receives the required information. [#SRC:80eb597d-32ee-446e-a416-b5777f98698b] [#TGT:46098015-5ac3-4e30-a252-1dc40ab3f6d6]

question: Under a Framework Contract, when the Customer is not a Natural Person, can the Customer and the Third Party Provider agree in writing to disapply the prohibition on charging for information required under Section 20.2, and what form and scope must that agreement take?
gold_answer: Yes. If the Customer is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider are permitted to make a written agreement that certain specified rules do not apply, and that carve-out can include the rules dealing with charges for information. [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] In the absence of such a written agreement, the Third Party Provider is not permitted to charge for providing or making available information that must be provided or made available under Section 20.2 in a Framework Contract context. [#TGT:50664c7f-6f26-481a-8070-81ff2afddce3] The agreement must be in writing and is limited to the enumerated rules that the parties may disapply, including Rules 20.2.15 and 20.2.16 (identified as the rules on charges for information). [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] Practically, this means the parties must (i) confirm the Customer is not a Natural Person, (ii) expressly document in writing that Rules 20.2.15 and 20.2.16 do not apply, and (iii) understand that the default position under Section 20.2 is that required information must be provided without charge unless those specific rules are contractually disapplied in the permitted way. [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] [#TGT:50664c7f-6f26-481a-8070-81ff2afddce3]

question: If the Customer is a company (not a Natural Person), can the Customer and the Third Party Provider put in writing that the Third Party Provider may charge for information that Section 20.2 says must be provided under a Framework Contract?
gold_answer: They can, but only by using the specific written opt-out that is allowed when the Customer is not a Natural Person. [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] The general rule for a Framework Contract is that a Third Party Provider is not allowed to charge for giving or making available information that Section 20.2 requires to be provided or made available. [#TGT:50664c7f-6f26-481a-8070-81ff2afddce3] However, where the Customer is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider may agree in writing that certain listed rules do not apply, and that list includes Rules 20.2.15 and 20.2.16, which are the rules about charges for information. [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] So, to change the no-charge outcome for Section 20.2-required information, the parties would need a written agreement that specifically disapplies those charges-for-information rules, rather than relying on an informal understanding. [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] [#TGT:50664c7f-6f26-481a-8070-81ff2afddce3]

question: For an Authorised Person that falls within Category 1, 2, 3A or 5, how should it determine the frequency for calculating its NSFR so that it can monitor ongoing compliance and respond to potential material changes in its funding profile?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5 must treat the NSFR calculation as an ongoing monitoring tool and set a calculation frequency that is sufficient to confirm it can meet the NSFR requirement continuously, not merely at periodic reporting dates. [#TGT:c6a601d3-a2ca-464f-820c-bdd74b7e1759] In practice, this means the Authorised Person should calculate its NSFR often enough to be able to track whether it satisfies the requirement in Rule 10.4.1 at all times. [#SRC:50aee557-426a-475b-bbf3-73ca3ea00933] Beyond its baseline frequency, it should also perform an additional NSFR calculation whenever it believes a change has occurred to its Available Stable Funding or its Required Stable Funding that could cause a material change in the level of its NSFR. [#SRC:50aee557-426a-475b-bbf3-73ca3ea00933] Accordingly, for the covered categories, the frequency decision should incorporate both (i) a regular cadence designed to support continuous monitoring and (ii) an event-driven trigger tied to suspected material changes in either Available Stable Funding or Required Stable Funding. [#TGT:c6a601d3-a2ca-464f-820c-bdd74b7e1759] [#SRC:50aee557-426a-475b-bbf3-73ca3ea00933]

question: If an Authorised Person is in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5, when does it need to calculate its NSFR, and what kinds of changes should make it run the calculation again?
gold_answer: For an Authorised Person that is within Category 1, 2, 3A or 5, the NSFR calculation needs to be done often enough to support continuous monitoring of whether the firm meets the NSFR requirement, rather than being treated as a one-off exercise. [#TGT:c6a601d3-a2ca-464f-820c-bdd74b7e1759] The firm should set an appropriate calculation frequency so it can check its satisfaction of the requirement in Rule 10.4.1 at all times. [#SRC:50aee557-426a-475b-bbf3-73ca3ea00933] In addition to that regular frequency, it should calculate its NSFR again when it believes a change has happened to its Available Stable Funding or Required Stable Funding and that change might lead to a material shift in the NSFR level. [#SRC:50aee557-426a-475b-bbf3-73ca3ea00933] Put simply, for the categories covered by the Section, the trigger is twofold: routine calculations to maintain ongoing visibility, plus extra calculations prompted by suspected material changes in either side of the NSFR (Available Stable Funding or Required Stable Funding). [#TGT:c6a601d3-a2ca-464f-820c-bdd74b7e1759] [#SRC:50aee557-426a-475b-bbf3-73ca3ea00933]

question: How should an Authorised Person determine whether its Dealing in Investments as Principal activity keeps it in Category 2 or instead places it within Category 3A, where the firm asserts it acts only as a Matched Principal and holds residual positions? In your answer, include the specific conditions that must be met for the firm to be treated as dealing as a Matched Principal and explain how that interacts with the Category 2 guidance about dealing authorisation.
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person is authorised for Dealing in Investments as Principal, it will be treated as Category 2 on the basis that this authorisation (and not being authorised for the activities referenced as disqualifying in the Category 2 guidance) is determinative—unless its dealing is limited to acting only as Matched Principal, in which case the dealing activity is instead treated as falling within Category 3A. [#SRC:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] To support the “only as Matched Principal” position, the firm must meet the Rules’ Matched Principal conditions: it must transact as principal solely to fill Clients’ orders, and any positions held for its own account must arise only because Clients’ orders could not be matched. [#TGT:36237c4c-0aef-4cdf-879a-4f72f0c1facc] In addition, the total market value of those residual positions must not exceed 15% of the Firm’s Tier 1 Capital Resources, and the positions must be incidental and held only for the time reasonably required to complete such transactions. [#TGT:36237c4c-0aef-4cdf-879a-4f72f0c1facc] Accordingly, the classification hinges on combining (i) the Category 2 guidance that dealing authorisation is determinative, with (ii) the specific Matched Principal constraints that, if satisfied and if dealing is limited to that model, shift the dealing activity into Category 3A. [#SRC:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]

question: If an Authorised Person says it only deals as a Matched Principal, what exact limits must it follow (including the 15% test and how long it can hold positions), and how does meeting those limits affect whether its dealing activity is treated as Category 2 or Category 3A?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person’s dealing is genuinely limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the dealing activity is treated as falling within Category 3A rather than being treated under the Category 2 approach that focuses on authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal. [#SRC:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] To qualify as dealing as a Matched Principal for these Rules, the firm must enter into transactions as a principal only to fulfil its Clients’ orders, not for its own trading purposes. [#TGT:36237c4c-0aef-4cdf-879a-4f72f0c1facc] Any positions it holds for its own account must occur only because it failed to match Clients’ orders, and the total market value of those positions must be capped at no more than 15% of the Firm’s Tier 1 Capital Resources. [#TGT:36237c4c-0aef-4cdf-879a-4f72f0c1facc] The positions must also be incidental and kept strictly to the time reasonably required to carry out a transaction of that nature, which limits both the purpose and duration of any residual exposure. [#TGT:36237c4c-0aef-4cdf-879a-4f72f0c1facc] Putting these together, the firm uses the Matched Principal definition to evidence that its dealing is “only” in that capacity, and that is the linkage that moves the dealing activity into Category 3A rather than Category 2. [#SRC:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]

question: Where the Regulator has exercised its discretion to approve an Offer document (including any conditions or restrictions it imposes), what are the Issuer’s obligations regarding when and in what form that approved Offer document must be made available to the public?
gold_answer: Once the Regulator has approved the relevant Offer document under the Rule that allows the Regulator to approve it in accordance with the Rule’s requirements and procedures, and to attach any conditions or restrictions it considers appropriate, the document triggers a public-availability obligation. [#TGT:cff95a0c-cf4e-421f-aef9-c27588e13519] Specifically, after that approval has occurred, the Offer document must be made available to the public without undue delay—i.e., as soon as reasonably practicable. [#SRC:22b3eee4-acfd-4a8b-9dc9-e3c9ff07d5ca] In addition, the version made public must match the form that was approved by the Regulator, meaning the public-facing document must be the approved form rather than an alternative or modified version. [#SRC:22b3eee4-acfd-4a8b-9dc9-e3c9ff07d5ca] In practical compliance terms, the key sequencing is that the Regulator’s approval (potentially subject to conditions or restrictions) is the prerequisite event, and the Issuer must then promptly publish the Offer document in the approved form. [#TGT:cff95a0c-cf4e-421f-aef9-c27588e13519] [#SRC:22b3eee4-acfd-4a8b-9dc9-e3c9ff07d5ca]

question: If the Regulator approves an Offer document and can add conditions or restrictions, what do you have to do next to share it with the public, and how quickly and in what version must you share it?
gold_answer: After the Regulator approves the Offer document under the Rule that lets it grant approval following the Rule’s procedures and also lets it impose any conditions or restrictions it thinks fit, you must move to public release. [#TGT:cff95a0c-cf4e-421f-aef9-c27588e13519] The timing requirement is that the approved Offer document must be made available to the public as soon as reasonably practicable after approval. [#SRC:22b3eee4-acfd-4a8b-9dc9-e3c9ff07d5ca] The format requirement is equally strict: the document you make public must be in the form that the Regulator approved, so the public version should not differ from the approved form. [#SRC:22b3eee4-acfd-4a8b-9dc9-e3c9ff07d5ca] Read together, these provisions mean the approval decision (including any conditions or restrictions attached to it) is the trigger point, and the compliance outcome is prompt public availability of the Offer document in the approved form. [#TGT:cff95a0c-cf4e-421f-aef9-c27588e13519] [#SRC:22b3eee4-acfd-4a8b-9dc9-e3c9ff07d5ca]

question: For a Mining Exploration Reporting Entity preparing its quarterly disclosure, what specific content must be included for each quarter (including any consolidated controlled-entity information and the 12‑month reserves/resources disclosure tracking), and by when after quarter-end must the report be disclosed?
gold_answer: A Mining Exploration Reporting Entity is required to disclose a quarterly report that both (i) contains the specified quarterly information set out for the entity and its controlled entities (on a consolidated basis if applicable) and (ii) is disclosed within the prescribed post‑quarter deadline. [#TGT:737c3487-346b-4104-8b50-78dd337bed22] The timing requirement is that the report required by Rule 11.10.1 must be disclosed no later than one month after the end of the quarter. [#SRC:8e80c422-3b41-4546-b511-41bb90ad9e79] The quarterly report must cover, for the Mining Exploration Reporting Entity and all controlled entities on a consolidated basis if applicable: (a) details of mining-related activities, including Exploration (or a statement of none) and production/development (or a statement of none); (b) a summary of expenditure for Exploration and for production/development; (c) Mining Tenements held at quarter end, their location, and percentage interest held, including beneficial interests in farm‑in/farm‑out agreements; and (d) Mining Tenements (including those beneficial interests) acquired or disposed of during the quarter and their location. [#TGT:737c3487-346b-4104-8b50-78dd337bed22] In addition, at least once every 12 months the report must include the Summary of Reserves and Resources required by Rule 11.11.1 unless it is included in the annual report, and it must state when the previous and upcoming disclosures of that summary were and will be made. [#TGT:737c3487-346b-4104-8b50-78dd337bed22]

question: When a Mining Exploration Reporting Entity has no Exploration activities in a quarter but does have production and development expenditure and tenement changes, what statements and tenement/expenditure details must still be included in the quarterly report, and what is the latest disclosure deadline after the quarter ends?
gold_answer: Even if there are no Exploration activities in the quarter, the Mining Exploration Reporting Entity must still produce a quarterly report containing the required categories of information (including explicit “no activity” statements where applicable) and disclose it within the required timeframe. [#TGT:737c3487-346b-4104-8b50-78dd337bed22] The disclosure deadline is no later than one month after the end of the quarter for the report required by Rule 11.10.1. [#SRC:8e80c422-3b41-4546-b511-41bb90ad9e79] On content, the report must include a statement that there have been no activities relating to Exploration where that is the case. [#TGT:737c3487-346b-4104-8b50-78dd337bed22] It must also include details of production and development activities (or a statement of none, if applicable) and a summary of expenditure incurred relating to both Exploration activities and production/development (so production/development expenditure must be summarized even if Exploration activity is absent).
