[#SRC:73f40402-9aa2-40a2-b7f9-ccba8d02720b] Practically, this means the meeting arrangements should not limit proxy access to equity holders only; instead, proxy rights and mechanisms must be made available to the class of Security holders who are entitled to vote at that meeting, with the Rule 9.3.6 and 9.3.7 considerations applied to that class. [#TGT:6364a6a2-b7e3-4559-8102-002850811697] [#SRC:73f40402-9aa2-40a2-b7f9-ccba8d02720b]

question: If a Listed Entity holds a meeting where Debenture holders (not ordinary Shareholders) can vote on changing their rights or terms, do they also need to be able to vote by proxy, and who is expected to treat the “Shareholder” wording as covering those Debenture holders (including considering Rules 9.3.6 and 9.3.7)?
gold_answer: Yes. When Debenture holders are the group that can vote at the meeting (for example, on a change to their rights or terms), they should be treated as the relevant “Shareholders” for applying the proxy requirement, meaning each eligible Debenture holder must be given both the right and the means to vote by proxy at that meeting. [#TGT:6364a6a2-b7e3-4559-8102-002850811697] This is because the Regulator expects that, in the relevant section, references to “Shareholder” are read to include holders of all classes of Securities where appropriate for the Listed Entity, and it gives the Debenture-holder voting example to illustrate that approach. [#SRC:73f40402-9aa2-40a2-b7f9-ccba8d02720b] The Regulator’s expectation is directed at the Person referred to in Rule 9.3.1, who must give proper attention to the requirements of Rules 9.3.6 and 9.3.7 as though those rules referred to the relevant Debenture holders in that context. [#SRC:73f40402-9aa2-40a2-b7f9-ccba8d02720b] So, even though the proxy rule is written for meetings where “Shareholders” can vote, it should be implemented for the actual voting class at the meeting, and the Rule 9.3.6/9.3.7 considerations should be applied on the same “as if” basis for that class. [#TGT:6364a6a2-b7e3-4559-8102-002850811697] [#SRC:73f40402-9aa2-40a2-b7f9-ccba8d02720b]

question: For a Remote Body’s annual report to the Regulator, how should the reporting period be set and sequenced across successive reports, and how does the suggested one-year period for the report submitted under Rule 7.4.1 fit with the start/end-date mechanics and the two‑month submission timing?
gold_answer: A Remote Body’s annual report should be structured so that each report covers a defined period that runs continuously from the end of the prior reporting period, and the report should then be delivered to the Regulator within the specified post-period deadline; within that framework, a one‑year coverage period is presented as the most convenient choice for the report submitted under Rule 7.4.1. [#SRC:1bdaf884-5e47-444f-a4b8-9cedd8d6e757] [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814] For the period boundaries, the period covered by a report begins the day after the period covered by the last report, or—if there is no prior report—begins after the making of the Recognition Order recognising the Remote Body as such. [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814] The period ends on the date specified in the report, or if no date is specified, it ends on the date of the report itself. [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814] If the Remote Body changes the period covered by its report, it should still ensure there is no gap or overlap by making the first day of the new period the day immediately following the last day of the previous period. [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814] Regardless of whether the period chosen is the convenient one‑year period referenced for Rule 7.4.1 reporting, copies should be sent to the Regulator within two months after the end of the period to which the report relates. [#SRC:1bdaf884-5e47-444f-a4b8-9cedd8d6e757] [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814]

question: If a Remote Body wants its annual report to cover about a year (as suggested for the report under Rule 7.4.1), when does that year start and end, what happens if it changes the period later, and how soon after the period ends must it send the report to the Regulator?
gold_answer: The Remote Body can align its annual report to cover a one‑year period, which is described as the most convenient length for the report submitted under Rule 7.4.1, but it still must follow the rules on how each reporting period starts/ends and when the report is sent. [#SRC:1bdaf884-5e47-444f-a4b8-9cedd8d6e757] [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814] The start of the period is tied to what came before: it begins the day after the period covered by the last report, or if there has not been a prior report, it begins after the making of the Recognition Order recognising the Remote Body as such. [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814] The end of the period is either the date the Remote Body states in the report, or if it does not state an end date, the period ends on the date of the report. [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814] If the Remote Body later changes the period it covers, it should keep the timeline continuous by making the first day of the new period the day immediately after the last day of the previous period. [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814] After the period ends (whether it is a year or another length), copies of the report should be sent to the Regulator within two months. [#SRC:1bdaf884-5e47-444f-a4b8-9cedd8d6e757] [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814]

question: For Derivatives (including written credit protection), how should a firm reconcile the SOURCE requirement to compute an Exposure value using an IFRS on-balance sheet amount plus an add-on for potential future Exposure with the TARGET SA-CCR requirement to calculate EAD per netting set using alpha, replacement cost (RC), and potential future exposure (PFE)?
gold_answer: For Derivatives (including written credit protection), the Exposure value framework in the SOURCE is built from two components: (i) an on-balance sheet amount determined under IFRS and (ii) an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated under specified App 4 rules. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] When the firm is applying the SA-CCR method described in the TARGET, it must calculate EAD separately for each netting set and determine it using the formula EAD = alpha * (RC + PFE), with alpha fixed at 1.4. [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] To reconcile the two, the firm should treat the TARGET’s PFE term as the structured “add-on for potential future Exposure” concept referenced in the SOURCE, because both are explicitly defined as potential future exposure amounts calculated under App 4 rule references. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] In addition, the TARGET requires RC (replacement cost) to be calculated under its specified rule set and combined with PFE before applying alpha, and this netting-set-by-netting-set EAD calculation provides the SA-CCR-specific way to operationalize the Exposure measurement for derivatives alongside the SOURCE’s IFRS-plus-add-on structure. [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007]

question: If you are working out exposure for Derivatives (including written credit protection), what are the pieces you need from the SOURCE (IFRS amount plus add-on) and how does the TARGET say to combine RC and PFE (with alpha) for each netting set?
gold_answer: For Derivatives (including written credit protection), the SOURCE says the Exposure value is made up of two parts: the on-balance sheet value measured under IFRS, plus an add-on for potential future Exposure that is calculated using the referenced App 4 rules. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] The TARGET then gives a specific SA-CCR calculation that must be done separately for each netting set, which is important because it sets the unit of calculation (netting set) rather than a single portfolio-wide number. [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] Under SA-CCR, EAD is computed as EAD = alpha * (RC + PFE), where alpha is 1.4, RC is replacement cost calculated under the specified rules, and PFE is the potential future exposure amount calculated under the specified rule. [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] Linking the two passages, the “add-on for potential future Exposure” concept in the SOURCE aligns with the TARGET’s PFE component, because both are explicitly framed as potential future exposure amounts determined by referenced App 4 rule calculations. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] Practically, you would identify the IFRS on-balance sheet amount per the SOURCE and then use the TARGET’s netting-set SA-CCR structure (RC and PFE with alpha) to express the exposure measurement in the SA-CCR form. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918]

question: If the Regulator approves an Application for a Key Individual with conditions and/or for a limited period because it considers that desirable to further its objectives, what mechanism allows the Recognised Body concerned to seek changes to those conditions, and what specific actions may the Regulator take on such a request?
gold_answer: When an application for approval of a Key Individual has been granted subject to conditions, the Recognised Body concerned has a route to request changes to those conditions by applying to the Regulator to vary the approval, but this is framed as applying where the approval was granted subject to one or both of the conditions under Rule 2.3.6. [#SRC:88fdc472-9333-426a-82ae-9602a9ab3418] This sits alongside the Regulator’s broader discretion to approve an Application subject to any conditions it considers appropriate and, if it considers it desirable to further one or more of its objectives, to approve for a limited period only. [#TGT:40fe745f-7cd6-4472-a500-6dcd7eb20714] On a Recognised Body’s application to vary the approval, the Regulator’s available outcomes are specifically to adjust the existing conditions by varying a condition, to lift an existing condition by removing a condition, or to add further constraints by imposing a new condition. [#SRC:88fdc472-9333-426a-82ae-9602a9ab3418] The TARGET passage explains the context in which conditions (and a limited approval period) may be attached in the first place—namely, where the Regulator considers this desirable to advance its objectives—while the SOURCE passage provides the procedural lever and the closed list of condition-related actions the Regulator may take once a variation request is made. [#TGT:40fe745f-7cd6-4472-a500-6dcd7eb20714] [#SRC:88fdc472-9333-426a-82ae-9602a9ab3418]

question: If the Regulator approves an Application with conditions (and maybe only for a limited time) because it thinks that helps its objectives, how can the Recognised Body concerned ask to change those conditions, and what can the Regulator do in response?
gold_answer: If an application for approval of a Key Individual is granted with conditions, the Recognised Body concerned can ask for those conditions to be changed by applying to the Regulator to vary the approval, in the situation described as being where the approval was granted subject to one or both of the conditions under Rule 2.3.6. [#SRC:88fdc472-9333-426a-82ae-9602a9ab3418] This request mechanism connects to the Regulator’s initial power to approve an Application with whatever conditions it considers appropriate and, where it considers it desirable to further one or more of its objectives, to approve for a limited period only. [#TGT:40fe745f-7cd6-4472-a500-6dcd7eb20714] After the Recognised Body applies to vary the approval, the Regulator has three specific options for dealing with conditions: it may change an existing condition, it may remove an existing condition, or it may add a new condition. [#SRC:88fdc472-9333-426a-82ae-9602a9ab3418] The TARGET text explains why conditions (and a time limit) might be attached at approval—because the Regulator thinks that approach supports its objectives—while the SOURCE text explains how the Recognised Body can seek changes and what the Regulator is allowed to do when considering that request. [#TGT:40fe745f-7cd6-4472-a500-6dcd7eb20714] [#SRC:88fdc472-9333-426a-82ae-9602a9ab3418]

question: When reviewing an Applicant’s submission that includes (among other items) details of arrangements for cooperating with the Regulator and other appropriate authorities (including draft memoranda of understanding or letters), how may the Regulator extend its information-gathering beyond the application contents, and from whom and where may it seek additional engagement?
gold_answer: The Regulator is not limited to assessing only the materials listed as items that an application “should include”; it may go further by requesting additional information from the Applicant, including information of the type referenced as being specified in Rule 2.15.4. [#SRC:428b2c75-c493-42dd-8496-629f64a61282] In practice, this means that even if the Applicant has provided the application content covering cooperation arrangements—such as details of how it will cooperate with the Regulator and other appropriate authorities, including draft memoranda of understanding or letters—the Regulator may still require further information beyond those submitted documents. [#TGT:e3ca5363-b207-4179-91e2-c6e34ac4384e] In addition to seeking further information directly from the Applicant, the Regulator may also need to hold discussions with the appropriate authorities in the Applicant’s home jurisdiction, which adds an external engagement channel that complements the Applicant’s own described cooperation framework. [#SRC:428b2c75-c493-42dd-8496-629f64a61282] Accordingly, an Applicant should be prepared both to supplement its application package and to support cross-jurisdictional regulatory discussions that the Regulator considers necessary. [#SRC:428b2c75-c493-42dd-8496-629f64a61282]

question: If an Applicant has already put in its application the last three annual reports and accounts and the current year’s quarterly management accounts, can the Regulator still ask for more information, and can it also talk to authorities in the Applicant’s home jurisdiction?
gold_answer: Yes. Even where the application includes financial materials such as copies of the last three annual reports and accounts and, for the current financial year, quarterly management accounts, the Regulator may still require further information from the Applicant. [#TGT:e3ca5363-b207-4179-91e2-c6e34ac4384e] The Regulator’s ability to seek more is not confined to the listed application contents; it may request additional information, including information described as being specified in Rule 2.15.4. [#SRC:428b2c75-c493-42dd-8496-629f64a61282] Separately from requesting more documents or explanations from the Applicant, the Regulator may also need to have discussions with the appropriate authorities in the Applicant’s home jurisdiction. [#SRC:428b2c75-c493-42dd-8496-629f64a61282] Taken together, this means that providing the specified financial submissions is necessary for a complete application package, but it does not prevent follow-up requests or cross-border regulatory engagement if the Regulator considers those steps needed. [#TGT:e3ca5363-b207-4179-91e2-c6e34ac4384e]

question: When an Authorised Person calculates the maximum distributable amount using the multiplication method in the SOURCE, how should it treat interim or year-end profits that were not included in CET1 Capital, given the TARGET’s description of what CET1 Capital consists of, and how does the CET1 Capital quartile position affect the factor applied?
gold_answer: In determining the maximum distributable amount, an Authorised Person must start from the specified pool of profits and then apply a factor that depends on where its CET1 Capital sits within the Combined Buffer Requirement. [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1] The profit pool used in the multiplication is limited to interim or year-end profits that were not included in CET1 Capital and that accrued after the most recent distribution of profits and after any actions referenced in the SOURCE. [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1] This “not included in CET1 Capital” condition should be understood against the CET1 Capital composition: CET1 Capital is made up of specified capital elements such as capital instruments meeting Rule 3.10.3 conditions, related share premium, retained earnings, accumulated other comprehensive income (as defined in IFRS), and other IFRS-disclosed reserves (with stated exclusions). [#TGT:6ae8d23c-06f5-4f8c-b1b1-824cb6db43eb] After identifying the eligible profit pool, the Authorised Person must multiply it by the factor tied to its CET1 Capital (excluding CET1 used to meet the Capital Requirement, including any Individual Capital Requirement) falling into the first, second, third, or fourth quartile of the Combined Buffer Requirement: 0, 0.2, 0.4, or 0.6 respectively. [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1]

question: If an Authorised Person has profits since the last profit distribution, how do they decide which profits go into the maximum distributable amount calculation, using the CET1 Capital definition in the TARGET and the quartile-based factor rules in the SOURCE?
gold_answer: To decide what profits feed into the maximum distributable amount calculation, the Authorised Person must first identify the relevant profits and then apply the correct quartile-based factor. [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1] The profits that can be used are only interim or year-end profits that were not included in CET1 Capital, and they must have accrued after the most recent distribution of profits and after any actions referenced in the SOURCE. [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1] Whether profits were “included in CET1 Capital” should be assessed in light of what CET1 Capital consists of: it is the sum of specified elements including qualifying capital instruments (subject to Rule 3.10.3 conditions), related share premium accounts, retained earnings, accumulated other comprehensive income (as defined in IFRS), and other IFRS-disclosed reserves (excluding amounts already counted in accumulated other comprehensive income or retained earnings). [#TGT:6ae8d23c-06f5-4f8c-b1b1-824cb6db43eb] Once the eligible profit amount is set, the Authorised Person multiplies it by a factor determined by where its CET1 Capital (excluding CET1 used to meet the Capital Requirement, including any Individual Capital Requirement) falls within the Combined Buffer Requirement quartiles: 0 in the first quartile, 0.2 in the second, 0.4 in the third, and 0.6 in the fourth. [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1]

question: When an Authorised Person is considering recognising the effects of CRM of a Credit Derivative where the protection provider is an MDB, how does the eligibility condition for recognising CRM interact with the requirement to risk weight a CR Exposure in the MDB asset class, including the applicable risk weights by Credit Quality Grade and for unrated exposures?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may recognise the effects of CRM of a Credit Derivative provided by an MDB only where the MDB is one of the MDBs referred to in Rules 4.12.7 to 4.12.9, so the protection provider must fall within that MDB category for CRM recognition to be available. [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] Separately, where the exposure is a CR Exposure in the MDB asset class, the Authorised Person must apply the MDB asset class risk-weighting table (noting it is stated to be subject to Rules 4.12.8 and 4.12.9). [#TGT:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c] In practice, this means you address two linked determinations: (i) whether the protection provider qualifies as an MDB for purposes of recognising CRM effects, and (ii) how the relevant CR Exposure in the MDB asset class is risk weighted under the table. [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] [#TGT:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c] Under the table, Credit Quality Grade 1 receives a 0% risk weight; Grades 2 and 3 receive 50%; Grades 4 and 5 receive 100%; Grade 6 receives 150%; and unrated exposures receive 50%. [#TGT:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c]

question: If the protection seller on a credit derivative is an MDB, what do you need to check so you can count the credit risk mitigation, and what risk weights apply to an MDB asset class CR Exposure by Credit Quality Grade (including unrated)?
gold_answer: To be able to recognise the effects of CRM from a Credit Derivative where the protection provider is an MDB, the Authorised Person must ensure the provider is an MDB of the type referenced in Rules 4.12.7 to 4.12.9, because CRM recognition is only allowed when the provider is one of the listed eligible entity types (including those MDBs). [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] In parallel, if the exposure being assessed is a CR Exposure in the MDB asset class, the Authorised Person must risk weight that exposure using the MDB asset class table (and the table is stated to operate subject to Rules 4.12.8 and 4.12.9). [#TGT:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c] So you combine an eligibility check (is the protection provider an MDB within the referenced rule set) with the required risk-weighting approach for MDB asset class exposures. [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] [#TGT:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c] The table assigns: 0% for Credit Quality Grade 1; 50% for Grades 2 and 3; 100% for Grades 4 and 5; 150% for Grade 6; and 50% for unrated exposures. [#TGT:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c]

question: When determining the Credit RWA of an Authorised Person, how must the securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures) component be calculated, including the treatment of SE Exposures that are instead required to be deducted from Capital Resources and the interaction with Early Amortisation Exposures?
gold_answer: In calculating Credit RWA, an Authorised Person must include a distinct SE Exposures component within the overall sum that makes up its Credit RWA. [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020] For that SE Exposures component, the Authorised Person must determine an Exposure value for each SE Exposure using the Exposure measurement methodology in Section 4.9 and taking into account any applicable CRM, then assign a Credit Quality Grade under Section 4.11 to identify the applicable risk weight. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] It must then compute the RWA amount for each SE Exposure using the formula RWA(SE) = SE × CRW, where SE is the Exposure value and CRW is the risk weight derived from the Credit Quality Grade. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] However, this per-exposure RWA calculation does not apply to SE Exposures that the Authorised Person is required to include as deductions from any component of Capital Resources. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] Finally, it must aggregate the RWA amounts for all SE Exposures (as calculated) and add them to the RWA amounts calculated under Rule 4.8.5 for Early Amortisation Exposures, and this combined result forms the SE Exposures element included in Credit RWA. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020]

question: If an Authorised Person is adding up its Credit RWA, what steps does it follow to work out the part for its securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures), and how does that part connect to Early Amortisation Exposures?
gold_answer: The Credit RWA of an Authorised Person is built by summing separate RWA components, one of which is the RWA for all its securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures). [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020] To calculate that SE Exposures component, the Authorised Person must first measure the Exposure value for each SE Exposure using the methodology in Section 4.9 and reflect any applicable CRM in that measurement. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] Next, it must assign a Credit Quality Grade for each SE Exposure under Section 4.11, because that grade is used to determine the applicable risk weight. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] It then calculates the risk-weighted amount for each SE Exposure using RWA(SE) = SE × CRW, where SE is the measured Exposure value and CRW is the risk weight determined from the Credit Quality Grade. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] SE Exposures that must be treated as deductions from any component of Capital Resources are not included in this per-exposure RWA calculation. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] Finally, it adds together the RWA amounts for all SE Exposures and then adds that total to the RWA amounts calculated under Rule 4.8.5 for Early Amortisation Exposures, and the result is the SE Exposures portion that feeds into Credit RWA. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020]

question: When calculating the Exposure value for on-balance sheet Derivatives (including written credit protection), how should the firm incorporate the potential future Exposure add-on, and how does that interact with the SA-CCR requirement to calculate RC and PFE differently for margined versus unmargined netting sets, including the cap on EAD for margined netting sets?
gold_answer: For on-balance sheet Derivatives (including written credit protection), the Exposure value is determined by combining two elements: the on-balance sheet value measured under IFRS and an additional amount for potential future Exposure that is calculated under the specified App 4 rules. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] When the derivative exposures are being assessed under SA-CCR, the firm must ensure that the replacement cost (RC) and potential future exposure (PFE) components are computed using different methods depending on whether the relevant netting set is margined or unmargined, so the PFE concept used for the add-on must be aligned to the appropriate margined/unmargined treatment. [#TGT:949c0178-dbd8-44f8-b832-e4c2a327c941] In addition, where the firm determines an exposure at default (EAD) for a margined netting set, it must apply the cap that limits that margined EAD to no more than the EAD that would result if the same netting set were calculated on an unmargined basis. [#TGT:949c0178-dbd8-44f8-b832-e4c2a327c941] Practically, this means the IFRS on-balance sheet value remains part of the Exposure value, while the potential future Exposure add-on is calculated per the referenced rules and then reflected consistently with the SA-CCR margined/unmargined netting set framework and the EAD cap. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:949c0178-dbd8-44f8-b832-e4c2a327c941]

question: If you’re working out Exposure value for on-balance sheet derivatives (including written credit protection), what pieces do you add together, and what extra SA-CCR step do you need to remember when the netting set is margined versus unmargined (including the cap)?
gold_answer: To calculate Exposure value for on-balance sheet Derivatives (including written credit protection), you add (1) the on-balance sheet value measured under IFRS and (2) an add-on for potential future Exposure that is calculated under the specified App 4 rules. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] When those derivative exposures are being handled under SA-CCR, you must also treat the replacement cost (RC) and potential future exposure (PFE) components differently depending on whether the netting set is margined or unmargined, so the potential future Exposure concept used for the add-on needs to be applied in a way that matches the correct margined/unmargined calculation basis. [#TGT:949c0178-dbd8-44f8-b832-e4c2a327c941] Finally, if you are calculating EAD for a margined netting set, you cannot let it exceed the EAD you would get for the same netting set if you calculated it as unmargined; the margined EAD must be capped at that unmargined amount. [#TGT:949c0178-dbd8-44f8-b832-e4c2a327c941] In short, the Exposure value build-up comes from IFRS plus a potential future Exposure add-on, and SA-CCR then dictates how RC/PFE are computed by margin status and imposes the margined EAD cap. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:949c0178-dbd8-44f8-b832-e4c2a327c941]

question: Where a RIE or MTF settles Digital Securities without engaging a RCH (for example, by using a DSF), what must be provided to the FSRA and what compliance standard applies to the DSF, and how does this interact with the statement that a Recognised Clearing House is not treated as breaching its Recognition Requirement solely because it cannot arrange settlement of a specific transaction?
gold_answer: If a RIE or MTF does not engage a RCH for Digital Securities settlement (for example, instead using a DSF), it must give the FSRA written details of the satisfactory arrangements it has made for settlement in that scenario. [#SRC:cf09ad93-5f69-4c7f-8239-0281b7659c5e] In addition, the settlement arrangements must be structured so that the DSF meets the requirements of MIR Rule 4.3.3, applying that rule as if references to a RCH were references to the DSF. [#SRC:cf09ad93-5f69-4c7f-8239-0281b7659c5e] This DSF-focused obligation is distinct from, and not replaced by, the position that a Recognised Clearing House is not regarded as failing to comply with the Recognition Requirement merely because it cannot arrange settlement for a particular transaction. [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e] Practically, the RIE or MTF cannot treat an inability to settle a specific transaction as eliminating the need to document and submit its non-RCH settlement arrangements to the FSRA, nor can it avoid ensuring the DSF is held to the MIR Rule 4.3.3 standard (with the RCH references adapted). [#SRC:cf09ad93-5f69-4c7f-8239-0281b7659c5e] The RCH statement instead clarifies how a RCH is assessed against its Recognition Requirement in a narrow circumstance, without changing the separate written-notification and DSF-compliance expectations when a RCH is not engaged. [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e]

question: If a RIE or MTF uses a DSF to settle Digital Securities instead of using a RCH, what does it need to send to the FSRA and what rule does the DSF have to meet—and does the fact that a Recognised Clearing House is not seen as failing just because it can’t settle one specific transaction change those DSF steps?
gold_answer: When a RIE or MTF settles Digital Securities without engaging a RCH (for example, by using a DSF), it must send the FSRA a written submission describing the details of the satisfactory settlement arrangements it has put in place for that non-RCH approach. [#SRC:cf09ad93-5f69-4c7f-8239-0281b7659c5e] It also needs to ensure the DSF used for settlement complies with MIR Rule 4.3.3, applying that rule on the basis that any mention of a RCH is treated as a mention of the DSF. [#SRC:cf09ad93-5f69-4c7f-8239-0281b7659c5e] The separate point about a Recognised Clearing House is that it is not considered to be breaching its Recognition Requirement only because it cannot arrange settlement for a particular transaction. [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e] That RCH-specific clarification does not remove or reduce the RIE/MTF’s obligations to (i) provide the FSRA with written details of its DSF-based arrangements and (ii) hold the DSF to the MIR Rule 4.3.3 standard (with the RCH references adapted). [#SRC:cf09ad93-5f69-4c7f-8239-0281b7659c5e] In other words, the RCH statement addresses how a RCH is judged in a narrow settlement-failure situation, while the DSF requirements govern what must be documented and ensured when a RCH is not used. [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e]

question: Where the Behaviour consists of disseminating information by any means that gives, or is likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity, what knowledge standard must be satisfied by the person who disseminates the information, and how is that standard framed (subjective vs objective) under the referenced test?
gold_answer: In this scenario, the knowledge element is satisfied if the person who disseminates the information either actually knew the information was false or misleading or, applying an objective standard, could reasonably be expected to have known it was false or misleading. [#TGT:69005f53-8e03-4e6f-b2eb-82b1fff946ef] This knowledge requirement is framed as a two-limb test: a subjective limb based on what the disseminator in fact knew, and an objective limb based on what the disseminator could reasonably be expected to know. [#SRC:c2310748-8c6b-4e04-95ef-fdccf6275cfc] The conduct context that triggers the need to apply this test is dissemination “by any means” of information that gives, or is likely to give, a false or misleading impression about the specified categories (a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset, or an Accepted Spot Commodity). [#TGT:69005f53-8e03-4e6f-b2eb-82b1fff946ef] When assessing whether the knowledge element is met for that dissemination, the applicable standard is therefore not limited to proof of actual awareness; it also captures cases where the person should have known, judged against what could reasonably be expected. [#SRC:c2310748-8c6b-4e04-95ef-fdccf6275cfc]

question: If someone shares information (in any way) that gives or is likely to give a false or misleading impression about a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset, or an Accepted Spot Commodity, what does it mean that they “knew or could reasonably be expected to have known” the information was false or misleading?
gold_answer: It means the knowledge condition can be met in two different ways for the person who disseminates the information: either they actually knew the information was false or misleading, or they did not know but could reasonably be expected to have known it was false or misleading. [#TGT:69005f53-8e03-4e6f-b2eb-82b1fff946ef] The first route is a subjective test focused on the person’s real awareness, while the second route is an objective test focused on what a person in that position could reasonably be expected to know. [#SRC:c2310748-8c6b-4e04-95ef-fdccf6275cfc] This two-part knowledge standard is applied specifically in the situation where the Behaviour is dissemination of information “by any means” that gives, or is likely to give, a false or misleading impression about the listed types of assets or instruments. [#TGT:69005f53-8e03-4e6f-b2eb-82b1fff946ef] So, for that kind of dissemination, it is not necessary to show only actual knowledge; it is also enough if the person is judged, on a reasonable-expectation basis, as someone who should have known the information was false or misleading. [#SRC:c2310748-8c6b-4e04-95ef-fdccf6275cfc]

question: Where an Authorised Person acts as both a Money Remitter and a Payment Account Provider, how must it determine the monthly payment volume base for its overall Variable Capital Requirement, and how is that base then applied to the Payment Account Provider Variable Capital Requirement rate bands?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that performs both Money Remitter and Payment Account Provider activities must first form a single monthly payment volume figure by aggregating (i.e., adding together) the monthly payment volumes attributable to those related activities, and it must use that combined figure as the basis for its overall Variable Capital Requirement calculation. [#SRC:b68ce9bd-b816-410b-92f6-32569f63a223] Once that combined monthly payment volume is determined, the Payment Account Provider Variable Capital Requirement is calculated by applying the tiered percentage rates to the combined volume in sequence: 2.5% applies to the first $10 million, 1% applies to the next $90 million, 0.5% applies to the next $150 million, and 0.25% applies to any remaining monthly payment volume above those tiers. [#TGT:7593338e-8695-47bb-ad6a-b441de562eb4] In practical terms, this means the firm does not calculate separate tiered amounts for each activity and then add the results; instead, it adds the monthly payment volumes for the two activities first and then runs the combined total through the tier structure to arrive at the Variable Capital Requirement amount. [#SRC:b68ce9bd-b816-410b-92f6-32569f63a223] [#TGT:7593338e-8695-47bb-ad6a-b441de562eb4]

question: If an Authorised Person is both a Money Remitter and a Payment Account Provider, do they add the two monthly payment volumes together first, and then use the Payment Account Provider percentage bands to work out the Variable Capital Requirement?
gold_answer: Yes. When an Authorised Person is acting as both a Money Remitter and a Payment Account Provider, it must combine the monthly payment volumes for those related activities by adding them together, and that combined monthly payment volume is used to calculate the overall Variable Capital Requirement. [#SRC:b68ce9bd-b816-410b-92f6-32569f63a223] After you have that single combined monthly payment volume, the Payment Account Provider calculation applies a stepped set of percentages to the total: 2.5% is applied to the first $10 million of monthly payment volume, 1% to the next $90 million, 0.5% to the next $150 million, and 0.25% to anything above those amounts. [#TGT:7593338e-8695-47bb-ad6a-b441de562eb4] This linkage matters because the combined-volume step determines which parts of the total fall into each band (for example, whether the total exceeds $10 million or $100 million), and the banded percentages then determine the resulting Variable Capital Requirement amount. [#SRC:b68ce9bd-b816-410b-92f6-32569f63a223] [#TGT:7593338e-8695-47bb-ad6a-b441de562eb4]

question: For a Petroleum Reporting Entity preparing a Summary of Reserves and Resources, how does the exemption for entities that file SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports annually with the SEC affect the obligation to include the MKT Form 12-1 table (including the “no earlier than one month prior” dating condition) that is otherwise required, and what is the resulting compliance position?
gold_answer: A Petroleum Reporting Entity that is required to file SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports annually with the SEC is exempt from complying with Rule 12.14.1. [#SRC:b249219a-57ec-4b15-be46-58475357c6c1] Separately, the rule governing the Summary of Reserves and Resources states that, subject to Rule 12.14.3, a Petroleum Reporting Entity must include a table in the form of MKT Form 12-1, and that table must be prepared as of a date no earlier than one month before the Summary of Reserves and Resources is disclosed. [#TGT:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] Read together, the SEC annual filer status removes the need to comply with Rule 12.14.1, but it does not, on these texts alone, remove the separate obligation to include the MKT Form 12-1 table with the specified timing condition when disclosing the Summary of Reserves and Resources. [#SRC:b249219a-57ec-4b15-be46-58475357c6c1] [#TGT:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] Accordingly, unless another provision (expressly referenced as Rule 12.14.3) changes the requirement, the entity should still include the MKT Form 12-1 table dated within the one-month window for the Summary of Reserves and Resources disclosure. [#TGT:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04]

question: If a Petroleum Reporting Entity files SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports every year, does it still need to put the MKT Form 12-1 table in its Summary of Reserves and Resources, and does the “dated no earlier than one month before disclosure” rule still matter?
gold_answer: If a Petroleum Reporting Entity is required to file SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports annually with the SEC, it is not required to comply with Rule 12.14.1. [#SRC:b249219a-57ec-4b15-be46-58475357c6c1] However, the Summary of Reserves and Resources requirement separately says that, subject to Rule 12.14.3, a Petroleum Reporting Entity must include a table in the form of MKT Form 12-1, and that table must be prepared as of a date that is no earlier than one month before the Summary of Reserves and Resources is disclosed. [#TGT:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] Putting these together, the SEC annual filing status only tells you that Rule 12.14.1 does not apply to that entity; it does not, by itself, remove the obligation described for the Summary of Reserves and Resources. [#SRC:b249219a-57ec-4b15-be46-58475357c6c1] [#TGT:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] So, based only on these passages, the entity should still plan to include the MKT Form 12-1 table and ensure the “no earlier than one month prior” dating condition is met when it discloses the Summary of Reserves and Resources, unless Rule 12.14.3 changes that outcome. [#TGT:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04]

question: Where a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a compliant disclosure of Non-Equivalent Estimates, under what conditions may a later disclosure omit the detailed items normally required for material Non-Equivalent Estimates (such as source/date, reliability, and the Competent Person statement), and what specific statement must still be included in the later disclosure?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity may omit the detailed information otherwise required for a disclosure of material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation only if the later disclosure is structured as a true follow-on to an earlier disclosure that already met those detailed requirements. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] To do so, the later disclosure must (i) point back to the earlier compliant disclosure, and (ii) include the Mining Reporting Entity’s confirmation that the earlier information still applies and that there is no new material information or data affecting either how the Non-Equivalent Estimates should be relied on/interpreted or the Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard. [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] Even when relying on that omission pathway, the later disclosure must still carry an at least equally prominent and proximate statement about the Non-Equivalent Estimates that addresses the same core matters as the required prominent/proximate warning for Non-Equivalent Estimates (i.e., that they are not reported under a Mining Reporting Standard, have not been sufficiently worked by a Competent Person for classification, and may never become reportable as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves). [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity is updating the market again about the same Non-Equivalent Estimates, when can it avoid repeating the long list of details (like the source and date, reliability, and what work is needed to verify them), and what must it say and do instead?
gold_answer: The Mining Reporting Entity can avoid repeating the full set of detailed disclosure items for material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation only when the new announcement is clearly tied to an earlier announcement that already included those items. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] In that situation, the later disclosure must refer readers to the earlier compliant disclosure and must include the Mining Reporting Entity’s confirmation that (a) the earlier information still applies and (b) there is no new material information or data that changes the reliability/interpretation of the Non-Equivalent Estimates or affects the Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard. [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] The later disclosure still needs a prominent and nearby warning statement about the Non-Equivalent Estimates, and it must be at least as prominent and proximate as the earlier required warning. [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] That warning must cover the key points that the estimates are Non-Equivalent Estimates not disclosed under a Mining Reporting Standard, that a Competent Person has not done enough work to classify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, and that it is uncertain they will ever be reportable as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves after further work. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]

question: For the non-prejudicing obligation that applies when an Employee discloses information regarding money laundering, which recipients qualify as an "other relevant body" beyond the Regulator, and how should a Relevant Person apply that classification when assessing whether its treatment of the Employee is prohibited?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person must treat the term “other relevant body” as covering specific types of authorities identified by the Regulator, and then ensure its conduct toward the Employee does not amount to prejudice when the disclosure is made to any of those recipients. [#TGT:c583c762-1740-4364-8f60-66ff7bd606e1] In applying this, the Relevant Person should recognize that the Regulator considers a “relevant body” to include the FIU, any other financial intelligence unit, the police, and an Abu Dhabi or Federal ministry or authority. [#SRC:bb51c6c0-5515-4091-9e92-a671edcc2bb4] Accordingly, if an Employee discloses information regarding money laundering to the Regulator, or instead to the FIU, another financial intelligence unit, the police, or an Abu Dhabi or Federal ministry or authority involved in preventing money laundering, the Relevant Person must ensure it does not prejudice that Employee because of the disclosure. [#TGT:c583c762-1740-4364-8f60-66ff7bd606e1] [#SRC:bb51c6c0-5515-4091-9e92-a671edcc2bb4] The practical compliance step is to map the disclosure recipient to this “relevant body” list and treat disclosures to any listed recipient the same as disclosures to the Regulator for purposes of the non-prejudicing requirement. [#TGT:c583c762-1740-4364-8f60-66ff7bd606e1] [#SRC:bb51c6c0-5515-4091-9e92-a671edcc2bb4]

question: If an Employee reports money laundering information, who counts as an “other relevant body” they can report to (besides the Regulator), and what does the Relevant Person have to do about how it treats that Employee?
gold_answer: The Relevant Person has to make sure it does not prejudice an Employee for sharing information about money laundering, whether the Employee reports to the Regulator or to another qualifying body involved in preventing money laundering. [#TGT:c583c762-1740-4364-8f60-66ff7bd606e1] To know which outside recipients qualify, the Regulator’s view is that a “relevant body” includes the FIU, any other financial intelligence unit, the police, and an Abu Dhabi or Federal ministry or authority. [#SRC:bb51c6c0-5515-4091-9e92-a671edcc2bb4] Putting these together, if the Employee makes the disclosure to any of those bodies (for example, the FIU or the police) rather than directly to the Regulator, the Relevant Person still must ensure the Employee is not prejudiced because of the disclosure. [#TGT:c583c762-1740-4364-8f60-66ff7bd606e1] [#SRC:bb51c6c0-5515-4091-9e92-a671edcc2bb4] In practice, the Relevant Person should treat disclosures to the listed bodies as within the same protected category as disclosures to the Regulator when deciding how it will act toward the Employee. [#TGT:c583c762-1740-4364-8f60-66ff7bd606e1] [#SRC:bb51c6c0-5515-4091-9e92-a671edcc2bb4]

question: During a Restriction Period, how should a Listed Entity comply with the prohibition on seeking or agreeing to release a holding lock, while also meeting the requirement to obtain and submit an undertaking (within two Business Days after issuing Restricted Securities) from an eligible third party to impose and maintain that holding lock?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity must both (i) ensure a holding lock is put in place through a qualifying third-party undertaking promptly after issuance of Restricted Securities and (ii) avoid any conduct during the Restriction Period that would undermine that lock, including requesting or agreeing to its release. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] [#SRC:344f9898-63f7-4bec-afdc-2c9984f6502d] The timing obligation applies within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities and requires the Listed Entity to obtain and submit to the Regulator an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD, or another entity the Regulator considers suitable. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] That undertaking must cover placing a holding lock on the Restricted Securities held by that entity and not releasing the lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] Separately, during a Restriction Period, a Listed Entity (as well as any Security Holder or Controller subject to a Restriction Agreement) must not ask for or agree to the release of a holding lock imposed in accordance with Rule 9.6.9. [#SRC:344f9898-63f7-4bec-afdc-2c9984f6502d] In practice, the Listed Entity should align its post-issuance undertaking process with the Restriction Period prohibition by ensuring any lock-release discussions are avoided unless the Regulator’s prior written consent is obtained under the undertaking framework. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] [#SRC:344f9898-63f7-4bec-afdc-2c9984f6502d]

question: If Restricted Securities have just been issued, what does a Listed Entity need to do within two Business Days to get a holding lock set up, and what must it avoid doing during the Restriction Period if it is subject to a Restriction Agreement?
gold_answer: The Listed Entity needs to take prompt steps to secure a third-party commitment to impose a holding lock and then ensure no one covered by the Restriction Agreement tries to get that lock lifted during the Restriction Period. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] [#SRC:344f9898-63f7-4bec-afdc-2c9984f6502d] Within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, the Listed Entity must obtain an undertaking and submit it to the Regulator. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] The undertaking must come from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD, or another entity the Regulator deems suitable, and it must require that entity to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities it holds. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] It must also state that the holding lock will not be released unless the Regulator gives prior written consent. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] At the same time, during a Restriction Period, a Listed Entity, Security Holder, or Controller that is subject to a Restriction Agreement must not ask for or agree to the release of a holding lock that was imposed in accordance with Rule 9.6.9. [#SRC:344f9898-63f7-4bec-afdc-2c9984f6502d] The practical result is that the Listed Entity should treat the lock as maintained unless the Regulator’s written consent is obtained and should avoid any request or agreement to release it during the Restriction Period. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] [#SRC:344f9898-63f7-4bec-afdc-2c9984f6502d]

question: When applying the 25% Tier 1 Large Exposures cap to positions in the Non Trading Book (and, where relevant, the Trading Book), what specific identification, measurement/aggregation, monitoring, and breach-notification steps must an Authorised Person perform so that the limit is assessed after eligible CRM is reflected?
gold_answer: To apply the 25% of Tier 1 Large Exposures cap to exposures in the Non Trading Book (and, where applicable, the Trading Book), an Authorised Person must operationalize a process that both quantifies exposures relative to Tier 1 and ensures the limit is assessed after eligible CRM is reflected. [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] This requires the Authorised Person to identify its Exposures and the relevant Counterparties (including whether any are Closely Related to each other or Connected to the Authorised Person), measure and establish the value of those Exposures, and determine each Exposure’s size as a proportion of Tier 1. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] Because the limit is applied after taking into account eligible CRM, the Authorised Person must also identify whether it has Exposures that are subject to the requirements of Section 4.13 (CRM) so the effect of eligible CRM can be reflected in the limit assessment. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] The Authorised Person must aggregate Exposures to the same Counterparty or to groups of Closely Related or Connected Counterparties, then monitor and control Exposures daily within the Large Exposures limits. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] If the 25% Tier 1 limit is breached, it must notify the Regulator immediately and confirm the breach in writing. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675]

question: If an Authorised Person is checking whether any exposure in the Non Trading Book (and, if relevant, the Trading Book) goes over 25% of Tier 1 after eligible CRM, what do they have to do each day and what must they do if they go over the limit?
gold_answer: When checking the 25% of Tier 1 Large Exposures cap for the Non Trading Book (and, where relevant, the Trading Book), the Authorised Person must ensure the calculation is done after the effect of any eligible CRM is taken into account. [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] To do that in a controlled way, the Authorised Person must first identify its Exposures and identify its Counterparties, including whether any Counterparties are Closely Related to each other or Connected to the Authorised Person. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] It must measure the size of its Exposures, establish their value, and determine each Exposure’s size as a proportion of Tier 1, which is the denominator used for the 25% cap. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] Because the limit is assessed after eligible CRM, it must also identify whether it has Exposures that are subject to the requirements of Section 4.13 (CRM), so the CRM effect can be reflected in the limit check. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] Each day, it must aggregate Exposures to the same Counterparty (or groups of Closely Related or Connected Counterparties) and monitor and control those Exposures within the Large Exposures limits. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] If the limit is breached, it must notify the Regulator immediately and then confirm the breach in writing. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675]

question: For unauthorised Third Party Transactions, when is a Third Party Provider required to provide a refund, and how does the position change if the Third Party Provider has reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behaviour by the Customer?
gold_answer: For an unauthorised (or incorrectly executed) Third Party Transaction, the Third Party Provider is required to provide a refund under Rule 20.12.1 promptly: it must do so as soon as practicable and, at the latest, by the end of the day after the day it confirms the transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed. [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] This timing obligation is framed around the point of confirmation, so the operational trigger for the deadline is the Third Party Provider’s confirmation that the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed. [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] However, the specific requirement to provide a refund within the timeframe prescribed in Rule 20.12.2 is disapplied where the Third Party Provider has reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behaviour by the Customer. [#SRC:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012] In practice, this means that even though refunds are generally expected quickly once unauthorised status is confirmed, the Third Party Provider is not bound by the Rule 20.12.2 timeframe in the fraud-suspicion scenario described. [#SRC:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012] The analysis therefore turns on (i) confirmation of unauthorised/incorrect execution for the standard deadline, and (ii) whether there are reasonable grounds to suspect Customer fraud for the Rule 20.12.2 timing carve-out. [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] [#SRC:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012]

question: If a Third Party Provider confirms a Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, how quickly must it refund, and what happens to the refund timing rule if it reasonably suspects the Customer is acting fraudulently?
gold_answer: Once the Third Party Provider has confirmed that a Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, it must provide a refund under Rule 20.12.1 as soon as practicable and no later than the end of the next day (the day after the confirmation day). [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] The key timing point is the Third Party Provider’s confirmation, because the “next-day” deadline is measured from that day. [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] There is also a specific exception tied to suspected fraud: the requirement to provide a refund within the timeframe set by Rule 20.12.2 does not apply if the Third Party Provider has reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behaviour by the Customer. [#SRC:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012] Put together, the general rule is a fast refund once unauthorised/incorrect execution is confirmed, but the Third Party Provider is not required to follow the Rule 20.12.2 timeframe when it has reasonable grounds for that fraud suspicion. [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] [#SRC:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012] This means your compliance check should identify (1) the confirmation date for the unauthorised/incorrect execution finding and (2) whether the fraud-suspicion condition is met, because that condition changes whether the Rule 20.12.2 timing requirement applies. [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] [#SRC:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012]

question: Where an Exposure is only partially guaranteed by an Authorised Person's Parent Financial Institution and the guaranteed portion would attract a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, how should the Authorised Person determine what portion (if any) can be excluded from the Large Exposure limits, and what additional parental-guarantee conditions and ongoing confirmations/notifications apply if the Authorised Person relies on the parental-guarantee treatment to exclude the Exposure?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person should treat the exemption as limited to the guaranteed slice of the Exposure: if the Exposure is only partly covered by a guarantee from the Authorised Person's Parent Financial Institution and that covered slice would receive a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, only the portion subject to the guarantee is exempt from the Large Exposure limit in Rule 4.15.5. [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3] If the Authorised Person instead seeks to exclude an Exposure from the Large Exposure limits under the parental-guarantee treatment, it may do so only within Rules 4.15.5 to 4.15.7 and only where the Parent either commits (via a legally binding agreement) to increase Tier 1 promptly and on demand to fully reverse loss effects or to ensure compliance with the Capital Requirement, or where the Parent (or regulated Group member) guarantees the Exposure to a Counterparty (or group of Closely Related Counterparties) that are not Connected to the Authorised Person and the specified conditions are met. [#TGT:032faf55-93b1-4f6a-ab8f-56eea4f82cff] Ongoing items include obtaining Home State Regulator confirmation, providing annual confirmation on enforceability, and notifying the Regulator at the 200%, 400% and 600% Tier 1 thresholds, with an overall Large Exposure limit of 800%. [#TGT:032faf55-93b1-4f6a-ab8f-56eea4f82cff]

question: If an Exposure is partly covered by a guarantee from an Authorised Person's Parent Financial Institution, what part of the Exposure can be treated as exempt from the Large Exposure limit, and what extra checks and follow-up actions are needed if the Authorised Person wants to exclude the Exposure using the parental-guarantee rules (including any annual confirmations and Regulator notifications)?
gold_answer: If the Exposure is only partially guaranteed by the Authorised Person's Parent Financial Institution and the guaranteed part would get a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, the exemption from the Large Exposure limit in Rule 4.15.5 applies only to the part that is actually covered by the guarantee, not to the whole Exposure. [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3] If the Authorised Person wants to exclude an Exposure from the Large Exposure limits by relying on the parental-guarantee treatment, it may do so for the limits in Rules 4.15.5 to 4.15.7 only when the Parent either (a) has a legally binding commitment to increase Tier 1 promptly and on demand to fully offset losses from that Exposure or to ensure the Authorised Person meets its Capital Requirement, or (b) provides a guarantee (itself or via a regulated Group member) to a Counterparty or group of Closely Related Counterparties that are not Connected to the Authorised Person, and the listed conditions are satisfied (including CRM alignment, bank regulatory standards acceptable to the Regulator, and credit assessment at Credit Quality Grade 1 or 2). [#TGT:032faf55-93b1-4f6a-ab8f-56eea4f82cff] The Authorised Person must also obtain Home State Regulator confirmation, provide an annual confirmation that enforceability has not changed, and notify the Regulator when the guarantees reach 200%, 400% and 600% of Tier 1, with an overall Large Exposure limit of 800%. [#TGT:032faf55-93b1-4f6a-ab8f-56eea4f82cff]

question: When designing an arrangement to make information public, what specific features must be present to treat the information as “made public” and “machine-readable,” and what operational controls and commercial access conditions must the arrangement also include?
gold_answer: An arrangement should be structured so the information qualifies as “made public” and meets “machine-readable” expectations, while also embedding reliability controls and fair public access terms. To be treated as made public, the information must be accessible through automated electronic means in a machine-readable manner, use technology that supports consolidation and commercially viable use, and be provided with instructions explaining how users can access it. [#SRC:bd13815d-1605-4be7-a0e5-e56cac1c6b24] In addition, where “machine-readable” criteria are relevant, the data should be in a computer-readable physical form and placed on a computer storage device in a location and format that are known in advance to the party seeking access. [#SRC:bd13815d-1605-4be7-a0e5-e56cac1c6b24] Operationally, the arrangement must take all reasonable steps to ensure the published information is reliable, continuously monitored for errors, and corrected promptly when errors are found. [#TGT:2a6804eb-793b-44fd-9895-a7d9d195c64e] It must also facilitate consolidation with similar data from other sources (aligning with the consolidation-focused technology expectation) and make the information available on a non-discriminatory commercial basis at a reasonable cost. [#TGT:2a6804eb-793b-44fd-9895-a7d9d195c64e] Finally, publishing only on a non-machine-readable website would not satisfy the relevant publication requirement. [#SRC:bd13815d-1605-4be7-a0e5-e56cac1c6b24]

question: If a firm wants to publish information to the public, what does it need to do so the data counts as public and machine-readable, and what extra steps are required to keep the data accurate and available fairly (including cost)?
gold_answer: To have the information treated as properly made public, the arrangement needs to deliver the data in a machine-readable way through automated electronic access, use technology that supports consolidating the data and enables commercially viable use, and include instructions telling users how to access it. [#SRC:bd13815d-1605-4be7-a0e5-e56cac1c6b24] If the arrangement is being assessed against machine-readable criteria, the data should be designed to be read by a computer and stored so that both the location and the format are known in advance to the party that wants to access it. [#SRC:bd13815d-1605-4be7-a0e5-e56cac1c6b24] Beyond the format and access method, the arrangement must include all reasonable steps to ensure the published information is reliable, is monitored continuously for errors, and is corrected as soon as errors are detected. [#TGT:2a6804eb-793b-44fd-9895-a7d9d195c64e] It also needs to support consolidation with similar data from other sources and make the information available to the public on a non-discriminatory commercial basis at a reasonable cost. [#TGT:2a6804eb-793b-44fd-9895-a7d9d195c64e] Publishing only on a non-machine-readable website would not meet the publication requirement. [#SRC:bd13815d-1605-4be7-a0e5-e56cac1c6b24]

question: For an Authorised Person that is a Payment Account Provider and has a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services, how must it determine its Capital Requirement, and how is the Variable Capital Requirement component calculated using monthly payment volume tiers?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services that undertakes the activity of a Payment Account Provider must set its Capital Requirement by taking the highest applicable amount under the capital-calculation hierarchy for its activities, which includes comparing the applicable Base Capital Requirement to the Payment Account Provider’s Variable Capital Requirement. [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304] For the Payment Account Provider activity specifically, the Variable Capital Requirement is determined by applying a tiered percentage schedule to monthly payment volume and summing the results across tiers. [#TGT:7593338e-8695-47bb-ad6a-b441de562eb4] In practice, this means the Payment Account Provider’s Variable Capital Requirement is the total of: 2.5% applied to the first $10 million of monthly payment volume, plus 1% applied to the next $90 million, plus 0.5% applied to the next $150 million, plus 0.25% applied to any remaining monthly payment volume above those tiers. [#TGT:7593338e-8695-47bb-ad6a-b441de562eb4] The resulting Variable Capital Requirement is then used as the Payment Account Provider component in the overall “highest of” comparison that determines the Capital Requirement for that activity (alongside the applicable Base Capital Requirement). [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304]

question: If an Authorised Person is a Payment Account Provider under Providing Money Services, what numbers does it compare to set its Capital Requirement, and how do you work out the Variable Capital Requirement from monthly payment volume?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person has a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services and it undertakes the activity of a Payment Account Provider, it must determine the Capital Requirement for that activity by using the “highest of” approach specified for money services activities, which includes comparing the applicable Base Capital Requirement against the Variable Capital Requirement for a Payment Account Provider. [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304] The Variable Capital Requirement for a Payment Account Provider is not a single flat rate; it is calculated by adding together amounts produced by applying different percentages to different bands of monthly payment volume. [#TGT:7593338e-8695-47bb-ad6a-b441de562eb4] To calculate that Variable Capital Requirement, apply 2.5% to the first $10 million of monthly payment volume, then apply 1% to the next $90 million, then apply 0.5% to the next $150 million, and finally apply 0.25% to any monthly payment volume above those tiers, and sum all those tier results. [#TGT:7593338e-8695-47bb-ad6a-b441de562eb4] Once you have that summed Variable Capital Requirement, it is the Payment Account Provider-specific figure used in the overall comparison that sets the Capital Requirement as the highest relevant amount for the activity (including the applicable Base Capital Requirement). [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304]

question: When calculating CET1 Capital deductions for holdings of CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities, how should an Authorised Person determine whether the holding is treated as a “significant investment” (thereby falling under the deduction category for significant investments rather than the category for non-significant investments), and what types of deductions are required to be taken from CET1 Capital in that calculation?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must first classify its holdings of CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities by determining whether the holding constitutes a “significant investment,” because the CET1 deduction category differs depending on that classification. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] A holding is treated as a significant investment if any of the specified conditions are met: the Authorised Person owns more than 10% of the CET1 Capital instruments issued by the Relevant Entity; or the Authorised Person has Close Links with the entity and owns its CET1 Capital instruments; or the Authorised Person owns the entity’s CET1 Capital instruments and the entity is not included in consolidation under Chapter 8 but is included in the same accounting consolidation as the Authorised Person for IFRS financial reporting. [#SRC:c9f19d0b-d036-4cfe-88ba-7e2528a70c11] Once classified, the Authorised Person must deduct from the calculation of its CET1 Capital the applicable amount of direct and indirect holdings in Relevant Entities where it does not have a significant investment, and separately the applicable amount of direct and indirect holdings in Relevant Entities where it does have a significant investment. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] In addition, the CET1 deduction calculation includes other specified items such as current-year losses, IFRS-defined goodwill and other intangible assets, and deferred tax assets that rely on future profitability. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]

question: If an Authorised Person owns CET1 Capital instruments issued by a Relevant Entity, what facts make that ownership a “significant investment,” and how does that decision change which CET1 deduction bucket the holding goes into?
gold_answer: To place a holding into the correct CET1 deduction bucket, an Authorised Person must decide whether its holding in a Relevant Entity is a “significant investment,” because the CET1 rules distinguish between deductions for holdings where the Authorised Person has a significant investment and holdings where it does not. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] The holding is a significant investment if any one of these conditions applies: the Authorised Person owns more than 10% of the CET1 Capital instruments issued by the Relevant Entity; or the Authorised Person has Close Links with the entity and owns its CET1 Capital instruments; or the Authorised Person owns the entity’s CET1 Capital instruments and, while the entity is not consolidated under Chapter 8, it is included in the same IFRS accounting consolidation as the Authorised Person for financial reporting. [#SRC:c9f19d0b-d036-4cfe-88ba-7e2528a70c11] If the holding meets one of those tests, the Authorised Person must treat it as a holding where it has a significant investment and deduct the applicable amount under the significant-investment category. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] If none of the tests are met, the holding falls into the non-significant-investment category and the applicable amount must be deducted under that separate category. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]

question: Where MIR, Chapter 5 requirements are triggered for an Authorised Person Operating a Recognised Investment Exchange, Multilateral Trading Facility or an Organised Trading Facility in relation to Accepted Spot Commodities (in the circumstances listed in the specified Items), how should the MIR terms “Recognised Body/Bodies” and “Financial Instrument(s)” be applied for the purposes of Rule 22.7.4 when determining what the Authorised Person must comply with?
gold_answer: In this scenario, the compliance obligation is that an Authorised Person operating a Recognised Investment Exchange, Multilateral Trading Facility or an Organised Trading Facility in relation to Accepted Spot Commodities must follow the MIR, Chapter 5 requirements that are expressly identified: Rules 5.1–5.3 and Rule 5.4.1, but only in the circumstances tied to the listed Items (including Items 19, 20, 24(a) and (b), 27, 28, 32, 33, 35, 37–39, 41, 43, 45–50, 52–55, and 57–62). [#TGT:3fec174f-e21d-4aa0-b244-0034deb32874] For the purposes of Rule 22.7.4, when reading MIR in order to apply those Chapter 5 requirements to this Accepted Spot Commodities context, the defined cross-reading applies: any MIR reference to “Recognised Body” or “Recognised Bodies” must be treated as a reference to “Authorised Person.” [#SRC:6f13bd3c-1af7-410b-8b34-a51c343db5a3] Likewise, any MIR reference to “Financial Instrument” or “Financial Instruments” must be treated as a reference to “Accepted Spot Commodity” or “Accepted Spot Commodities,” as applicable. [#SRC:6f13bd3c-1af7-410b-8b34-a51c343db5a3] Accordingly, the Authorised Person should apply the Chapter 5 obligations in the specified Item circumstances using these substitutions when interpreting MIR for Rule 22.7.4 purposes. [#TGT:3fec174f-e21d-4aa0-b244-0034deb32874] [#SRC:6f13bd3c-1af7-410b-8b34-a51c343db5a3]

question: If an Authorised Person runs a Recognised Investment Exchange, Multilateral Trading Facility or an Organised Trading Facility for Accepted Spot Commodities, which MIR Chapter 5 rules do they have to follow in the listed Item situations, and how do the MIR words “Recognised Body” and “Financial Instrument” get read for Rule 22.7.4?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person in this position must comply with the MIR, Chapter 5 requirements that are specifically called out: Rules 5.1–5.3 and Rule 5.4.1, and this duty applies only in the circumstances identified in the enumerated Items (including Items 19, 20, 24(a) and (b), 27, 28, 32, 33, 35, 37, 38, 39, 41, 43, 45, 46, 47, 48, 49, 50, 52, 53, 54, 55, 57, 58, 59, 60, 61 and 62). [#TGT:3fec174f-e21d-4aa0-b244-0034deb32874] When interpreting MIR for the purposes of Rule 22.7.4 in this Accepted Spot Commodities context, you must also apply the required term substitutions: wherever MIR uses “Recognised Body” or “Recognised Bodies,” it is to be understood as “Authorised Person.” [#SRC:6f13bd3c-1af7-410b-8b34-a51c343db5a3] Similarly, wherever MIR uses “Financial Instrument” or “Financial Instruments,” it is to be understood as “Accepted Spot Commodity” or “Accepted Spot Commodities,” as appropriate. [#SRC:6f13bd3c-1af7-410b-8b34-a51c343db5a3] Putting these together, the Authorised Person applies the specified Chapter 5 rules in the listed Item situations, while reading those two MIR terms through the Rule 22.7.4 substitutions. [#TGT:3fec174f-e21d-4aa0-b244-0034deb32874] [#SRC:6f13bd3c-1af7-410b-8b34-a51c343db5a3]

question: When the Regulator acts on its own initiative against an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission, what specific circumstances can trigger use of the power, and what range of outcomes (including partial changes versus full cancellation) may the Regulator impose on the Financial Services Permission?
gold_answer: The Regulator may act on its own initiative in relation to an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission when it appears that one or more specified triggering circumstances apply, and it may respond either by varying the permission (including limited changes to Regulated Activities) or by cancelling it entirely. [#SRC:cd2e3201-9c8d-41db-ae9e-c56f0e181dcb] Triggering circumstances include where the Authorised Person is failing or likely to fail to satisfy the Threshold Condition Rules, has contravened these Regulations or Rules made under them, has not carried on a relevant Regulated Activity for at least 12 months, or where exercising the power is desirable to further one or more of the Regulator’s objectives. [#TGT:702ea9bb-da70-4ea7-91e8-a693eb99447b] If the Regulator proceeds, it may cancel the Financial Services Permission to carry on one or more Regulated Activities, and in that context it may instead (or additionally) vary the Financial Services Permission by adding or removing a Regulated Activity, or by changing the description of a Regulated Activity provided the change does not widen that description. [#SRC:cd2e3201-9c8d-41db-ae9e-c56f0e181dcb] The Regulator may also vary the Financial Services Permission by including, in the permission as varied, any provision that could be included if a new Financial Services Permission were being sought, and it retains the option to cancel the permission entirely. [#SRC:cd2e3201-9c8d-41db-ae9e-c56f0e181dcb]

question: If an Authorised Person hasn’t carried on a Regulated Activity for at least 12 months, what can the Regulator do to the Financial Services Permission on its own initiative, and what limits apply if it changes the description of a Regulated Activity?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission has failed, during a period of at least 12 months, to carry on a Regulated Activity covered by that permission, the Regulator may use its power in relation to that person. [#TGT:702ea9bb-da70-4ea7-91e8-a693eb99447b] Acting on its own initiative, the Regulator may respond by cancelling the Financial Services Permission to carry on one or more Regulated Activities, or by cancelling the permission entirely. [#SRC:cd2e3201-9c8d-41db-ae9e-c56f0e181dcb] Instead of (or alongside) cancellation, the Regulator may vary the Financial Services Permission by adding a Regulated Activity, removing a Regulated Activity, or changing the description of a Regulated Activity, but any change to the description must not widen that description. [#SRC:cd2e3201-9c8d-41db-ae9e-c56f0e181dcb] In addition, when varying the permission, the Regulator may include in the permission as varied any provision that could be included if a new Financial Services Permission were being sought. [#SRC:cd2e3201-9c8d-41db-ae9e-c56f0e181dcb] This means the 12‑month inactivity trigger can lead to either targeted adjustments to the permission or full removal of permission, depending on the Regulator’s chosen outcome. [#TGT:702ea9bb-da70-4ea7-91e8-a693eb99447b]

question: When an Authorised Person (and its participants) selects a delivery and/or storage facility for Accepted Spot Commodities from an appropriate jurisdiction outside the ADGM, what specific facility-level conditions must be satisfied to meet the Rule 22.4.2 standard referenced by the location restriction?
