gold_answer: An Authorised Person and its participants may use a delivery and/or storage facility for Accepted Spot Commodities outside the ADGM only if the jurisdiction is “appropriate” because the facility can meet the requirements of Rule 22.4.2, rather than merely being located outside the ADGM. [#TGT:4230a066-37c4-4630-bb93-d9a0ed5bc81b] For a facility operating from outside ADGM, Rule 22.4.2 requires that it operate under rules and regulations equivalent to those applying in the Abu Dhabi Global Market. [#SRC:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5] In addition, the facility must continuously comply with all applicable laws in the relevant jurisdiction or elsewhere, including port conditions, customs requirements, anticorruption laws, and taxation requirements. [#SRC:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5] The facility must also adhere to appropriate international standards for storage and delivery mechanisms (including IOSCO Good and Sound Practices) and maintain OHSAS 18001 Health & Safety Management (or equivalent) certification standards. [#SRC:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5] Finally, it must have appropriate audit and control arrangements for inventories, deliveries, and physical infrastructure, and appropriate insurance covering operational, security, fraud, natural disasters, and other applicable risks. [#SRC:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5]

question: If an Authorised Person wants to use a delivery and/or storage facility for Accepted Spot Commodities that is not in the ADGM, what does the facility need to have or follow so the place counts as an “appropriate jurisdiction” under the rule?
gold_answer: A facility outside the ADGM can only be used for Accepted Spot Commodities if it is in an “appropriate jurisdiction” in the sense that the facility can meet the Rule 22.4.2 requirements; otherwise, the Authorised Person and its participants are limited to facilities within the ADGM. [#TGT:4230a066-37c4-4630-bb93-d9a0ed5bc81b] For an outside-ADGM facility, those requirements include operating under rules and regulations equivalent to those applying in the Abu Dhabi Global Market. [#SRC:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5] The facility must also comply at all times with applicable laws, specifically including local port conditions, customs requirements, anticorruption laws, and taxation requirements (and any other applicable rules). [#SRC:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5] It must follow appropriate international standards for storage and delivery mechanisms (including IOSCO Good and Sound Practices) and hold OHSAS 18001 Health & Safety Management or equivalent certification standards. [#SRC:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5] It also needs suitable audit/control arrangements for inventories, deliveries, and physical infrastructure, plus insurance that covers operational, security, fraud, natural disasters, and other relevant risks. [#SRC:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5]

question: Where an Applicant for a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services will conduct both of the activities referenced in Rule 3.9.1, how should the Applicant determine the application fee payable to the Regulator, given the activity-based fee table for Currency exchange or Money Remittance and for Payment Services?
gold_answer: If the Applicant will conduct both of the activities referenced in Rule 3.9.1, the application fee payable to the Regulator is $25,000. [#SRC:de0a3426-7cb3-4c24-8d47-e3d9292e2019] This conclusion is reached by applying the specific rule for Applicants conducting both Rule 3.9.1 activities, which sets a single application fee amount for that combined scope. [#SRC:de0a3426-7cb3-4c24-8d47-e3d9292e2019] The activity-based table otherwise differentiates fees depending on which Providing Money Services activity the Applicant will carry on, listing $15,000 for “Currency exchange or Money Remittance” and $25,000 for “Payment Services.” [#TGT:6ba8367f-82df-4c72-a188-980f7efc3b1b] In the combined-activities scenario, the Applicant should not attempt to derive a different amount by selecting only one row of the table; instead, the combined-activities condition triggers the $25,000 fee stated for Applicants conducting both Rule 3.9.1 activities. [#SRC:de0a3426-7cb3-4c24-8d47-e3d9292e2019] The payment is made by the Applicant to the Regulator as an application fee for the Financial Services Permission for Providing Money Services. [#SRC:de0a3426-7cb3-4c24-8d47-e3d9292e2019] [#TGT:6ba8367f-82df-4c72-a188-980f7efc3b1b]

question: If an Applicant is applying for permission to provide money services and plans to do both activities mentioned in Rule 3.9.1, what application fee do they pay, and how does that relate to the table that lists fees for “Currency exchange or Money Remittance” and “Payment Services”?
gold_answer: An Applicant that plans to conduct both of the activities mentioned in Rule 3.9.1 pays an application fee of $25,000 to the Regulator. [#SRC:de0a3426-7cb3-4c24-8d47-e3d9292e2019] This is a specific fee outcome tied to the Applicant’s scope of activities (i.e., doing both Rule 3.9.1 activities) rather than choosing a fee solely by matching a single activity label. [#SRC:de0a3426-7cb3-4c24-8d47-e3d9292e2019] The table for Providing Money Services shows that the fee depends on the activity the Applicant will carry on, with $15,000 for “Currency exchange or Money Remittance” and $25,000 for “Payment Services.” [#TGT:6ba8367f-82df-4c72-a188-980f7efc3b1b] When the Applicant’s plan is broader—covering both Rule 3.9.1 activities—the combined-activities rule sets the payable amount at $25,000, aligning with the higher figure shown in the table but justified by the “both activities” condition. [#SRC:de0a3426-7cb3-4c24-8d47-e3d9292e2019] The payment is made as an application fee to the Regulator in connection with the Financial Services Permission application for the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services. [#SRC:de0a3426-7cb3-4c24-8d47-e3d9292e2019] [#TGT:6ba8367f-82df-4c72-a188-980f7efc3b1b]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure that includes a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets, how do the preparation requirements interact with the scope of materials covered and the expectation to use a specific table format for consistency?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure that contains statements about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets must be prepared in accordance with both a Mining Reporting Standard and the chapter setting the disclosure requirements. [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d] In applying that preparation obligation, the scope of covered disclosures is broad: the relevant rule applies to all disclosures made or required under the Rules that include such statements, including (among other examples) a Prospectus, Exempt Offer document, bidder’s and target’s statements, annual reports, financial statements, technical papers, presentations, and website content and disclosures. [#SRC:96612327-1f00-4faf-abc6-2c914cc73738] To support consistency across those various disclosure channels, Issuers and Mining Reporting Entities are expected to be mindful of the table format for disclosing Ore Reserves and Mineral Resources set out in MKT Form-11-1. [#SRC:96612327-1f00-4faf-abc6-2c914cc73738] Practically, this means the entity should (i) ensure the disclosure is prepared under the specified standard and chapter framework, and (ii) align the presentation of Ore Reserves and Mineral Resources with the referenced table format when those topics are included, so that disclosures remain consistent across documents and media. [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d] [#SRC:96612327-1f00-4faf-abc6-2c914cc73738]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity puts Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves information on its website or in a presentation, what does it have to prepare it under, and what format guidance should it keep in mind so the information stays consistent across different documents?
gold_answer: If a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure that includes statements about Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves (or the other listed mining categories), it must prepare that disclosure in line with a Mining Reporting Standard and also in line with the chapter that sets the disclosure requirements. [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d] The rule’s coverage is not limited to formal offering documents; it extends to all disclosures made or required under the Rules that include these kinds of statements, and it explicitly includes presentations and website content and disclosures (as well as items like annual reports, financial statements, technical papers, and a Prospectus). [#SRC:96612327-1f00-4faf-abc6-2c914cc73738] To keep disclosures consistent across those different channels, Issuers and Mining Reporting Entities should be mindful of the table format for disclosing Ore Reserves and Mineral Resources that is set out in MKT Form-11-1. [#SRC:96612327-1f00-4faf-abc6-2c914cc73738] In other words, the preparation framework comes from the Mining Reporting Standard plus the chapter, while the consistency cue for how to present Ore Reserves and Mineral Resources comes from the referenced table format. [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d] [#SRC:96612327-1f00-4faf-abc6-2c914cc73738]

question: For an Issuer making an Exempt Offer of a Digital Security, how do the requirements that the Digital Security be deemed a Security under Section 58(2)(b) of FSMR and the Regulator’s power to deem an investment to be a Security interact, and does the Issuer need FSRA approval for the Exempt Offer document itself?
gold_answer: An Issuer making an Exempt Offer of a Digital Security must still ensure that the Digital Security is treated as a Security under Section 58(2)(b) of FSMR, even though the Exempt Offer is exempt in other respects. [#SRC:6a0e8ba4-de85-4c15-9077-73f73de9d727] The Regulator has an express power, by written notice, to deem an investment that is not otherwise a Security to be a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and the Rules made under them, and it may attach terms and conditions it considers appropriate. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] Read together, this means the “deemed Security” status relevant to an Exempt Offer can be achieved through the deeming mechanism contemplated in the framework, while still operating within the Exempt Offer context described for Digital Securities. [#SRC:6a0e8ba4-de85-4c15-9077-73f73de9d727] [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] Separately, the Issuer of the Exempt Offer document is not required to obtain FSRA approval for the Exempt Offer document itself. [#SRC:6a0e8ba4-de85-4c15-9077-73f73de9d727] Nothing in the deeming power text states that such a deeming decision requires FSRA approval of the Exempt Offer document; instead, it focuses on the Regulator’s ability to deem and to set any associated terms and conditions by written notice. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]

question: If an Issuer is doing an Exempt Offer of a Digital Security, do they still need the Digital Security to count as a Security, and how could the Regulator’s written notice power help with that? Also, do they need FSRA approval for the Exempt Offer document?
gold_answer: Yes. Even when the offer is an Exempt Offer, the Issuer still has to have the Digital Security treated as a Security under Section 58(2)(b) of FSMR. [#SRC:6a0e8ba4-de85-4c15-9077-73f73de9d727] The Regulator can support that outcome because it may, by written notice, deem an investment that is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and the Rules made under them, and it can impose any terms and conditions it considers appropriate. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] Linking the two points: in an Exempt Offer context where the Digital Security still needs “deemed Security” status, the Regulator’s deeming power is the mechanism described that can convert a non-Security investment into a Security for the relevant regulatory purposes. [#SRC:6a0e8ba4-de85-4c15-9077-73f73de9d727] [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] On the document side, the Issuer of the Exempt Offer document does not need to obtain FSRA approval for the Exempt Offer document itself. [#SRC:6a0e8ba4-de85-4c15-9077-73f73de9d727] The Regulator’s notice power is framed as excluding requirements or deeming status, not as an approval requirement for the Exempt Offer document. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]

question: Where a Payment Service Provider proposes to change the exchange rate used in Payment Transactions under a Framework Contract, what implementation standard applies to that exchange-rate change and what is the minimum advance notice period for providing the change to the Payment Service User before it takes effect?
gold_answer: A proposed change to the exchange rate used in Payment Transactions must be applied in a way that is neutral and does not collectively disadvantage Payment Service Users, and it must also be communicated to the Payment Service User at least two months before the change takes effect. [#TGT:e696d18d-c269-44cd-907e-9701efbb42dc] [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] This conclusion applies when the Payment Service Provider is making a change that falls within proposed changes to the existing terms of the Framework Contract or to the information that must be provided under Rule 19.2.1, because those categories trigger the advance-provision requirement. [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] In practice, the Payment Service Provider should (i) ensure the method for implementing and calculating the revised exchange rate is neutral and non-discriminatory in its collective effect on Payment Service Users, and (ii) provide the proposed change to the Payment Service User no later than two months before the effective date stated for the change. [#TGT:e696d18d-c269-44cd-907e-9701efbb42dc] [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] The notice obligation is expressly stated as being subject to Rule 19.2.7, so the Payment Service Provider must apply that stated qualification when determining whether and how the two-month timing applies in the specific case. [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5]

question: If the exchange rate used in Payment Transactions is going to change, what does “neutral and non-discriminatory” mean for how it’s applied, and how long before the change starts does the Payment Service Provider have to tell the Payment Service User?
gold_answer: When the exchange rate used in Payment Transactions is changed, the change must be put into effect and worked out in a neutral way that does not collectively discriminate against Payment Service Users. [#TGT:e696d18d-c269-44cd-907e-9701efbb42dc] If that exchange-rate change is part of a proposed change to the existing terms of the Framework Contract or to the information specified in Rule 19.2.1, the Payment Service Provider must provide the proposed change to the Payment Service User no later than two months before the date it will take effect. [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] Putting these together means the Payment Service Provider has two linked duties: (1) the content/operation of the exchange-rate change must be neutral and non-discriminatory in its collective impact on Payment Service Users, and (2) the Payment Service User must receive the proposed change at least two months in advance of the effective date. [#TGT:e696d18d-c269-44cd-907e-9701efbb42dc] [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] The two-month timing is expressly stated to be subject to Rule 19.2.7, so the Payment Service Provider must take that stated condition into account when applying the notice rule. [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5]

question: Where a contravention is committed by one person, how does liability attach to another person who is Knowingly Concerned, and how do the consequences differ when the contravention is of FSMR or Rules versus a contravention of these Regulations?
gold_answer: If a contravention is committed by one person and another person is Knowingly Concerned in that contravention, both texts treat the involvement as a basis for liability for both individuals, but they describe the legal framing slightly differently depending on the instrument. [#SRC:a2dd84dd-1b01-465d-808a-b2f653dd4e93] [#TGT:5e4bc632-0693-4b1c-a3b9-ef28fb2a8441] For contraventions of FSMR or Rules, the SOURCE explains that when one person is Knowingly Concerned in another person’s contravention, section 220 of FSMR provides that both persons may be held liable for committing a contravention. [#SRC:a2dd84dd-1b01-465d-808a-b2f653dd4e93] For contraventions of these Regulations, the TARGET states that the person who is Knowingly Concerned, as well as the person who committed the underlying contravention, commits the contravention and is liable to be proceeded against and dealt with accordingly. [#TGT:5e4bc632-0693-4b1c-a3b9-ef28fb2a8441] In practical compliance terms, the shared trigger is the “Knowingly Concerned” involvement in another’s contravention, while the linkage across the two passages is that the SOURCE ties liability to section 220 of FSMR for FSMR/Rules contraventions, whereas the TARGET expressly describes exposure to being proceeded against for contraventions of these Regulations. [#SRC:a2dd84dd-1b01-465d-808a-b2f653dd4e93] [#TGT:5e4bc632-0693-4b1c-a3b9-ef28fb2a8441]

question: If one person breaks the rules and another person is Knowingly Concerned, who can be treated as having committed the contravention, and what does that mean for a contravention of FSMR or Rules compared with a contravention of these Regulations?
gold_answer: When one person commits a contravention and another person is Knowingly Concerned in it, both passages indicate that responsibility can extend beyond the primary actor to the involved person as well. [#SRC:a2dd84dd-1b01-465d-808a-b2f653dd4e93] [#TGT:5e4bc632-0693-4b1c-a3b9-ef28fb2a8441] Under the SOURCE, the scenario is framed specifically for a contravention of FSMR or Rules committed by another person: if someone is Knowingly Concerned, then under section 220 of FSMR both persons may be held liable for committing a contravention. [#SRC:a2dd84dd-1b01-465d-808a-b2f653dd4e93] Under the TARGET, the same “Knowingly Concerned” involvement concept is applied to a contravention of these Regulations committed by another person, and it goes further by stating that the involved person and the original contravener each commits the contravention and is liable to be proceeded against and dealt with accordingly. [#TGT:5e4bc632-0693-4b1c-a3b9-ef28fb2a8441] Put together, the key linkage is that the SOURCE anchors liability for FSMR/Rules contraventions to section 220 of FSMR, while the TARGET describes the enforcement consequence for contraventions of these Regulations as exposure to being proceeded against and dealt with accordingly. [#SRC:a2dd84dd-1b01-465d-808a-b2f653dd4e93] [#TGT:5e4bc632-0693-4b1c-a3b9-ef28fb2a8441]

question: When applying the formula-based restriction on new Issues of Equity Securities, how must a Listed Entity treat Securities whose approval under Rule 9.7.5 has lapsed when determining whether the issue would exceed the “Maximum number of Equity Securities” without holder approval, and which component(s) of the calculation are affected?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity must treat Securities whose approval under Rule 9.7.5 has lapsed as no longer qualifying as issued “with approval under Rule 9.7.5” for the purposes of the Rule 9.7.1 calculation, and instead count them within “Relevant Issues” under Rule 9.7.1. [#SRC:76970fb8-577b-4a21-8996-4c8bde4ef2d2] This matters because the restriction on new Issues of Equity Securities limits issuance (absent approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities) to a “Maximum number of Equity Securities” computed as (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] Under the definition of Relevant Issues, Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the prior 12 months are excluded only if they were issued with holder approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5, or under an exception in Rule 9.7.4. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] Because a lapsed Rule 9.7.5 approval removes the ability to treat those Securities as approved under Rule 9.7.5 for Rule 9.7.1 purposes, they cannot be excluded on that basis and must be included in Relevant Issues. [#SRC:76970fb8-577b-4a21-8996-4c8bde4ef2d2] Including them increases Relevant Issues and therefore reduces the Maximum number available without holder approval under the formula. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]

question: If a Listed Entity is working out how many Equity Securities it can issue without getting approval from holders of Ordinary Securities, what happens in the calculation if an earlier approval under Rule 9.7.5 has lapsed?
gold_answer: If an approval under Rule 9.7.5 has lapsed, the Securities covered by that lapsed approval must no longer be treated as Securities issued with approval under Rule 9.7.5 for the Rule 9.7.1 counting exercise. [#SRC:76970fb8-577b-4a21-8996-4c8bde4ef2d2] Instead, they must be counted within “Relevant Issues” under Rule 9.7.1. [#SRC:76970fb8-577b-4a21-8996-4c8bde4ef2d2] This affects the Listed Entity’s ability to issue more Equity Securities without holder approval because the rule sets a cap using the formula: Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues, unless the holders of Ordinary Securities approve. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] “Relevant Issues” generally includes Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the prior 12 months, except those issued with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5 or under an exception in Rule 9.7.4. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] Because the lapsed approval means the Securities cannot be treated as approved under Rule 9.7.5 for this purpose, they are not excluded on that basis and therefore increase Relevant Issues, reducing the maximum headroom under the formula. [#SRC:76970fb8-577b-4a21-8996-4c8bde4ef2d2] [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]

question: When calculating CET1 Capital, how must an Authorised Person treat (i) Credit Enhancing Interest Only Strips (net of the deductions from CET1 Capital required at Rule 4.14.13) and (ii) any increase in issued capital or reserves resulting from a securitisation (including gain-on-sale amounts tied to expected future margin income), and how do these treatments interact in the CET1 deduction calculation?
gold_answer: In calculating CET1 Capital, an Authorised Person must apply two distinct deduction treatments that can both affect the same overall CET1 computation: (1) a mandatory full deduction for Credit Enhancing Interest Only Strips (after netting for specified prior deductions), and (2) a requirement to deduct securitisation-driven increases in issued capital or reserves (including certain gain-on-sale components). Specifically, Credit Enhancing Interest Only Strips—measured net of the deductions from CET1 Capital required at Rule 4.14.13—must be deducted at a 100% rate from CET1 Capital. [#SRC:c0b36aad-933a-4667-a073-ebb69b3f1aab] Separately, the Authorised Person must include as deductions from CET1 Capital any increase in issued capital or reserves that arises from a securitisation, with an explicit example being expected future margin income that creates a gain on sale and is recognised as issued capital or reserves. [#TGT:6300f7af-226b-41ca-ac50-e4802726964c] Practically, this means the firm should (a) identify any securitisation-related uplift recorded in issued capital or reserves and deduct it from CET1, and (b) identify any Credit Enhancing Interest Only Strips and deduct them fully, using the net-of-Rule-4.14.13 amount as the base for the 100% deduction. [#SRC:c0b36aad-933a-4667-a073-ebb69b3f1aab] [#TGT:6300f7af-226b-41ca-ac50-e4802726964c]

question: If an Authorised Person has a securitisation that creates a gain on sale (from expected future margin income) recorded in issued capital or reserves, and it also holds Credit Enhancing Interest Only Strips, what exactly has to be deducted from CET1 Capital and at what rate for the strips (taking into account the “net of Rule 4.14.13 deductions” wording)?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must make CET1 Capital deductions for both the securitisation-related accounting uplift and for the Credit Enhancing Interest Only Strips, and the strips have a specified deduction rate. First, any increase in issued capital or reserves that results from a securitisation must be included as a deduction from CET1 Capital; the text highlights as an example expected future margin income that produces a gain on sale and is recognised as issued capital or reserves. [#TGT:6300f7af-226b-41ca-ac50-e4802726964c] Second, Credit Enhancing Interest Only Strips are deducted from CET1 Capital at 100%, but the amount to which the 100% rate applies is the strips “net of the deductions from CET1 Capital required at Rule 4.14.13.” [#SRC:c0b36aad-933a-4667-a073-ebb69b3f1aab] Put together, the firm should (a) identify and deduct the securitisation-driven increase in issued capital or reserves (including the gain-on-sale amount tied to expected future margin income), and (b) separately compute the net amount of Credit Enhancing Interest Only Strips after applying the referenced Rule 4.14.13 deductions, then deduct that net strip amount in full from CET1 Capital. [#TGT:6300f7af-226b-41ca-ac50-e4802726964c] [#SRC:c0b36aad-933a-4667-a073-ebb69b3f1aab]

question: If an Authorised Person has a CR Exposure to a central government or central bank of a GCC member country (including an individual Emirate of the UAE treated as a GCC member country), and the exposure is not denominated and funded in that domestic currency, how must the exposure be treated and can a 0% risk weight still be applied?
gold_answer: A CR Exposure to a central government or central bank of a GCC member country may receive a 0% risk weight only when it is both denominated and funded in that GCC member country’s domestic currency (and, for this purpose, each individual Emirate of the UAE is treated as though it were a GCC member country). [#TGT:0b38a29a-6f32-46d4-b772-9682878dc7c1] If those conditions are not satisfied, the exposure does not meet the stated requirements for that treatment and must instead be handled under the alternative treatment specified for cases where the requirements of Rule 4.12.5 are not met. [#SRC:d005dde9-921a-4f5c-ac96-c708712bf938] In practical terms, the Authorised Person should first determine whether the counterparty is a central government or central bank of a GCC member country (including an individual Emirate of the UAE as treated for this purpose) and then verify that the exposure is denominated and funded in the relevant domestic currency. [#TGT:0b38a29a-6f32-46d4-b772-9682878dc7c1] Where either the denomination or funding condition is missing, the exposure must be treated in accordance with Rule 4.12.4 rather than receiving the 0% risk weight described for qualifying exposures. [#SRC:d005dde9-921a-4f5c-ac96-c708712bf938]

question: When can an Authorised Person use a 0% risk weight for a CR Exposure to a GCC central government/central bank, and what happens if the Rule 4.12.5 requirements for that treatment are not met (including for an individual Emirate of the UAE)?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person can apply a 0% risk weight to a CR Exposure only if the exposure is to a central government or central bank of a GCC member country and it is both denominated and funded in that GCC member country’s domestic currency; for this specific rule, each individual Emirate of the UAE is treated as though it were a GCC member country. [#TGT:0b38a29a-6f32-46d4-b772-9682878dc7c1] If the requirements of Rule 4.12.5 are not met, the CR Exposure must be treated under Rule 4.12.4 instead of using the treatment tied to meeting Rule 4.12.5. [#SRC:d005dde9-921a-4f5c-ac96-c708712bf938] To apply this correctly, the Authorised Person should (i) confirm the counterparty falls within the central government/central bank category and the relevant GCC member country (including an individual Emirate of the UAE as treated for this purpose), and (ii) check that both the denomination and funding are in that domestic currency. [#TGT:0b38a29a-6f32-46d4-b772-9682878dc7c1] If either of those currency conditions is not satisfied, the exposure is handled using the Rule 4.12.4 approach because the Rule 4.12.5 requirements have not been met. [#SRC:d005dde9-921a-4f5c-ac96-c708712bf938]

question: For an Authorised Person that is a Virtual Asset Custodian, how does the requirement to treat “Client Assets” and “Client Investments” as including “Virtual Assets” affect the minimum technology governance systems and controls that must be implemented for Virtual Asset Wallets, keys, transaction origin/destination, security, and risk management?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that is a Virtual Asset Custodian must treat “Virtual Assets” as falling within the scope of “Client Assets” and “Client Investments,” so the custody protections applied to those categories extend to Accepted Virtual Assets, and the firm must operationalise that treatment through the minimum technology governance and control framework required for Virtual Asset activities. [#SRC:15ac7d0d-8853-444c-8a24-8678075fa3c7] In practice, this means the firm’s custody arrangements for Virtual Assets should be supported by documented procedures and controls that cover the full lifecycle and oversight of Virtual Asset Wallets (including setup, access privileges, user management, limits, and audit/oversight). [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] It also requires procedures for private and public keys (generation, exchange, storage, backup, destruction, access management, sharing, and re-use as applicable), because those mechanisms are integral to controlling and safeguarding Virtual Assets held in custody. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] Additionally, the firm must have systems and controls to determine the origin of incoming Virtual Assets and the destination of outgoing Virtual Assets to mitigate misuse risk, aligning with the objective of affording Accepted Virtual Assets protections comparable to other products and activities under the FSMR and the FSRA Rulebook. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] [#SRC:15ac7d0d-8853-444c-8a24-8678075fa3c7] Finally, the firm must maintain a security plan (covering sensitive data, networks/systems, cloud services, physical facilities, and documents) and a risk management plan addressing operational, technology (including hacking), market risk for each Accepted Virtual Asset, and Financial Crime risk. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6]

question: If an Authorised Person is holding Virtual Assets for clients, what does it mean that “Client Assets” and “Client Investments” must be read to include “Virtual Assets,” and what minimum systems and controls must the firm have for wallets, keys, tracking where funds come from/go to, security, and risk management?
gold_answer: Reading “Client Assets” and “Client Investments” to include “Virtual Assets” means Virtual Assets (including Accepted Virtual Assets) are intended to receive the same type of protections as other similar products and activities under the FSMR and the FSRA Rulebook, rather than being treated as outside the client-asset/client-investment framework. [#SRC:15ac7d0d-8853-444c-8a24-8678075fa3c7] For an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, the minimum way to implement that protective approach is to have systems and controls that specifically govern how Virtual Assets are created, accessed, safeguarded, and monitored in the firm’s technology environment. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] Concretely, the firm must maintain procedures for Virtual Asset Wallets that cover wallet creation and lifecycle actions (such as configuration, deployment, deletion, backup and recovery), access privilege management, user management, wallet rules/limits and their review, and audit/oversight. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] It must also maintain procedures for private and public keys (including generation, storage, backup, destruction, access management, and sharing/re-use as applicable). [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] To reduce misuse risk, it must have controls to determine the origin of Virtual Assets for incoming transactions and the destination for outgoing transactions, which supports the goal of applying comparable protections to Accepted Virtual Assets. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] [#SRC:15ac7d0d-8853-444c-8a24-8678075fa3c7] Finally, it must have a security plan (covering data privacy, networks/systems, cloud services, physical facilities, and documents) and a risk management plan addressing operational, technology/hacking, market risk for each Accepted Virtual Asset, and Financial Crime risk. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6]

question: When an Authorised Person uses the FCSA to recognise eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure, how must it split the Exposure into collateralised and uncollateralised portions, and what CRW must it apply to the collateralised portion when the CRW applicable to the Collateral would otherwise be below 20%, including the specific exceptions that permit 0% or 10%?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person using the FCSA must treat eligible financial Collateral by separating the CR Exposure into two parts and then applying the appropriate CRW to each part, with a floor on the collateralised portion unless an exception applies. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] The collateralised portion must be set equal to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and the uncollateralised portion must be the CR Exposure amount reduced by that latest fair value. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] For Credit RWA calculation purposes, the collateralised portion generally takes the CRW applicable to the Collateral as if the Authorised Person had a direct Exposure to it, while the uncollateralised portion takes the CRW applicable to the obligor. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] However, if the CRW that would be used for the collateralised portion (i.e., the CRW applicable to the Collateral) is below 20%, the Authorised Person must apply 20% to the collateralised portion unless one of the specified cases applies. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438] The exceptions include qualifying SFTs (0% if the Counterparty is a core market participant; 10% if not), certain daily-marked OTC Derivatives with no currency mismatch (0% if collateralised by cash; 10% if collateralised by specified 0%-risk-weight government/central bank/PSE exposures), and certain no-currency-mismatch transactions where the Collateral is specified cash on Deposit or specified 0%-risk-weight government/central bank/PSE exposures and the latest fair value used for the collateralised portion has been discounted by 20%. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438]

question: If an Authorised Person is using the FCSA and the Collateral’s risk weight would come out below 20%, what do they do with the Exposure split (collateralised vs uncollateralised) and when can they use 0% or 10% instead of 20% for the collateralised part?
gold_answer: Under the FCSA approach, the Authorised Person must first split the CR Exposure into a collateralised portion and an uncollateralised portion, and then apply risk weights to each portion based on what each portion represents. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] The collateralised portion is measured as the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and the uncollateralised portion is the CR Exposure amount minus that latest fair value. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] For Credit RWA purposes, the collateralised portion uses the CRW that applies to the Collateral as if it were a direct Exposure to that Collateral, while the uncollateralised portion uses the CRW that applies to the obligor. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] If the CRW for the collateralised portion (based on the Collateral) would be less than 20%, the default outcome is that the Authorised Person must apply a 20% CRW to the collateralised portion. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438] The Authorised Person may instead apply 0% or 10% only in the listed cases, including qualifying SFTs depending on whether the Counterparty is a core market participant, and certain daily mark-to-market OTC Derivative transactions with no currency mismatch depending on whether the Collateral is cash or specified 0%-risk-weight government/central bank/PSE exposures. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438] A further 0% option exists for certain no-currency-mismatch transactions where the Collateral is specified cash on Deposit or specified 0%-risk-weight government/central bank/PSE exposures and the latest fair value used in the collateralised portion has been discounted by 20%. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438]

question: When preparing the quarterly report disclosure that must include (at least once every 12 months) the Summary of Reserves and Resources, what specific table format and “as of” date constraint must the Mining Reporting Entity apply to that Summary, and how does that constraint relate to the timing of the quarterly report’s disclosure of when the previous and upcoming Summary will be made?
gold_answer: A Mining Exploration Reporting Entity’s quarterly report must, at least once every 12 months, include the Summary of Reserves and Resources required by Rule 11.11.1 unless that Summary is instead included in the entity’s annual report, and the quarterly report must also state when the prior and the next such Summary was and will be disclosed. [#SRC:737c3487-346b-4104-8b50-78dd337bed22] When that Summary of Reserves and Resources is prepared for disclosure (including when it is the item being tracked as “previous” and “upcoming” in the quarterly report), a Mining Reporting Entity must include a table in the form of MKT Form 11-1. [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd] In addition, the table must be presented “as of” a date that is no earlier than one month before the Summary of Reserves and Resources is disclosed. [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd] Practically, this means the entity should align the quarterly report’s disclosure of the timing of the previous and upcoming Summary with a Summary that contains the required MKT Form 11-1 table and uses an “as of” date that falls within the permitted one-month lookback from the actual disclosure date. [#SRC:737c3487-346b-4104-8b50-78dd337bed22] [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd]

question: In the quarterly report, the Mining Exploration Reporting Entity has to include a Summary of Reserves and Resources at least once every 12 months (unless it’s in the annual report) and say when the last and next Summary will be disclosed. What table has to be inside that Summary, and how recent does the table’s “as of” date have to be compared with the Summary’s disclosure date?
gold_answer: In the quarterly report, a Mining Exploration Reporting Entity must provide a report for each quarter and, at least once every 12 months, include the Summary of Reserves and Resources required by Rule 11.11.1 unless that Summary is included in the entity’s annual report; the quarterly report must also indicate when the previous and upcoming Summary disclosure occurred and will occur. [#SRC:737c3487-346b-4104-8b50-78dd337bed22] For the content of that Summary of Reserves and Resources, a Mining Reporting Entity must include a table in the form of MKT Form 11-1. [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd] The table must be prepared “as of” a date that is not earlier than one month before the Summary of Reserves and Resources is disclosed, meaning the “as of” date must fall within the one-month period leading up to the disclosure. [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd] Read together, the quarterly report’s required statement of when the last and next Summary will be disclosed should correspond to a Summary that includes the MKT Form 11-1 table and uses an “as of” date that satisfies the one-month timing limit tied to the disclosure date. [#SRC:737c3487-346b-4104-8b50-78dd337bed22] [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity publishes forecast financial information derived from a Production Target and, in the same disclosure package, also discloses an estimate of Ore Reserves, what specific categories of assumptions and supporting information must be included for (i) the forecast financial information and (ii) the Ore Reserves estimate, including how commercially sensitive material economic assumptions are to be handled?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity must ensure the disclosure covers two distinct but complementary information sets: the assumption framework supporting the forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, and the key technical context required when an Ore Reserves estimate is disclosed. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:cb1ec09f-a7d3-4c38-ba2e-4e72ed8c3129] For the forecast financial information, the disclosure must include all material economic assumptions used, plus all other material assumptions applied. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions commercially sensitive, it must state that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions (rather than omitting the topic entirely). [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] The disclosure must also identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, and include the information required to be contained in that Production Target disclosure. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] Separately, when disclosing an estimate of Ore Reserves, the disclosure must also include key information on mining (recovery/dilution) factors or assumptions, metallurgical factors or assumptions, cut-off parameters, study status, and the relative accuracy/confidence. [#TGT:cb1ec09f-a7d3-4c38-ba2e-4e72ed8c3129]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity shares forecast financial information based on a Production Target and also includes an Ore Reserves estimate, what details do they need to add about assumptions for the forecast and what extra technical details must be included for the Ore Reserves part (including what to do if the economic assumptions are commercially sensitive)?
gold_answer: The disclosure needs to cover both (1) the assumptions and source basis for the forecast financial information and (2) the specific technical context required when an Ore Reserves estimate is disclosed. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:cb1ec09f-a7d3-4c38-ba2e-4e72ed8c3129] For the forecast financial information, the Mining Reporting Entity must include all material economic assumptions used to determine the forecast, and it must also include all other material assumptions used. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity believes the material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it must say they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] The Mining Reporting Entity must also state the Production Target the forecast is derived from, and include the information that must be provided with that Production Target. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In addition, when the disclosure includes an estimate of Ore Reserves, it must also include key information about mining (recovery/dilution) factors or assumptions, metallurgical factors or assumptions, cut-off parameters, the study status, and the relative accuracy/confidence of the estimate. [#TGT:cb1ec09f-a7d3-4c38-ba2e-4e72ed8c3129]

question: When applying the restriction on new Issues of Equity Securities, how should a Listed Entity treat an earlier issue that falls within “(a) above” in the Relevant Issues carve-out, and what approval condition must be satisfied for that earlier issue to be treated as approved for these purposes?
gold_answer: An earlier issue can be excluded from “Relevant Issues” only if it fits within the carve-out for issues made with the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 (or Rule 9.7.5), because Relevant Issues excludes Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the prior 12 months where that holder approval was obtained. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] For the specific category described as “(a) above,” the issue is not treated as approved unless it has in fact been approved under Rule 9.7.1. [#SRC:b0911de0-2418-4fb5-9565-683577084295] Practically, this means the Listed Entity must confirm that the earlier issue has the required Rule 9.7.1 approval before relying on the Relevant Issues exclusion; otherwise, the earlier issue remains part of the count of Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the 12 months before the current issue or agreement date. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] This approval condition is critical because the maximum number of Equity Securities that may be issued without holder approval is calculated as (20% * Base Amount) minus Relevant Issues, so whether an earlier issue is excluded from Relevant Issues directly affects the remaining capacity under the formula. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]

question: If a Listed Entity is working out how many Equity Securities it can issue under the 20% formula, can it leave out a past issue from “Relevant Issues” just because it thinks it fits item “(a) above,” and what exact approval does that past issue need?
gold_answer: The Listed Entity can only leave a past issue out of “Relevant Issues” if it falls within the stated exclusions, including where the Equity Securities were issued or agreed to be issued with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 (or Rule 9.7.5). [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] For the particular situation described as “(a) above,” it is not enough to assume it qualifies; the issue must actually have been approved under Rule 9.7.1. [#SRC:b0911de0-2418-4fb5-9565-683577084295] If that Rule 9.7.1 approval is not in place, the past issue should be counted in “Relevant Issues,” which increases the subtraction in the formula and reduces the number of Equity Securities the Listed Entity can issue without getting holder approval. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] In other words, the decision to exclude the past issue depends on confirming the specific Rule 9.7.1 approval requirement for “(a) above,” because the formula’s output turns on the size of “Relevant Issues” over the 12 months before the current issue or agreement date. [#SRC:b0911de0-2418-4fb5-9565-683577084295] [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]

question: When the Regulator is assessing an application for a Financial Services Permission to Operate a Multilateral Trading Facility, how should the applicant treat the TARGET’s references to “Investment” if the applicant is an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, and how does that affect the way the applicant addresses the Regulator’s stated assessment matters?
gold_answer: For an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, the applicant should treat the TARGET’s “Investment” references as referring to “Virtual Asset” when framing its application narrative and evidence for the Regulator’s assessment. [#SRC:726a7101-d094-4454-93b6-5e5561582705] This is because GEN Rule 5.2.14 is applied in that Virtual Asset MTF context and requires that “Investment” references be read as “Virtual Asset,” which directly informs how the applicant should present impacts on the traded asset class. [#SRC:726a7101-d094-4454-93b6-5e5561582705] Accordingly, in responding to the Regulator’s application assessment, the applicant should address the listed matters with Virtual Assets as the relevant instrument, including: whether establishing the Multilateral Trading Facility is, or is likely to be, in the interests of the Financial Services and Markets industry; whether the facility will or is likely to improve price discovery of, or deepen liquidity in, the relevant asset; and whether the proposed operation creates risks of market fragmentation, loss of liquidity, or inefficiency in price discovery. [#TGT:66edbeb0-e20b-498a-8b25-cfd2a59dae31] The practical effect is that the applicant’s discussion of price discovery, liquidity, and fragmentation should be anchored to Virtual Assets (not Investments) while still aligning to the Regulator’s stated evaluation framework for permissions to Operate a Multilateral Trading Facility. [#SRC:726a7101-d094-4454-93b6-5e5561582705] [#TGT:66edbeb0-e20b-498a-8b25-cfd2a59dae31]

question: If an Authorised Person wants permission to run a Multilateral Trading Facility for Virtual Assets, what should they do with the word “Investment” in the Regulator’s application checks, and what are the main checks they still need to cover?
gold_answer: They should treat the Regulator’s “Investment” wording as meaning “Virtual Asset” for this type of Multilateral Trading Facility, because GEN Rule 5.2.14 applies to an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets and requires that “Investment” references be read as “Virtual Asset.” [#SRC:726a7101-d094-4454-93b6-5e5561582705] That translation matters when the applicant explains how the proposed venue affects the asset being traded, since the Regulator’s assessment includes whether the venue will improve price discovery of, or deepen liquidity in, an Investment (which, in this context, should be treated as the Virtual Asset). [#TGT:66edbeb0-e20b-498a-8b25-cfd2a59dae31] Even with that substitution, the applicant still needs to address the Regulator’s stated areas of focus for a Financial Services Permission to Operate a Multilateral Trading Facility, including: (1) whether the establishment of the facility is, or is likely to be, in the interests of the Financial Services and Markets industry; (2) whether the facility will or is likely to lead to more efficient price discovery or deeper liquidity in the relevant asset; and (3) whether the proposed operation creates risks of market fragmentation, loss of liquidity, or inefficiency in price discovery. [#TGT:66edbeb0-e20b-498a-8b25-cfd2a59dae31] This lets the applicant align its Virtual Asset MTF case to the Regulator’s permission assessment framework. [#SRC:726a7101-d094-4454-93b6-5e5561582705] [#TGT:66edbeb0-e20b-498a-8b25-cfd2a59dae31]

question: When calculating the Exposure value for on-balance sheet SFTs, how should an Authorised Person reflect the netting approach described for legally valid bilateral netting that substitutes a single payable/receivable amount, and what calculation framework must be used?
gold_answer: For on-balance sheet SFTs, the Exposure value must be calculated using the IFRS-based approach specified for SFTs, and it must incorporate the applicable netting requirements for those SFTs. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] Where the Authorised Person applies a legally valid form of bilateral netting that produces legal substitution—i.e., replacing prior gross obligations with one single payable/receivable amount—this netting concept is the type of netting that may be used to net transactions and should be reflected in how the SFT exposure is determined under the referenced netting requirements. [#TGT:af6814ee-9972-4eb9-996b-eb4446ec5113] In practical terms, the calculation is anchored in IFRS for the on-balance sheet measurement of the SFT exposure, while the netting treatment is constrained to bilateral netting arrangements that are legally valid and achieve legal substitution into a single net amount. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:af6814ee-9972-4eb9-996b-eb4446ec5113] This linkage matters because the SFT exposure rule requires both the IFRS calculation basis and compliance with the netting requirements, and the netting-set concept clarifies the kind of bilateral netting that can be used to arrive at a single net payable/receivable amount rather than gross obligations. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:af6814ee-9972-4eb9-996b-eb4446ec5113]

question: If an Authorised Person uses a legally valid bilateral netting agreement that turns many gross amounts into one net payable/receivable amount, how does that connect to the way Exposure value must be worked out for on-balance sheet SFTs?
gold_answer: The Exposure value for on-balance sheet SFTs must be calculated using IFRS and by applying the netting requirements referenced for SFTs. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] Separately, an Authorised Person is permitted to net transactions when the netting is a legally valid form of bilateral netting that legally substitutes a single payable/receivable amount for the prior gross obligations. [#TGT:af6814ee-9972-4eb9-996b-eb4446ec5113] Read together, this means that when the Authorised Person’s SFTs are subject to such legally substituting bilateral netting, the Exposure value calculation for those on-balance sheet SFTs should be performed on the IFRS basis while also reflecting netting in the manner contemplated by the applicable netting requirements. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:af6814ee-9972-4eb9-996b-eb4446ec5113] The key linkage is that the SFT rule does not stand alone: it explicitly requires both IFRS measurement and adherence to netting requirements, and the netting-set description explains that netting is tied to a legally valid bilateral arrangement that collapses gross obligations into one net payable/receivable amount. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:af6814ee-9972-4eb9-996b-eb4446ec5113]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information derived from a Production Target for an operating mine, in what circumstances is it not required to comply with Rule 11.9.2, and what specific content must still be included in the disclosure under Rule 11.9.1 (including how to handle commercially sensitive material economic assumptions)?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is not required to comply with Rule 11.9.2 for forecast financial information derived from a Production Target relating to an operating mine(s) where that forecast financial information is wholly based on (i) Ore Reserves, (ii) a combination of Ore Reserves and Measured Mineral Resources, or (iii) a combination of Ore Reserves with Measured Mineral Resources and/or Indicated Mineral Resources, provided the Indicated Mineral Resources are not the determining factor in project viability. [#SRC:bf5c6652-b4c7-4b61-8732-68aed56e52a7] Even in that scenario, if the Mining Reporting Entity is making a disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1, the disclosure must include the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, covering all material economic assumptions employed and all other material assumptions utilised. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, it must state that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] The Rule 11.9.1 disclosure must also identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including all information required by Rule 11.8.3. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity’s forecast financial information comes from a Production Target for an operating mine, when can it skip complying with Rule 11.9.2, and what does it still have to put in its Rule 11.9.1 disclosure (especially if the economic assumptions are commercially sensitive)?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity can avoid having to comply with Rule 11.9.2 for forecast financial information derived from a Production Target relating to an operating mine(s) when the forecast is wholly based on Ore Reserves, or on Ore Reserves combined with Measured Mineral Resources, or on Ore Reserves combined with Measured Mineral Resources and/or Indicated Mineral Resources as long as the Indicated Mineral Resources are not what determines whether the project is viable. [#SRC:bf5c6652-b4c7-4b61-8732-68aed56e52a7] However, where the Mining Reporting Entity is making a disclosure under Rule 11.9.1, it still must include details about the assumptions used to work out the forecast financial information, including all material economic assumptions and all other material assumptions. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If it believes the material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it must say they are commercially sensitive and describe the methodology it used to determine those assumptions. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] It must also include the Production Target the forecast is based on, and that Production Target must be presented with all the information required by Rule 11.8.3. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]

question: For a Preference Security that is not a Share, how must the terms of issue frame the Security holder’s voting rights so that they follow the Rule 9.3.10 voting mechanics (with necessary adaptation to the instrument’s form) while also limiting entitlement to vote to the specific circumstances listed for Preference Securities?
gold_answer: The terms of issue for a Preference Security that is not a Share must do two things in combination: (i) build in voting rights that operate using the same voting approach as Rule 9.3.10, adjusted as needed to fit the particular form of the Preference Security; and (ii) confine when the holder is entitled to vote to the enumerated situations applicable to Preference Securities. [#SRC:b44527f3-ec4a-46f4-a7ee-2c90ce42c3da] In practice, this means the document should not grant a general or standing vote; instead, it should specify that voting is available only in the limited cases, and then describe how the vote is exercised using the Rule 9.3.10-style mechanics as adapted for a non-Share instrument. [#SRC:b44527f3-ec4a-46f4-a7ee-2c90ce42c3da] The permitted voting triggers are limited to: when a dividend or distribution (or part of it) is in arrears for a Security; resolutions affecting rights attached to the Preference Security; resolutions on reduction of the Share capital of a Listed Entity; resolutions on a buy-back agreement; resolutions to wind up a Listed Entity; resolutions to dispose of the whole of a Listed Entity’s business and undertaking; and voting during the winding up of a Listed Entity. [#TGT:53783cfa-4f5d-4db7-8ffc-7ef9fc4273ff] Accordingly, the adapted Rule 9.3.10 voting framework should be drafted to activate only for those triggers and not beyond them. [#TGT:53783cfa-4f5d-4db7-8ffc-7ef9fc4273ff]

question: If a company issues a Preference Security that is not a Share, what should the terms say about how the holder votes (using the Rule 9.3.10 approach, adapted to the security’s form) and when the holder is allowed to vote (only in the listed situations)?
gold_answer: For a Preference Security that is not a Share, the terms of issue need to describe the holder’s voting rights in a way that mirrors the Rule 9.3.10 voting method, but adjusted so it works for the particular form of that Preference Security. [#SRC:b44527f3-ec4a-46f4-a7ee-2c90ce42c3da] At the same time, the terms should make clear that the holder is not automatically entitled to vote on everything; the entitlement to vote must be limited to specific situations, and the adapted voting method should apply only when one of those situations occurs. [#SRC:b44527f3-ec4a-46f4-a7ee-2c90ce42c3da] Those situations are: if a dividend or distribution (or part of it) is in arrears for a Security; if a resolution affects rights attached to the Preference Security; if there is a resolution about reducing the Share capital of a Listed Entity; if there is a resolution about a buy-back agreement; if there is a resolution to wind up a Listed Entity; if there is a resolution for a Listed Entity to dispose of the whole of its business and undertaking; or during the winding up of a Listed Entity. [#TGT:53783cfa-4f5d-4db7-8ffc-7ef9fc4273ff] Drafting should therefore connect the adapted Rule 9.3.10 voting process to these triggers only. [#TGT:53783cfa-4f5d-4db7-8ffc-7ef9fc4273ff]

question: Where a FinTech Participant cannot meet the applicable criteria, when must it stop carrying on the Regulated Activity of Developing Financial Technology Services within the RegLab, and how does the Regulator’s ability to vary or cancel a Financial Services Permission affect that deadline under the framework addressing variation and cancellation on the Regulator’s initiative?
gold_answer: If a FinTech Participant is unable to satisfy the applicable criteria, it must stop carrying on the Regulated Activity of Developing Financial Technology Services within the RegLab. [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7] The default deadline for ceasing that Regulated Activity is the point when its RegLab FSP expires, reflecting the stated two-year validity period for that permission. [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7] However, that deadline is not fixed solely by expiry: it can be brought forward (or otherwise altered) if the Regulator varies or cancels the FSP, because the cessation deadline is also defined as “at such time as the Regulator varies or cancels the FSP” in accordance with the referenced mechanism. [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7] In applying this, the relevant framework is the regime concerning “Variation and cancellation of a Financial Services Permission,” specifically where variation or cancellation occurs on the initiative of the Regulator. [#TGT:445d41e7-27aa-41c1-84e4-194553261f8a] Accordingly, compliance planning should treat expiry as the baseline stop date, but also monitor for any Regulator-initiated variation or cancellation that would trigger an earlier (or otherwise revised) cessation point. [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7] [#TGT:445d41e7-27aa-41c1-84e4-194553261f8a]

question: If a FinTech Participant can’t meet the criteria, when do they have to stop doing the Regulated Activity in the RegLab, and how could the Regulator changing or cancelling the Financial Services Permission (on the Regulator’s own initiative) change that timing?
gold_answer: A FinTech Participant that cannot satisfy the criteria must stop carrying on the Regulated Activity of Developing Financial Technology Services within the RegLab. [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7] The normal stop point is when its RegLab FSP reaches the end of its validity, which is described as a two-year period. [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7] But the timing can change because the deadline is also tied to the moment the Regulator varies or cancels the FSP, meaning the Participant may have to stop earlier than expiry if the Regulator takes that action. [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7] The relevant context for that possibility is the topic of “Variation and cancellation of a Financial Services Permission,” including cases where the variation or cancellation happens on the initiative of the Regulator. [#TGT:445d41e7-27aa-41c1-84e4-194553261f8a] In practice, the Participant should plan around the two-year expiry date while also recognizing that a Regulator-initiated variation or cancellation can set the effective stop date instead. [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7] [#TGT:445d41e7-27aa-41c1-84e4-194553261f8a]

question: When the Third Party Provider intends to change exchange rates under the Governing Contract, how do the notice timing requirements interact with the circumstances in which exchange-rate changes may be applied immediately and without notice, including any dependency on Reference Exchange Rate information provided under Rule 20.2.2?
gold_answer: As a baseline, the Third Party Provider must give the Customer advance notice of proposed changes to either the existing terms of the Governing Contract or the information specified in Rule 20.2.2, and that notice must be delivered no later than two months before the change takes effect. [#SRC:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f] However, exchange-rate changes can be implemented immediately and without notice in the limited situations described for exchange rates, which operate as an exception to the general two‑month lead time for changes. [#TGT:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2] In practice, immediate/no-notice application is permitted only where one of the following conditions is met: - The Governing Contract includes an agreed right to apply exchange-rate changes, and the changes are based on Reference Exchange Rate information that has already been provided to the Customer in accordance with Rule 20.2.2. [#TGT:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2] - The exchange-rate changes are more favourable to the Customer. [#TGT:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2] If an exchange-rate change does not fall within those immediate/no-notice conditions, it remains a proposed change to contractual terms or related information and therefore must be provided to the Customer at least two months before it takes effect. [#SRC:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f]

question: If the Third Party Provider wants to change something in the Governing Contract, when do they have to tell the Customer, and when can an exchange-rate change happen right away without notice (including any link to Reference Exchange Rate information under Rule 20.2.2)?
gold_answer: The general rule is that the Third Party Provider must give the Customer details of any proposed change to the existing terms of the Governing Contract or to the information listed in Rule 20.2.2, and it must do so no later than two months before the change is due to start. [#SRC:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f] Exchange rates are treated differently in specific cases: an exchange-rate change may be applied immediately and without notice when the stated conditions for exchange-rate changes are met. [#TGT:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2] Those immediate/no-notice cases are limited to: - Where the Governing Contract includes an agreed right to make exchange-rate changes and the change is based on Reference Exchange Rate information that has already been provided to the Customer in line with Rule 20.2.2. [#TGT:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2] - Where the exchange-rate change is more favourable to the Customer. [#TGT:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2] If the exchange-rate change does not fit one of those scenarios, the Third Party Provider should treat it as a proposed contractual (or Rule 20.2.2 information) change and provide it to the Customer at least two months in advance. [#SRC:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f]

question: For Derivative transactions (including written credit protection) that are on-balance sheet items, how should the firm determine the exposure measure, and how does that interact with the requirement to calculate exposure at default (EAD) for Derivative transactions under the Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR) unless the Authorised Person has Regulator permission to use an internal model?
gold_answer: For on-balance sheet Derivatives (including written credit protection), the firm should build the exposure measure by combining two components: (1) the on-balance sheet value determined under IFRS and (2) an add-on for potential future exposure calculated under Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] In parallel, the exposure at default (EAD) for Derivative transactions (whether OTC or exchange-traded) must be calculated in accordance with the SA-CCR section, and this SA-CCR requirement also applies to long settlement transactions. [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff] The linkage is that, when the Derivative is an on-balance sheet item, the exposure value construction (IFRS on-balance sheet value plus the specified potential future exposure add-on) provides the concrete inputs and method elements the firm uses to operationalize its Derivative exposure calculation, while the SA-CCR section establishes that the firm must calculate EAD under that section for Derivative transactions unless it has been granted permission by the Regulator to use an internal model. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff] If the Authorised Person has Regulator permission to use an internal model, the SA-CCR calculation mandate does not apply in the same way for those transactions. [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff]

question: If you’re working out risk for a Derivative transaction and it’s also an on-balance sheet item, what numbers do you add up for the exposure value, and when do you have to use SA-CCR to calculate EAD instead of another method?
gold_answer: When the Derivative is an on-balance sheet item (including written credit protection), you calculate its exposure value by adding the IFRS on-balance sheet value to an add-on for potential future exposure that is worked out under Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] Separately, for Derivative transactions (both OTC and exchange-traded) and for long settlement transactions, the exposure at default (EAD) must be calculated using the SA-CCR section. [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff] Putting these together: if your Derivative is on-balance sheet, the exposure value method tells you the specific building blocks (IFRS value plus the specified potential future exposure add-on) that you use in your Derivative exposure calculation, while SA-CCR tells you that the required EAD framework for Derivative transactions is SA-CCR unless the Authorised Person has been granted permission by the Regulator to use an internal model. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff] If the Regulator has granted that permission, the SA-CCR requirement is displaced for the relevant transactions because the internal model is allowed. [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff]

question: When applying Rule 4.12.19 to determine whether an Exposure (other than those referred to in Rule 4.12.20) is associated with particularly high risks, how must an Authorised Person combine the risk-characteristic assessment with the rule’s mandatory inclusion of certain Investments (e.g., venture capital funds, hedge funds/alternative investment funds, speculative immovable property financing, or Investments declared high risk by the Regulator)?
gold_answer: In applying Rule 4.12.19, an Authorised Person must treat the determination of “particularly high risks” as having two necessary components: (1) a mandatory inclusion list for certain Investments, and (2) a risk-characteristic assessment for other Exposures (excluding those referred to in Rule 4.12.20). [#TGT:634d7695-6188-4cdb-bdd8-bc789adba744] For the inclusion component, Exposures with particularly high risks must include Investments in venture capital funds, Investments in hedge funds or alternative investment funds (including but not limited to Private Equity Funds), speculative immovable property financing, and any Investments the Regulator has declared to be high risk for this Rule. [#TGT:634d7695-6188-4cdb-bdd8-bc789adba744] Separately, when assessing whether an Exposure other than Exposures referred to in Rule 4.12.20 is associated with particularly high risks, the Authorised Person must take into account specified risk characteristics, namely that there is a high risk of loss due to a default of the obligor and that it is impossible to assess adequately whether that high-default-loss condition applies. [#SRC:3d42a036-1c75-4f4c-882c-847760f2d90c] Practically, the listed Investments are included as particularly high risk for Rule 4.12.19, while other in-scope Exposures are evaluated against the two risk characteristics to decide whether they are also particularly high risk. [#SRC:3d42a036-1c75-4f4c-882c-847760f2d90c] [#TGT:634d7695-6188-4cdb-bdd8-bc789adba744]

question: If you are an Authorised Person and you are checking whether something counts as an Exposure with particularly high risks under Rule 4.12.19, what do you do when it is (i) an Investment like a venture capital fund or hedge fund, versus (ii) another Exposure (not one of the Exposures referred to in Rule 4.12.20) where you are unsure how risky it is?
gold_answer: Under Rule 4.12.19, you need to handle “particularly high risks” in two ways: some Investments are automatically included, and other Exposures must be assessed using stated risk characteristics (except for Exposures referred to in Rule 4.12.20). [#TGT:634d7695-6188-4cdb-bdd8-bc789adba744] For the automatic inclusion part, Exposures with particularly high risks must include Investments in venture capital funds, Investments in hedge funds or alternative investment funds (including but not limited to Private Equity Funds), speculative immovable property financing, and any Investments the Regulator has declared to be high risk for this Rule. [#TGT:634d7695-6188-4cdb-bdd8-bc789adba744] For other Exposures (other than Exposures referred to in Rule 4.12.20), an Authorised Person must assess whether the Exposure is associated with particularly high risks by taking into account two risk characteristics: there is a high risk of loss because the obligor may default, and it is impossible to assess adequately whether that high-default-loss condition applies. [#SRC:3d42a036-1c75-4f4c-882c-847760f2d90c] So, if it is one of the listed Investments, it is included as particularly high risk for Rule 4.12.19; if it is another Exposure in scope, you decide based on those two risk characteristics, including the case where you cannot adequately assess whether the default-loss risk is present. [#SRC:3d42a036-1c75-4f4c-882c-847760f2d90c] [#TGT:634d7695-6188-4cdb-bdd8-bc789adba744]

question: When an Authorised Person is calculating RWA for all its securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures), how must it treat Early Amortisation Exposures within that overall calculation, including (i) the formula and risk-weight basis used for Early Amortisation Exposures and (ii) how those results are combined with the RWA for other SE Exposures?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must compute RWA for its SE Exposures by calculating RWA for each SE Exposure (other than those required to be deducted from any component of Capital Resources) and then combining those amounts with the separately calculated RWA for its Early Amortisation Exposures. [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] For each SE Exposure that is not deducted from Capital Resources, it must first determine the Exposure value under the Section 4.9 exposure measurement methodology while recognising applicable CRM, assign a Credit Quality Grade under Section 4.11, and then apply the formula RWA(SE) = SE × CRW, where CRW is the risk weight determined from that Credit Quality Grade. [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] In parallel, for each Early Amortisation Exposure it must calculate the Exposure value (EAE) under Section 4.9 while recognising applicable CRM and then compute RWA(EAE) = EAE × CRW, where CRW is the risk weight for the underlying Exposure type as if the Exposure had not been securitised. [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e] Finally, it must add together (i) the RWA(SE) amounts across all relevant SE Exposures and (ii) the aggregated RWA(EAE) amounts across all Early Amortisation Exposures to arrive at the combined RWA total for these securitisation-related positions. [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e]

question: If an Authorised Person has both SE Exposures and Early Amortisation Exposures, what steps does it follow to work out the risk-weighted amounts for each type, and how are the two sets of results added together?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must calculate risk-weighted Exposure amounts separately for SE Exposures and for Early Amortisation Exposures, and then add the totals together as part of the overall securitisation-related RWA calculation. [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] For SE Exposures, it must measure each Exposure value using the Section 4.9 methodology while recognising any applicable CRM, allocate a Credit Quality Grade under Section 4.11, and then compute RWA(SE) = SE × CRW, where CRW is the risk weight that corresponds to that Credit Quality Grade. [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] For Early Amortisation Exposures, it must measure each Exposure value (EAE) using the same Section 4.9 methodology and CRM recognition, and then compute RWA(EAE) = EAE × CRW. [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e] The key difference is that, for Early Amortisation Exposures, CRW is taken from the underlying Exposure type as though the Exposure had not been securitised, rather than being derived from a Credit Quality Grade. [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e] After calculating each set, it must sum the RWA(EAE) amounts across all Early Amortisation Exposures and add that sum to the RWA(SE) amounts calculated for its SE Exposures (excluding any SE Exposures required to be deducted from Capital Resources). [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e]

question: Where a Listed Entity has issued, or agreed to issue, Securities without prior approval, under what conditions is that issue treated as approved for Rule 9.7.1 purposes, and how does that treatment affect whether those Securities are excluded from “Relevant Issues” when applying the 20% formula restriction on new Issues of Equity Securities?
gold_answer: An unapproved issue (or agreement to issue) Securities can be treated as if it had approval for Rule 9.7.1, but only if three conditions are met: it stayed within the Rule 9.7.1 limit, the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities later approve it, and the Securities are then issued within three months after that approval date. [#SRC:3f609871-988e-4e0c-921f-6e1066c630f6] Once that subsequent approval treatment applies, the issue is treated as having approval “for the purposes of Rule 9.7.1,” which matters when calculating the restriction on new issues because “Relevant Issues” excludes Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the prior 12 months if they were made with approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 (or Rule 9.7.5).
