gold_answer: An Authorised Person that has established a branch outside ADGM and conducts Regulated Activities from that branch is required to pay the Regulator an annual supervision fee calculated as 50% of the highest annual supervision fee applicable to the Regulated Activities it undertakes from the branch. [#TGT:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c] For the first period, the initial supervision fee is not necessarily a full-year amount; it must be prorated and then paid following the approach specified in Rule 1.2.2(a). [#TGT:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c] In addition to these supervision-fee obligations for the outside-ADGM branch, the Regulator may impose a supplementary fee where the proposed branch would operate in a jurisdiction that lacks an adequate memorandum of understanding between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator for that jurisdiction. [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92] This supplementary fee is described as being in addition to the fees specified in Rule 7.1.1 and 7.1.2, and it is triggered by the absence of adequate cross-regulator cooperation arrangements for the branch’s jurisdiction. [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92]

question: If an Authorised Person runs Regulated Activities from a branch outside ADGM, what fee do they pay each year and how is the first payment handled, and when could the Regulator add a supplementary fee because of the branch’s country?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person has established a branch outside ADGM and uses that branch to conduct Regulated Activities, it must pay the Regulator an annual supervision fee set at 50% of the highest annual supervision fee for the Regulated Activities it carries on from that branch. [#TGT:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c] The first supervision fee payment is not automatically the full annual amount; instead, the initial supervision fee must be prorated and paid in the manner described in Rule 1.2.2(a). [#TGT:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c] Separately, the Regulator may also charge a supplementary fee (on top of the fees referenced in Rule 7.1.1 and 7.1.2) when the proposed branch would operate in a jurisdiction where there is no adequate memorandum of understanding between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator in that jurisdiction. [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92] In practical terms, the supervision fee is driven by the branch’s Regulated Activities and the proration rule for the initial payment, while the supplementary fee is tied to whether the branch’s jurisdiction has adequate regulator-to-regulator cooperation arrangements in place. [#TGT:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c] [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92]

question: How should a Recognised Body structure its arrangements so that its monitoring and enforcement of compliance with its rules is complemented by procedures for handling complaints about Persons using its facilities and appeals against the Recognised Body’s decisions, including where the Recognised Body is a Recognised Investment Exchange monitoring transactions to detect disorderly trading conditions or Market Abuse?
gold_answer: A Recognised Body should implement a single, coherent set of arrangements that both (i) monitors and enforces compliance with its rules and (ii) provides formal procedures to address complaints and appeals arising from use of its facilities and its decision-making. [#TGT:2ab875a8-156c-4fce-8482-013f133be759] The monitoring and enforcement component must be effective, and where the Recognised Body is a Recognised Investment Exchange it must include effective transaction monitoring designed to identify disorderly trading conditions or Market Abuse. [#TGT:2ab875a8-156c-4fce-8482-013f133be759] In parallel, the arrangements must include procedures to investigate complaints made to the Recognised Body about the conduct of Persons when they are using the Recognised Body’s facilities. [#SRC:e5494e74-1e44-4fa9-8687-49f899851a47] The arrangements must also include procedures that ensure appeals against decisions of the Recognised Body are resolved in a manner that is fair, independent, and impartial. [#SRC:e5494e74-1e44-4fa9-8687-49f899851a47] Taken together, this means the Recognised Body’s compliance oversight (including transaction monitoring for a Recognised Investment Exchange) should be complemented by complaint-investigation and appeal-resolution processes so that issues detected through monitoring or raised by users can be examined and, where relevant, challenged through an impartial appeal mechanism. [#TGT:2ab875a8-156c-4fce-8482-013f133be759] [#SRC:e5494e74-1e44-4fa9-8687-49f899851a47]

question: If a Recognised Body is checking that people follow its rules (and, for a Recognised Investment Exchange, watching transactions to spot disorderly trading conditions or Market Abuse), what extra processes must it also have for complaints about Persons using its facilities and for appeals against its decisions?
gold_answer: A Recognised Body must pair its compliance oversight with formal complaint and appeal processes, so that rule compliance is actively monitored and enforced while users also have structured routes for raising concerns and challenging decisions. [#TGT:2ab875a8-156c-4fce-8482-013f133be759] Specifically, it must have effective arrangements to monitor and enforce compliance with its rules; and if it is a Recognised Investment Exchange, those arrangements must include effective monitoring of transactions to identify disorderly trading conditions or Market Abuse. [#TGT:2ab875a8-156c-4fce-8482-013f133be759] Alongside that monitoring/enforcement framework, the arrangements must include procedures to investigate complaints made to the Recognised Body about the conduct of Persons when they are using the Recognised Body’s facilities. [#SRC:e5494e74-1e44-4fa9-8687-49f899851a47] The arrangements must also include procedures for resolving appeals against decisions of the Recognised Body, and that appeal resolution must be fair, independent, and impartial. [#SRC:e5494e74-1e44-4fa9-8687-49f899851a47] In practice, this means the Recognised Body’s transaction or rule monitoring function should be complemented by a complaint-investigation track and an impartial appeal track, so issues can be addressed whether they arise from surveillance/enforcement activity or from complaints about facility use and subsequent decisions. [#TGT:2ab875a8-156c-4fce-8482-013f133be759] [#SRC:e5494e74-1e44-4fa9-8687-49f899851a47]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information under Rule 11.9.1 that is derived from a Production Target, what specific Production Target-related content must be carried into the Rule 11.9.1 disclosure, and what additional Production Target disclosure elements are required under Rule 11.8.2 (including any required statements where forecast commodity prices or Inferred Mineral Resources are involved)?
gold_answer: A Rule 11.9.1 disclosure of forecast financial information must incorporate the underlying Production Target and, specifically, must include that Production Target together with all the information that Rule 11.8.3 requires for the Production Target. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In addition, the Production Target disclosure framework in Rule 11.8.2 requires detailed content about how the Production Target was determined, which becomes relevant because the forecast financial information is expressly derived from that Production Target. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] In practice, the Production Target disclosure must cover the assumptions used to determine the Production Target, including all material economic assumptions, or (if treated as commercially sensitive) a sensitivity statement plus an explanation of the methodology used to determine those economic assumptions, and all other material assumptions. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] If forecast commodity prices were used to determine the Production Target, the disclosure must also state that the forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] Where the Production Target is wholly or partly based on Inferred Mineral Resources (or partly on an Exploration Target), the disclosure must include the specified prominent, proximate cautionary statements and, for a wholly Inferred basis, additional explanation and a Technical Study prepared by or under the supervision of a named independent Competent Person(s). [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity is preparing a Rule 11.9.1 disclosure with forecast financial information and says some economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, what must it include about those assumptions, and how does that connect to the similar assumption disclosure required when it discloses the Production Target under Rule 11.8.2?
gold_answer: For forecast financial information disclosed under Rule 11.9.1, the Mining Reporting Entity must disclose all material economic assumptions used to determine that forecast information; if it considers those material economic assumptions commercially sensitive, it must say so and explain the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions, and it must also disclose all other material assumptions used. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] This requirement links directly to the Production Target disclosure because the Rule 11.9.1 disclosure must also include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all information required by Rule 11.8.3). [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] Under Rule 11.8.2, when disclosing the Production Target itself, the Mining Reporting Entity must provide the same core assumption transparency: it must disclose all material economic assumptions used to determine the Production Target, or (if commercially sensitive) provide a statement that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine them, and it must disclose all other material assumptions used. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] As a result, when forecast financial information is built from a Production Target, the entity should ensure the commercially sensitive assumption treatment is consistent across both disclosures: the forecast-financial-information disclosure must contain the methodology explanation for sensitive economic assumptions, and the Production Target disclosure must do the same for the assumptions used to set the Production Target. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]

question: Where an Authorised Person is operating an MTF using Virtual Assets and wishes to also operate a Recognised Investment Exchange, how should the firm structure its authorisation/recognition so it can continue operating the MTF, and what is the compliance consequence for the MTF function once the Recognition Order includes the relevant stipulation?
gold_answer: To continue operating an MTF while also operating as a Recognised Investment Exchange, the firm must ensure that the Recognition Order expressly permits the additional MTF function, and it must manage the transition in status/permissions accordingly. An Authorised Person that is operating an MTF and seeks to also operate a Recognised Investment Exchange is required to relinquish its FSP upon obtaining the Recognition Order to operate as a Recognised Investment Exchange. [#SRC:16e6290e-4660-4e38-9618-89de6a251764] If the FSRA licenses the firm to carry out both activities (operating an MTF and operating a Recognised Investment Exchange), the Recognition Order should contain a stipulation reflecting that dual permission (referenced as being pursuant to MIR Rule 3.4.1). [#SRC:16e6290e-4660-4e38-9618-89de6a251764] In parallel, a Recognised Investment Exchange may only carry on the Regulated Activity of operating an MTF (or OTF) where its Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting it to do so. [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388] Once that stipulation is present, the specific COBS rules on MTFs and OTFs apply to the MTF/OTF function, and they apply only to that function rather than to the Recognised Investment Exchange’s other activities. [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388]

question: If an Authorised Person already runs an MTF using Virtual Assets and then becomes a Recognised Investment Exchange, what must happen to its FSP, and when the Recognition Order lets it keep running the MTF, which rule set applies to that MTF work?
gold_answer: In this scenario, the firm needs to handle both (1) the change in its licensing/recognition position and (2) the rule framework that applies to the MTF activity once it is carried on by a Recognised Investment Exchange. When an Authorised Person operating an MTF wishes to also operate a Recognised Investment Exchange, it must give up (relinquish) its FSP once it obtains the Recognition Order to operate as a Recognised Investment Exchange. [#SRC:16e6290e-4660-4e38-9618-89de6a251764] If the FSRA licenses the firm to do both activities at the same time (operating an MTF and operating a Recognised Investment Exchange), the Recognition Order is expected to include a stipulation stating that dual permission (noted as being pursuant to MIR Rule 3.4.1). [#SRC:16e6290e-4660-4e38-9618-89de6a251764] Separately, a Recognised Investment Exchange is allowed to operate an MTF (or OTF) only if its Recognition Order contains a stipulation permitting that Regulated Activity. [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388] Where the stipulation is included, the COBS rules that specifically govern MTFs and OTFs apply to the MTF/OTF function, and they apply only to that function. [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388]

question: Where a Third Party Provider is permitted to make unilateral changes to the Governing Contract, what combined notice content and minimum advance delivery timing must it meet when proposing changes to the existing terms or to the information specified in Rule 20.2.2, including how Customer acceptance is treated and any termination right before the changes take effect?
gold_answer: When a Third Party Provider is allowed to make unilateral changes to the Governing Contract and proposes changes, it must both (i) deliver the proposed changes within the required lead time and (ii) include specific customer-facing statements about deemed acceptance and termination rights. [#SRC:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468] [#TGT:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f] For timing, proposed changes to either the existing terms of the Governing Contract or the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 must be provided to the Customer no later than two months before the date the changes are intended to take effect. [#TGT:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f] For notice content, the Third Party Provider must inform the Customer that, unless the Customer notifies the Third Party Provider to the contrary before the proposed entry-into-force date, the Customer will be treated as having accepted the changes that were communicated under Rule 20.2.5. [#SRC:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468] It must also inform the Customer that the Customer may terminate the Governing Contract without charge at any time before the proposed entry-into-force date. [#SRC:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468]

question: If the Third Party Provider can change the Governing Contract on its own, what does it have to tell the Customer about (1) when the changes must be sent and (2) what happens if the Customer does nothing, including whether the Customer can end the contract for free before the changes start?
gold_answer: If the Third Party Provider is permitted to make unilateral changes to the Governing Contract and it proposes changes, it must meet both an advance-notice deadline and specific customer disclosures about acceptance and termination. [#SRC:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468] [#TGT:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f] On timing, any proposed changes to the existing terms of the Governing Contract or to the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 must be provided to the Customer at least two months before the date the changes are intended to take effect. [#TGT:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f] On what the Customer must be told, the Third Party Provider has to explain that the Customer will be treated as having accepted the changes (as communicated under Rule 20.2.5) unless the Customer tells the Third Party Provider otherwise before the proposed date the changes start. [#SRC:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468] It also has to tell the Customer that the Customer can terminate the Governing Contract without charge at any time before that proposed start date. [#SRC:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468]

question: When the Regulator is considering issuing a “negative” direction to a Recognised Body that has not taken action under its Default Rules but appears to be proposing to take or may take action, what consultation step and satisfaction threshold must be met before the direction can be given, and what are the permissible bases for that satisfaction?
gold_answer: If the Regulator is contemplating a “negative” direction (i.e., a direction not to take action) in a situation where a Recognised Body has not acted under its Default Rules but seems to be proposing to act or may act, the Regulator must first consult the Recognised Body concerned before giving the direction. [#TGT:380d251f-0ce7-47ae-9d49-d8e2e45a9c8e] [#SRC:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3] Following that consultation, the Regulator is prohibited from giving the direction unless it is satisfied—based on the consultation—that at least one specified justification applies. [#SRC:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3] Those permissible bases are: (a) taking action would be premature or otherwise undesirable in the interests of investors or other market participants; (b) the direction is necessary in light of the public interest in the financial stability of the Abu Dhabi Global Market; or (c) the direction is necessary to facilitate a proposed or possible use of a power under chapter 16 of COBS, or in connection with a particular exercise of a power under that Part. [#SRC:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3] In practice, the “negative” direction scenario supplies the factual trigger (no Default Rules action yet, but potential action is contemplated), while the consultation and satisfaction tests govern whether the Regulator may proceed to issue the direction at all. [#TGT:380d251f-0ce7-47ae-9d49-d8e2e45a9c8e] [#SRC:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3]

question: If a Recognised Body hasn’t used its Default Rules yet but looks like it is about to (or might) take action, what does the Regulator have to do before telling it not to act, and what reasons can justify that instruction?
gold_answer: Where a Recognised Body has not taken action under its Default Rules but it appears to the Regulator that the Recognised Body is proposing to take action or may take action, the Regulator may consider issuing a “negative” direction telling it not to take action. [#TGT:380d251f-0ce7-47ae-9d49-d8e2e45a9c8e] Before giving such a direction, the Regulator must consult the Recognised Body in question. [#SRC:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3] After that consultation, the Regulator cannot give the direction unless it is satisfied, in light of what comes out of the consultation, that at least one of the allowed reasons applies. [#SRC:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3] The allowed reasons are that: taking action would be premature or otherwise undesirable for investors or other market participants; or the direction is necessary because of the public interest in the financial stability of the Abu Dhabi Global Market; or the direction is necessary to help enable a proposed or possible use of a power under chapter 16 of COBS, or to support a particular exercise of a power under that Part. [#SRC:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3] Put together, the “about to act” Default Rules situation explains when a negative direction may be relevant, and the consultation-plus-justification test explains what must be done and shown before the Regulator can actually issue it. [#TGT:380d251f-0ce7-47ae-9d49-d8e2e45a9c8e] [#SRC:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3]

question: When an Issuer is considering either (i) making an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM or (ii) seeking admission of Securities to trading on a RIE/Recognised Investment Exchange, what is the combined prohibition and what is the stated compliance pathway/exception that permits the activity?
gold_answer: An Issuer is prohibited from making an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, and is likewise prohibited from having Securities admitted to trading on a RIE, unless the activity is carried out in the manner the applicable framework allows. [#SRC:5f3625e1-2e7d-4bc8-b5e4-a0649ca42237] The general rule is framed as a “shall not” restriction on any person making an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or arranging for Securities to be admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange. [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a] For an Issuer specifically, the SOURCE clarifies that the prohibition applies to Offers of Securities to the Public made in or from ADGM and to admissions to trading on a RIE, and it identifies the permitted route as doing so only in accordance with FSMR and MKT. [#SRC:5f3625e1-2e7d-4bc8-b5e4-a0649ca42237] The TARGET provides the complementary exception structure: the prohibition is lifted only where the action is “provided by or under these Regulations,” meaning the Regulations themselves must contain the enabling basis for the Offer or admission. [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a] Read together, the compliance pathway is that an Issuer may proceed only where the Regulations permit it and where the Issuer follows the FSMR and MKT requirements identified for such Offers/admissions. [#SRC:5f3625e1-2e7d-4bc8-b5e4-a0649ca42237] [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a]

question: If someone wants to make an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market, and an Issuer wants to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM (or get Securities admitted to trading on a RIE), what do the rules say they can and cannot do, and what is the allowed way to do it?
gold_answer: The rules set a baseline ban: a person is not allowed to make an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or to have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange unless the Regulations themselves allow it. [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a] For Issuers, the restriction is described in the specific context of “Offers of Securities to the Public” made in or from ADGM, and it also covers the scenario where the Issuer has Securities admitted to trading on a RIE. [#SRC:5f3625e1-2e7d-4bc8-b5e4-a0649ca42237] The permitted route is not a free choice: the Issuer may only proceed if it does so in accordance with the governing framework identified for these activities. [#SRC:5f3625e1-2e7d-4bc8-b5e4-a0649ca42237] In parallel, the general exception language requires that the Offer or admission must be “provided by or under these Regulations,” so the legal basis must come from the Regulations rather than from the person’s preference. [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a] Putting both together, an Issuer (and any person) must treat Offers in ADGM and admissions to trading as prohibited by default and only proceed where the Regulations permit it and, for Issuers, where the activity is carried out in line with FSMR and MKT. [#SRC:5f3625e1-2e7d-4bc8-b5e4-a0649ca42237] [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a]

question: How should an Authorised Person be categorised where its Financial Services Permission includes Managing Assets and it also undertakes Dealing in Investments as Agent, but only in a way that is wholly incidental to Managing Assets; and how does that interact with the Category 2 test for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal) and the requirement that dealing activities are not limited in scope?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person should be treated as falling within Category 3C (rather than Category 3A) if it carries out Dealing in Investments as Agent only in a manner that is wholly incidental to Managing Assets, and it otherwise meets the Category 3C conditions. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] Category 3C applies where the Financial Services Permission authorises one or more specified Regulated Activities, including Managing Assets, and the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B or 5. [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0] The “wholly incidental” linkage is important because, although Category 3A is generally determined by authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Agent (and the absence of certain other authorisations), the text expressly directs that incidental Dealing in Investments as Agent alongside Managing Assets results in Category 3C treatment. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] Separately, Category 2 is triggered by authorisation for Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal), combined with dealing activities that are not limited in scope, and the firm not meeting Categories 1 or 5. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] Therefore, to remain in Category 3C, the firm must not meet the Category 2 criteria while satisfying the Category 3C conditions tied to Managing Assets and the exclusion of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B and 5. [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0]

question: If an Authorised Person is allowed to do Managing a Collective Investment Fund and also does Dealing in Investments as Agent only as a small, wholly incidental part of that work, which category should it be in, and what would make it Category 2 instead?
gold_answer: It should be regarded as Category 3C if it carries out Dealing in Investments as Agent only in a manner that is wholly incidental to Managing an Investment Fund (or Managing Assets), and it otherwise fits the Category 3C definition. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] Category 3C covers an Authorised Person whose Financial Services Permission authorises one or more listed Regulated Activities, including Managing a Collective Investment Fund, provided it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B or 5. [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0] This means the incidental dealing-as-agent activity does not push the firm into Category 3A, because the text explicitly directs that such incidental Dealing in Investments as Agent is treated as Category 3C when it is tied to Managing an Investment Fund or Managing Assets. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] It would instead be Category 2 if its Financial Services Permission authorises Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal), its dealing activities are not limited in scope, and it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] So, the classification turns on (i) whether the firm meets the Category 3C activity-and-exclusion test and (ii) whether it meets the separate Category 2 principal-dealing/credit test. [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0]

question: For an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4, how does the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum—being a component of the Capital Requirement calculation under Section 3.6—feed into the trigger for notifying the Regulator when Capital Resources decline, and what are the required timing and follow-up steps once the trigger is met?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 must treat the Capital Requirement as the benchmark for the notification trigger, and that Capital Requirement includes the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum as one component of its calculation under Section 3.6. [#SRC:596309d5-cc1a-4a45-9e6d-2042ff11da76] The notification obligation is triggered when the firm’s Capital Resources fall below 120% of that Capital Requirement (as calculated, including the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum component). [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d] Once the threshold is breached, the firm must notify the Regulator immediately and then provide a written confirmation of that notification. [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d] Because the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum is relevant to determining whether the Regulator has to be notified under Rule 3.20.2, the firm should ensure that this component is properly reflected in the Capital Requirement figure used to assess whether Capital Resources have dropped below the 120% level. [#SRC:596309d5-cc1a-4a45-9e6d-2042ff11da76] In practical terms, the firm’s compliance assessment should link (i) the Section 3.6 Capital Requirement computation (including the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum) to (ii) the immediate notification and written confirmation steps required upon falling below 120% of that computed requirement. [#SRC:596309d5-cc1a-4a45-9e6d-2042ff11da76] [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d]

question: If an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 is checking whether it needs to tell the Regulator about low Capital Resources, how should it use the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum (as part of the Capital Requirement under Section 3.6), and what exactly must it do when Capital Resources drop too far?
gold_answer: To decide whether it must notify the Regulator, an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 needs to compare its Capital Resources to its Capital Requirement, and that Capital Requirement is calculated under Section 3.6 with the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum included as a component. [#SRC:596309d5-cc1a-4a45-9e6d-2042ff11da76] The notification trigger occurs when Capital Resources fall below 120% of the Capital Requirement (meaning the 120% test is applied to the Capital Requirement figure that includes the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum component). [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d] When that happens, the firm must notify the Regulator immediately and then confirm the notification in writing. [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d] Because the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum is specifically described as relevant to determining whether the Regulator has to be notified under Rule 3.20.2, the firm should ensure it is using the correct Capital Requirement calculation when applying the 120% threshold. [#SRC:596309d5-cc1a-4a45-9e6d-2042ff11da76] Put together, the compliance steps are: compute the Capital Requirement under Section 3.6 (including the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum), monitor Capital Resources against 120% of that amount, and if the firm falls below, notify immediately and follow up with written confirmation. [#SRC:596309d5-cc1a-4a45-9e6d-2042ff11da76] [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d]

question: Where a Listed Entity issues Securities under a dividend or distribution plan (including an issue under an agreement to Underwrite the shortfall), what disclosure pathway must be used, and what timing and pre-disclosure conditions apply to the issue?
gold_answer: The Listed Entity’s issue of Securities in this scenario must be supported by the specific pre-disclosure and timing conditions for the dividend/distribution plan (including any Underwriting shortfall arrangement), and the relevant disclosure must be made using the Rule 7.7.1 disclosure mechanism for the matters specified in APP 2. [#TGT:6cfc6a56-abb6-4c69-abdb-4c43dd17c326] In particular, where the issue is under an agreement to Underwrite the shortfall on a dividend or distribution plan, the details of the Underwriting agreement must have been Disclosed before the dividend or distribution payment date, using the disclosure route referenced for that pre-disclosure (Rule 3.8.1 or 7.6.1). [#SRC:2d5c5459-6ae1-4b60-9b4f-4f9784697558] The Listed Entity must also complete the issue within 15 Business Days after the date for payment of the dividend or distribution. [#SRC:2d5c5459-6ae1-4b60-9b4f-4f9784697558] Separately, to the extent the Listed Entity is also a Reporting Entity, it must Disclose (in accordance with Rule 7.7.1) the matters specified in APP 2 as part of its disclosure obligations. [#TGT:6cfc6a56-abb6-4c69-abdb-4c43dd17c326] Together, this means the entity must both satisfy the plan/Underwriting-specific preconditions and timing, and use the Rule 7.7.1 pathway for APP 2 matters where applicable. [#SRC:2d5c5459-6ae1-4b60-9b4f-4f9784697558][#TGT:6cfc6a56-abb6-4c69-abdb-4c43dd17c326]

question: If a Listed Entity is issuing Securities because of a dividend or distribution plan, and there is an Underwriting agreement for any shortfall, what has to be disclosed before the payment date, when must the issue happen, and what rule is used to disclose the APP 2 matters for a Reporting Entity?
gold_answer: For an issue of Securities connected to a dividend or distribution plan, the key compliance points are (1) whether the issue is tied to an Underwriting shortfall agreement and (2) whether the entity also has Reporting Entity disclosure duties. [#SRC:2d5c5459-6ae1-4b60-9b4f-4f9784697558][#TGT:6cfc6a56-abb6-4c69-abdb-4c43dd17c326] If the issue is under an agreement to Underwrite the shortfall on the plan, the details of that Underwriting agreement must have been Disclosed before the dividend or distribution payment date, using the disclosure route identified for that purpose (Rule 3.8.1 or 7.6.1). [#SRC:2d5c5459-6ae1-4b60-9b4f-4f9784697558] After the payment date, the Listed Entity must make the issue within 15 Business Days. [#SRC:2d5c5459-6ae1-4b60-9b4f-4f9784697558] In addition, where the entity is a Reporting Entity, it must Disclose the matters specified in APP 2, and it must do so in accordance with Rule 7.7.1. [#TGT:6cfc6a56-abb6-4c69-abdb-4c43dd17c326] Practically, this means you check the Underwriting pre-disclosure and the 15 Business Day issuance window, and you also ensure APP 2 matters are disclosed via Rule 7.7.1 when the Reporting Entity obligation applies. [#SRC:2d5c5459-6ae1-4b60-9b4f-4f9784697558][#TGT:6cfc6a56-abb6-4c69-abdb-4c43dd17c326]

question: For a Recognised Clearing House that is providing Central Counterparty Services, which specific Rule governs stress testing of capital, and what must the Recognised Clearing House do with the results of those stress tests in relation to its total financial resources?
gold_answer: For a Recognised Clearing House that is providing Central Counterparty Services, the stress testing of capital requirement is located in Rule 4.6. [#SRC:6112097d-0f5d-40e8-9a64-1aa7b6b520a6] In applying that stress testing framework, the Recognised Clearing House is required to use the stress test results as an input to assess whether its total financial resources are sufficient, and it must then change those resources where the evaluation indicates that adjustments are appropriate. [#TGT:3e191799-f7b9-49c8-84c3-cfefdc35ed2e] This means the stress testing activity is not merely performed for monitoring purposes; it must feed into an adequacy evaluation of total financial resources and, where warranted, lead to responsive action to recalibrate those resources. [#TGT:3e191799-f7b9-49c8-84c3-cfefdc35ed2e] The scope of this obligation is tied to the Recognised Clearing House’s provision of Central Counterparty Services, for which the applicable requirements are identified as including Rule 4.6 alongside other specified areas (credit risk, collateral and margin, and segregation and portability). [#SRC:6112097d-0f5d-40e8-9a64-1aa7b6b520a6]

question: If a Recognised Clearing House is providing Central Counterparty Services, where do the rules say stress testing of capital sits, and how should the Recognised Clearing House use the stress test results when checking whether it has enough total financial resources?
gold_answer: When a Recognised Clearing House is providing Central Counterparty Services, the rules identify Rule 4.6 as the place where stress testing of capital is addressed. [#SRC:6112097d-0f5d-40e8-9a64-1aa7b6b520a6] The Recognised Clearing House must then take the outputs from those stress tests and apply them to a specific purpose: evaluating whether its total financial resources are adequate. [#TGT:3e191799-f7b9-49c8-84c3-cfefdc35ed2e] If that evaluation shows the resources are not adequate (or could be improved), it must make adjustments that are appropriate in light of the stress test results. [#TGT:3e191799-f7b9-49c8-84c3-cfefdc35ed2e] This requirement sits within the set of requirements that apply to a Recognised Clearing House providing Central Counterparty Services, which includes Rule 4.6 as well as other specified rule areas (credit risk, collateral and margin, and segregation and portability). [#SRC:6112097d-0f5d-40e8-9a64-1aa7b6b520a6] In practice, the stress testing work under Rule 4.6 must be connected to a decision process about the level of total financial resources and whether changes are needed. [#TGT:3e191799-f7b9-49c8-84c3-cfefdc35ed2e]

question: For the purposes of an investigation, how may the Investigator exercise the power to require a person to attend an interview and answer questions, and what additional requirements can be included in the same written notice (including any conditions on time, place, or premises access)?
gold_answer: The Investigator’s power to compel interview attendance is exercised for the purposes of an investigation by requiring a person (the interviewee) to attend an interview and answer questions. [#SRC:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf] In operational terms, the Investigator may implement that power by issuing a written notice to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, including someone not connected to the Person Under Investigation, requiring them to attend an interview at a specified time and place and answer questions. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] The same written notice can also impose additional, distinct requirements that support the investigation, including: producing specified documents (or documents of a specified description) at a specified time and place; providing information; providing assistance; and permitting entry to the person’s business premises during normal business hours so the Investigator can inspect and copy documents located there. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] Accordingly, when the Investigator uses the interview power for investigative purposes, the notice can combine the interview obligation with document, information, assistance, and premises-access obligations, each framed with the timing/place parameters or business-hours condition stated for that requirement. [#SRC:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]

question: If the Investigator is running an investigation, who can be told to come to an interview and answer questions, and what else can the Investigator ask for in the same written notice (including when and where things must happen)?
gold_answer: In an investigation, the Investigator can require a person (the interviewee) to attend an interview and answer questions for the purposes of that investigation. [#SRC:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf] The Investigator can do this by sending a written notice to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, even if that other person is not connected to the Person Under Investigation, telling them to attend an interview at a specified time and place and answer questions. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] That same written notice can also require additional cooperation steps, such as producing specified documents (or documents of a specified description) at a specified time and place, providing information, and providing assistance. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] It can also require the person to allow the Investigator to enter the person’s business premises during normal business hours so the Investigator can inspect and copy documents kept there. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] Taken together, the investigative interview requirement can be paired with these other notice-based requirements, with the notice setting the relevant specified time/place or the normal-business-hours condition, as applicable. [#SRC:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]

question: For a Listed Entity that has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities, how should it determine whether it must apply the restriction in APP 7, and how does the carve-out for categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 operate when the entity qualifies under Rule 2.3.15 or meets the Regulator’s profitability/revenue or tangible-asset criteria?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity that has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities is required to apply the restriction in APP 7 (or any other restrictions the Regulator chooses to impose) as the baseline obligation. [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f] However, when assessing what parts of APP 7 must be applied, the entity must also consider the specific non-application rule for certain APP 7 categories, which can remove the need to apply categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 unless the Regulator decides otherwise. [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac] In practice, the entity should: (i) confirm it is within scope because it has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities; (ii) start from the requirement to apply APP 7 restrictions (or other restrictions set by the Regulator); and then (iii) test whether it meets any of the qualifying conditions that switch off the listed APP 7 categories. [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f] The categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply if the Listed Entity qualifies for admission to the Official List under Rule 2.3.15, or has a profitability/revenue track record acceptable to the Regulator, or (in the Regulator’s opinion) has tangible assets with readily ascertainable value forming a substantial proportion of total asset value—unless the Regulator decides otherwise. [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]

question: If a Listed Entity plans to issue Restricted Securities, does it always have to apply APP 7 restrictions, or can some APP 7 categories be switched off when it qualifies under Rule 2.3.15 or meets the Regulator’s profitability/revenue or tangible-asset test?
gold_answer: The starting point is that a Listed Entity that has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities must apply the restriction in APP 7, unless the Regulator uses its discretion to require different restrictions. [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f] But that baseline obligation is narrowed by a specific carve-out: unless the Regulator decides otherwise, the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply for certain Listed Entities. [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac] To decide what to apply, the entity should check whether it meets any of the carve-out conditions while still recognizing that APP 7 is the default restriction framework for Restricted Securities. [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f] The carve-out applies if the Listed Entity (1) qualifies for admission to the Official List under Rule 2.3.15, or (2) has a track record of profitability or revenue that the Regulator accepts, or (3) in the Regulator’s opinion has tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value that make up a substantial proportion of the total value of its assets—unless the Regulator decides otherwise. [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac] This means the entity may still need to apply other APP 7 restrictions (or other restrictions the Regulator sets), but the listed categories can be disapplied when the conditions are met. [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f] [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]

question: Where an Authorised Person’s ability to maintain the minimum Leverage Ratio is threatened, what immediate notification duty is triggered, and how does the Tier 1 Capital requirement inform whether the Authorised Person is likely not to hold the amount and quality of capital needed to comply with Rule 3.21.3?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must provide an immediate written notification to the Regulator when it does not hold, or expects it will not hold, the amount and quality of capital needed to comply with Rule 3.21.3. [#SRC:cb563a7f-d8cf-4245-afdb-e5c995f3df81] In assessing whether that notification trigger is met, the Authorised Person must take into account its obligation to hold sufficient Tier 1 Capital so that it can maintain, at all times, at least a 3% Leverage Ratio (or a different level if the Regulator sets one). [#TGT:e9e2bf18-6110-4e9f-8060-c59b85e5cd8e] If the Authorised Person’s Tier 1 Capital position is such that it cannot maintain the required minimum Leverage Ratio on a continuous basis, that circumstance is relevant to whether it is likely not to hold the necessary capital amount and quality for Rule 3.21.3, and therefore whether the immediate notification obligation is engaged. [#TGT:e9e2bf18-6110-4e9f-8060-c59b85e5cd8e] [#SRC:cb563a7f-d8cf-4245-afdb-e5c995f3df81] The notification must be made immediately and in writing, and it is triggered by either an actual shortfall or a likely future shortfall in the required capital position. [#SRC:cb563a7f-d8cf-4245-afdb-e5c995f3df81]

question: If an Authorised Person thinks it might not be able to keep the required Leverage Ratio because of its Tier 1 Capital level, what does it have to tell the Regulator, and how quickly?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person does not have, or expects it may not have, the amount and quality of capital needed to comply with Rule 3.21.3, it must notify the Regulator immediately and the notice must be in writing. [#SRC:cb563a7f-d8cf-4245-afdb-e5c995f3df81] This matters in practice because the Authorised Person is required to hold enough Tier 1 Capital to maintain a minimum Leverage Ratio of 3% at all times, unless the Regulator sets a different minimum. [#TGT:e9e2bf18-6110-4e9f-8060-c59b85e5cd8e] So, if the Authorised Person’s Tier 1 Capital position indicates it cannot keep that minimum Leverage Ratio continuously, that is a concrete sign it may be likely not to hold the capital needed for Rule 3.21.3, which is exactly the situation that triggers the immediate written notification duty. [#TGT:e9e2bf18-6110-4e9f-8060-c59b85e5cd8e] [#SRC:cb563a7f-d8cf-4245-afdb-e5c995f3df81] The trigger is not limited to an actual breach; it also covers a forward-looking risk that the required capital position will not be maintained. [#SRC:cb563a7f-d8cf-4245-afdb-e5c995f3df81]

question: When the Investigator uses a written notice to require a person to “provide such information as the Investigator may require,” how broadly should “information” be understood, and how does that breadth affect what the person may need to supply in response to interview questions or other requests in the notice?
gold_answer: “Information” should be read expansively, so a written notice requiring a person to provide information can legitimately call for many different forms of content, not just formal documents. [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32] In practice, where the Investigator issues a written notice to the Person Under Investigation or any other person (even if not connected) requiring them to provide information, attend an interview and answer questions, or take other steps, the recipient should treat “information” as covering a wide range of material that can be supplied in response to those requirements. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] This broad scope includes, for example: knowledge communicated or received about a matter; knowledge gained through work or study; computer-processed data at any stage (input, output, storage, or transmission); explanations or statements; identification details about a person, matter, or thing; and direct responses to questions. [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32] Because the notice can also require attendance at an interview at a specified time and place to answer questions, the recipient should be prepared to provide “information” in the form of verbal answers and explanations, not only in written form. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] The key compliance takeaway is to map each notice requirement to this broad meaning so the response captures all requested knowledge, data, identifications, and statements. [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]

question: If the Investigator serves a written notice on a person (including someone not connected to the Person Under Investigation) requiring them to answer questions at an interview and to provide information, what types of content can fall within “information,” including any computer-related data, and why?
gold_answer: A written notice can require the Person Under Investigation or any other person (whether or not connected) to attend an interview at a specified time and place and answer questions, and it can also require that person to provide information the Investigator requires. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] The content that can qualify as “information” for these purposes is intentionally broad and should be understood according to its ordinary meaning rather than being limited to a narrow category. [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32] Accordingly, when preparing for the interview and any accompanying information request, the recipient should treat “information” as potentially including: (i) knowledge communicated or received about a particular matter, fact, or circumstance; (ii) knowledge gained through work, commerce, study, communication, research, or instruction; (iii) computer-derived data produced by processing input data with a program, as well as data at any stage of processing, including input, output, storage, or transmission; (iv) explanations or statements about a matter; (v) identification of a person, matter, or thing; and (vi) responses to questions. [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32] This breadth matters because the notice-driven interview obligation to “answer questions” can be satisfied by providing information in the form of explanations, identifications, and direct responses, including where the relevant content is embodied in computer-processed data rather than traditional narrative descriptions. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]

question: When evaluating interest rate risk arising from Non Trading Book activities, how must an Authorised Person determine which currencies are “material currencies” for purposes of measuring risk Exposures in each currency, and what quantitative threshold applies to Non Trading Book assets or liabilities?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must evaluate its Exposure to interest rate risk that arises from its Non Trading Book activities, and where it has balance sheet positions in different currencies it must measure its risk Exposures separately in each material currency. [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3] For purposes of identifying which currencies are “material currencies” in this context, the Authorised Person should treat as material each currency that represents 5% or more of its Non Trading Book assets or 5% or more of its Non Trading Book liabilities. [#SRC:fa74198b-0ce3-4a0c-a1a1-e2a3e719df28] Practically, this means the evaluation of interest rate risk must be supported by a currency-by-currency measurement approach whenever multiple currencies are present on the balance sheet, but the measurement obligation is focused on those currencies meeting the 5% materiality threshold based on Non Trading Book assets or liabilities. [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3] [#SRC:fa74198b-0ce3-4a0c-a1a1-e2a3e719df28] The threshold is applied by reference to the Authorised Person’s Non Trading Book positions (assets and liabilities), and the resulting set of material currencies defines the minimum set of currencies in which risk Exposures must be measured for the interest rate risk evaluation. [#SRC:fa74198b-0ce3-4a0c-a1a1-e2a3e719df28] [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3]

question: If an Authorised Person has Non Trading Book positions in more than one currency, what does it have to do about interest rate risk, and how do you decide which currencies count as “material” for measuring the risk?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person has balance sheet positions in different currencies, it must evaluate its Exposure to the interest rate risk coming from its Non Trading Book activities and measure its risk Exposures in each material currency. [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3] To decide which currencies are “material” for that measurement, the Authorised Person should treat a currency as material if it makes up at least 5% of its Non Trading Book assets or at least 5% of its Non Trading Book liabilities. [#SRC:fa74198b-0ce3-4a0c-a1a1-e2a3e719df28] In other words, the interest rate risk evaluation is not done only in aggregate across all currencies; it requires a separate measurement in each currency that meets the 5% threshold based on Non Trading Book assets or liabilities. [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3] [#SRC:fa74198b-0ce3-4a0c-a1a1-e2a3e719df28] This approach links the scope of the required currency-by-currency risk measurement to a defined materiality test, so that the set of currencies requiring measurement is determined by the size of each currency’s share of Non Trading Book assets or liabilities. [#SRC:fa74198b-0ce3-4a0c-a1a1-e2a3e719df28] [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3]

question: When a Third Party Provider reserves the right to stop or prevent a Third Party Transaction from being executed under the Governing Contract, what must the Third Party Provider do upon refusing a Third Party Transaction, and how must the contract frame the communication method for that refusal?
gold_answer: If a Third Party Provider refuses a Third Party Transaction (including where it has reserved a contractual right to stop or prevent execution), it must issue a refusal notification using the agreed manner specified for such notifications. [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575] The Governing Contract must therefore set out, unless otherwise agreed in writing between the Third Party Provider and their Customer, the means of communication the parties have agreed for transmitting information or notifications, including any relevant technical requirements for the Customer’s equipment and software. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] In addition, because the contract must describe the conditions under which the Third Party Provider proposes to reserve the right to stop or prevent a Third Party Transaction from being executed, the refusal-notification process should operate within that stated contractual context (i.e., the refusal occurs when those conditions are met). [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] Practically, compliance should ensure the refusal notification is delivered through the contractually agreed channel and in the agreed manner, and that the contract’s communication section and the “stop/prevent” conditions are consistent with how refusals will be communicated. [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575] [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]

question: If the contract says the Third Party Provider can stop a Third Party Transaction, what does the Third Party Provider have to do when it actually refuses a transaction, and what does the contract need to say about how that message is sent?
gold_answer: When a Third Party Provider refuses a Third Party Transaction, it must send a refusal notification in the agreed manner. [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575] To make that workable, the Governing Contract (unless the Third Party Provider and their Customer otherwise agree in writing) must include the agreed means of communication for sending information or notifications, including any technical requirements for the Customer’s equipment and software to receive them. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] The same contract must also describe, where relevant, the conditions under which the Third Party Provider proposes to reserve the right to stop or prevent a Third Party Transaction from being executed, so the refusal and the notification occur within those stated conditions. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] In practice, this means the refusal message should be sent through the communication channel the contract identifies, and the contract should clearly connect the “stop/prevent” conditions to the operational step of issuing the refusal notification in the agreed manner. [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575] [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]

question: When an Authorised Person is considering recognising a guarantee for credit risk mitigation where the guarantor is an MDB, how should the Authorised Person identify whether the guarantor is an eligible guarantor and, if the exposure is directly to that MDB, what risk weight must be applied to the CR Exposure?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may treat a guarantee as eligible for credit risk mitigation when the guarantor is an MDB that falls within the MDBs referenced for guarantee eligibility, and the Authorised Person should determine this by checking whether the MDB is one of the qualifying MDBs listed for the MDB asset class. [#SRC:bedaa8b8-4488-4156-9886-a8e1e2edd6b8] [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4] Where the relevant MDB is among the qualifying MDBs (for example, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) or the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD)), the Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to that MDB. [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4] In practical terms, this means the same MDB list used to determine which MDB exposures receive a 0% risk weight also provides the concrete set of MDB names that can be used to confirm the MDB is within the category of MDBs that may be recognised as guarantors for guarantee-based credit risk mitigation. [#SRC:bedaa8b8-4488-4156-9886-a8e1e2edd6b8] [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4] This linkage is limited to MDBs: other eligible guarantor categories (such as PSEs or certain international institutions) are separate from the MDB list and are not needed to determine the 0% risk weight for qualifying MDB exposures. [#SRC:bedaa8b8-4488-4156-9886-a8e1e2edd6b8]

question: If an Authorised Person wants to count a guarantee from an MDB, which MDB names can they use to confirm it fits the MDB category, and what risk weight applies if the Authorised Person has a CR Exposure to that same MDB?
gold_answer: To use an MDB as a guarantor for credit risk mitigation, the Authorised Person needs the guarantor to fall within the MDB category that is permitted for recognised guarantees, and the practical way to confirm the MDB is to match it to the qualifying MDBs that are explicitly named for the MDB asset class. [#SRC:bedaa8b8-4488-4156-9886-a8e1e2edd6b8] [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4] The qualifying MDB names include, among others, the World Bank Group entities (IBRD, MIGA, and IFC), the African Development Bank (AfDB), and the Islamic Development Bank (IDB). [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4] If the Authorised Person’s position is a CR Exposure to one of these qualifying MDBs (i.e., the exposure is to the MDB itself), the Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to that exposure. [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4] This connects the guarantee-recognition concept (MDBs are an eligible guarantor type) with the exposure treatment concept (qualifying MDB exposures receive a 0% risk weight), using the same concrete list of MDB institutions to identify the relevant MDB. [#SRC:bedaa8b8-4488-4156-9886-a8e1e2edd6b8] [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4]

question: When seeking the Regulator’s approval to replace a Trustee, what specific submissions must the Fund Manager provide, and how should the Fund Manager assess whether the proposed replacement Trustee satisfies the independence standard (including the listed non-independence relationships) in addition to meeting the FSMR eligibility requirement referenced in the approval condition?
gold_answer: To obtain the Regulator’s approval to replace a Trustee, the Fund Manager must submit a written notice stating its intention to remove the Trustee and must support that notice either with a certification that the removal will not harm Unitholders’ interests and will not impair the Fund Manager’s ability to comply with the Trust Deed, Prospectus, these Rules and the FSMR, or with a Special Resolution of Unitholders approving both the removal and the replacement. [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2] The application must also include the written consent of the person agreeing to act as the replacement Trustee, and the Fund Manager must ensure that person meets the requirements for a Trustee in Section 114(2) of the FSMR to be able to act in that role. [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2] In parallel, because the Trustee of an Investment Trust must be independent of the Fund Manager, the Fund Manager should evaluate the proposed replacement Trustee against the specific circumstances that negate independence. [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c] Independence is not present if there are cross-shareholdings or voting rights, a common holding company or ultimate holding company, overlapping Directors on the Governing Body, shared individuals performing Controlled Functions, or professional/material business dealings within the previous two years (other than acting as Fund Manager/Trustee for other funds). [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c]

question: If a Fund Manager wants to remove a Trustee and appoint a new one, what paperwork must be sent to the Regulator, and what kinds of links between the Fund Manager and the new Trustee would mean the new Trustee is not independent?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager must give the Regulator a written notice saying it intends to remove the Trustee, and it must include either (i) a certification that the change will not negatively affect Unitholders’ interests and will not undermine the Fund Manager’s ability to comply with the Trust Deed, Prospectus, these Rules and the FSMR, or (ii) a Special Resolution of Unitholders approving the removal and the replacement with another Trustee. [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2] The Fund Manager must also provide the written consent of the person who will be the replacement Trustee and confirm that person meets the requirements for a Trustee in Section 114(2) of the FSMR to be able to act as replacement Trustee. [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2] Separately, the Trustee must be independent of the Fund Manager, so the Fund Manager should check that none of the listed relationships exist between it and the proposed replacement Trustee. [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c] The new Trustee would not be independent if either party holds or votes Shares of the other, they share a common holding company (or ultimate holding company), they have Directors who sit on both Governing Bodies, they share individuals performing Controlled Functions, or they have had professional or material business dealings in the last two years (other than acting as Fund Manager/Trustee for other funds). [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c]

question: When an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business intends to pay, or permit to be paid, Client Money to a Third-Party Agent, what specific Third-Party Agent documentation must be included in the Resolution Pack to evidence the required prior suitability assessment and related acknowledgement for Client Money?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may only pay, or allow payment of, Client Money to a Third-Party Agent if it has first assessed that Third-Party Agent’s suitability and reached a reasonable conclusion that the agent is suitable to hold Client Money in a Client Account. [#TGT:7ec4ca22-df40-4fb5-ae3b-c48036500143] To evidence that prerequisite in the Resolution Pack, the Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must include the records specified for Third-Party Agents in relation to Client Money, namely the assessment of appropriateness of the Third-Party Agent and the Third-Party Agent’s acknowledgement in respect of Client Money. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] Practically, this means the Resolution Pack should contain documentation showing (i) the prior assessment performed before any payment/permitted payment of Client Money to the Third-Party Agent and (ii) the acknowledgement obtained from that Third-Party Agent regarding Client Money. [#TGT:7ec4ca22-df40-4fb5-ae3b-c48036500143] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] This linkage is important because the payment permission is conditioned on a prior suitability conclusion, and the Resolution Pack requirement identifies the specific records that demonstrate the assessment and acknowledgement for Client Money. [#TGT:7ec4ca22-df40-4fb5-ae3b-c48036500143] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]

question: If an Authorised Person wants to let Client Money be paid to a Third-Party Agent, what must they do first, and what related items have to be kept in the Resolution Pack to show they met that condition?
gold_answer: Before Client Money is paid (or allowed to be paid) to a Third-Party Agent, the Authorised Person must carry out a prior assessment of the Third-Party Agent’s suitability and, on reasonable grounds, decide the Third-Party Agent is suitable to hold Client Money in a Client Account. [#TGT:7ec4ca22-df40-4fb5-ae3b-c48036500143] To show that this condition has been met, the Resolution Pack for an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must include the specific Third-Party Agent records for Client Money: the assessment of appropriateness of the Third-Party Agent and the Third-Party Agent’s acknowledgement in respect of Client Money. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] In other words, the Resolution Pack should contain evidence of the assessment that was done before any payment/permitted payment, and it should also contain the acknowledgement obtained from the Third-Party Agent about Client Money. [#TGT:7ec4ca22-df40-4fb5-ae3b-c48036500143] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] This ties the “prior assessment and reasonable conclusion” requirement for paying Client Money to a Third-Party Agent to the concrete Resolution Pack contents that document that assessment and acknowledgement. [#TGT:7ec4ca22-df40-4fb5-ae3b-c48036500143] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]

question: Where an Exposure is partially guaranteed by an Authorised Person's Parent Financial Institution and only the guaranteed portion would attract a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, how should the Authorised Person apply the 25% of Tier 1 Large Exposures limit for its Non Trading Book (and, as applicable, Trading Book) after recognising eligible CRM—specifically, which portion is excluded from the Large Exposure limit and which portion remains subject to the limit?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person should apply the 25% of Tier 1 Large Exposures limit to the Exposure after recognising eligible CRM, but it may exclude only the portion of the Exposure that is covered by the parental guarantee (and that would receive the lower risk weight under Section 4.12). [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] The exemption is not an all-or-nothing treatment: if the Exposure is only partially guaranteed by an Authorised Person's Parent Financial Institution, only the guaranteed part is exempt from the Large Exposure limit in Rule 4.15.5, while the unguaranteed remainder continues to count toward the Large Exposures limit. [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3] In practical terms, the Authorised Person should (i) identify the Exposure and determine the portion subject to the parental guarantee, (ii) confirm that the guaranteed portion is the part that would be assigned a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, and (iii) apply the Large Exposures limit to the remaining portion in the relevant book (Non Trading Book and, where applicable, Trading Book) after taking into account eligible CRM. [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3] [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] The Authorised Person may also consider exemptions permitted under Rule 4.15.18 relating to parental guarantees when assessing this treatment. [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3]

question: If an Exposure is only partly covered by an Authorised Person's Parent Financial Institution guarantee, and the guaranteed part would get a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, does the 25% of Tier 1 Large Exposures cap apply to the whole Exposure or only to the part not covered by the guarantee (after eligible CRM and for the Non Trading Book/Trading Book as relevant)?
gold_answer: The 25% of Tier 1 Large Exposures cap applies to what remains of the Exposure once you have taken into account eligible CRM, but you can leave out only the part that is actually covered by the parental guarantee (and that would receive the lower risk weight under Section 4.12). [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] The rule on exempt exposures is limited to the guaranteed slice: when an Exposure is partially guaranteed by an Authorised Person's Parent Financial Institution, only the portion subject to that guarantee is exempt from the Large Exposure limit in Rule 4.15.5, and the rest of the Exposure is still counted for Large Exposures purposes. [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3] This means you should separate the Exposure into guaranteed and unguaranteed parts, exclude only the guaranteed part from the Large Exposure limit, and then test the remaining part against the 25% of Tier 1 limit in the Non Trading Book (and, subject to the stated Trading Book condition, in the Trading Book). [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3] [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] When doing this assessment, the Authorised Person may also consider exemptions permitted under Rule 4.15.18 relating to parental guarantees. [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3]

question: How must an Authorised Person operationalise the requirement that the sum of its Large Exposures does not exceed 800% of its Tier 1, including the specific identification, measurement, aggregation, monitoring, and breach-notification steps that must be performed to manage that cap?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must run a Large Exposures control framework that both calculates exposures relative to Tier 1 and keeps the total of Large Exposures within the 800% of Tier 1 ceiling. [#TGT:342299bc-1d26-4555-9104-cf3347054697] To do this, it must first identify its Exposures and the relevant Counterparties, including whether Counterparties are Closely Related to each other or Connected to the Authorised Person, because those relationships affect how exposures are grouped for control purposes. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] It must then measure the size and establish the value of its Exposures, and determine each Exposure’s size as a proportion of its Tier 1, so that the Tier 1-based limit can be assessed. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] It must also identify Exposures subject to Section 4.13 (CRM) and identify any Exposures exempt under Section A4.11 from the limits in Rules 4.15.4 to 4.15.7, while still ensuring the overall sum of Large Exposures remains within the 800% cap. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] Operationally, it must aggregate Exposures to the same Counterparty or to groups of Closely Related or Connected Counterparties, monitor and control Exposures daily within the Large Exposures limits, and immediately notify the Regulator of any breach and confirm the breach in writing. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675]

question: If an Authorised Person is trying to stay under the rule that total Large Exposures must not be more than 800% of Tier 1, what day-to-day steps does it have to take (like grouping counterparties, calculating exposures vs Tier 1, and what to do if it goes over)?
gold_answer: To comply, an Authorised Person must ensure the combined total of its Large Exposures stays at or below 800% of its Tier 1. [#TGT:342299bc-1d26-4555-9104-cf3347054697] Doing that requires a set of daily controls that start with mapping what counts toward the limit: it must identify its Exposures and identify its Counterparties, including checking whether any Counterparties are Closely Related to each other or Connected to the Authorised Person, because those links drive how exposures are grouped. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] It must measure the size of its Exposures, establish their value, and calculate each Exposure as a proportion of Tier 1 so it can manage the Tier 1-based cap. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] It must aggregate Exposures to the same Counterparty and to groups of Closely Related or Connected Counterparties, then monitor and control Exposures on a daily basis within the Large Exposures limits so the total remains within 800% of Tier 1. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] It also has to identify whether any Exposures are subject to Section 4.13 (CRM) and which Exposures are exempt under Section A4.11 from the limits in Rules 4.15.4 to 4.15.7, while still managing the overall Large Exposures total. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] If the limits are breached, it must notify the Regulator immediately and then confirm the breach in writing. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675]

question: For an Authorised Person operating as a Domestic Firm, what capital-resources and liquidity obligations apply under the Rules, and how does the Section’s allocation of Rules by operating form determine that these obligations apply to a Domestic Firm rather than a Branch?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person operating as a Domestic Firm is subject to the Domestic Firm capital-resources requirements because this Section states that Rules 3.2.3 to 3.2.5 apply to an Authorised Person operating as a Domestic Firm (whereas Rule 3.2.2 applies to an Authorised Person operating as a Branch). [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6] Within that Domestic Firm framework, the Authorised Person must have and maintain, at all times, Capital Resources of the types and amounts specified in, and calculated in accordance with, these Rules. [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56] In addition, it must ensure it maintains capital and liquid assets beyond that baseline requirement that are adequate for the nature, size and complexity of its business, with the objective of avoiding any significant risk that it cannot meet liabilities as they fall due. [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56] The practical implication of the Section’s allocation is that these “Domestic Firms – maintaining capital resources” obligations attach when the Authorised Person operates as a Domestic Firm, and the Branch allocation indicates a different rule set would apply in that operating form. [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6]

question: If an Authorised Person is a Domestic Firm (not a Branch), what does it have to do about capital resources and liquid assets, and why do these duties apply to it under this Section?
gold_answer: These duties apply because the Section says that Rules 3.2.3 to 3.2.5 apply to an Authorised Person operating as a Domestic Firm, while a different rule (Rule 3.2.2) applies to an Authorised Person operating as a Branch. [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6] As a result, an Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must keep Capital Resources continuously: it must have and maintain, at all times, Capital Resources of the types and amounts specified in, and calculated in accordance with, these Rules. [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56] It also has to go further than just meeting that baseline calculation by ensuring it holds additional capital and liquid assets that are adequate for the nature, size and complexity of its business. [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56] The purpose of that extra buffer is to make sure there is no significant risk that the Domestic Firm cannot pay its liabilities when they become due. [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56] This is tied to the operating form because the Section explicitly separates which rules apply to Domestic Firms versus Branches. [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6]

question: When a Trading Halt is imposed pursuant to Rule 7.8.1, what is the maximum duration of that halt, and within what window may the Regulator impose a suspension in relation to that halt?
gold_answer: For a Trading Halt imposed pursuant to Rule 7.8.1, the halt is capped at two Business Days unless the Regulator agrees to a shorter period. [#TGT:88d53574-f94b-4da4-8a47-2afa2fd511db] In relation to that same Rule 7.8.1 Trading Halt, the Regulator has discretion to impose a suspension at any point while the Trading Halt is in effect, meaning the suspension can be imposed during the halt without waiting for the halt to run its full permitted duration. [#SRC:dd30220a-9ed3-4f7f-98aa-99f1bd8dd3da] Read together, this means the outer boundary for how long the Rule 7.8.1 Trading Halt itself may last is two Business Days (or less if the Regulator agrees), but the timing of a suspension decision is not limited to the end of that period and may occur at any time during the halt. [#TGT:88d53574-f94b-4da4-8a47-2afa2fd511db] [#SRC:dd30220a-9ed3-4f7f-98aa-99f1bd8dd3da] The key compliance implication is to treat the Rule 7.8.1 halt duration limit as a separate constraint from the Regulator’s ability to impose a suspension during that halt, because the suspension power operates throughout the halt window rather than only after it expires. [#SRC:dd30220a-9ed3-4f7f-98aa-99f1bd8dd3da] [#TGT:88d53574-f94b-4da4-8a47-2afa2fd511db]

question: If there is a Trading Halt under Rule 7.8.1, how long can it last at most, and can the Regulator impose a suspension before the halt ends?
gold_answer: A Trading Halt that is imposed under Rule 7.8.1 is limited in length: it cannot run for more than two Business Days, unless the Regulator agrees to a shorter time period. [#TGT:88d53574-f94b-4da4-8a47-2afa2fd511db] Separately, during that same Rule 7.8.1 Trading Halt, the Regulator is allowed to impose a suspension at any time while the halt is ongoing, rather than having to wait until the halt finishes. [#SRC:dd30220a-9ed3-4f7f-98aa-99f1bd8dd3da] Putting these points together, you should understand the “two Business Days (or less)” limit as the maximum duration of the Trading Halt itself, while the suspension power can be exercised at any moment within that halt window. [#TGT:88d53574-f94b-4da4-8a47-2afa2fd511db] [#SRC:dd30220a-9ed3-4f7f-98aa-99f1bd8dd3da] This means that even if the Trading Halt is expected to last up to the maximum period, the Regulator can still decide to impose a suspension before the halt reaches its endpoint. [#SRC:dd30220a-9ed3-4f7f-98aa-99f1bd8dd3da] [#TGT:88d53574-f94b-4da4-8a47-2afa2fd511db]
