question: When calculating CET1 Capital, how should an Authorised Person treat (i) unrealised gains or losses on liabilities valued at fair value that arise from changes in its own credit quality, and (ii) any other unrealised gains or losses on assets or liabilities measured at fair value, given the general prohibition on making fair-value adjustments except for items referred to in Rule 3.10.5?
gold_answer: In calculating CET1 Capital, an Authorised Person is required to exclude all unrealised gains or losses on its liabilities that are valued at fair value when those gains or losses result from changes in the Authorised Person’s own credit quality, unless the gains or losses are offset by a change in the fair value of another Financial Instrument that is measured at fair value and that offset also results from changes in the Authorised Person’s own credit quality. [#TGT:6e1d64e5-60c2-4627-af1c-f05e612f92bc] Separately, as a general rule for CET1 adjustments, the Authorised Person must not make adjustments that remove unrealised gains or losses on assets or liabilities measured at fair value from its Capital Resources, except for the items referred to in Rule 3.10.5. [#SRC:977b51e8-a945-4729-87fb-0845f5319ed6] Read together, this means the CET1 calculation must implement the specific exclusion for own-credit-quality-driven fair-value movements on liabilities (subject to the stated offset exception), while otherwise avoiding discretionary “removal” adjustments for fair-value unrealised gains or losses unless the adjustment falls within the Rule 3.10.5 carve-out. [#TGT:6e1d64e5-60c2-4627-af1c-f05e612f92bc] [#SRC:977b51e8-a945-4729-87fb-0845f5319ed6]

question: If an Authorised Person is working out CET1 Capital, what must it take out for (a) increases in equity under International Financial Reporting Standards tied to future margin income or securitisation future income, and how does that fit with the rule that it generally must not adjust away unrealised fair-value gains or losses (except for items in Rule 3.10.5)?
gold_answer: When calculating CET1 Capital, an Authorised Person must exclude certain increases in its equity that arise under the International Financial Reporting Standards, including increases linked to future margin income that produces a gain on sale for the Authorised Person and, where the Authorised Person is the Originator of a securitisation, net gains from capitalising future income from securitised assets that provide Credit Enhancement to positions in the securitisation. [#TGT:6e1d64e5-60c2-4627-af1c-f05e612f92bc] At the same time, the general CET1 adjustment principle is that (other than items referred to in Rule 3.10.5) the Authorised Person must not make adjustments that remove unrealised gains or losses on assets or liabilities measured at fair value from its Capital Resources. [#SRC:977b51e8-a945-4729-87fb-0845f5319ed6] Putting these together, the IFRS-related equity exclusions are mandatory components of the CET1 calculation, while the broader prohibition limits the Authorised Person from making additional fair-value “removal” adjustments beyond what is specifically permitted by the Rule 3.10.5 exception. [#TGT:6e1d64e5-60c2-4627-af1c-f05e612f92bc] [#SRC:977b51e8-a945-4729-87fb-0845f5319ed6]

question: When applying the Large Exposures limit for positions in the Non Trading Book (and, where relevant, the Trading Book), how must an Authorised Person reflect eligible CRM where a Client exposure is (i) secured by third‑party Collateral or (ii) guaranteed by a third party, including any condition about maturity mismatch?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must apply the Large Exposures cap after recognising the effect of eligible credit risk mitigation (CRM), and it must ensure that the resulting Large Exposures in the Non Trading Book (and, subject to the stated Trading Book condition) do not exceed 25% of its Tier 1. [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] Where a Client exposure is supported by a third party, the Authorised Person may re-attribute only the supported portion to the third party—but only if the relevant Collateral or guarantee meets the Section 4.13 (CRM) requirements and would receive a lower risk weight under Section 4.12. [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e] Specifically, the portion secured by third‑party Collateral must be treated as incurred to the third party providing the Collateral (not the Client) for purposes of considering the applicable limits, and the portion covered by a qualifying third‑party guarantee must likewise be treated as incurred to the guarantor (not the Client) for purposes of considering the applicable limits. [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e] In addition, when relying on a guarantee for this treatment, there must be no maturity mismatch between the guarantee and the underlying exposure. [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e]

question: If a Client exposure is partly covered by third‑party Collateral or a third‑party guarantee, how do you work out whether the firm stays under the 25% Tier 1 Large Exposures limit, and what extra check applies if you use a guarantee?
gold_answer: To stay within the Large Exposures limit, an Authorised Person must measure Large Exposures in its Non Trading Book (and, with the stated condition for the Trading Book) after factoring in the effect of any eligible CRM, and it must not exceed 25% of its Tier 1. [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] If the Client exposure is supported by a third party, the firm can treat only the supported portion as an exposure to that third party, but only where the Collateral or guarantee satisfies Section 4.13 (CRM) and would attract a lower risk weight under Section 4.12. [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e] For Collateral, the secured portion must be treated as incurred to the third party providing the Collateral (rather than the Client) when considering the relevant limits. [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e] For a guarantee, the guaranteed portion must be treated as incurred to the guarantor (rather than the Client) when considering the relevant limits, and the firm must also confirm there is no maturity mismatch between the guarantee and the underlying exposure. [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e]

question: For a Listed Entity that qualifies for admission to the Official List under Rule 2.3.15 and has Restricted Securities, how do the Regulator’s discretion to disapply APP 7 restriction categories and the Controller’s need (or not) to be a party to the Rule 9.6.2 Restriction Agreement interact, including any remaining circumstances where the Controller still would not need to be a party?
gold_answer: If the Regulator does not decide otherwise, a Listed Entity that qualifies for admission to the Official List under Rule 2.3.15 is carved out from the application of restrictions in APP 7 categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9, so those category-based restrictions would not apply to that Listed Entity in the first place. [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac] Separately, where a Restriction Agreement under Rule 9.6.2 is relevant, a Controller is not required to be a party to that agreement if any of the specified conditions is met. [#SRC:afb239cd-ac67-4702-8e1d-e5293bccd010] In practice, even for a Listed Entity benefiting from the Regulator’s disapplication of the listed APP 7 categories, the Controller’s non-party status is still supported where (i) the Restricted Security’s value is below 10% of the total assets of the holder or an intermediate entity through which the Controller holds its interest, or (ii) the holder (or such intermediate entity) is itself a Listed Entity (or listed on an exchange that is a full member of the World Federation of Exchanges) or is a trustee, custodian or nominee. [#SRC:afb239cd-ac67-4702-8e1d-e5293bccd010] Additionally, if the holder’s Securities are Restricted Securities because category 2 or 4 applies, the Controller need not be a party—while noting that those categories may be among those the Regulator can disapply for the qualifying Listed Entity. [#SRC:afb239cd-ac67-4702-8e1d-e5293bccd010] [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]

question: If a Listed Entity qualifies for admission under Rule 2.3.15, when do APP 7 restriction categories stop applying, and in that same situation when can a Controller still avoid signing the Rule 9.6.2 Restriction Agreement because of the 10% asset-value test or because the holder is a trustee/custodian/nominee?
gold_answer: For a Listed Entity that qualifies for admission to the Official List under Rule 2.3.15, the restrictions in APP 7 categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 are stated not to apply unless the Regulator decides otherwise. [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac] That category-based disapplication is separate from the rule on who must sign the Restriction Agreement referenced in Rule 9.6.2. [#SRC:afb239cd-ac67-4702-8e1d-e5293bccd010] Under the signing rule, a Controller does not have to be a party to the Restriction Agreement if any listed condition is met, including where the Restricted Security is worth less than 10% of the total asset value of the holder of the Restricted Securities (or of an intermediate entity through which the Controller has its interests). [#SRC:afb239cd-ac67-4702-8e1d-e5293bccd010] The Controller also does not need to sign if the holder (or that intermediate entity) is a trustee, custodian or nominee. [#SRC:afb239cd-ac67-4702-8e1d-e5293bccd010] So, even if the Regulator’s Rule 2.3.15-based carve-out means certain APP 7 restriction categories do not apply to the Listed Entity, the Controller’s ability to avoid being a party to the Rule 9.6.2 Restriction Agreement still depends on meeting one of the specific conditions such as the 10% test or the trustee/custodian/nominee status. [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac] [#SRC:afb239cd-ac67-4702-8e1d-e5293bccd010]

question: For an Applicant that is seeking to be treated as a Listed Entity, how should it align its constitutional arrangements so that it both operates in conformity with its constitution and also enables enforcement of Restriction Agreements?
gold_answer: An Applicant seeking to be treated as a Listed Entity should ensure its constitution both governs its operations and contains provisions that make Restriction Agreements enforceable. [#TGT:0011b198-f2c8-4274-b104-904e8a80b9d0] [#SRC:e54d518f-d9f5-40da-a031-b346bfca2a53] In practical terms, the Applicant’s constitutional framework must support two linked outcomes: (1) the Applicant operates in conformity with its constitution, and (2) the constitution includes the necessary provisions to allow enforcement of Restriction Agreements. [#TGT:0011b198-f2c8-4274-b104-904e8a80b9d0] [#SRC:e54d518f-d9f5-40da-a031-b346bfca2a53] This means the Applicant should review and, where needed, update its constitution so that the relevant constitutional provisions exist and can be applied in practice through the Applicant’s ongoing operations. [#SRC:e54d518f-d9f5-40da-a031-b346bfca2a53] [#TGT:0011b198-f2c8-4274-b104-904e8a80b9d0] The compliance linkage is that operating “in conformity with its constitution” is only meaningful for Restriction Agreements if the constitution itself contains provisions that permit their enforcement; otherwise, conformity would not deliver enforceability. [#TGT:0011b198-f2c8-4274-b104-904e8a80b9d0] [#SRC:e54d518f-d9f5-40da-a031-b346bfca2a53]

question: If an Applicant is properly incorporated and must operate in line with its constitution, what does it need to make sure its constitution includes so that Restriction Agreements can actually be enforced once it is a Listed Entity?
gold_answer: It needs to ensure that its constitution contains provisions that allow Restriction Agreements to be enforced, and then operate in line with that constitution. [#SRC:e54d518f-d9f5-40da-a031-b346bfca2a53] [#TGT:0011b198-f2c8-4274-b104-904e8a80b9d0] The two requirements work together: the Applicant must be operating in conformity with its constitution, but that operational conformity will only support Restriction Agreements if the constitution has the right enforcement-enabling provisions in the first place. [#TGT:0011b198-f2c8-4274-b104-904e8a80b9d0] [#SRC:e54d518f-d9f5-40da-a031-b346bfca2a53] Accordingly, the Applicant should check its constitution for the necessary provisions and, if they are missing, amend the constitution so that enforcement of Restriction Agreements is possible, and then ensure its ongoing conduct follows the constitution as amended. [#SRC:e54d518f-d9f5-40da-a031-b346bfca2a53] [#TGT:0011b198-f2c8-4274-b104-904e8a80b9d0] This aligns the Applicant’s constitutional compliance obligation with the Listed Entity expectation that the constitution supports enforcement of Restriction Agreements. [#TGT:0011b198-f2c8-4274-b104-904e8a80b9d0] [#SRC:e54d518f-d9f5-40da-a031-b346bfca2a53]

question: For an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5 that is Managing a PSIA which is an Unrestricted PSIA, how do the applicable 25% exposure caps operate across (i) Financial Group Large Exposures (including the Financial Group's PSIAus) measured against the Group's Tier 1 and (ii) counterparty exposures measured against Capital Resources, including the financing-based 25%/40% thresholds?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5 must comply with a group-level ceiling on Financial Group Large Exposures and, if it is Managing an Unrestricted PSIA, must also comply with counterparty exposure limits that depend on how the exposure is financed. [#SRC:daaa6de1-3ef9-4148-ae13-789a1bb8a600] [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] At the group level, the Authorised Person is prohibited from incurring any Financial Group Large Exposure (expressly including the Financial Group's PSIAus) above 25% of its Group's Tier 1, and this prohibition applies subject to IFR Rule 5.4.15. [#SRC:daaa6de1-3ef9-4148-ae13-789a1bb8a600] Separately, when Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA, the Authorised Person must ensure its Exposure to a Counterparty, Connected Counterparty, group of Closely Related Counterparties, or group of Connected Counterparties does not exceed specified percentages of its Capital Resources. [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] The applicable percentage is 25% where the exposure is financed by its Capital Resources or Unrestricted PSIAs, and 40% where financed by an aggregate of its own Capital Resources and Unrestricted PSIAs. [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] Accordingly, compliance requires monitoring both the Tier 1-based group cap (including PSIAus) and the Capital Resources-based counterparty caps (with financing determining whether 25% or 40% applies). [#SRC:daaa6de1-3ef9-4148-ae13-789a1bb8a600] [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f]

question: If an Authorised Person is in Category 1, 2 or 5 and it manages an Unrestricted PSIA, what are the two different “25%” limits it has to watch—one tied to the Group’s Tier 1 (including PSIAus) and one tied to Capital Resources for exposures to counterparties—and when can the counterparty limit be 40% instead?
gold_answer: In this situation, the Authorised Person has to track two separate limit frameworks that both include a 25% threshold but use different measurement bases and apply to different exposure types. [#SRC:daaa6de1-3ef9-4148-ae13-789a1bb8a600] [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] First, because it is an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5, it must not incur any Financial Group Large Exposure above 25% of its Group’s Tier 1, and this group-level restriction explicitly includes the Financial Group’s PSIAus (and is stated to operate subject to IFR Rule 5.4.15). [#SRC:daaa6de1-3ef9-4148-ae13-789a1bb8a600] Second, because it is Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA, it must keep its Exposure to a Counterparty, Connected Counterparty, group of Closely Related Counterparties, or group of Connected Counterparties within limits expressed as percentages of its Capital Resources. [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] Under that counterparty framework, the cap is 25% when the exposure is financed by its Capital Resources or Unrestricted PSIAs, but the cap can be 40% when the exposure is financed by an aggregate of its own Capital Resources and Unrestricted PSIAs. [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] The practical takeaway is that the same firm may need to apply a Tier 1-based 25% group cap (including PSIAus) and, separately, a Capital Resources-based counterparty cap that is either 25% or 40% depending on financing. [#SRC:daaa6de1-3ef9-4148-ae13-789a1bb8a600] [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f]

question: In a Framework Contract, when the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, how may the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider contractually handle (i) charges for information requested by the Payment Service User and (ii) the applicability of the specific rule on “charges for information,” and what form must that agreement take?
gold_answer: The Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User can contractually set charges for certain user-requested information, but they can also (if the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person) agree to disapply the specific “charges for information” rules, provided the agreement is in writing. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] In particular, the parties may agree on charges for information supplied at the Payment Service User’s request when that information goes beyond what Section 19.2 requires, is delivered more often than Section 19.2 specifies, or is sent using a communication method different from what the Framework Contract specifies. [#TGT:18f42ca0-235a-47ac-9e8c-47bd6dd631d7] Separately, where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider may agree in writing that Rules 19.2.16 and 19.2.17 (identified as covering charges for information) do not apply. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] Read together, this means the parties can (a) price qualifying “additional/more frequent/alternative channel” information requests, and (b) if eligible, document in writing that the referenced “charges for information” rules are switched off for their relationship. [#TGT:18f42ca0-235a-47ac-9e8c-47bd6dd631d7] [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]

question: If the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, can the Payment Service Provider still charge for extra information the user asks for (like information beyond Section 19.2 or sent in a different way than the Framework Contract), and can the parties also switch off the “charges for information” rules—what must they do to make that happen?
gold_answer: Yes—there are two related contracting options, and the second one depends on the Payment Service User not being a Natural Person. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] First, the Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User may agree on charges for information that the Payment Service User requests when the information is extra compared with what Section 19.2 requires, is provided more often than Section 19.2 sets out, or is delivered using a communication method other than the one specified in the Framework Contract. [#TGT:18f42ca0-235a-47ac-9e8c-47bd6dd631d7] Second, if the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider may agree in writing that Rules 19.2.16 and 19.2.17 (the rules identified as dealing with charges for information) do not apply. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] Putting these together, the parties can either (a) keep the information-charging approach and set the price for those qualifying requests, or (b) where eligible, formally document in writing that the specific “charges for information” rules are not applicable between them. [#TGT:18f42ca0-235a-47ac-9e8c-47bd6dd631d7] [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]

question: When the FSRA expects a "substantial additional" regulatory burden or costs/effort in dealing with an application or ongoing supervision, what should the Applicant/Authorised Person do regarding fee implications, and how does this relate to the Regulator’s ability to require a supplementary fee (including in the example of migrating an MTF to become a conventional "Securities" Recognised Investment Exchange)?
gold_answer: Where a matter creates a “substantial additional” burden for the FSRA/Regulator, the fee outcome can extend beyond standard charges, and the Applicant/Authorised Person should proactively engage early on fee implications. [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc] Specifically, the FSRA indicates it retains the ability to impose additional fees when a “substantial additional” regulatory burden is placed on it, and it highlights migration of an MTF into a conventional “Securities” Recognised Investment Exchange as an example of such a circumstance. [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc] In parallel, the Regulator’s supplementary-fee power is framed around situations where it expects to incur substantial additional costs or to expend substantial additional effort in handling an application, authorisation, filing, or in conducting on-going supervision. [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080] Taken together, the practical compliance step is that, when the Applicant/Authorised Person anticipates a scenario like an MTF migration (or any application/supervision activity likely to drive substantial additional effort), they should discuss fee implications with the FSRA as early as practicable, because the Regulator may respond by requiring a supplementary fee reflecting that additional cost/effort. [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc] [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]

question: If a Person’s application or ongoing supervision will take the Regulator a lot of extra work, what kind of extra fee can be charged, and what does the FSRA recommend the Applicant/Authorised Person do (for example, if an MTF is migrating to a conventional "Securities" Recognised Investment Exchange)?
gold_answer: If the Regulator expects that dealing with a matter will require substantial additional costs or substantial additional effort, it can require the Person to pay a supplementary fee. [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080] The FSRA also signals that it keeps the right to impose additional fees when a “substantial additional” regulatory burden is imposed on it, and it gives the migration of an MTF to become a conventional “Securities” Recognised Investment Exchange as an example of a situation that can trigger this type of fee treatment. [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc] Because these extra-fee tools are tied to the same practical driver—substantial additional burden/cost/effort—the FSRA recommends that the Applicant/Authorised Person raise and discuss fee implications with the FSRA as early as practicable when such a scenario is in view. [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc] This early discussion is the stated action point for the Applicant/Authorised Person, while the supplementary-fee concept explains the type of charge the Regulator may require when the work involved in an application, authorisation, filing, or on-going supervision is materially higher than usual. [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]

question: When assessing whether a Digital Settlement Facility (DSF) has satisfactory arrangements to secure the timely discharge of rights and liabilities under MIR Rule 4.3.3, how should the FSRA treat a situation where a Recognised Clearing House is unable to arrange settlement for a specific transaction, and what DSF arrangements should still be evaluated in that context?
gold_answer: A single instance where a Recognised Clearing House cannot arrange settlement for a particular transaction should not, by itself, be treated as a compliance failure against the applicable recognition standard; that inability alone does not mean the Recognised Clearing House has failed to comply with the Recognition Requirement. [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e] In parallel, when the FSRA is determining under MIR Rule 4.3.3 whether a DSF has satisfactory arrangements to secure the timely discharge of parties’ rights and liabilities, the FSRA should still evaluate the DSF’s own clearing-and-settlement framework and operational controls rather than relying solely on the outcome of one transaction. [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36] This evaluation can include the DSF’s rules and practices for clearing and settlement (including any arrangements with another Person to provide those services), trade-matching arrangements to ensure agreement on trade details, and (where relevant) delivery and payment arrangements across jurisdictions. [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36] The FSRA may also consider the DSF’s procedures to detect and address a Member’s (or participant’s) failure to settle, its arrangements to take action to settle when a Member (or participant) does not, and its monitoring of Members’ settlement performance, including Default Rules and default procedures where appropriate. [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36]

question: If a Recognised Clearing House can’t get one specific transaction settled, does that automatically mean it failed the Recognition Requirement, and what DSF features does the FSRA still look at under MIR Rule 4.3.3 to judge timely settlement arrangements?
gold_answer: No—being unable to arrange settlement for a particular transaction, on its own, does not mean a Recognised Clearing House is treated as failing to comply with the Recognition Requirement. [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e] Even in that situation, the FSRA’s assessment of a DSF under MIR Rule 4.3.3 focuses on whether the DSF has satisfactory arrangements to secure the timely discharge of the rights and liabilities of transaction parties. [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36] To make that determination, the FSRA may look at practical elements of the DSF’s design and operations, including its clearing and settlement rules and practices and any arrangements it has with another Person to provide clearing and settlement services. [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36] The FSRA may also consider how the DSF matches trades and confirms the parties agree on trade details, and (where relevant) how it handles deliveries and payments in the jurisdictions involved. [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36] In addition, the FSRA can review the DSF’s tools for detecting and dealing with settlement failures by a Member (or participant), its arrangements to take action to settle when a Member (or participant) does not, and its monitoring of Members’ settlement performance, including Default Rules and default procedures where appropriate. [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36]

question: For an MTF (using Virtual Assets), which notification obligations drawn from the Recognised Body notification table must it treat as applicable under COBS Rule 17.7.4, and what timing and information must be provided if it proposes to appoint or elect a Person as a Key Individual?
gold_answer: An MTF (using Virtual Assets) must treat certain notification requirements that apply to Recognised Investment Exchanges under MIR Rules 5.1 and 5.3, and certain information requirements under MIR Rule 5.4.1, as additional requirements that also apply to the MTF. [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8] Using the Recognised Body notification table as the operational detail for what a notification looks like in practice, if the MTF proposes to appoint or elect a Person as a Key Individual, the notification must be made at least 30 days before the appointment or election becomes effective, and it must include the Person’s name, date of birth, and a description of the responsibilities in the post. [#TGT:4089ddbd-ee76-45ed-a673-48384237c975] This linkage matters because COBS Rule 17.7.4 extends specified RIE/MIR notification and information requirements to MTFs using Virtual Assets, so the MTF should plan its governance changes (such as Key Individual appointments) to meet the advance-notice timing and content expectations reflected in the table. [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8] In addition, the MTF must also comply with any other applicable notification requirements, including those referenced in paragraph 29 of the Guidance regarding the use of additional Accepted Virtual Assets. [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8]

question: If an MTF (using Virtual Assets) has a Key Individual who resigns, what does COBS Rule 17.7.4 imply about applying the Recognised Body notification approach, and what timing and information does the table require for that resignation notice?
gold_answer: COBS Rule 17.7.4 makes certain notification requirements that apply to Recognised Investment Exchanges under MIR Rules 5.1 and 5.3, and certain information requirements under MIR Rule 5.4.1, apply to MTFs (using Virtual Assets) as additional requirements. [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8] Reading that extension together with the Recognised Body notification table, a resignation (or cessation) of a Key Individual is an event that must be notified as soon as practicable, and the information required for that notice is the Key Individual’s name. [#TGT:4089ddbd-ee76-45ed-a673-48384237c975] The practical compliance outcome is that an MTF using Virtual Assets should treat Key Individual departures as a notifiable governance event and be ready to send a prompt notice containing the required identifier, rather than waiting for periodic reporting. [#TGT:4089ddbd-ee76-45ed-a673-48384237c975] Separately, the MTF must also comply with any other applicable notification requirements, including those referenced in paragraph 29 of the Guidance concerning the use of additional Accepted Virtual Assets, so the MTF should check whether the resignation coincides with any other notifiable changes in its Virtual Asset arrangements. [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8]

question: For an ADGM Green Fund, when does the Fund Manager have to appoint a third party to attest compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement, and how does that obligation change if the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund where the Fund Manager elects to self-attest, or if all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund must generally appoint a third party to attest, on an ongoing basis and at least annually, that it complies with the Green Fund Investment Requirement, but this obligation is limited in scope and can be displaced by specified alternatives. [#SRC:900d63ac-47c0-453a-91f1-79eaee1ab8f1] The third-party appointment requirement applies only to the portion of the Eligible Green Fund Property that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy (i.e., the taxonomy-aligned portion described in connection with Rule 20.2.3(a)). [#SRC:900d63ac-47c0-453a-91f1-79eaee1ab8f1] However, the Fund Manager is not required to appoint a third party if the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund and the Fund Manager elects to provide the attestation itself, in which case the attestation function is performed by the Fund Manager rather than an external party. [#TGT:700ed6a6-3a4a-49b8-8bae-3980c9d36df0] Separately, if all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark (as referenced with Rule 20.2.3(b)), then no attestation is required at all, removing both the third-party and self-attestation pathways for that scenario. [#TGT:700ed6a6-3a4a-49b8-8bae-3980c9d36df0]

question: If a Fund Manager runs an ADGM Green Fund, what part of the Fund’s property needs an ongoing and at least annual third-party attestation, and when can the Fund Manager avoid appointing a third party (either by self-attesting for a Qualified Investor Fund or because the assets track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark)?
gold_answer: As a baseline, the Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund must appoint a third party to attest to compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually, but only for a defined slice of the Fund’s holdings. [#SRC:900d63ac-47c0-453a-91f1-79eaee1ab8f1] Specifically, the requirement is limited to the portion of the Eligible Green Fund Property that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy (the taxonomy-aligned portion described in connection with Rule 20.2.3(a)). [#SRC:900d63ac-47c0-453a-91f1-79eaee1ab8f1] There are two ways the Fund Manager can avoid appointing a third party: (1) if the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund and the Fund Manager chooses to provide the attestation itself, then a third-party appointment is not required because the Fund Manager performs the attestation. [#TGT:700ed6a6-3a4a-49b8-8bae-3980c9d36df0] (2) if all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark (linked to Rule 20.2.3(b)), then no attestation is required at all. [#TGT:700ed6a6-3a4a-49b8-8bae-3980c9d36df0]

question: When determining the Credit RWA of an Authorised Person as a sum of component RWAs, how should the Authorised Person delineate what is included in the RWA calculation for Credit Risk Exposures (CR Exposures) versus what is carved out because it is treated as securitisation or Trading Book exposure, including any Traditional Securitisation risk-transference recognition condition?
gold_answer: In calculating Credit RWA, an Authorised Person must aggregate three distinct RWA components: (i) RWA for all Credit Risk Exposures (CR Exposures), (ii) RWA for all securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures), and (iii) RWA for Counterparty Risk Exposures, each computed under the specified rule sets for those components. [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020] For the CR Exposure component specifically, the Authorised Person must include both on-balance sheet assets and off-balance sheet items in the CR Exposure RWA calculation. [#TGT:cb5e6ab2-3cae-450b-87c6-acb11128d3f0] However, to keep the CR Exposure component distinct from the other Credit RWA components, the Authorised Person must exclude from CR Exposure RWA: (a) any SE Exposure (which instead belongs in the securitisation RWA component of Credit RWA), (b) any securitised Exposure that qualifies for recognition of risk transference in a Traditional Securitisation under Section 4.14, and (c) any Exposure classified as a position or instrument in the Trading Book under Section A2.1. [#TGT:cb5e6ab2-3cae-450b-87c6-acb11128d3f0] This delineation ensures the CR Exposure RWA is calculated on the intended population while the excluded items are addressed through the separate securitisation and other relevant RWA calculations that together form Credit RWA. [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020]

question: If an Authorised Person is adding up its Credit RWA, what kinds of items go into the CR Exposures part (on- and off-balance sheet), and which items must be left out because they are SE Exposures, Traditional Securitisation risk-transfer exposures, or Trading Book positions?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person’s Credit RWA is built by summing separate RWA amounts for (1) all Credit Risk Exposures (CR Exposures), (2) all securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures), and (3) Counterparty Risk Exposures, with each part calculated under the referenced rules and sections for that category. [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020] For the CR Exposures part, the Authorised Person must count both any on-balance sheet asset and any off-balance sheet item when calculating RWA for CR Exposures. [#TGT:cb5e6ab2-3cae-450b-87c6-acb11128d3f0] At the same time, the CR Exposures calculation must not include certain exposures because they are treated elsewhere within the overall Credit RWA framework: it must exclude any SE Exposure, and it must also exclude any securitised Exposure that meets the Section 4.14 requirements for recognising risk transference in a Traditional Securitisation. [#TGT:cb5e6ab2-3cae-450b-87c6-acb11128d3f0] In addition, any Exposure that is classified as a position or instrument in the Trading Book under Section A2.1 is excluded from the CR Exposures RWA calculation. [#TGT:cb5e6ab2-3cae-450b-87c6-acb11128d3f0] Those exclusions help keep the CR Exposures component aligned with the separate securitisation and other components that together make up Credit RWA. [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020]

question: For an Authorised Person that falls within the categories covered by the Chapter, which specific categories are identified as having different treatment regarding use of the Simplified Approach under Section 4.7, and what is the nature of that differentiation?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5 is within the scope of the Chapter. [#TGT:0e6645d8-2aef-402c-b9d3-94e8ac522d5d] Within that covered population, the differentiated treatment described applies specifically to Category 3A firms and Category 2 firms in relation to the Simplified Approach under Section 4.7. [#SRC:082e5005-d051-49ac-86ab-930ae5cfbe2f] The differentiation is that Category 3A firms are required to use the Simplified Approach under Section 4.7, whereas Category 2 firms are permitted (but not required) to use it. [#SRC:082e5005-d051-49ac-86ab-930ae5cfbe2f] By contrast, while Category 1 and Category 5 are included in the Chapter’s scope, the differentiated Simplified Approach rule described does not assign them a “must” or “may” position in the same way as it does for Categories 3A and 2. [#TGT:0e6645d8-2aef-402c-b9d3-94e8ac522d5d] Accordingly, when assessing whether the Simplified Approach under Section 4.7 is mandatory or optional, the key step is to confirm that the entity is an Authorised Person within the Chapter’s covered categories and then apply the specific Category 3A (mandatory) versus Category 2 (optional) treatment. [#TGT:0e6645d8-2aef-402c-b9d3-94e8ac522d5d] [#SRC:082e5005-d051-49ac-86ab-930ae5cfbe2f]

question: If an Authorised Person is in one of the categories this Chapter covers, when do they have to use the Simplified Approach under Section 4.7, and when is it only allowed?
gold_answer: First confirm the Authorised Person is in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5, because those are the categories the Chapter applies to. [#TGT:0e6645d8-2aef-402c-b9d3-94e8ac522d5d] Once you know the Chapter applies, the rule about the Simplified Approach under Section 4.7 is not the same for every covered category. [#SRC:082e5005-d051-49ac-86ab-930ae5cfbe2f] Category 3A firms are required to use the Simplified Approach under Section 4.7. [#SRC:082e5005-d051-49ac-86ab-930ae5cfbe2f] Category 2 firms are allowed to use the Simplified Approach under Section 4.7, but they are not required to do so. [#SRC:082e5005-d051-49ac-86ab-930ae5cfbe2f] The Chapter’s scope statement also includes Category 1 and Category 5, but the differentiated Simplified Approach rule described only specifies “must” for Category 3A and “may” for Category 2, so you should not treat Category 1 or Category 5 as automatically falling into either of those two positions based on these passages alone. [#TGT:0e6645d8-2aef-402c-b9d3-94e8ac522d5d] [#SRC:082e5005-d051-49ac-86ab-930ae5cfbe2f] In practice, the decision point is the firm’s category: Category 3A means mandatory use, and Category 2 means optional use, within the Chapter’s covered categories. [#SRC:082e5005-d051-49ac-86ab-930ae5cfbe2f] [#TGT:0e6645d8-2aef-402c-b9d3-94e8ac522d5d]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses a Production Target in relation to its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or a material Mining Project (including multiple Mining Projects that are material together), under what conditions may a subsequent disclosure omit the information otherwise required by Rule 11.8.3, and what additional proximate statements are required where the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or is based in part on an Exploration Target?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity may disclose a Production Target in relation to its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or a material Mining Project (including two or more Mining Projects that are material together), and if it has already made a disclosure under Rule 11.8.2, a later Production Target disclosure in that context can omit the information that Rule 11.8.3 would otherwise require, but only if specific conditions are met. [#TGT:9ecca3cb-1427-4279-b104-2bb3d2f1d7f6] [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] To rely on this omission pathway, the subsequent disclosure must (i) point back to the earlier disclosure that complied with Rule 11.8.3 and (ii) confirm that the material assumptions used for the original Production Target continue to apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] In addition, if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the subsequent disclosure must include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement about the Production Target that corresponds to the statement described in Rule 11.8.3(5)(d). [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] If the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, it must likewise include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement corresponding to Rule 11.8.3(7)(b). [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity is talking about a Production Target for its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or for a material Mining Project (or several Mining Projects that are material together), when can it leave out the Rule 11.8.3 details in a later update, and what extra nearby statements does it need if the target is all Inferred Mineral Resources or partly an Exploration Target?
gold_answer: For a Production Target that is disclosed in relation to a Mining Reporting Entity’s Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or a material Mining Project (including multiple Mining Projects that are material together), a later update does not have to repeat the information normally required by Rule 11.8.3 if the Mining Reporting Entity previously made a disclosure under Rule 11.8.2 and the later update satisfies the specified conditions. [#TGT:9ecca3cb-1427-4279-b104-2bb3d2f1d7f6] [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] The later disclosure must clearly refer back to the earlier disclosure that complied with Rule 11.8.3, and it must also state that the key assumptions used for the original Production Target still apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] If the Production Target is entirely based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the update must add a statement placed close to the Production Target and with at least equal prominence, matching the type of statement described in Rule 11.8.3(5)(d). [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] If the Production Target is partly based on an Exploration Target, it must similarly include a proximate and equally prominent statement matching the one described in Rule 11.8.3(7)(b). [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef]

question: For a Low-Value Payment Instrument (as referred to under Rule 19.3.1) that is governed by a Framework Contract, what information must the Payment Service Provider give the Payer about the Payment Service, and how does that obligation apply given that such instruments can be used in relation to both Payment Accounts and Stored Value?
gold_answer: For a Low-Value Payment Instrument governed by a Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider is not required to provide the broader general information otherwise compelled under Section 19.2 for Framework Contracts; instead, it must provide the Payer with information focused on the main characteristics of the Payment Service. [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21] This streamlined disclosure approach applies in the Low-Value Payment Instrument context even though the instruments referred to under Rule 19.3.1 cover use in relation to both Payment Accounts and Stored Value, so the Payment Service Provider should frame the “main characteristics” information to match how the instrument is used in those contexts. [#SRC:9098e83a-9451-476e-8f4a-60bedc364e14] The required “main characteristics” information includes: how the Payment Instrument can be used; the Payer’s liability (as set out in Rule 19.20.1); charges levied; any other material information the Payer needs to make an informed decision; and where the general information specified in Rule 19.2.1 is made available in an easily accessible manner. [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21] In practice, because the same Low-Value Payment Instrument category spans both Payment Accounts and Stored Value, the Payment Service Provider should ensure the usage description and any material decision-making information are presented in a way that is meaningful for the relevant mode of use. [#SRC:9098e83a-9451-476e-8f4a-60bedc364e14]

question: Where the parties have agreed to disapply the individual Payment Transaction information requirements for a Low-Value Payment Instrument governed by a Framework Contract, what alternative transaction information must the Payment Service Provider provide or make available, and what is the fallback requirement when the instrument is used anonymously—particularly in light of the fact that Low-Value Payment Instruments under Rule 19.3.1 include instruments used for Stored Value?
gold_answer: If, for a Low-Value Payment Instrument governed by a Framework Contract, the parties agree that the usual information for individual Payment Transactions (as specified in Rules 19.2.13 and 19.2.14) will not apply, the Payment Service Provider must follow the alternative information approach set out for such instruments. [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21] Under that alternative approach, the Payment Service Provider must provide or make available a reference that enables the Payment Service User to identify the Payment Transaction, the amount of the Payment Transaction, and any charges payable for that Payment Transaction. [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21] If there are several Payment Transactions of the same kind made to the same Payee, the Payment Service Provider must instead provide or make available information about the total amount of those Payment Transactions and any charges for them. [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21] Where the Payment Instrument is used anonymously, or the Payment Service Provider is not technically able to provide or make available the information described above, the Payment Service Provider must enable the Payer to verify the amount of Money stored. [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21] This fallback is especially relevant because Low-Value Payment Instruments referred to under Rule 19.3.1 include instruments used in relation to Stored Value, making verification of stored Money a necessary substitute when transaction-level reporting cannot be delivered. [#SRC:9098e83a-9451-476e-8f4a-60bedc364e14]

question: When an Authorised Person prepares or publishes Investment Research while providing any Regulated Activities, what conflict-of-interest identification steps must it take under Principle 7 (Rule 2.2.7), and which categories of relationships must be considered in addition to maintaining adequate procedures and controls for the research output?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person preparing or publishing Investment Research must both maintain adequate procedures and controls for that research and take reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest, with the identification exercise aligned to Principle 7 as outlined in Rule 2.2.7. [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759] [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319] In practice, the conflict-identification duty applies to conflicts that arise or may arise in the course of the Authorised Person providing any Regulated Activities, so the Authorised Person should assess conflicts connected to those activities even where the immediate deliverable is Investment Research. [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319] The categories that must be considered when identifying conflicts include: (i) conflicts between the Authorised Person (including its managers, Employees and Clients, and any person directly or indirectly linked to them by control) and a Client; and (ii) conflicts between one Client and another Client. [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319] Separately, beyond identification, the Authorised Person is required to prevent or manage conflicts once identified, and this sits alongside the requirement to have adequate procedures and controls for Investment Research preparation or publication. [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]

question: If an Authorised Person is doing Regulated Activities and also putting out Investment Research, who does it need to check for conflicts under Principle 7 (Rule 2.2.7), and what extra control requirement applies to the Investment Research itself?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must run a conflicts check that matches Principle 7 in Rule 2.2.7 and, at the same time, ensure it has adequate procedures and controls for the Investment Research it prepares or publishes. [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319] [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759] The conflicts check is not limited to obvious issues; it requires taking all reasonable steps to identify conflicts that arise or may arise while the Authorised Person is providing any Regulated Activities. [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319] When doing that identification, the Authorised Person must look for conflicts between (1) the Authorised Person (including its managers, Employees and Clients, and any person directly or indirectly linked to them by control) and a Client, and (2) one Client and another Client. [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319] In addition to identifying conflicts, the Authorised Person is expected to take reasonable steps to prevent or manage actual or potential conflicts, and this obligation sits alongside the separate requirement for adequate procedures and controls around Investment Research. [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]

question: When assessing potential contravention of section 92(2) (Insider Dealing), how should a firm distinguish between (i) a person merely executing their own pre-formed intention to deal and (ii) dealing on the basis of “Inside Information” for Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, or Accepted Spot Commodities (including Related Instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives)?
gold_answer: A person’s execution of their own pre-formed intention to deal, by itself, is treated as not breaching section 92(2) (Insider Dealing); the compliance focus therefore shifts to whether the dealing is instead connected to “Inside Information” as defined for the relevant instruments. [#SRC:78dea780-e39f-407d-855f-5cb46c1b30d7] For Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities, and Related Instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives, “Inside Information” is limited to information that is precise, not generally available, and that relates (directly or indirectly) to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers or to the instruments themselves, and that would likely move the price significantly if it became generally available. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] In practical terms, the firm should (1) confirm the person formed an intention to deal before dealing and recognize that carrying out that intention alone is not the contravention trigger, [#SRC:78dea780-e39f-407d-855f-5cb46c1b30d7] and (2) separately test whether any information influencing the trade meets all elements of the “Inside Information” definition (precise, non-public, relevant to Reporting Entities/Issuers or the instruments, and price-significant). [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] This linkage matters because the “own intention” concept addresses the act of dealing, while the “Inside Information” definition supplies the characteristics of information that could make dealing problematic under an insider dealing analysis. [#SRC:78dea780-e39f-407d-855f-5cb46c1b30d7] [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977]

question: If someone plans to trade a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset, or an Accepted Spot Commodity, when is simply following their own plan not enough to count as insider dealing, and what extra “Inside Information” features would you check for (including for Related Instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives)?
gold_answer: Following a person’s own plan to trade—where they formed the intention to deal before they traded—does not, by itself, amount to contravening section 92(2) (Insider Dealing). [#SRC:78dea780-e39f-407d-855f-5cb46c1b30d7] To decide whether there is a remaining insider dealing concern, you would then check whether the trade is connected to “Inside Information” as defined for Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities, or Related Instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] Under that definition, the information must be precise and not generally available, it must relate (directly or indirectly) to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers or to the instruments themselves, and it must be the kind of information that would likely have a significant effect on price if it became generally available. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] So the combined approach is: treat “carrying out of own trading intention” as not automatically triggering the insider dealing contravention, [#SRC:78dea780-e39f-407d-855f-5cb46c1b30d7] but still evaluate whether any relevant non-public, precise, price-significant information about Reporting Entities/Issuers or the instruments is involved, because that is what qualifies as “Inside Information” for these products. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977]

question: For a Payment Service User that is not a Natural Person, how does a written agreement with the Payment Service Provider to apply a different time period for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions (for the purposes of Rule 19.17.1) interact with the Chapter condition that redress is available only if the Payment Service User notifies the Payment Service Provider without undue delay and no later than twelve months after the debit date?
gold_answer: A Payment Service User’s ability to obtain redress under the Chapter is conditioned on giving notice to its Payment Service Provider without undue delay and, at the latest, within twelve months of the debit date once it becomes aware of an unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transaction. [#TGT:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd] Separately, where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider may, by written agreement, set a different time period concerning unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 19.17.1. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] Read together, this means the Chapter’s redress entitlement hinges on timely notification (including the twelve‑month outer limit stated in the Chapter), while the parties also have an express ability—limited to the Rule 19.17.1 context—to contract for a different time period addressing unauthorised or incorrectly executed transactions when the user is not a Natural Person. [#TGT:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd] [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] In practice, the Payment Service User should (i) confirm it is not a Natural Person and that any variation is in writing, and (ii) ensure its notification to the Payment Service Provider satisfies the Chapter’s notice condition while also aligning with any agreed alternative time period applicable for Rule 19.17.1. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] [#TGT:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd]

question: If the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person and it has a written deal with the Payment Service Provider to use a different time limit for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions (for Rule 19.17.1), what notice timing does the Payment Service User still need to meet to be entitled to redress under the Chapter?
gold_answer: To be entitled to redress under the Chapter, the Payment Service User must notify its Payment Service Provider without undue delay and, in any case, no later than twelve months after the debit date once it becomes aware of an unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transaction. [#TGT:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd] In addition, when the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider may agree in writing that a different time period applies concerning unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 19.17.1. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] Putting these together, the Payment Service User should treat the Chapter’s notice requirement (including the twelve‑month latest date) as the condition for accessing redress, while also checking whether its written agreement sets a different time period that applies specifically in the Rule 19.17.1 context for unauthorised or incorrectly executed transactions. [#TGT:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd] [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] Operationally, this means the Payment Service User should (i) identify the debit date and when it became aware of the issue, (ii) notify the Payment Service Provider promptly, and (iii) confirm whether the written agreement changes the relevant time period for Rule 19.17.1 so its actions align with both the Chapter condition and the agreed Rule-specific timing. [#TGT:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd] [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]

question: When considering an Application for Listing, to what extent is the Regulator permitted to attach, later change, or remove conditions or restrictions relating to the admission of Securities to the Official List, and how does that permission align with the Regulator’s power described in the FSMR?
gold_answer: Across both passages, the Regulator is expressly permitted to manage the admission of Securities to the Official List by imposing conditions or restrictions and then subsequently adjusting that regulatory treatment. The SOURCE states that, under the FSMR, the Regulator may impose conditions or restrictions in respect of the admission of Securities to the Official List and may also vary or withdraw those conditions or restrictions, establishing the baseline permission and its ongoing nature [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226]. The TARGET confirms the same permission in the specific context of the Regulator’s decision-making on an Application for Listing, listing as an available action the ability to impose conditions or restrictions (and to vary or withdraw them) in respect of admission to the Official List, and indicating that this is exercisable in the circumstances specified in a further subsection [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b]. Read together, the Regulator’s permission covers (i) initial imposition at admission, and (ii) later variation or withdrawal, with the TARGET situating that permission within the application/decision framework.

question: If the Regulator is deciding whether to accept an Application for Listing, can it set limits or requirements on the admission of Securities to the Official List and later change or remove them, and is that the same power described in the FSMR?
gold_answer: Yes. Both passages describe the Regulator’s permission to control admission of Securities to the Official List through conditions or restrictions, and to revisit those measures later. The SOURCE explains that, under the FSMR, the Regulator may impose conditions or restrictions in respect of the admission of Securities to the Official List and may also vary or withdraw those conditions or restrictions, showing that the permission is not limited to a one-time decision [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226]. The TARGET repeats that the Regulator may impose conditions or restrictions in respect of admission to the Official List and may vary or withdraw them, and it places that permission alongside the Regulator’s other option to refuse an Application for Listing, indicating these are tools available when handling listing applications [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b]. Taken together, the TARGET’s application-focused framing aligns with the SOURCE’s FSMR-based statement of the same permission to impose, change, or remove admission-related conditions or restrictions.

question: For a Reporting Entity, what is the mandatory action regarding having an auditor, and how must that appointment be carried out under the applicable framework?
gold_answer: A Reporting Entity has a mandatory obligation to ensure an auditor is in place by appointing one, and this is not discretionary. The SOURCE establishes that the Reporting Entity is required to appoint an auditor, framing the duty as a regulatory requirement applicable to the Reporting Entity [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33]. The TARGET then specifies how that obligation must be satisfied in practice: the Reporting Entity shall have an auditor appointed in accordance with Part 15 and any Rules made for the purposes of that Part, meaning the appointment must follow the procedural and substantive requirements set out in that Part and its related Rules [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb]. Read together, the combined requirement is twofold: (1) the Reporting Entity must appoint an auditor (the existence of the duty), and (2) the Reporting Entity must ensure the appointment is made in the manner prescribed by Part 15 and any associated Rules (the method of compliance).

question: Does a Reporting Entity have to appoint an auditor, and if so, what rules must it follow when making that appointment?
gold_answer: Yes. A Reporting Entity is under a requirement to appoint an auditor, so it must take action to ensure an auditor is appointed rather than treating it as optional [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33]. In addition, the way the Reporting Entity fulfills that requirement is constrained by the applicable appointment framework: the Reporting Entity shall have an auditor appointed in accordance with Part 15 and any Rules made for the purposes of that Part [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb]. This means compliance is not achieved merely by selecting an auditor; the Reporting Entity must ensure the appointment process and outcome align with Part 15 and any related Rules. Taken together, the passages require both the appointment itself and adherence to the specified Part 15/Rules-based mechanism for making that appointment.

question: Where an Applicant/Authorised Person seeks FSRA approval for its FSP to cover Regulated Activities in both conventional assets and Spot Commodities, may the Regulator exercise discretion to reduce or waive fees so that the fees for the conventional and Spot Commodity activities are not applied cumulatively, and what fairness-based condition governs that discretion?
gold_answer: Yes. In the scenario where an Applicant/Authorised Person will undertake a Regulated Activity involving conventional assets in addition to Spot Commodities and therefore must seek FSRA approval for its FSP to permit activity across both asset types, the fee outcome may be affected by the exercise of discretion described in both passages. The SOURCE explains that, in this dual-asset approval context, the fees attributable to the Authorised Person for its conventional and Spot Commodity-related Regulated Activities may not be cumulative if the FSRA applies its discretion to reduce or waive a fee, with the SOURCE also indicating this is considered in light of the high fees already imposed on Applicants/Authorised Persons conducting Regulated Activities using Spot Commodities [#SRC:e801f4a4-1a6e-4c91-92d6-724eec350cc0]. The TARGET sets the governing condition for that discretion: the Regulator may at any time reduce, waive, or refund all or part of any fee (including supplementary or late payment fees) if, in the circumstances of the particular case, it considers it fair and reasonable to do so [#TGT:0caa9f08-40e5-42b7-9cef-4148ae1dc036]. Together, these provisions support non-cumulative fee treatment where the Regulator/FSRA determines fairness and reasonableness in the specific case.

question: If an Applicant/Authorised Person needs FSRA approval for its FSP to do Regulated Activities in both conventional assets and Spot Commodities, can the Regulator reduce or waive fees so the two sets of fees are not added together, and when is it allowed to do that?
gold_answer: It can, but only through the Regulator’s/FSRA’s discretionary relief and only when the fairness test is met. The SOURCE describes a situation where an Applicant/Authorised Person will be undertaking a Regulated Activity involving conventional assets as well as Spot Commodities and therefore needs to seek FSRA approval for its FSP to permit it to carry out Regulated Activity in relation to both asset types. In that context, the SOURCE states that the fees attributable to the Authorised Person for its Regulated Activities (conventional and Spot Commodity-related) may not be cumulative if the FSRA applies its discretion to reduce or waive a fee, noting this in light of the high fees already imposed on Applicants/Authorised Persons conducting Regulated Activities using Spot Commodities [#SRC:e801f4a4-1a6e-4c91-92d6-724eec350cc0]. The TARGET explains the condition and scope of that discretion: the Regulator may at any time reduce, waive, or refund all or part of any fee (including supplementary or late payment fees) if it considers that, in the circumstances of the particular case, it would be fair and reasonable to do so [#TGT:0caa9f08-40e5-42b7-9cef-4148ae1dc036].

question: When assessing whether it may give a direction requiring a Recognised Body to take specified steps (including granting premises access for inspection or suspending an activity), in what circumstances will the Regulator usually consider revoking the Recognition Order instead of proceeding with that direction?
gold_answer: The Regulator may direct a Recognised Body to take specified steps to secure compliance with the Recognition Requirements, including granting the Regulator access to the Recognised Body’s premises to inspect premises or documents and requiring suspension of the carrying on of an activity for a specified period [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500]. However, the Regulator will usually consider revoking a Recognition Order rather than relying on such a direction where the Recognised Body is failing or has failed to satisfy one or more Recognition Requirements and the failure has or will have serious consequences, or where it would not be possible for the Recognised Body to comply with a direction. Revocation will also usually be considered where, for some other reason, it would not be appropriate for the Regulator to give a direction under its power to give directions, and where the Recognised Body has not carried on the business of a Recognised Body during the relevant 12-month period after the Recognition Order took effect or at any time during the six months ending with the day the Recognition Order is revoked [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a].

question: If a Recognised Body is failing to meet Recognition Requirements and the consequences are or will be serious, can the Regulator still use its power to direct specified remedial steps (including inspection access or suspension), and what additional factors would lead it to usually consider revocation instead?
gold_answer: The Regulator can use its power to give directions to a Recognised Body to take specified steps to secure compliance with the Recognition Requirements, and those steps may include granting access to the Recognised Body’s premises for inspection of premises or documents and suspending the carrying on of any activity for a period specified in the direction [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500]. At the same time, where the Recognised Body is failing or has failed to satisfy one or more Recognition Requirements and that failure has or will have serious consequences, the Regulator will usually consider revoking the Recognition Order, indicating that revocation is a likely regulatory response in that scenario [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a]. Beyond seriousness of consequences, the Regulator will usually consider revocation if it would not be possible for the Recognised Body to comply with a direction, or if for some other reason it would not be appropriate to give a direction. Revocation is also usually considered where the Recognised Body has not carried on the business of a Recognised Body during the specified 12-month period after the Recognition Order took effect, or has not carried on that business at any time during the six months ending with the day the Recognition Order is revoked [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a].

question: When can the Regulator tell a Recognised Body to take steps like letting the Regulator inspect its premises or stopping an activity for a set time, and when will the Regulator usually think about revoking the Recognition Order instead?
gold_answer: The Regulator has the power to give directions to a Recognised Body to take specified steps to secure compliance with the Recognition Requirements. The steps the Regulator may require can include granting the Regulator access to the Recognised Body’s premises to inspect the premises or documents on the premises, and suspending the carrying on of any activity by the Recognised Body for the period specified in the direction [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500]. Even though those directions are available, the Regulator will usually consider revoking a Recognition Order in several situations: if the Recognised Body is failing or has failed to satisfy one or more Recognition Requirements and that failure has or will have serious consequences; if it would not be possible for the Recognised Body to comply with a direction; or if, for some other reason, it would not be appropriate for the Regulator to give a direction under its power to give directions [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a]. The Regulator will also usually consider revocation if the Recognised Body has not carried on the business of a Recognised Body during the 12 months after the Recognition Order took effect, or has not carried on that business at any time during the six months ending with the day the Recognition Order is revoked [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a].

question: If a Recognised Body cannot follow a direction (like giving access for inspection or suspending an activity), what can the Regulator do, and when does it usually consider revoking the Recognition Order?
gold_answer: The Regulator can give directions to a Recognised Body to take specified steps to secure compliance with the Recognition Requirements, and those steps may include giving the Regulator access to the Recognised Body’s premises to inspect the premises or documents there, as well as suspending the carrying on of any activity for a period set out in the direction [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500]. But the Regulator will usually consider revoking the Recognition Order where it would not be possible for the Recognised Body to comply with a direction, meaning the direction route is not workable in practice [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a]. The Regulator will also usually consider revocation if the Recognised Body is failing or has failed to satisfy one or more Recognition Requirements and that failure has or will have serious consequences, or if for some other reason it would not be appropriate for the Regulator to give a direction under its power to give directions. Separately, revocation is usually considered if the Recognised Body has not carried on the business of a Recognised Body during the 12 months after the Recognition Order took effect, or has not carried on that business at any time during the six months ending with the day the Recognition Order is revoked [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a].

question: When an Issuer makes an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM and has published a Prospectus, what must the Issuer or the person responsible for the issue of the Prospectus do if a significant change occurs, a material mistake or inaccuracy is identified, or a significant new matter arises after the Prospectus is issued?
gold_answer: Where an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, the regulatory framework contemplates an obligation to publish a Prospectus as part of the applicable requirements for Offers of Securities [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd]. Once a Prospectus has been issued in that context, the ongoing obligation is that, if at any time after the issue of the Prospectus there is (i) a significant change in any matter contained in the Prospectus, (ii) a material mistake or inaccuracy affecting any matter contained in the Prospectus, or (iii) a significant new matter arises, the Issuer or the person responsible for the issue of the Prospectus shall issue a supplementary prospectus [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c]. The supplementary prospectus must provide details of the relevant change, mistake, inaccuracy, or new matter, and it must also comply with the applicable requirements referenced for such supplementary disclosure [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c].

question: If an Issuer offers Securities to the Public in or from ADGM and has already issued a Prospectus, what must happen if something important changes, a serious error is found, or a major new matter comes up after the Prospectus is issued?
gold_answer: For an Issuer making an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, the applicable requirements for Offers of Securities include an obligation to publish a Prospectus [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd]. After that Prospectus has been issued, there is a further disclosure obligation triggered by post-issuance developments: if at any time there is a significant change in, or a material mistake or inaccuracy affecting, any matter contained in the Prospectus, or if a significant new matter arises, the Issuer or the person responsible for the issue of the Prospectus must issue a supplementary prospectus [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c]. That supplementary prospectus must (a) provide details of the change, mistake, inaccuracy, or new matter, and (b) comply with the specified requirements applicable to supplementary prospectuses [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c]. In practical terms, the Prospectus publication obligation is not “one and done”; it is paired with a continuing duty to update the disclosure through a supplementary prospectus when the stated triggers occur [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd].

question: When a Petroleum Reporting Entity must immediately disclose a new material estimate of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves that has not previously been disclosed, what must it ensure the disclosure includes regarding the permits or licences connected to those estimates?
gold_answer: Where a Petroleum Reporting Entity has a new material estimate of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves that has not previously been disclosed, it must make an immediate disclosure of that estimate [#TGT:1d41da19-7d47-42e7-baf3-28af0f6c1c12]. When making that disclosure, the Petroleum Reporting Entity must also ensure the disclosure contains specific supporting content, including the types of permits or licences it holds that relate to the estimates being disclosed [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704]. In practice, this means the immediate disclosure obligation is not satisfied by stating the new estimate alone; the disclosure must identify the relevant permit or licence types held by the Petroleum Reporting Entity in connection with the estimate. The same disclosure package must also include an explanation of the new data and information, an explanation of how that new data and information affected the estimates, and any changes or additions to previously disclosed information relating to Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources, or Petroleum Reserves, as applicable [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704].

question: If a Petroleum Reporting Entity has a new material estimate it has not disclosed before and must disclose it immediately, what permit or licence details must it include in that disclosure?
gold_answer: If a Petroleum Reporting Entity has any new material estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves that have not previously been disclosed, it must disclose those estimates immediately [#TGT:1d41da19-7d47-42e7-baf3-28af0f6c1c12]. When it makes that disclosure, it must ensure the disclosure includes the types of permits or licences the Petroleum Reporting Entity holds that relate to the estimates being disclosed [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704]. So, the disclosure should not just provide the new estimate; it must also state what kinds of permits or licences support or connect to the estimate. In addition, the same disclosure must include an explanation of the new data and information, explain how that new data and information affected the estimates, and include any changes or additions to information previously disclosed for Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources, or Petroleum Reserves (as relevant to the estimate being updated) [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704]. Together, these requirements ensure the immediate disclosure is accompanied by the key contextual details required.

question: For a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity, what is the latest time by which it must disclose the quarterly report, and what minimum subject-matter must that quarterly report cover for the entity and all controlled entities on a consolidated basis (if applicable)?
gold_answer: A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity must disclose its quarterly report no later than one month after the end of the relevant quarter [#SRC:380ff25a-7805-4020-9f40-da991f91eab1]. The report that must be disclosed is a report for each quarter of its financial year and must cover, in respect of the Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity and all controlled entities (on a consolidated basis, if applicable), specified information about Petroleum-related activities and positions [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62].
