At a minimum, the quarterly report must include: details of activities relating to Petroleum (Exploration, and production and development, or statements that there were no such activities); a summary of expenditure incurred relating to Petroleum (Exploration activities, and production and development); the Petroleum Tenements held at quarter end (including location, percentage interest held, and beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements); and Petroleum Tenements acquired or disposed of during the quarter (including location and beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements) [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62]. In addition, at least once every 12 months the report must address the Summary of Reserves and Resources requirement (unless included in the annual report) and state when the previous and upcoming disclosures of that summary were and are to be made [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62].

question: By when does a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity have to publish its quarterly report, and what information must it include about the entity and all controlled entities (if it reports on a consolidated basis)?
gold_answer: A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity must disclose the required quarterly report no later than one month after the end of the quarter [#SRC:380ff25a-7805-4020-9f40-da991f91eab1]. The report it must disclose is a report for each quarter of its financial year and it must include specific information for the Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity and all controlled entities, on a consolidated basis if applicable [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62]. The quarterly report must cover Petroleum-related activities (Exploration, and production and development), or clearly state if there were no such activities; it must also summarise expenditure incurred for Petroleum Exploration activities and for production and development [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62]. It must list the Petroleum Tenements held at the end of the quarter, including their location, the percentage interest held, and any beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements, and it must also identify Petroleum Tenements acquired or disposed of during the quarter (again including location and beneficial interests) [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62]. Finally, at least once every 12 months it must address the Summary of Reserves and Resources disclosure (unless included in the annual report) and state when the previous and upcoming disclosures of that summary were and are to be made [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62].

question: Where the Listing Authority concludes, following an enquiry into complaints or allegations, that accurate information constitutes Inside Information and is not exempt from disclosure, what procedural content should an ‘aware letter’ include to address the Reporting Entity’s timing of disclosure and its compliance position, and in what circumstances may the Listing Authority choose to issue that letter rather than only requesting a disclosure?
gold_answer: When, as a result of an enquiry into complaints or allegations of non-compliance, the Listing Authority forms the view that the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not within an exemption from disclosure, it will ask the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter, and if the information should have been Disclosed earlier the Listing Authority may issue an ‘aware letter’ or take other relevant action [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944]. Procedurally, an ‘aware letter’ generally follows a standard template and should (a) identify the information in question and the relevant date it was Disclosed, and (b) require the Reporting Entity to state whether it believes the information is Inside Information. If the Reporting Entity answers “yes,” the letter should require confirmation of when the Reporting Entity first became aware of the Inside Information (including time and circumstances) and, if it was aware before the letter date, why it did not Disclose earlier or request a Trading Halt or Suspension, with specific comment on the application of the disclosure obligation. If the Reporting Entity answers “no,” it should confirm the basis for that view. The letter should also seek confirmation that the Reporting Entity is in compliance with the Markets Rules, in particular the disclosure obligation [#TGT:f221a729-4fb2-4eca-bb45-6c892c667a28].

question: If the Listing Authority’s enquiry leads it to think the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not exempt, and it believes the information should have been disclosed earlier, what does an ‘aware letter’ usually ask the Reporting Entity to confirm, and when is the Listing Authority allowed to send that letter (instead of only asking for a disclosure)?
gold_answer: If, following an enquiry into complaints or allegations of non-compliance, the Listing Authority forms the view that the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not within an exemption from disclosure, it will ask the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter; and if the information should have been Disclosed earlier, the Listing Authority may issue an ‘aware letter’ (or take other relevant action) [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944]. An ‘aware letter’ generally uses a standard template and typically identifies the information in question and the date it was Disclosed, then asks the Reporting Entity whether it believes the information is Inside Information. If the Reporting Entity says “yes,” it is asked to confirm when it first became aware of the Inside Information (including the time and circumstances) and, if it was aware before the letter date, why it did not Disclose earlier or request a Trading Halt or Suspension, including specific comment on how the disclosure obligation applied. If it says “no,” it must confirm the basis for not treating the information as Inside Information. The letter also asks the Reporting Entity to confirm it is in compliance with the Markets Rules, particularly the disclosure obligation [#TGT:f221a729-4fb2-4eca-bb45-6c892c667a28].

question: When the Regulator considers a Fund or Sub Fund name to be undesirable, misleading, or conflicting with another Fund or Sub-Fund name, may it issue a direction requiring the Fund Manager to change that name, and how does this relate to the Regulator’s broader ability to direct changes where a class of Units name is also problematic?
gold_answer: Yes. Where, in the opinion of the Regulator, the name of a Fund or of a Sub Fund is undesirable, misleading, or conflicts with the name of another Fund or Sub-Fund, the Regulator may issue a direction to the Fund Manager requiring a change to the name of the Fund or the Sub Fund [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff]. This permission sits within a broader power described for the Regulator to make a direction when a name used for a Fund, a Sub-Fund, or a class of Units in a Fund is undesirable, misleading, or conflicts with a name used by another Fund, Sub-Fund, or class of Units of a Fund [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295]. Read together, the Target specifies the concrete remedial outcome (a directed name change by the Fund Manager) for Fund and Sub Fund names, while the Source confirms that the Regulator’s direction-making power is not limited to those entities and can also be triggered by issues with class of Units naming. In each case, the trigger is the Regulator’s assessment of undesirability, misleading character, or conflict with existing names.

question: If the Regulator thinks a Fund or Sub Fund name is misleading, undesirable, or too similar to another Fund or Sub-Fund name, can it tell the Fund Manager to change it? Does the same kind of power also apply when the problem is with the name of a class of Units in a Fund?
gold_answer: Yes. If, in the opinion of the Regulator, the name of a Fund or of a Sub Fund is undesirable, misleading, or conflicts with the name of another Fund or Sub-Fund, the Regulator is permitted to direct the Fund Manager to change the name of the Fund or the Sub Fund [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff]. The same overall direction-making concept also extends beyond just Fund and Sub-Fund names: the Regulator has the power to make a direction where the name of a Fund, a Sub-Fund, or a class of Units in a Fund is undesirable, misleading, or conflicts with a name used by another Fund, Sub-Fund, or class of Units of a Fund [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295]. Taken together, this means the Regulator’s permission to intervene is triggered by the same types of naming concerns (conflict, undesirability, or misleading effect), and the Target clarifies that, at least for Fund and Sub Fund names, the direction can require the Fund Manager to implement a name change.

question: Before a Customer becomes bound by the Governing Contract, what information must a Third Party Provider provide, and how does that obligation align with the requirement that the Governing Contract itself include specified content unless the parties agree otherwise in writing?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider must ensure that, before the Customer is bound by the Governing Contract, the Customer is provided with the information that is required to be given at that pre‑contract stage [#SRC:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8]. In parallel, unless the Third Party Provider and their Customer otherwise agree in writing, the Governing Contract between the Third Party Provider and their Customers must itself contain specified information covering: details about the Third Party Provider (including identity, ADGM office contact details, and regulator/FSP details); the Third Party Services (including key characteristics, required Customer identifiers, consent process, receipt timing, service timeframes, and usage limits); charges and exchange rates; agreed communications and information delivery arrangements; safeguards and corrective measures (including notification periods for unauthorised/incorrectly executed Third Party Transactions, fraud/security contact procedures, stopping conditions, and liability/refund-related terms); changes and termination terms; and redress mechanisms (including applicable law/courts and any alternative dispute resolution) [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. Taken together, the Third Party Provider must both provide the required information before the Customer is bound and, absent a written variation, embed the required disclosures and operational terms within the Governing Contract itself.

question: Where a Third Party Provider and their Customer have not agreed in writing to vary contractual content, what must the Third Party Provider do to ensure the Customer receives the required information before being bound, given the mandatory information that must be included in the Governing Contract?
gold_answer: If there is no written agreement between a Third Party Provider and their Customer to vary the contractual content, the Third Party Provider must structure compliance in two linked ways. First, the Third Party Provider must provide the Customer with the required information before the Customer is bound by the Governing Contract [#SRC:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8]. Second, the Third Party Provider must ensure the Governing Contract contains the specified information set out for inclusion unless otherwise agreed in writing [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. That contract content spans: who the Third Party Provider is and how to contact its ADGM office, its regulator and Financial Service Permission; what Third Party Services will be provided and how Third Party Transactions are initiated and timed; what charges and (where relevant) exchange rates apply; how communications and information provision will occur and what Customer information will be transferred to the Customer’s Financial Institution; safeguards such as notification periods for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transactions and fraud/security contact procedures; how changes and termination operate; and what redress options exist. Practically, the pre‑binding provision obligation is met by delivering these required disclosures to the Customer in advance, while also ensuring they are reflected in the Governing Contract absent a written variation.

question: What must a Third Party Provider give a Customer before the Customer is bound by the Governing Contract, and what information must the Governing Contract include unless both sides agree in writing to something different?
gold_answer: Before the Customer is bound by the Governing Contract, a Third Party Provider must provide the Customer with the required information at that stage [#SRC:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8]. Separately, unless the Third Party Provider and their Customer agree otherwise in writing, the Governing Contract must include a defined set of information [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. This includes: who the Third Party Provider is (name, ADGM office contact details, and regulator/FSP details); what the Third Party Services are (main characteristics, what identifier/info the Customer must provide for a Third Party Transaction, how consent is given, when a Third Party Transaction is received, service time limits, and any usage limits); what charges and (where relevant) exchange rates apply; how the parties will communicate and how often information will be provided or made available; safeguards such as how quickly the Customer must report unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transactions and how the Third Party Provider will contact the Customer about fraud/security threats; how changes/termination work; and what redress options exist. In practice, the Third Party Provider should deliver these disclosures before the Customer is bound and ensure they are also captured in the contract unless a written variation applies.

question: If there is no written agreement to change what goes into the Governing Contract, how should a Third Party Provider meet the rule that the Customer must get the required information before being bound?
gold_answer: Without a written agreement changing the contract content, the Third Party Provider must do two connected things. The Third Party Provider must provide the Customer with the required information before the Customer is bound by the Governing Contract [#SRC:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8]. At the same time, the Governing Contract must contain the specified information unless otherwise agreed in writing [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. That means the contract should set out, among other items, the Third Party Provider’s identity and ADGM contact details, its regulator and Financial Service Permission, the key features and limits of the Third Party Services, what the Customer must provide and how consent works for a Third Party Transaction, timing and maximum service timeframes, all charges and any relevant exchange rate approach, agreed communication methods and information frequency, safeguards and corrective steps (including reporting periods and fraud/security contact procedures), how changes and termination will operate, and available redress (courts/law and any alternative dispute resolution). Delivering these disclosures to the Customer before they are bound, and ensuring they appear in the contract, satisfies both requirements.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity prepares a disclosure under a Mining Reporting Standard, how must it address non-mandatory requirements—particularly where it does not fully comply with them—and what explanation must be included in the disclosure?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is expected to fully comply with all non-mandatory requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard, even though those requirements are described as non-mandatory, and this expectation sits alongside the obligation to fully comply with all binding requirements in the same standards [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124]. If, in a particular disclosure, the Mining Reporting Entity does not meet a non-mandatory requirement contained in the relevant Mining Reporting Standard, it must not remain silent or rely on the non-mandatory label; instead, it must include an explicit statement within the disclosure explaining both how the disclosure differs from the non-mandatory requirement and why it differs [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f]. In practice, this means the disclosure should identify the specific non-mandatory requirement that is not met, describe the nature of the deviation (the “how”), and provide the rationale for the deviation (the “why”), thereby addressing the Regulator’s expectation of full compliance or a clear explanation of non-compliance [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124] while satisfying the disclosure-level statement requirement [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f].

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure does not follow a non-mandatory requirement in a Mining Reporting Standard, what must it say in the disclosure, given the Regulator’s expectation about complying with those non-mandatory requirements?
gold_answer: The Mining Reporting Entity should approach non-mandatory requirements in a Mining Reporting Standard as requirements it is expected to fully comply with, even though they are not described as binding, because the Regulator expects full compliance with those non-mandatory requirements (in addition to full compliance with binding requirements) [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124]. When the Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure does not meet a non-mandatory requirement contained in the relevant Mining Reporting Standard, it must address that gap directly in the disclosure itself by providing a statement that explains both (1) how the disclosure differs from the non-mandatory requirement and (2) why it differs [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f]. This means the disclosure should not merely note that the requirement is “non-mandatory”; it must describe the nature of the non-compliance and the reason for it, so the reader can understand the deviation against the relevant Mining Reporting Standard [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f]. This disclosure statement also aligns with the Regulator’s expectation that the Mining Reporting Entity either fully complies with non-mandatory requirements or explains its non-compliance [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124].

question: Where a Listed Entity has not fully adopted, or has only partially adopted, the best practice standards in APP 4, what must its annual financial report state and explain about the reasons and any alternative actions taken, and how does this align with the Regulator’s expectation for disclosure in the Prospectus and subsequent disclosures?
gold_answer: If a Listed Entity has not fully adopted, or has only partially adopted, the best practice standards in APP 4, its annual financial report must (i) state whether those standards have been adopted, and (ii) where adoption is incomplete, explain why full adoption did not occur and what actions, if any, have been taken to achieve compliance to the extent the standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e]. This annual reporting obligation aligns with the Regulator’s broader disclosure expectation that, when a Reporting Entity does not adopt the APP 4 best practice standards (or adopts them only partially), the reasons for doing so and any alternative measures adopted to achieve the intended outcomes should be disclosed in the Prospectus and then continued thereafter through the relevant ongoing disclosure channel [#SRC:ff5bac8d-3dc7-46dd-a9ce-b0c32a42422e]. Read together, the two passages require a coherent narrative across initial offering disclosure and ongoing annual reporting: the entity must be transparent about the rationale for any deviation from APP 4 and must describe the substitute steps or measures it has adopted to pursue the Corporate Governance Principles’ outcomes, updated through annual compliance reporting.

question: If a Listed Entity does not fully follow APP 4, what does it have to say in its annual financial report about the reasons and what it did instead, and what does the Regulator expect to be disclosed in the Prospectus and then later on?
gold_answer: When a Listed Entity has not fully adopted, or has only partially adopted, the best practice standards in APP 4, its annual financial report must clearly state whether APP 4 has been adopted and, if not fully, explain the reasons for the shortfall and describe what actions, if any, it has taken to achieve compliance to the extent the standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e]. The Regulator’s expectation complements this by focusing on disclosure continuity: if a Reporting Entity does not adopt APP 4 (or adopts it only partially), the Regulator expects the reasons and any alternative measures adopted to achieve the intended outcomes of the Corporate Governance Principles to be disclosed in the Prospectus and then continued thereafter through the applicable ongoing disclosure process [#SRC:ff5bac8d-3dc7-46dd-a9ce-b0c32a42422e]. Together, these requirements mean the entity should provide consistent explanations and descriptions of substitute measures across both the initial Prospectus disclosure and the later annual reporting cycle, so stakeholders can understand both why APP 4 was not fully followed and how the entity is still working toward the governance outcomes.

question: When compiling the Resolution Pack for an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, what must the Authorised Person do to ensure the required master list of all Client Accounts is maintained and sufficiently detailed, and which specific account attributes must be captured to meet the record-keeping obligation?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must ensure that the Resolution Pack includes the required records relating to master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. To satisfy that inclusion requirement, the Authorised Person must also maintain a master list of all Client Accounts and ensure the list contains the prescribed level of detail [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d]. Specifically, the master list must capture, for each Client Account, the account name and account number, where the account is located, and the bank’s identity together with its address and contact information. It must also record the account’s terms and conditions, indicate whether the account is currently open or closed, and include the date the account was opened or closed. In practice, the Authorised Person should treat the maintained master list as the authoritative source document that is then included within the Resolution Pack, ensuring the pack reflects the same complete set of required fields for all Client Accounts relevant to Client Money and Client investments.

question: If an Authorised Person is preparing the Resolution Pack while conducting Investment Business, what must they do about the master list of all Client Accounts, and what details must that list include for each account?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must ensure the Resolution Pack contains the required records, including the master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. To be able to include that record properly, the Authorised Person must maintain a master list of all Client Accounts and make sure it is complete and detailed in the way required [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d]. For each Client Account, the list must state the account’s name and number, where the account is located, and the bank’s name along with the bank’s address and contact information. It must also include the account’s terms and conditions, show whether the account is open or closed, and record the date the account was opened or closed. This means the maintained master list should be kept up to date so that, when the Resolution Pack is assembled, the included master list already contains all required fields for every relevant Client Account.

question: When the Regulator issues a collateral notice, how may the Regulator determine the maximum value of assets a Captive Insurer can be required to make available, and how is that value calculated where the relevant case is a Captive Cell of a Captive Insurer which is a Cell Company versus a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company?
gold_answer: The Regulator is permitted to require a Captive Insurer, by written collateral notice, to make available assets of the relevant type and in the relevant manner, but the value of those assets is capped by a “lower of” test: it must not exceed the lower of any amount specified in the notice and the amount determined under the Rule 10.3.2(4) methodology [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7]. The Rule 10.3.2(4) amount is calculated differently depending on the case. For a Captive Cell of a Captive Insurer which is a Cell Company, it is the sum of (i) the Insurance Liabilities attributable to that Captive Cell and (ii) the Minimum Cellular Capital Requirement applicable to that Captive Cell [#SRC:9585f95e-ae97-44a1-966f-ec94cc458c39]. For a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company, it is the sum of (i) the Captive Insurer’s Insurance Liabilities and (ii) the Captive Insurer’s minimum capital requirement as provided for in Rule 2.2 [#SRC:9585f95e-ae97-44a1-966f-ec94cc458c39]. Accordingly, the collateral notice requirement operates within these case-specific calculation limits.

question: If the Regulator sends a collateral notice, how can the Regulator decide the value limit for the assets a Captive Insurer must make available, and how is that limit worked out in the case of a Long-Term Insurance Fund?
gold_answer: The Regulator is allowed to require a Captive Insurer, by written collateral notice, to make available assets, but the value of those assets is not open-ended: it is set as the lower of (i) any amount stated in the notice and (ii) the amount calculated under the Rule 10.3.2(4) framework, with the value determined in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 6 [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7]. In the specific case of a Long-Term Insurance Fund, the Rule 10.3.2(4) amount is calculated as the sum of two components: (1) the Insurance Liabilities attributable to that Long-Term Insurance Fund and (2) the Minimum Fund Capital Requirement applicable to that Long-Term Insurance Fund, subject to the stated conditions that apply to that case [#SRC:9585f95e-ae97-44a1-966f-ec94cc458c39]. Practically, this means the collateral notice can require assets only up to the smaller of the notice’s stated amount (if any) and this liabilities-plus-capital-requirement total for the Long-Term Insurance Fund.

question: In defining when a filed Prospectus becomes an Approved Prospectus, how do the Regulations’ general test for approval under the Rules interact with the requirement that the Regulator issue an approval notice to the Applicant, including where the Prospectus consists of multiple documents?
gold_answer: Read together, the two definitions establish both a general criterion and a specific procedural condition for when a Prospectus attains “Approved Prospectus” status. Under the Regulations, a Prospectus qualifies as an Approved Prospectus when it is approved by the Regulator in accordance with the requirements prescribed in the Rules, and references to a Prospectus in the Regulations are generally to an Approved Prospectus unless context indicates otherwise [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1]. The Source clarifies that merely filing a Prospectus with the Regulator does not meet that status unless the Regulator has issued to the Applicant a notice stating its approval [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e]. That notice must cover the Prospectus (or, where applicable, the Supplementary Prospectus), and if the Prospectus comprises multiple documents, the notice must state approval of all of those documents [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e]. Accordingly, the general “approved in accordance with the Rules” standard is operationalized by requiring an explicit approval notice to the Applicant, and the multi-document structure does not dilute the approval requirement; it expands the scope of what must be expressly approved.

question: When is a Prospectus treated as an Approved Prospectus, and why is filing it with the Regulator not enough unless the Regulator sends the Applicant an approval notice (including for a Prospectus made up of several documents)?
gold_answer: A Prospectus is treated as an Approved Prospectus only when it has actually been approved by the Regulator in line with the requirements prescribed in the Rules, and the Regulations generally treat any reference to a “Prospectus” as meaning an Approved Prospectus unless the context requires otherwise [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1]. The Source adds an important practical condition: simply filing a Prospectus with the Regulator does not make it an Approved Prospectus unless the Regulator has issued a notice to the Applicant stating that it approves the Prospectus (or, where relevant, the Supplementary Prospectus) [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e]. If the Prospectus is made up of multiple documents, the approval notice must state approval of all of those documents, not just some of them [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e]. Put together, the Target provides the definition based on Regulator approval under the Rules, while the Source explains that the approval must be evidenced by a specific notice issued to the Applicant, and that the notice must cover the full set of documents where the Prospectus is multi-part.

question: When an Authorised Person is designing and operating anti-fraud and anti-Financial Crime systems, how must it meet its duty to establish and maintain effective systems and controls to deter, prevent, and report suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes, and to what extent may it incorporate secure authentication, biometrics, and monitoring of customer behaviour metrics as part of those systems and controls?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must establish and maintain effective systems and controls that are capable of deterring and preventing suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes against the Authorised Person and its Customers, and it must also ensure those systems and controls support reporting suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes to the relevant authorities [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596]. In meeting that obligation, the Authorised Person should observe best practices when establishing the required systems and controls, recognising that Financial Crime evolves over time [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7]. Those best practices may include incorporating secure authentication, biometrics, and the monitoring of customer behaviour metrics into the anti-fraud and anti-Financial Crime systems and controls, as part of a broader control framework aimed at deterrence, prevention, and effective escalation/reporting of suspected activity [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7]. Accordingly, the obligation sets the required outcomes (effective deterrence, prevention, and reporting), while the permission/guidance supports using these specific techniques as optional components to strengthen the overall effectiveness of the systems and controls [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7].

question: What does an Authorised Person have to do to stop and report suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes, and can it use secure authentication, biometrics, and customer behaviour monitoring to help meet that requirement?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must put in place and keep effective systems and controls that deter and prevent suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes against the Authorised Person and its Customers, and it must also report suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes to the relevant authorities [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596]. When building the required systems and controls, the Authorised Person should follow best practices because Financial Crime changes over time, so controls need to be designed with that evolving risk in mind [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7]. As part of those best practices, the Authorised Person may incorporate secure authentication, biometrics, and monitoring of customer behaviour metrics into its anti-fraud and anti-Financial Crime systems and controls [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7]. These measures are not described as the only way to comply, but they are expressly identified as examples of practices that can be used to strengthen the systems and controls that the Authorised Person is required to establish and maintain for deterrence, prevention, and reporting [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7].

question: Where Eligible Green Portfolio Assets in an ADGM Green Portfolio are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark, must the Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager still appoint a third party to provide ongoing and at least annual attestation of compliance, and how does this interact with the limitation that the attestation obligation applies only to the portion invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager of an ADGM Green Portfolio is generally required to appoint a third party to attest, on an ongoing basis and at least annually, to the Investment Manager’s compliance with the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement, but that obligation is scoped to apply only to the portion of the Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e]. Separately, the scope provision states that the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86]. Read together, the Investment Manager must apply the attestation obligation only to the relevant portion of Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that falls within the stated applicability, and must exclude from that attestation any Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that meet the EU Paris Aligned Benchmark condition. In practice, this means the third-party appointment and attestation coverage should be calibrated to the portfolio’s composition so that only in-scope assets are attested and the benchmark-tracking assets are carved out.

question: If an ADGM Green Portfolio holds Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark, does the Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager still have to hire a third party to attest compliance at least every year, and which part of the assets does that attestation cover?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager of an ADGM Green Portfolio must appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually, but the obligation is expressly limited to the portion of the Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e]. At the same time, the scope statement provides that the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86]. Putting these together, the Investment Manager’s third-party attestation should not be required for the benchmark-tracking Eligible Green Portfolio Assets, even though the Investment Manager still has an attestation obligation for any remaining portion of Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy. The practical result is that the attestation engagement should be structured to cover only the in-scope portion and to exclude the EU Paris Aligned Benchmark-tracking portion.

question: When a person is making an Offer of a Unit, how is the scope of this Chapter and its related Rules limited, and how does that exclusion align with the treatment of Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds under the Rulebook’s prospectus content and structure requirements?
gold_answer: Where a person is making an Offer of a Unit, the scope of the regime is expressly narrowed so that the provisions in the Chapter and any Rules made for the purposes of that Chapter do not apply to that person in relation to that activity [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a]. This exclusion is consistent with the separate treatment of Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds under the Rulebook: the prospectus requirements on content and structure in chapter 4 of the Rulebook are stated not to apply to Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds, and instead the prospectus requirements that do apply to an Offer of Units of Funds are located in the Fund Rules [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94]. Read together, the passages indicate that, for Unit-related offers, the general Chapter-based framework and the general chapter 4 prospectus content/structure framework are both disapplied in their respective ways, with the applicable prospectus obligations for Offers of Units of Funds being redirected to the Fund Rules rather than the general Rulebook chapter 4 requirements [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] and with the Chapter itself not applying to the person for the act of making the Offer of a Unit [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a].

question: If someone is making an Offer of a Unit, do the rules in this Chapter apply to them, and does the Rulebook’s usual prospectus content and structure chapter apply to Prospectuses for Units of Funds?
gold_answer: For a person making an Offer of a Unit, the provisions in the Chapter and the Rules made for the purposes of that Chapter are stated not to apply to that person in relation to making that offer [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a]. Separately, the Rulebook explains that its prospectus requirements on content and structure in chapter 4 do not apply to Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94]. Instead of relying on those general chapter 4 prospectus requirements, the Rulebook points to a different source for what does apply: prospectus requirements that apply to an Offer of Units of Funds are found in the Fund Rules [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94]. Taken together, these two scope statements mean that Unit-related offers are carved out from the Chapter-based framework for the act of making the offer, and Fund Prospectuses are carved out from the general chapter 4 content and structure requirements, with the applicable prospectus obligations for Offers of Units of Funds being addressed through the Fund Rules rather than the general prospectus chapter [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] while the Chapter itself is disapplied for the person making the Offer of a Unit [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a].

question: Where an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and is determining the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure under the specified measurement basis, how must the Authorised Person recognise the effect of that Collateral across the Non Trading Book and the Trading Book, including any consistency and non-combination requirements?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined under the specified measurement basis, the firm is permitted to recognise the effect of that Collateral (i.e., it may take the Collateral’s effect into account when measuring E) [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778]. However, when it does so, the method it must use depends on whether the SFT sits in the Non Trading Book or the Trading Book. For any SFT in the Non Trading Book, the Authorised Person must use either the FCSA or the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral, must apply the chosen approach consistently to the entire Non Trading Book, and must not combine the two approaches within that book [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412]. For any pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT in the Trading Book, the Authorised Person must only use the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412].

question: When an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and seeks to take that Collateral into account in measuring pre settlement Counterparty Exposure, what approach selection is permitted, and what mandatory constraints apply to approach choice and mixing for the Non Trading Book versus the Trading Book?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT is allowed to recognise the effect of that Collateral when measuring the relevant pre settlement Counterparty Exposure, provided the exposure is determined under the specified measurement basis and the recognition is done in accordance with the applicable recognition framework referenced in the permission [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778]. Once the firm elects to recognise collateral effects, the Target text imposes mandatory constraints on how that recognition must be performed depending on book classification. In the Non Trading Book, the Authorised Person must choose one of two approaches—either the FCSA or the FCCA—to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral, must apply that chosen approach consistently across the entire Non Trading Book, and must not use a combination of both approaches within that book [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412]. In contrast, for any pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT in the Trading Book, the Authorised Person is restricted to a single approach and must only use the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412].

question: If an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and wants to count that Collateral when measuring the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure, what must it do in the Non Trading Book and what must it do in the Trading Book?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined under the specified measurement basis, the firm is allowed to recognise the effect of that Collateral (so it can reflect the Collateral’s effect in the exposure measurement) in line with the recognition framework referenced in the permission [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778]. But the way it must recognise that effect depends on where the SFT sits. For any SFT in the Non Trading Book, the Authorised Person must use either the FCSA or the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral, must use the same chosen approach consistently across the entire Non Trading Book, and must not mix the two approaches in that book [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412]. For any pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT in the Trading Book, the Authorised Person must only use the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412].

question: When an Authorised Person has eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and is measuring the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure, can it recognise the Collateral’s effect, and if it does, how must it pick and apply FCSA or FCCA across the Non Trading Book and the Trading Book?
gold_answer: Yes. If an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined under the specified measurement basis, it may recognise the effect of that Collateral when measuring E, subject to following the recognition framework referenced in the permission [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778]. Once it recognises collateral effects, it must follow strict approach rules based on book classification. In the Non Trading Book, the Authorised Person must choose one approach—either the FCSA or the FCCA—to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral, must apply that chosen approach consistently to the entire Non Trading Book, and must not use a combination of both approaches within that book [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412]. For SFTs in the Trading Book, the rule is tighter: for any pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT in the Trading Book, the Authorised Person must only use the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412].

question: When an Authorised Person is permitted to reduce the value of its Exposures using credit risk mitigation techniques, what policy documentation must it maintain regarding the use of exclusions, and how should that documentation align with the discretionary reductions it applies?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may, for the purposes of the Section on recognition of credit risk mitigations, reduce the value of its Exposures at its discretion by applying one or more specified reduction methods, including specific provisions tied to credit loss risk, eligible netting (subject to applicable conditions), qualifying Collateral, eligible guarantees, qualifying Credit Derivatives, and securitisation-based credit risk transfers where the stated conditions are met [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3]. In parallel with exercising that discretion, the Authorised Person must document its policy governing the use of any exclusions referenced for recognition of credit risk mitigations [#SRC:5a4ad383-0e7b-476f-84ee-d6bce45b2270]. Practically, this means the firm’s written policy should clearly describe when and how it will apply exclusions in connection with its chosen exposure-reduction approaches, so that the discretionary use of provisions, netting, Collateral, guarantees, Credit Derivatives, or securitisation is supported by an articulated internal framework. The documentation obligation is not optional and should be maintained as part of the firm’s approach to applying the permitted exposure reductions under the Section.

question: If an Authorised Person chooses to reduce the value of its Exposures using things like provisions, netting, Collateral, guarantees, Credit Derivatives, or securitisation, what written policy must it have about using exclusions?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is permitted, for the purposes of the Section on recognition of credit risk mitigations, to reduce the value of its Exposures at its discretion by using one or more of the listed methods, such as deducting specific provisions related to credit loss risk, netting claims and liabilities to a Counterparty where the stated conditions are met, applying qualifying Collateral, using eligible guarantees, recognising qualifying Credit Derivatives, and reflecting securitisation transactions that transfer Credit Risks where the relevant conditions are satisfied [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3]. If it does so, it also has a separate mandatory requirement: the Authorised Person must document its policy for the use of any exclusions referenced for recognition of credit risk mitigations [#SRC:5a4ad383-0e7b-476f-84ee-d6bce45b2270]. In other words, even though the exposure reductions are discretionary, the firm must still keep a written policy explaining how it will use exclusions in this area, so its approach to applying the permitted reductions is governed by documented internal rules rather than ad hoc decisions.

question: When a Fund Manager appoints an auditor for a Fund, what must the Fund Manager require the auditor to do in relation to auditing the Fund’s financial statements, and what specific statements must the Fund Manager ensure the Auditor includes when producing the Fund Auditor’s Report?
gold_answer: A Fund Manager must take two linked steps that span both the audit work and the resulting reporting. First, the Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to conduct an audit of the Fund’s financial statements in accordance with the requirements of the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB), and to produce a Fund Auditor’s Report on the audited financial statements [#SRC:8949f938-33e5-4393-a256-021917125579]. Second, when procuring the production of that Fund Auditor’s Report, the Fund Manager must ensure that an Auditor states a defined set of matters in the report, including whether the financial statements were properly prepared in accordance with the financial reporting standards adopted by the Fund, whether they give a true and fair view of the Fund’s (or Sub-Fund’s) financial position and results for the annual accounting period, whether proper accounting records have not been kept or the statements are not in agreement with records/returns or do not comply with applicable standards, whether the Auditor received all necessary information and explanations, whether the Directors’ report or the Fund Manager’s report is consistent with the financial statements, and any other matter required by FUNDS [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce].

question: In meeting its obligations around the Fund Auditor’s Report, how must a Fund Manager structure its written instruction to the auditor regarding the audit, and what minimum content must the Fund Manager ensure the Auditor expressly addresses in the report for the annual accounting period?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager’s obligations operate as a chain from instruction to deliverable. The Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to conduct an audit of the Fund’s financial statements in accordance with the relevant IAASB standards and to produce a Fund Auditor’s Report on those audited financial statements [#SRC:8949f938-33e5-4393-a256-021917125579]. Beyond requiring the report, the Fund Manager must also manage the report’s substance: in procuring the production of the Fund Auditor’s Report, the Fund Manager must ensure that an Auditor states at least the specified conclusions and disclosures. These include whether the financial statements were properly prepared under the financial reporting standards adopted by the Fund, whether they present a true and fair view of the Fund’s (or Sub-Fund’s) financial position and performance for the annual accounting period and at period end, and whether there are issues such as accounting records not being kept, lack of agreement between statements and records/returns, or non-compliance with applicable financial reporting standards [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce]. The Auditor must also state whether it received all information and explanations necessary for the audit, whether the Directors’ report or the Fund Manager’s report is consistent with the financial statements, and any other matter or opinion required by FUNDS [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce].

question: What does a Fund Manager have to tell its auditor to do about auditing the Fund’s financial statements, and what does the Fund Manager have to make sure the Auditor says in the Fund Auditor’s Report?
gold_answer: A Fund Manager must do more than simply appoint an auditor; it must set clear requirements for both the audit and the report. The Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to conduct an audit of the Fund’s financial statements in line with the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB), and it must require the auditor to produce a Fund Auditor’s Report on the audited financial statements [#SRC:8949f938-33e5-4393-a256-021917125579]. Then, when the Fund Manager is procuring the production of that Fund Auditor’s Report, it must ensure the Auditor includes specific statements. These cover whether the financial statements were properly prepared using the financial reporting standards adopted by the Fund, whether they give a true and fair view of the Fund’s (or Sub-Fund’s) financial position and results for the annual accounting period and at the end of that period, and whether there are problems such as missing accounting records, disagreement between the financial statements and accounting records/returns, or non-compliance with applicable financial reporting standards [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce]. The Auditor must also state whether it received all necessary information and explanations, whether the Directors’ report or the Fund Manager’s report is consistent with the financial statements, and any other matter required by FUNDS [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce].

question: If a Fund Manager is arranging for a Fund Auditor’s Report, what are the two main things it must do: one about the audit itself and one about what the report must cover?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager has two connected duties: one is to make sure the audit is carried out properly, and the other is to make sure the report contains the required conclusions. On the audit side, the Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to conduct an audit of the Fund’s financial statements in accordance with the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB), and to produce a Fund Auditor’s Report on the audited financial statements [#SRC:8949f938-33e5-4393-a256-021917125579]. On the report side, when procuring the production of the Fund Auditor’s Report, the Fund Manager must ensure that an Auditor states whether the financial statements were properly prepared under the financial reporting standards adopted by the Fund, and whether they give a true and fair view of the Fund’s (or Sub-Fund’s) financial position and results for the annual accounting period and at the end of that period [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce]. It must also ensure the report addresses whether proper accounting records have not been kept or the statements do not agree with records/returns or do not comply with applicable standards, whether the Auditor received all necessary information and explanations, whether the Directors’ report or the Fund Manager’s report is consistent with the financial statements, and any other matter required by FUNDS [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce].

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity withholds detail of material economic assumptions on the basis of commercial sensitivity, what must it include in its disclosure to substantiate that position, and how should it assess whether the claim is credible where no commercially sensitive contracts underpin commodity price, capital expenditure, or operational expenditure assumptions?
gold_answer: Where a Mining Reporting Entity treats material economic assumptions used to determine forecast financial information as commercially sensitive, its disclosure must still include all material economic assumptions employed, and—specifically for any assumptions it considers commercially sensitive—a clear statement that the assumptions are commercially sensitive together with an explanation of the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions, as well as all other material assumptions utilised [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. In applying that requirement, the Entity should be careful not to assert commercial sensitivity where it is not genuinely the case: if it has not yet entered into any commercially sensitive contracts that underpin its commodity price, capital expenditure, or operational expenditure assumptions, it would be difficult to form a view that information about those assumptions would be commercially sensitive [#TGT:3b4ca4c9-5690-4bae-8c30-3d06642d6e95]. Accordingly, the Entity should align its sensitivity statement and methodology explanation with the factual basis for sensitivity, and avoid using sensitivity as a blanket rationale where the underlying assumptions are not contractually or otherwise commercially constrained.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity says its key economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, what does it have to add to its disclosure, and what warning applies if it has not signed any sensitive contracts supporting its price, capex, or opex assumptions?
gold_answer: If a Mining Reporting Entity considers its material economic assumptions (used to determine forecast financial information) to be commercially sensitive, it must still disclose all material economic assumptions employed, and it must add a statement that the assumptions are commercially sensitive plus an explanation of the methodology used to determine those assumptions; it must also disclose all other material assumptions utilised [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. At the same time, it needs to be careful not to label information as commercially sensitive when it is not: where the Entity has not yet entered into any commercially sensitive contracts that underpin its commodity price, capital expenditure, or operational expenditure assumptions, it would be difficult to justify treating information about those assumptions as commercially sensitive [#TGT:3b4ca4c9-5690-4bae-8c30-3d06642d6e95]. Practically, that means the Entity should only use the sensitivity statement when there is a real basis for it, and it should ensure the methodology explanation is consistent with the actual circumstances supporting (or not supporting) the sensitivity claim.

question: How must an Authorised Person maintain its Financial Group Capital Resources relative to its Financial Group Capital Requirement, and if it fails to do so, what factors will the Regulator consider—particularly regarding remedial steps—when deciding whether to take enforcement action?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must ensure on an ongoing basis that its Financial Group Capital Resources (calculated under the applicable capital resources calculation) are at least equal to its Financial Group Capital Requirement (calculated under the applicable requirement calculation), meaning it must continuously monitor and manage its position so that resources do not fall below the requirement [#TGT:b0fe779d-b7f0-48a6-a00d-06a3f3dc8106]. If the Authorised Person breaches the relevant rule underpinning this obligation, the Regulator’s approach to enforcement is not automatic or purely mechanical; instead, the Regulator will take into account the full circumstances of the case when determining what enforcement action, if any, it will take [#SRC:12a7fe75-3ede-4f19-86af-34a1e60cfe3b]. Those circumstances expressly include any remedial steps taken either by another regulator or by the Authorised Person itself, so evidence of prompt corrective measures and coordination with other regulators can be relevant to the Regulator’s decision on whether and how to proceed. This links the continuous capital maintenance duty with the procedural enforcement assessment applied after a breach.

question: What does an Authorised Person have to do to keep its group capital position compliant at all times, and if it falls short, how will the Regulator look at the situation (including any fixes made by the Authorised Person or another regulator) before deciding on enforcement?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to keep its Financial Group Capital Resources at least equal to, or higher than, its Financial Group Capital Requirement at all times, based on the specified methods for calculating each figure [#TGT:b0fe779d-b7f0-48a6-a00d-06a3f3dc8106]. This is a continuous obligation, so the Authorised Person should be able to demonstrate that it monitors and manages its capital position so that resources do not drop below the requirement. If the Authorised Person breaches the relevant rule connected to this requirement, the Regulator will not decide enforcement solely on the fact of the breach; it will take into account the full circumstances of the case when determining what enforcement action, if any, it will take [#SRC:12a7fe75-3ede-4f19-86af-34a1e60cfe3b]. In doing so, the Regulator will consider remedial steps, including steps taken by the Authorised Person itself and steps taken by another regulator. Practically, that means the Authorised Person’s corrective actions and any parallel regulatory remediation can be important context in how the Regulator assesses the breach and whether enforcement is warranted.

question: For an Applicant seeking to admit Debentures to the Official List, how must the minimum market value threshold be applied, and how does that obligation differ from the requirements triggered when the Applicant instead relies on the assets eligibility test?
gold_answer: When an Applicant applies to admit Debentures to the Official List, it must ensure that both the Applicant and the Securities it seeks to admit have a Market Capitalisation of at least $2 million; this is a direct minimum-threshold condition tied specifically to Debentures and is framed as something the Applicant must ensure for itself and the relevant Securities [#SRC:7aa7740f-0ed0-4fd2-8217-d13529994838]. By contrast, the assets eligibility test is a defined pathway that applies as an eligibility test (used in the Shares context) and is met only if the Applicant satisfies the requirements that constitute that test; it is not expressed as a standalone market-capitalisation minimum in the definition itself, but rather as a set of requirements the Applicant must satisfy to meet that test [#TGT:86469cd3-cfcc-448c-b4e2-e50bf2d32f91]. Accordingly, the compliance approach differs: for Debentures, the Applicant should evidence the $2 million Market Capitalisation for both itself and the Debentures being admitted, whereas for the assets eligibility test the Applicant should focus on demonstrating satisfaction of the test’s underlying requirements as the condition for meeting that eligibility route.

question: If an Applicant is listing Debentures, what minimum market value must it make sure it and the Debentures meet, and how is that different from what it must do to meet the assets eligibility test?
gold_answer: For Debentures, the Applicant has a clear minimum market value obligation: it must ensure that it, and the Securities it seeks to admit to the Official List, have a Market Capitalisation of at least $2 million [#SRC:7aa7740f-0ed0-4fd2-8217-d13529994838]. That requirement is framed as a specific threshold the Applicant must ensure is met for both the Applicant and the Debentures being admitted. The assets eligibility test, however, is defined as an eligibility test that is met only when the Applicant satisfies the requirements that make up that test; the definition focuses on the need to satisfy those requirements rather than stating a market-capitalisation minimum [#TGT:86469cd3-cfcc-448c-b4e2-e50bf2d32f91]. So, in practical terms, Debenture applicants should be prepared to demonstrate the $2 million Market Capitalisation for both the Applicant and the Debentures, while an Applicant relying on the assets eligibility test should be prepared to show it satisfies the test’s specified requirements in order to meet that eligibility route.

question: When applying the CRM provisions to determine the value inputs for a reverse repurchase agreement, how must the MV of Securities and the value of Collateral be calculated, and how do those calculated amounts feed into the defined exposure measure E for that transaction?
gold_answer: For a reverse repurchase agreement, the exposure measure E is defined by combining two specific components: the Amount paid (or Collateral given) and the MV of the Securities received, as set out in the reverse repurchase agreement definition [#TGT:4262e773-aad2-4422-b6b3-fea38fd9d619]. The MV of Securities and the value of Collateral that populate those components are not left to ad hoc valuation; instead, they should be calculated in accordance with the CRM provisions referenced for those values [#SRC:379a83c2-96da-4b2a-acea-f8779444878d]. Practically, this means that when you compute E for a reverse repurchase agreement, you must first determine (i) the MV of the Securities received and (ii) the value of any Collateral given using the CRM calculation approach, and then use those CRM-calculated figures as the relevant inputs in the E definition. This links the required valuation methodology (CRM-based calculation of MV and collateral value) to the defined exposure formula for reverse repurchase agreements, ensuring consistency between the valuation rules and the exposure computation.

question: For a reverse repurchase agreement, what is E made up of, and what method must be used to calculate the MV of the Securities and the value of any Collateral that go into that E calculation?
gold_answer: In a reverse repurchase agreement, E is defined using two elements: the Amount paid (or Collateral given) and the MV of the Securities received [#TGT:4262e773-aad2-4422-b6b3-fea38fd9d619]. To apply that definition correctly, the MV of Securities and the value of Collateral used in those elements should be calculated in accordance with the CRM provisions [#SRC:379a83c2-96da-4b2a-acea-f8779444878d]. In other words, you do not simply insert any market value or collateral figure into the E definition; you must first calculate the MV of the Securities and the collateral value using the CRM approach specified for those values, and then use those CRM-calculated amounts as the inputs to E. This ensures that both the securities leg (MV of the Securities received) and the collateral leg (Amount paid or Collateral given, where relevant) are valued consistently under the CRM provisions before being combined in the reverse repurchase agreement exposure measure.

question: Where a trader rapidly accumulates control of more than 90% of the physical inventory underlying a crude oil contract on a Commodity Derivative Exchange and then exits the position in the final settlement window at escalating prices, how should this conduct be assessed against the definition of Behaviour that involves effecting transactions or orders to trade other than for legitimate reasons and not in conformity with Accepted Market Practices, particularly in relation to creating a misleading impression of supply/demand or securing an abnormal or artificial price level?
gold_answer: The scenario describes an “abusive squeeze” in which a trader rapidly builds a dominant position in the physical inventory underlying a crude oil contract, does not offer to lend the crude oil back at a reasonable commercial rate, and then unwinds the position in the Exchange’s final settlement window at rapidly increasing prices, with the stated effect of cornering/squeezing the market and causing an abnormal movement in forward-month crude oil contract prices [#SRC:350b6237-da6f-47c6-b04c-10caf56bf9d7]. Under the definition, the relevant assessment is whether the trader’s conduct constitutes “Behaviour” consisting of effecting transactions or orders to trade otherwise than for legitimate reasons and not in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market, and whether those transactions/orders (a) give or are likely to give a false or misleading impression as to supply, demand, or price, or (b) secure the price at an abnormal or artificial level [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f]. The described withholding of inventory from lending and the subsequent unwind at escalating prices, coupled with the abnormal price movement, are the key factual elements to map to the definition’s “misleading impression” and “abnormal/artificial level” limbs.

question: If a trader quickly takes more than 90% of the physical crude oil inventory behind a contract and then sells out during the final settlement window at rising prices, when does that become the kind of Behaviour defined as trading without legitimate reasons and not following Accepted Market Practices—especially if it makes supply/demand look different or pushes prices to an abnormal level?
gold_answer: In the example, the Regulator describes an abusive squeeze where, during a trading day on a Commodity Derivative Exchange, a trader rapidly builds up more than 90% of the physical inventory underlying a crude oil contract, fails to offer to lend the crude oil back to other market participants at a reasonable commercial rate, and then unwinds the position in the Exchange’s final settlement window at rapidly increasing prices, thereby cornering/squeezing the market and causing an abnormal movement in the price of crude oil contracts for forward month delivery [#SRC:350b6237-da6f-47c6-b04c-10caf56bf9d7]. The definition to apply asks whether the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade other than for legitimate reasons and not in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market, and whether those trades/orders either (a) give or are likely to give a false or misleading impression about supply, demand, or price, or (b) secure the price at an abnormal or artificial level [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f]. Practically, you would connect the inventory dominance, refusal to lend, and settlement-window unwind to the definition’s focus on misleading impressions and abnormal/artificial pricing outcomes.

question: When an Authorised Person is using the FCCA, how should eligible financial Collateral be defined by combining the general composition criteria (including instruments listed in the relevant rule, certain traded equity Securities, and qualifying Units in a Collective Investment Fund) with the specific exclusion for certain Capital instruments issued within the Authorised Person’s Financial Group and held as Collateral?
gold_answer: For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral is defined by starting with the categories that are permitted and then applying the stated carve-out. The permitted composition includes (i) any instrument listed in the relevant rule, (ii) any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange, and (iii) any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund that invests in those traded equity Securities, provided a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily and at least 90% of the Fund’s deposited property is invested in instruments listed in the FCCA eligibility rule and the referenced rule. However, even if an instrument would otherwise fall within the “instrument listed” limb, it must be treated as ineligible if it is a T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by any entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person and held by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities as Collateral. This exclusion operates as a limitation on what can be counted as eligible financial Collateral under the FCCA definition. [#SRC:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685] [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85]

question: In defining eligible financial Collateral for an Authorised Person using the FCCA, how do the eligibility conditions for Units in a Collective Investment Fund interact with the rule-based instrument list, and what additional restriction applies where the Collateral is a T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by an entity in the Authorised Person’s Financial Group and held within that group as Collateral?
gold_answer: Eligible financial Collateral for an Authorised Person using the FCCA includes Units in a Collective Investment Fund only where the Fund invests in equity Securities that are traded on a regulated exchange, the Unit price is publicly quoted daily, and at least 90% of the Fund’s deposited property is invested in instruments that are within the FCCA eligibility rule and the referenced rule-based list. This means the Fund’s portfolio must be predominantly composed of instruments that meet the specified eligibility framework, including those drawn from the instrument list incorporated by reference. At the same time, the definition is constrained by an explicit exclusion that removes certain intra-group capital instruments from eligibility: any T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by any entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person is excluded where it is held by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities as Collateral. Accordingly, even if a capital instrument might otherwise appear to fit within the broader “instrument listed” concept that supports the Fund’s 90% test, it cannot be treated as eligible financial Collateral when it meets the intra-group issuance and holding conditions. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] [#SRC:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685]

question: If an Authorised Person is using the FCCA, what counts as eligible financial Collateral, and what kinds of T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument must be left out when they are issued within the Authorised Person’s Financial Group and held as Collateral?
gold_answer: For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral is built from three main buckets: instruments that are on the relevant rule-based list, equity Securities (including a convertible bond) that are traded on a regulated exchange, and Units in a Collective Investment Fund that invests in those traded equity Securities. For the Fund Units to qualify, the Unit price must be publicly quoted daily and at least 90% of the Fund’s deposited property must be invested in instruments that fall within the FCCA eligibility rule and the referenced rule-based list. After identifying Collateral that fits within those categories, an additional filter must be applied: eligible financial Collateral excludes any T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by any entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person, where that instrument is held by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities as Collateral. So, even if a capital instrument could otherwise be viewed as part of the “instrument listed” category, it is not eligible when it is an intra-group T1 or T2 Capital instrument held as Collateral. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] [#SRC:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685]

question: When checking whether Collateral is eligible financial Collateral under the FCCA, how do you apply the list of allowed instruments and the rules for traded equity Securities and Fund Units, while also making sure you do not include excluded Capital instruments issued by an entity in the Authorised Person’s Financial Group?
gold_answer: To determine eligible financial Collateral under the FCCA for an Authorised Person, first confirm the Collateral fits within the allowed types: it is either an instrument on the relevant rule-based list, an equity Security (including a convertible bond) traded on a regulated exchange, or a Unit in a Collective Investment Fund that invests in those traded equity Securities. If the Collateral is a Fund Unit, it only qualifies if its price is publicly quoted daily and at least 90% of the Fund’s deposited property is invested in instruments that are within the FCCA eligibility rule and the referenced rule-based list. Once the Collateral meets one of these inclusion tests, you must then apply the exclusion that overrides eligibility for certain intra-group capital instruments. Specifically, you must not treat as eligible any T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by any entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person, where it is held by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities as Collateral. This ensures the FCCA eligibility definition is applied with both the inclusion categories and the mandatory carve-out. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] [#SRC:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685]

question: For an Authorised Person, what conditions must be satisfied to be treated as Category 2, and how does that classification differ from Category 1 where the Financial Services Permission covers deposit-taking or managing a PSIAu?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is in Category 2 where its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (and not merely acting as Matched Principal), its dealing activities are not limited in scope in the way contemplated for certain limited dealing permissions, and it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5 [#SRC:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f]. The Target text reinforces that Category 2 status is determinatively driven by authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, together with the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1, and it also clarifies that where dealing is limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the firm’s activities fall within Category 3A rather than Category 2 [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. By contrast, Category 1 is determinatively based on authorisation to Accept Deposits or to Manage a Profit Sharing Investment Account that is a PSIAu, provided the Authorised Person does not meet Category 5; other authorisations may exist but do not drive the Category 1 classification [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66].

question: When is an Authorised Person put in Category 2, and how can you tell it is not Category 1 based on what its Financial Services Permission lets it do?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person falls into Category 2 when its Financial Services Permission allows it to do Providing Credit or to do Dealing in Investments as Principal (and not as Matched Principal), its dealing permission is not restricted to a limited scope of dealing, and it also does not meet the criteria for Categories 1 or 5 [#SRC:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f]. The Target text adds practical classification guidance: even if the firm can do other Regulated Activities, Category 2 is driven by being authorised for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, and by not being authorised for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1; it also explains that if the firm’s dealing is limited to acting only as Matched Principal, that dealing sits in Category 3A rather than Category 2 [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. You can tell it is not Category 1 because Category 1 is driven by permission to Accept Deposits or to Manage a Profit Sharing Investment Account that is a PSIAu (and not meeting Category 5), which is a different determinative permission set from Category 2 [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66].
