The individual referred to in Rule 15.9.4 must provide a written statement confirming that the reconciliation has been undertaken in accordance with the requirements of the relevant section, so there is clear written evidence that the reconciliation was carried out as required [#SRC:bcd90aa9-d7d1-47be-b4cb-45b877ddba30]. In addition, the reconciliation performed in accordance with Rule 15.9.1 must be reviewed by a member of the Authorised Person who has adequate seniority, meaning the review must be done by someone sufficiently senior within the Authorised Person rather than by a junior staff member [#TGT:60712e89-ce53-445d-81a8-f2d744fc8851]. Together, these obligations ensure both documentation (through the written statement) and oversight (through senior review) for reconciliations carried out under the specified reconciliation rule.

question: How must a Listed Entity structure and hold its Board accountable to ensure prudent and sound management of its business, and how does this obligation align with the governance standards applicable to a Reporting Entity, including the ability to implement additional measures where needed to meet the relevant Principles?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity is required to have an effective Board that is collectively accountable for ensuring the Listed Entity’s business is managed prudently and soundly [#TGT:cc0b2dc3-e4d1-4d0b-9e8f-9e362faac1ac]. This obligation aligns with the corresponding requirement that every Reporting Entity must have an effective Board of Directors (the Board) with collective accountability for ensuring the Reporting Entity’s business is managed prudently and soundly [#SRC:47a6d063-88ea-47de-8f2f-a3fb49962d43]. In applying these parallel obligations, the governance standards for a Reporting Entity are expressly described as not exhaustive, and therefore a Reporting Entity may implement additional measures as required to comply with the Principles and contribute to sound and prudent governance of the entity [#SRC:47a6d063-88ea-47de-8f2f-a3fb49962d43]. Read together, both frameworks place the core duty on an effective Board with collective accountability for prudent and sound management, while the Reporting Entity framework also contemplates supplementing baseline standards with additional measures where necessary to achieve compliance with the Principles.

question: What does a Listed Entity have to do to make sure it has an effective Board that is responsible for prudent and sound management, and how is this similar to what a Reporting Entity must do, including the option to add extra governance measures if needed?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity must have an effective Board that is collectively accountable for ensuring the Listed Entity’s business is managed prudently and soundly [#TGT:cc0b2dc3-e4d1-4d0b-9e8f-9e362faac1ac]. This is essentially the same core requirement imposed on a Reporting Entity, which must have an effective Board of Directors (the Board) that is collectively accountable for ensuring the Reporting Entity’s business is managed prudently and soundly [#SRC:47a6d063-88ea-47de-8f2f-a3fb49962d43]. In addition, the Reporting Entity governance standards are stated to be not exhaustive, meaning a Reporting Entity may implement any additional measures as required so it can comply with the Principles and contribute to sound and prudent governance of the entity [#SRC:47a6d063-88ea-47de-8f2f-a3fb49962d43]. Taken together, both texts require an effective, collectively accountable Board focused on prudent and sound management, and the Reporting Entity text also makes clear that extra measures may be added when needed to meet the Principles.

question: When a Listed Entity seeks the Regulator’s approval to allot, issue, or grant Shares with Weighted Voting Rights that change the equality or proportionality of Shareholder voting power and equity interest, what must the Board of the Listed Entity do to ensure compliance with its duty to treat holders of Securities of the same class or type equally in respect of all rights attaching to those Securities?
gold_answer: Where a Listed Entity is permitted, upon approval from the Regulator, to allot, issue or grant Shares with Weighted Voting Rights in a way that alters the equality and proportionality of Shareholder voting power and equity interest, the Board of that Listed Entity must still ensure equality of treatment of all holders of Securities of a particular class or type in respect of all rights attaching to the Securities of that class or type. In practice, the permission to introduce Weighted Voting Rights is conditional on Regulator approval and relates to changes in voting power and equity interest [#SRC:12f21edd-7868-4706-b1f4-3b2e9af8d6aa], but it does not displace the Board’s ongoing obligation to ensure that, within any given class or type of Securities, holders are treated equally as to the rights attached to that class or type. The Board should therefore structure and implement any approved Weighted Voting Rights so that any differentiation is properly reflected in the relevant class/type design and does not result in unequal treatment among holders within the same class or type regarding the rights attaching to those Securities, as required [#TGT:194cf07e-3ce5-429a-9d01-6e1c25bef4ae].

question: If a Listed Entity gets the Regulator’s approval to issue Shares with Weighted Voting Rights that change how voting power and equity interest are shared, what must the Board do to make sure investors holding the same class or type of Securities are treated equally for all rights attached to that class or type?
gold_answer: Even if a Listed Entity is allowed, with the Regulator’s approval, to allot, issue or grant Shares with Weighted Voting Rights that alter the equality and proportionality of Shareholder voting power and equity interest, the Board still has a separate duty about how investors are treated. Specifically, the Board of a Listed Entity must ensure equality of treatment of all holders of Securities of a particular class or type in respect of all rights attaching to the Securities of that class or type. That means the Board cannot rely on the fact that Weighted Voting Rights are permitted (subject to approval) to justify unequal treatment among holders within the same class or type of Securities. Instead, the Board should ensure that any approved Weighted Voting Rights are implemented in a way that preserves equal treatment for all holders within each class or type as to the rights attached to that class or type, while recognizing that the approved structure may change voting power and equity interest at the broader Shareholder level [#SRC:12f21edd-7868-4706-b1f4-3b2e9af8d6aa] and must still satisfy the equality-of-treatment requirement [#TGT:194cf07e-3ce5-429a-9d01-6e1c25bef4ae].

question: When an Authorised Person is determining whether it may recognise the credit risk mitigation effects of a guarantee provided by a multilateral development bank, what must it do to ensure the guarantor is a qualifying MDB and how must it treat any CR Exposure to that qualifying MDB for risk-weighting purposes?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may recognise the effects of CRM of a guarantee only where the guarantor is an eligible provider, which includes an MDB of the type referenced for this purpose [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d]. To meet that eligibility condition in the MDB context, the Authorised Person must confirm that the guarantor is one of the qualifying MDBs identified for the MDB asset class (for example, entities within the World Bank Group such as IBRD, MIGA, and IFC, as well as ADB, AfDB, EBRD, IADB, EIB, EIF, NIB, CDB, IDB, and CEDB) [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4]. Once the MDB is confirmed as qualifying, the Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to that qualifying MDB [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4]. In practice, the compliance steps are (i) validate the guarantor’s status against the qualifying MDB list to support recognition of the guarantee’s CRM effects, and (ii) apply the mandated 0% risk weight to the Authorised Person’s CR Exposure to that qualifying MDB, consistent with the MDB asset class treatment [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d] [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4].

question: If an Authorised Person wants to count a guarantee as credit risk mitigation and the guarantor is an MDB, what must the Authorised Person check about the MDB, and what risk weight must it apply to any CR Exposure to that MDB?
gold_answer: To use a guarantee as credit risk mitigation, an Authorised Person is permitted to recognise the guarantee’s CRM effects only if the guarantee is provided by an eligible type of entity, and one eligible category is an MDB of the relevant kind [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d]. Where the guarantor is an MDB, the Authorised Person must check that the MDB is one of the qualifying MDBs listed for the MDB asset class (including the World Bank Group entities IBRD, MIGA and IFC, and other named MDBs such as ADB, AfDB, EBRD, IADB, EIB, EIF, NIB, CDB, IDB and CEDB) [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4]. If the MDB is on that qualifying list, the Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to that qualifying MDB [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4]. So the practical sequence is: confirm the guarantor fits the eligible-MDB category so the guarantee’s CRM effects can be recognised, and then apply the required 0% risk weight to the Authorised Person’s CR Exposure to that qualifying MDB [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d] [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4].

question: May a Recognised Investment Exchange carry on the Regulated Activity of operating an MTF, and what conditions determine which rule sets apply to that MTF function versus the remainder of the Recognised Investment Exchange’s operations?
gold_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange is permitted to operate an MTF only where its Recognition Order includes an express stipulation allowing it to do so; without that stipulation, the permission to operate the MTF is not available. This permission framework is aligned across both passages: the SOURCE confirms the ability for a Recognised Investment Exchange to operate an MTF subject to the Recognition Order stipulation and adds that, where the MTF is operated using Virtual Assets, the Recognised Investment Exchange must meet the requirements of the Virtual Asset Framework for that MTF activity, while the remainder of its operations must continue to comply with the MIR Rules [#SRC:54b67759-66a7-4cbd-a335-1a40ee4894bb]. The TARGET similarly conditions the permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of operating an MTF (and also an OTF) on the same Recognition Order stipulation, and clarifies that if the stipulation is present, the specific rules on MTFs and OTFs in COBS apply to that function only, rather than to the Recognised Investment Exchange’s other functions [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388].

question: Can a Recognised Investment Exchange run an MTF, and if it can, which rules apply just to the MTF activity and which rules still apply to everything else it does?
gold_answer: Yes, but only on a condition: a Recognised Investment Exchange may operate an MTF only if its Recognition Order includes a stipulation that permits it. The SOURCE explains that this permission is tied to the Recognition Order and adds an important operational split: where the stipulation is granted and the Recognised Investment Exchange operates an MTF using Virtual Assets, it must meet the requirements of the Virtual Asset Framework for that MTF operation, while the remainder of its operations must be run in compliance with the MIR Rules [#SRC:54b67759-66a7-4cbd-a335-1a40ee4894bb]. The TARGET confirms the same Recognition Order stipulation as the gateway for carrying on the Regulated Activity of operating an MTF (and also an OTF) and further clarifies how rule application is scoped: if the stipulation exists, the specific rules on MTFs and OTFs in COBS apply to that function only, meaning they do not automatically extend to the Recognised Investment Exchange’s other activities [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388].

question: Before a PFP Operator publishes a financing proposal for a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, what due diligence must it perform to support its disclosure obligations, and for how long must it maintain records evidencing that due diligence and related communications and disclosures?
gold_answer: Before publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence on the PFP Prospect to satisfy the disclosure requirements imposed on it, and that due diligence must include (at a minimum) reviewing information provided by the PFP Prospect covering: (i) management details and background, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers; (ii) the PFP Prospect’s background, including financial soundness, good standing and (where relevant) regulatory status; and (iii) the financing proposal itself to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, the content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce]. In addition, the PFP Operator must, for a minimum of six years, maintain and keep records of the due diligence it undertook, as well as all disclosures made in accordance with the applicable disclosure rules and all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7].

question: How should a PFP Operator evidence compliance when it conducts pre-publication due diligence on a PFP Prospect to ensure the financing proposal is not misleading, and what minimum retention period applies to those due diligence records and associated disclosure and transaction documentation?
gold_answer: To evidence compliance, the PFP Operator should be able to demonstrate that, prior to publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, it performed due diligence on the PFP Prospect aimed at satisfying its disclosure requirements. That due diligence must include reviewing information provided by the PFP Prospect about management (including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers), the PFP Prospect’s background (including financial soundness, good standing and any relevant regulatory status), and the financing proposal itself so that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, the proposal’s content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce]. The PFP Operator must then maintain and keep, for a minimum of six years, a record of the due diligence undertaken, together with records of all disclosures made under the applicable disclosure rules and all documentation exchanged between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7].

question: What checks must a PFP Operator do on a PFP Prospect before it posts a financing proposal on a Private Financing Platform, and how long must it keep records showing those checks and related disclosures and communications?
gold_answer: Before the PFP Operator publishes a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, it must perform due diligence on the PFP Prospect to meet its disclosure requirements. This due diligence must include reviewing information the PFP Prospect provides about: (1) management details and background, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers; (2) the PFP Prospect’s background, including financial soundness, good standing and (if relevant) regulatory status; and (3) the financing proposal, to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, the proposal is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce]. The PFP Operator must also keep evidence of what it did: for a minimum of six years it must maintain and keep a record of the due diligence it undertook, all disclosures made under the applicable disclosure rules, and all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7].

question: If a PFP Operator reviews a financing proposal to make sure it is clear and not misleading, what other due diligence items must it review, and what records must it keep for at least six years?
gold_answer: When the PFP Operator is preparing to publish a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, it must do due diligence on the PFP Prospect to satisfy its disclosure requirements. Beyond reviewing the financing proposal to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, it is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading, the due diligence must also include reviewing information provided by the PFP Prospect on management (including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers) and on the PFP Prospect’s background (including financial soundness, good standing and any relevant regulatory status) [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce]. The PFP Operator must then keep records to show what it did: for a minimum of six years it must maintain and keep a record of the due diligence undertaken, all disclosures made under the applicable disclosure rules, and all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7].

question: Where an Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business has a Financial Service Permission that entitles it to hold Client Money, what must it do to ensure a Client Money Auditor's Report is submitted to the Regulator annually, and what specific confirmations must it ensure an Auditor includes in that report as at the date of the audited statement of financial position?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business whose Financial Service Permission entitles it to hold Client Money must arrange for a Client Money Auditor's Report to be submitted to the Regulator on an annual basis [#SRC:c42abaa9-4c93-4d5b-b989-aa4ec57cf600]. In addition, when procuring the production of that Client Money Auditor's Report, the Authorised Person must ensure that an Auditor states, as at the date of which the Authorised Person’s audited statement of financial position was prepared, the amount of Client Money the Authorised Person was holding and controlling in accordance with COBS Chapter 14 [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17]. The Authorised Person must also ensure the Auditor addresses whether the Authorised Person maintained throughout the year systems and controls to comply with the relevant provisions of COBS Chapter 14, whether controls ensure Client Money is identifiable and secure at all times, and whether any COBS Chapter 14 requirements were not met. The report must further cover whether Client Money was pooled in a single client Account or segregated in Client Accounts for individual Clients, whether (if applicable) the appropriate amount of Client Money was held and controlled as at the statement date, whether the Auditor received all necessary information and explanations, and whether (if applicable) there were any material reconciliation discrepancies [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17].

question: If an Authorised Person is allowed to hold Client Money, what must it do each year about the Client Money Auditor's Report, and what must it make sure the Auditor says in the report about Client Money and controls as at the audited statement of financial position date?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business has a Financial Service Permission that entitles it to hold Client Money, it must arrange for a Client Money Auditor’s Report to be submitted to the Regulator every year [#SRC:c42abaa9-4c93-4d5b-b989-aa4ec57cf600]. When it is procuring the production of that report, the Authorised Person must also ensure an Auditor includes specific statements tied to the date the Authorised Person’s audited statement of financial position was prepared [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17]. These include the amount of Client Money the Authorised Person was holding and controlling in accordance with COBS Chapter 14, and whether the Authorised Person maintained systems and controls throughout the year to comply with the relevant COBS Chapter 14 provisions. The Auditor must also state whether controls keep Client Money identifiable and secure at all times, whether any COBS Chapter 14 requirements were not met, and whether Client Money was pooled in a single client Account or segregated in Client Accounts for individual Clients. If applicable, the Auditor must address whether the appropriate amount of Client Money was held and controlled at the statement date, whether the Auditor received all necessary information and explanations, and whether there were any material discrepancies in Client Money reconciliation [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17].

question: Where an Authorised Person is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, must it treat the Chapter 5 requirements as exhaustive, or must it also ensure compliance with any other applicable notification requirements that may apply to MTFs using Virtual Assets (including those linked to adding further Accepted Virtual Assets)?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets must comply with the specified Chapter 5 requirements, including the notification-related rules and the identified information requirements, as applicable to the circumstances described for that facility [#TGT:7404ef72-3a2f-4c07-a166-0dfd8a480e8d]. However, those Chapter 5 requirements are not presented as the full universe of notification obligations for MTFs using Virtual Assets. The guidance explains that the notification and information requirements applied to MTFs using Virtual Assets are additional requirements and that such MTFs will also need to comply with any other applicable notification requirements [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8]. This includes notification requirements referenced in the guidance in relation to the use of additional Accepted Virtual Assets. Accordingly, compliance should be structured so that the Authorised Person both (i) meets the Chapter 5 rule set that is expressly applied to Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets and (ii) separately identifies and satisfies any other notification requirements that are applicable in the particular circumstances, including where the facility proposes to use additional Accepted Virtual Assets.

question: In implementing compliance controls for an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, how should the firm reconcile the obligation to comply with the Chapter 5 notification and information requirements with the separate expectation that MTFs using Virtual Assets must meet any other applicable notification requirements beyond those Chapter 5 provisions?
gold_answer: The compliance framework should start from the baseline obligation that an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets must comply with the Chapter 5 requirements that are expressly applied to that activity, including the specified notification-related rules and the information requirement where the stated circumstances apply [#TGT:7404ef72-3a2f-4c07-a166-0dfd8a480e8d]. At the same time, the guidance makes clear that these applied notification and information requirements are additional requirements for MTFs using Virtual Assets and that such MTFs will also need to comply with any other applicable notification requirements [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8]. Practically, this means controls should not be limited to checking only the Chapter 5 items listed for Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets; they should also include a process to identify other notification triggers that may apply to the MTF’s use of Virtual Assets, including those referenced in the guidance in relation to the use of additional Accepted Virtual Assets. The result is a two-layer approach: mandatory Chapter 5 compliance plus a broader scan for other applicable notification duties.

question: If an Authorised Person is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, is it enough to follow the listed Chapter 5 requirements, or must it also follow any other notification requirements that apply to MTFs using Virtual Assets (including when adding more Accepted Virtual Assets)?
gold_answer: No. The Authorised Person must comply with the Chapter 5 requirements that are expressly applied to Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, including the specified notification-related rules and the information requirement when the stated circumstances apply [#TGT:7404ef72-3a2f-4c07-a166-0dfd8a480e8d]. But the guidance also says that the notification and information requirements applied to MTFs using Virtual Assets are additional requirements and that MTFs using Virtual Assets will also need to comply with any other applicable notification requirements [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8]. That includes notification requirements mentioned in the guidance in relation to the use of additional Accepted Virtual Assets. So, the firm should treat the Chapter 5 list as required minimum obligations for this type of Multilateral Trading Facility, and then separately check whether there are other notification duties that apply in its specific situation, especially where it plans to use additional Accepted Virtual Assets.

question: When setting up a checklist for an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, what should be included to make sure it meets both the Chapter 5 requirements and any other notification duties that might apply?
gold_answer: The checklist should include two parts. First, it must cover the Chapter 5 requirements that apply when an Authorised Person is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, including the specified notification-related rules and the information requirement when the listed circumstances apply [#TGT:7404ef72-3a2f-4c07-a166-0dfd8a480e8d]. Second, it must go beyond that list, because the guidance states that these applied notification and information requirements are additional requirements for MTFs using Virtual Assets and that such MTFs will also need to comply with any other applicable notification requirements [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8]. The checklist should therefore include a step to identify other notification triggers that may apply to the MTF’s use of Virtual Assets, including those referenced in the guidance in relation to the use of additional Accepted Virtual Assets. This ensures the firm does not treat the Chapter 5 list as the only notification obligations it must meet.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure that includes forecast financial information derived from a Production Target and also includes information drawn from a separate report on Ore Reserves, what must it include about the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, and how must the information included in the disclosure be presented relative to the separate report (including any annexure expectations)?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity must ensure its disclosure addresses two distinct but related obligations. First, where the disclosure contains forecast financial information, it must include, in relation to the assumptions used to determine that forecast financial information, all material economic assumptions employed; if it considers those material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, it must state that and explain the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and it must include all other material assumptions utilised. It must also include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including the information required to accompany that Production Target. Second, where the disclosure includes information drawn from the separate report on Ore Reserves, the information included in the disclosure must be a fair and balanced representation of the information contained in that separate report, and that separate report must be included as an annexure to the disclosure. In meeting this, the FSRA does not expect a full summary; only information material to understanding the estimates of Mineral Resources in the separate report, and not otherwise in the body, is expected to be included. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:b8cb4fdb-f627-43ae-90bf-801a549f8d63]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information based on a Production Target and also includes Ore Reserves information from a separate report, what details must it give about the assumptions behind the forecast, and what does it need to do to make sure the disclosure fairly reflects the separate report (including what goes in an annexure)?
gold_answer: The Mining Reporting Entity must cover both the forecast-assumptions requirements and the Ore Reserves presentation requirements in the same disclosure. For the forecast financial information, it must include all material economic assumptions used to determine that forecast; if it considers those material economic assumptions commercially sensitive, it must say so and explain the methodology used to determine them; and it must include all other material assumptions utilised. It must also include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, together with the information that must accompany that Production Target. Separately, for the Ore Reserves-related content, the information included in the disclosure must be a fair and balanced representation of what is in the separate report, and that separate report must be included as an annexure to the disclosure. The FSRA does not expect the Mining Reporting Entity to summarise everything in the separate report; instead, it is expected to include only the information that is material to understanding the estimates of Mineral Resources in the separate report and that is not already included in the body of the disclosure. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:b8cb4fdb-f627-43ae-90bf-801a549f8d63]

question: When the Fund Manager of a Passported Fund must notify the Regulator of a material event (including where the Prospectus is amended or replaced), what minimum content must accompany that notification and how does this interact with the required timing for giving notice?
gold_answer: Where the Fund Manager of a Passported Fund is required to notify the Regulator of any material events, the notification must be made as soon as practicable and, for the specified categories of events, in any case no later than seven days after the Fund Manager (or the governing body or trustee, where applicable) becomes aware of the event [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]. In addition to meeting that timing obligation, the notification must satisfy minimum content requirements: it must be in the prescribed form that the Regulator may direct from time to time, and it must be accompanied by reasonable detail of the event [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f]. If the material event involves the Prospectus being amended or replaced, the notification must also include a copy of the new Prospectus, ensuring the Regulator receives both the substantive description of what occurred and the updated disclosure document alongside the notice [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f].

question: For notifications to the Regulator about material events affecting a Passported Fund (including changes to the Fund Manager, service providers, or commencement of winding-up), what are the mandatory form and information elements that must be provided with the notice, and by when must the notice be submitted once the relevant party becomes aware?
gold_answer: A Fund Manager of a Passported Fund must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable of any material events, and for the listed events (including retirement, removal or replacement of the Fund Manager; appointment or resignation of a material service provider, Agent or Licensed Person; commencement of winding-up; or an intention to vary or revoke a Financial Service Permission), the notice must be given as soon as practicable and in any case no later than seven days after it becomes aware of the event [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]. Alongside meeting this timing requirement, the notification must comply with the Regulator’s prescribed form as directed from time to time and must, at a minimum, be accompanied by reasonable detail of the event so the Regulator can understand what has occurred and its significance [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f]. Where the event is that the Prospectus has been amended or replaced, the notification must also include a copy of the new Prospectus, ensuring the updated document is provided together with the event details [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f].

question: If the Fund Manager of a Passported Fund has to tell the Regulator about a material event, what details must be included with the notice, and how quickly must the notice be sent after the Fund Manager becomes aware?
gold_answer: When the Fund Manager of a Passported Fund must notify the Regulator of a material event, the notice must be sent as soon as practicable and, for the specific events listed (such as changes to the Fund Manager, key service providers, or the Prospectus, or the start of winding-up), no later than seven days after it becomes aware of the event [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]. The notice is not just a timing obligation; it also has minimum content requirements. It must be submitted in the prescribed form that the Regulator may direct from time to time, and it must be accompanied by reasonable detail of the event so the Regulator receives enough information to understand what happened [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f]. If the event is that the Prospectus relating to the Passported Fund has been amended or replaced, the notice must also include a copy of the new Prospectus, so the Regulator receives the updated document together with the event description [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f].

question: When the Prospectus for a Passported Fund is amended or replaced and the Regulator must be notified, what must be sent with the notification, and what is the latest deadline for sending it once the relevant party knows about the change?
gold_answer: If the Prospectus relating to a Passported Fund is amended or replaced, this is one of the events that triggers a requirement to notify the Regulator as soon as practicable and, in any case, no later than seven days after it becomes aware of the event [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]. The notification must also meet minimum submission and information standards. It must be made in the prescribed form that the Regulator may direct from time to time, and it must be accompanied by reasonable detail of the event—here, the nature of the Prospectus change—so the Regulator has an adequate description of what occurred [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f]. In addition, because the Prospectus has been amended or replaced, the notification must include a copy of the new Prospectus, ensuring the Regulator receives the updated disclosure document together with the notice and supporting detail [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f].

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a compliant disclosure about a Production Target, under what conditions may its later disclosure omit the detailed assumption and proportion information that would otherwise be required, and what confirmations or cautionary statements must still be included depending on whether the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or based in part on an Exploration Target?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity’s initial disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include specified content about the assumptions used to determine the Production Target (including material economic assumptions or, if commercially sensitive, a sensitivity statement plus methodology, and all other material assumptions), any reasonable-grounds statement for forecast commodity pricing, and the proportions of the Production Target attributable to Ore Reserves, Mineral Resources (including Inferred Mineral Resources), and any Exploration Target, together with required viability and cautionary statements where applicable [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. After that, if the Mining Reporting Entity made the earlier disclosure and it was compliant with the information requirements that would otherwise apply, a subsequent disclosure in relation to the Production Target is permitted to omit that otherwise-required information, but only if it (i) references the earlier compliant disclosure, and (ii) confirms that all material assumptions in the initial disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef]. In addition, the subsequent disclosure must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, and likewise must include an equally prominent proximate cautionary statement if the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef].

question: How should a Mining Reporting Entity reconcile its obligation to include material economic assumptions and other required Production Target content in a disclosure with the ability to streamline later Production Target disclosures, and what specific cross-referencing and “no material change” confirmation is required to rely on that streamlining?
gold_answer: The Mining Reporting Entity must ensure that its disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 contains the required baseline information, including all material economic assumptions employed (or, if commercially sensitive, a statement that they are commercially sensitive and an explanation of the methodology used to determine them), all other material assumptions utilised, and other required Production Target elements such as any reasonable-grounds statement for forecast commodity pricing and the required breakdown of proportions across Ore Reserves, Mineral Resources (including Inferred Mineral Resources), and any Exploration Target, plus the applicable viability and cautionary statements [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. Once that baseline disclosure has been made and was compliant with the information requirements that would otherwise need to be repeated, the Mining Reporting Entity may make a subsequent disclosure in relation to the Production Target without re-including that otherwise-required information, but only if the later disclosure expressly references the earlier compliant disclosure and includes a statement confirming that all the material assumptions in the initial disclosure, on which the Production Target is based, continue to apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef]. Where the Production Target triggers special cautionary statements (for example, being wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or based in part on an Exploration Target), the subsequent disclosure must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement to the relevant effect [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef].

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a full Production Target disclosure, when can it leave out the detailed assumptions and proportion breakdown in a later update, and what does it still need to say in that later update (including any special warning statements)?
gold_answer: In its disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2, a Mining Reporting Entity must include key details about how the Production Target was determined, including the material economic assumptions (or, if commercially sensitive, a statement that they are commercially sensitive and an explanation of the methodology used), all other material assumptions, any statement about forecast commodity pricing being arrived at on reasonable grounds, and the proportions of the Production Target based on Ore Reserves, Mineral Resources (including Inferred Mineral Resources), and any Exploration Target, plus the required viability and cautionary statements where applicable [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. After it has made that earlier disclosure and it was compliant with the information requirements that would otherwise need to be repeated, the Mining Reporting Entity may make a later disclosure about the Production Target without re-including that otherwise-required information, but only if the later disclosure (1) points back to the earlier compliant disclosure and (2) confirms that the material assumptions in the initial disclosure still apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef]. Also, the later disclosure must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate warning statement if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, and must include a similarly prominent proximate warning statement if the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef].

question: What must be included in the first Production Target disclosure, and what extra steps let a Mining Reporting Entity avoid repeating that same information in a later Production Target disclosure?
gold_answer: For the first disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2, the Mining Reporting Entity must include required information about the assumptions used to determine the Production Target, including all material economic assumptions (or, if it considers them commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine them) and all other material assumptions utilised; it must also include other required Production Target items such as any statement that forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds, the proportions of the Production Target based on different categories (including Inferred Mineral Resources and any Exploration Target), and the required statements addressing viability and the required cautionary statements where applicable [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. After that, a later disclosure in relation to the Production Target is allowed to leave out the information that would otherwise have to be disclosed again, but only if the Mining Reporting Entity references the earlier disclosure that was compliant with those information requirements and includes a confirmation that all the material assumptions in the initial disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef]. If the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or is based in part on an Exploration Target, the later disclosure must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement to the relevant effect [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef].

question: When assessing an Offer of Digital Securities, may the Regulator deem an investment that is not otherwise a Security to be a Security, and how does the availability and completeness of the Securities Note information affect whether FSRA is able to support that outcome?
gold_answer: The Regulator is permitted to deem an investment that is not a Security to be a Security, but only by issuing a written notice and it may attach any terms and conditions it considers appropriate to that notice [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]. In the context of an Offer of Digital Securities, FSRA indicates that the information submitted as part of a Securities Note is key information it reviews when considering whether to use its deeming power [#SRC:b77f9697-b690-4a8b-9139-913a81e95aed]. Accordingly, even though the Regulator has the permission to deem, FSRA signals a practical constraint: if the Securities Note information is not available or has not been completed appropriately, it is most likely that FSRA will not be in a position to utilise that deeming power [#SRC:b77f9697-b690-4a8b-9139-913a81e95aed]. Read together, the permission in the Regulations establishes the mechanism (written notice, potentially conditional), while the Markets Rules guidance explains the evidentiary and completeness expectations that typically need to be met for FSRA to be able to proceed with deeming in this offers context [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] [#SRC:b77f9697-b690-4a8b-9139-913a81e95aed].

question: Can the Regulator treat an investment as a Security for these Regulations, and what happens if the Securities Note information for an Offer of Digital Securities is missing or not properly completed so that FSRA is not able to act?
gold_answer: Yes. The Regulator may, by written notice, deem an investment that is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and the Rules made under them, and it may impose any terms and conditions it considers appropriate [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]. However, in the specific setting of an Offer of Digital Securities, FSRA explains that the information required to be submitted as part of a Securities Note is key information it reviews when deciding whether to use that deeming power [#SRC:b77f9697-b690-4a8b-9139-913a81e95aed]. FSRA further cautions that if this Securities Note information is not available, or has not been completed appropriately, it is most likely that FSRA will not be in a position to utilise its deeming power [#SRC:b77f9697-b690-4a8b-9139-913a81e95aed]. So, while the Regulations allow the Regulator to deem by written notice (and to set conditions), the Markets Rules guidance indicates that incomplete or missing Securities Note content will typically prevent FSRA from being able to proceed with deeming in practice [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] [#SRC:b77f9697-b690-4a8b-9139-913a81e95aed].

question: For purposes of recognising and measuring an Insurer’s assets and liabilities, what basis of accounting must the Insurer apply, and how does that requirement differ depending on whether the Insurer is a Takaful Insurer or not, subject to any Chapter-level exceptions?
gold_answer: An Insurer must recognise and measure its assets and liabilities using the basis of accounting specified for it, unless the Chapter expressly provides otherwise. The recognition and measurement obligation is that the Insurer’s assets and liabilities must be accounted for in accordance with a basis of accounting set out for this purpose [#TGT:35397bd0-0c01-4dec-8eba-1b904df8b4d4]. The applicable basis is determined by the type of Insurer: where the Insurer is a Takaful Insurer, the basis of accounting it adopts for these purposes must be the standards of the Accounting and Auditing Organisation for Islamic Financial Institutions; in any other case, the basis of accounting it adopts must be International Financial Reporting Standards [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0]. Read together, this means the Insurer must first identify whether it is a Takaful Insurer and then apply the corresponding required accounting standards as its adopted basis, and use that basis to recognise and measure assets and liabilities, except to the extent an exception within the Chapter overrides that general approach [#TGT:35397bd0-0c01-4dec-8eba-1b904df8b4d4] [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0].

question: When an Insurer records its assets and liabilities, what accounting rules must it use, and which standards apply if it is a Takaful Insurer versus any other Insurer (unless the Chapter says otherwise)?
gold_answer: An Insurer must record (recognise) and value (measure) its assets and liabilities using the required basis of accounting, unless the Chapter provides an exception. The obligation is that the Insurer’s assets and liabilities must be recognised and measured in line with the basis of accounting that is set out for this purpose [#TGT:35397bd0-0c01-4dec-8eba-1b904df8b4d4]. The content of that basis depends on what kind of Insurer it is. If the Insurer is a Takaful Insurer, the basis of accounting it adopts for these purposes must follow the standards of the Accounting and Auditing Organisation for Islamic Financial Institutions. If it is not a Takaful Insurer, then the basis of accounting it adopts must be International Financial Reporting Standards [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0]. Putting both requirements together, the Insurer must (1) determine whether it is a Takaful Insurer, (2) adopt the corresponding required standards as its basis of accounting, and (3) use that adopted basis to recognise and measure assets and liabilities, except where the Chapter explicitly provides otherwise [#TGT:35397bd0-0c01-4dec-8eba-1b904df8b4d4] [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0].

question: For an Authorised Person, in which circumstances does the chapter’s scope trigger the requirement to keep the specified Resolution Pack continuously and in a retrievable form, and what activities determine whether the Authorised Person is in-scope?
gold_answer: The requirement to maintain the specified documents and records as a “Resolution Pack” on an ongoing basis, and to be able to retrieve them in the manner described in the chapter, applies to an Authorised Person only when it is within the chapter’s stated scope [#SRC:9dc5d839-07b0-4c04-9b95-1b5733012807]. The chapter applies where the Authorised Person (a) holds, safeguards or administers Financial Instruments or Virtual Assets for a Client; (b) acts as Trustee, Eligible Custodian or Fund Manager of Fund; or (c) otherwise holds Client Money, Relevant Money or Safe Custody Assets in accordance with the referenced chapters [#TGT:d5c306cd-f521-4933-8a2e-3788cde7e07c]. Accordingly, the applicability boundary is activity-based: if the Authorised Person performs any of these custody, administration, trustee/custodian/fund management, or money/safe-custody holding functions, it must maintain the Resolution Pack at all times and ensure it is retrievable as required by the chapter [#SRC:9dc5d839-07b0-4c04-9b95-1b5733012807]. If none of these conditions apply, the chapter’s requirements—including the continuous maintenance and retrievability obligation—are not triggered [#TGT:d5c306cd-f521-4933-8a2e-3788cde7e07c].

question: When does an Authorised Person have to keep the Resolution Pack up to date at all times and be able to retrieve it—does this apply only if it holds or safeguards client assets or money, or also in other roles?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must maintain the specified documents and records (the “Resolution Pack”) at all times and be able to retrieve them in the manner described in the chapter, but this obligation is tied to whether the Authorised Person is within the chapter’s scope [#SRC:9dc5d839-07b0-4c04-9b95-1b5733012807]. The chapter applies to an Authorised Person where it holds, safeguards or administers Financial Instruments or Virtual Assets for a Client, or where it acts as Trustee, Eligible Custodian or Fund Manager of Fund [#TGT:d5c306cd-f521-4933-8a2e-3788cde7e07c]. It also applies where the Authorised Person otherwise holds Client Money, Relevant Money or Safe Custody Assets in accordance with the referenced chapters [#TGT:d5c306cd-f521-4933-8a2e-3788cde7e07c]. So, the requirement is not limited to one narrow custody scenario: any of these listed activities brings the Authorised Person into scope, and once in scope it must keep the Resolution Pack continuously and ensure it can be retrieved as required by the chapter [#SRC:9dc5d839-07b0-4c04-9b95-1b5733012807]. If the Authorised Person does not do any of the listed activities, the chapter (and therefore this obligation) does not apply [#TGT:d5c306cd-f521-4933-8a2e-3788cde7e07c].

question: When an Authorised Person takes reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest and then prevent or manage them, what must the Authorised Person ensure about the form and content of any conflict-of-interest disclosure made to a Client so the Client can make an informed decision in relation to the relevant service?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to take reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest and then prevent or manage them, and these requirements apply in addition to other requirements under FSMR and any rules made thereunder [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]. Where a conflict of interest arises in the context of providing a service to a Client and a disclosure is made, the disclosure must meet specific delivery and content standards: it must be made in a durable medium and it must include sufficient detail, taking into account the nature of the Client, to enable that Client to take an informed decision with respect to the service in the context of which the conflict of interest arises [#TGT:448d19a7-728b-491f-9eb2-284dc92112e9]. Read together, the Authorised Person’s conflict identification and prevention/management steps should be supported by a disclosure process that is capable of producing a durable record and tailoring the level of detail to the Client’s characteristics, so that the disclosure meaningfully informs the Client’s decision about the relevant service rather than being generic or purely formal.

question: If an Authorised Person finds an actual or potential conflict of interest, what must it do to make sure any disclosure to the Client is delivered properly and gives enough detail for the Client to decide about the service?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must take reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest and then prevent or manage them, and this applies in addition to other requirements under FSMR and any rules made thereunder [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]. If, in the context of a service, a conflict of interest arises and the Authorised Person makes a disclosure to the Client, the disclosure has to satisfy two core requirements. First, it must be made in a durable medium, meaning it is provided in a form that can be retained and referred to later [#TGT:448d19a7-728b-491f-9eb2-284dc92112e9]. Second, it must include enough detail—adjusted for the nature of the Client—so the Client can make an informed decision about the service in which the conflict arises [#TGT:448d19a7-728b-491f-9eb2-284dc92112e9]. In practice, the identification and prevention/management steps should feed into a disclosure that is specific to the conflict and the service, and is detailed enough for that particular Client to understand the issue and decide how to proceed.

question: How should an Issuer assess whether an Offer of Securities continues to qualify as an Exempt Offer when different tranches or communications cause the Offer to meet more than one prescribed exempt circumstance, and what minimum condition must be satisfied across the whole Offer for the exemption to be maintained?
gold_answer: An Offer of Securities can continue to be treated as an Exempt Offer even where, in whole or in part, it falls within more than one of the prescribed exempt circumstances, provided the entire Offer is covered by at least one prescribed circumstance. In practice, the Issuer (or other person structuring the Offer) should map each part of the Offer to the Regulator’s prescribed circumstances for when an Offer is an Exempt Offer—such as an Offer made only to Professional Clients, an Offer directed at no more than a specified number of Persons in a 12‑month period (with stated exclusions), or an Offer meeting specified monetary thresholds for consideration, denomination, or aggregate size, as well as the other listed transactional contexts (e.g., certain substitutions, takeovers, mergers, rights issues, or employee/director offers with required documents). The key condition is not that the Offer fits only one category, but that all of the Offer fits within at least one of the Regulator-prescribed circumstances at all times, even if different parts also satisfy additional circumstances. This continuity principle is set out in the Source [#SRC:93a2a61f-b4c9-4b29-bec3-d7bdd00541c0] and depends on the Target’s list of prescribed circumstances [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc].

question: If an Offer of Securities fits more than one exempt category (for example, it is aimed only at Professional Clients and also meets a money threshold), does it still count as an Exempt Offer, and what must be true about the whole Offer?
gold_answer: Yes. An Offer of Securities can remain an Exempt Offer even if the Offer, in whole or in part, falls within more than one of the Regulator’s prescribed exempt circumstances. The important requirement is that all of the Offer must fall within at least one of those prescribed circumstances, so there is no part of the Offer that sits outside every exempt category. The prescribed circumstances include, among others, an Offer made to or directed at only Professional Clients; certain Offers in or from the ADGM directed at no more than a stated number of Persons in a 12‑month period (with specified exclusions); Offers meeting stated minimum consideration or denomination amounts; Offers below a stated aggregate consideration cap over 12 months; and several specific transaction situations (such as certain share substitutions, certain offers to existing members or creditors with no additional consideration, and certain takeover, merger, rights issue, dividend, or employee/director offers where a document is made available with specified information). The Source explains that overlapping categories do not remove the exemption as long as the whole Offer is covered [#SRC:93a2a61f-b4c9-4b29-bec3-d7bdd00541c0], and the Target provides the categories you must check against [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc].

question: In dealings with a Retail Client, when is an Authorised Person prohibited from using a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement, and how does the prohibition differ between entering into the agreement with the client versus using it in respect of the client’s assets?
gold_answer: Across both provisions, the core restriction is that an Authorised Person is prohibited from using a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement in connection with a Retail Client. The SOURCE establishes a direct counterparty-based prohibition: an Authorised Person may not enter into a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement with a Retail Client, meaning the agreement itself cannot be formed where the Retail Client is the contracting party [#SRC:f8d4b63b-c965-42c6-abf2-f70dfb84afaa]. The TARGET reinforces and extends the prohibition by focusing on the subject matter of the arrangement: an Authorised Person must not enter into a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement in respect of an asset belonging to a Retail Client, even where the agreement is framed around the Retail Client’s assets rather than solely the identity of the counterparty [#TGT:45762c70-0a0b-47e4-9db7-e70b9924abeb]. Read together, an Authorised Person must not structure a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement either (i) directly with a Retail Client, or (ii) in a way that captures assets belonging to a Retail Client, because both the client relationship and the client-asset nexus are expressly prohibited.

question: When dealing with a Retail Client, what exactly is an Authorised Person not allowed to do with a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement, including cases where the agreement relates to the Retail Client’s assets?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is not allowed to use a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement in connection with a Retail Client in either of two closely related ways. First, the SOURCE makes it clear that the Authorised Person may not enter into a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement with a Retail Client, so the Retail Client cannot be the party to such an agreement with the Authorised Person [#SRC:f8d4b63b-c965-42c6-abf2-f70dfb84afaa]. Second, the TARGET states that an Authorised Person must not enter into a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement in respect of an asset belonging to a Retail Client, which captures situations where the agreement is tied to, or concerns, assets that belong to the Retail Client [#TGT:45762c70-0a0b-47e4-9db7-e70b9924abeb]. Taken together, the prohibition applies both to the identity of the client (a Retail Client) and to the ownership of the assets (assets belonging to a Retail Client). Therefore, an Authorised Person must not enter into a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement either directly with a Retail Client or in relation to assets owned by a Retail Client.

question: Where an MTF admits to trading Securities offered by way of an Exempt Offer, what systems and controls must the MTF have to manage admission and trading restrictions, and how must a Recognised Investment Exchange’s Business Rules ensure that any Financial Instruments it admits can be traded fairly, orderly and efficiently?
gold_answer: An MTF that admits to trading Securities offered by way of an Exempt Offer must have effective systems and controls that govern both who and what is admitted and how trading is constrained. Specifically, it must ensure it admits only Securities from Exempt Offers made on its own platform, can identify the Persons to whom the Exempt Offer was made, and can restrict trading so that no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients can trade those Securities. It must also have controls to comply with the applicable admission-to-trading requirements referenced for the relevant Securities and to allow users of its market to obtain Inside Information, including relevant offer documents. In parallel, when a Recognised Investment Exchange admits Financial Instruments to trading, its Business Rules must be clear and transparent on admission and must ensure that all admitted Financial Instruments are capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner. Together, these obligations require both operational controls at the MTF level and rule-based safeguards at the Recognised Investment Exchange level to support orderly admission and trading outcomes. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215]

question: If an MTF lets Exempt Offer Securities trade, what controls must it have to limit who can trade and to give users access to key information, and what must a Recognised Investment Exchange’s Business Rules do to make sure trading in admitted Financial Instruments works properly?
gold_answer: If an MTF admits to trading Securities offered by way of an Exempt Offer, it must put effective systems and controls in place that manage admission, participant identification, trading limits, and information access. That includes controls to admit only Securities from Exempt Offers made on its own platform, to identify the Persons to whom the Exempt Offer was made, and to restrict trading so that no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients can trade the Securities. It must also have controls to comply with the applicable admission-to-trading requirements for the relevant Securities and to allow users of its market to obtain Inside Information, including relevant offer documents. Separately, a Recognised Investment Exchange that admits Financial Instruments to trading must have Business Rules that are clear and transparent about admission and that ensure all admitted Financial Instruments can be traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner. Read together, the MTF’s operational controls and the Recognised Investment Exchange’s rule framework both aim to support controlled admission and trading that functions properly and predictably for market users. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215]

question: When a Third Party Provider intends to apply changes in exchange rates immediately and without giving notice, what must the Governing Contract include regarding exchange-rate methodology and any agreed approach to applying changes in Reference Exchange Rates, and under what contractual conditions is the Third Party Provider permitted to implement such immediate, no-notice changes?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider can only apply changes in exchange rates immediately and without notice if the Governing Contract gives it that right and the resulting exchange-rate changes are based on Reference Exchange Rate information that has been provided to the Customer, or if the changes are more favourable to the Customer [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2]. To support that permission, the Governing Contract must (unless otherwise agreed in writing between the Third Party Provider and their Customer) contain specified information about charges and exchange rates, including details of the exchange rates to be applied or, where Reference Exchange Rates are to be used, the method of calculating the relevant date for determining those Reference Exchange Rates [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. In addition, where relevant and if agreed, the contract must address the application of changes in Reference Exchange Rates and the information requirements relating to any such changes, which is directly relevant to any immediate, no-notice application of exchange-rate changes [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49].

question: If a Third Party Provider relies on the contractual ability to change exchange rates immediately and without notice, how must the Governing Contract document the exchange-rate terms and any agreed information requirements for changes, and how does the exception for changes that are more favourable to the Customer affect the Third Party Provider’s ability to act without notice?
gold_answer: The Governing Contract must set out the exchange-rate framework in a way that aligns with when immediate, no-notice changes are allowed. Specifically, unless otherwise agreed in writing between a Third Party Provider and their Customer, the contract must include details of the exchange rates to be applied or, if Reference Exchange Rates are used, the method for calculating the relevant date for determining those Reference Exchange Rates, and (where relevant and if agreed) it must also cover how changes in Reference Exchange Rates will be applied and the related information requirements [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. Against that baseline, immediate and without-notice application of exchange-rate changes is permitted where the Governing Contract includes such a right and the changes are based on Reference Exchange Rate information that has been provided to the Customer, or where the changes are more favourable to the Customer [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2]. The “more favourable” condition operates as an alternative basis for acting immediately without notice, even where the change is not framed as being based on provided Reference Exchange Rate information [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2].

question: If a Third Party Provider wants to change exchange rates right away and not tell the Customer first, what must be written into the Governing Contract about exchange rates and Reference Exchange Rates, and when is the Third Party Provider allowed to make those immediate changes?
gold_answer: The Third Party Provider is only allowed to apply exchange-rate changes immediately and without notice in limited situations: either the Governing Contract gives the Third Party Provider that right and the change is based on Reference Exchange Rate information that has been provided to the Customer, or the change is more favourable to the Customer [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2]. To make this workable and transparent, the Governing Contract must (unless otherwise agreed in writing between the Third Party Provider and their Customer) include required information about charges and exchange rates. That includes details of the exchange rates to be applied, or if Reference Exchange Rates will be used, the method for calculating the relevant date used to determine those Reference Exchange Rates [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. Also, where relevant and if agreed, the contract must explain how changes in Reference Exchange Rates will be applied and what information requirements apply to those changes, which connects directly to any plan to change rates without advance notice [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49].

question: What does the Governing Contract have to say about exchange rates so that a Third Party Provider can change them immediately without notice, and does it matter if the change is better for the Customer?
gold_answer: For immediate, no-notice exchange-rate changes, two things must line up: what the contract must contain, and when the Third Party Provider is permitted to act. Unless otherwise agreed in writing between a Third Party Provider and their Customer, the Governing Contract must include exchange-rate information such as the exchange rates to be applied or, if Reference Exchange Rates are used, the method for calculating the relevant date for determining those Reference Exchange Rates; and where relevant and if agreed, it must also cover how changes in Reference Exchange Rates will be applied and the information requirements for those changes [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. On permission to act, changes in exchange rates may be applied immediately and without notice if the Governing Contract includes that right and the changes are based on Reference Exchange Rate information that has been provided to the Customer, or if the changes are more favourable to the Customer [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2]. So yes, it matters: a change that is more favourable to the Customer is itself a basis for immediate, no-notice application [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2].

question: How does the Regulator’s ability to prescribe certain communications as Exempt Communications affect whether a person is prohibited from making an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or having Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, and what is the practical compliance boundary for relying on that exemption?
gold_answer: A person is generally prohibited from making an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or having Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, unless an exception applies under these Regulations [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a]. The Regulator’s power to prescribe certain communications as Exempt Communications creates a key boundary for that prohibition: when a communication is prescribed as an Exempt Communication, it is not subject to the relevant prohibition because it falls outside the definition of an “Offer of Securities” [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f]. Practically, this means compliance analysis should first determine whether the activity in question is a “communication” that the Regulator has prescribed as exempt; if so, that communication is treated as not being an Offer of Securities for these purposes, and the prohibition on making an Offer is not engaged. If the communication is not prescribed as exempt, the baseline prohibition remains applicable, and the person must look to whether the Regulations otherwise provide an applicable exception for the intended offer or admission to trading.

question: If a person must not make an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or seek admission of Securities to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, when can they rely on the Regulator’s power to treat a communication as exempt so it is not treated as an offer?
gold_answer: The starting point is that a person is prohibited from making an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market and from having Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, unless the Regulations provide otherwise [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a]. The Regulator’s power to prescribe certain communications as Exempt Communications is relevant because those prescribed communications are not subject to the prohibition that would otherwise apply to offers, since they fall outside the definition of an “Offer of Securities” [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f]. In practical terms, a person can rely on this only where what they plan to say or distribute is a “communication” that has been prescribed by the Regulator as exempt. If it is prescribed as an Exempt Communication, it is treated as not being an Offer of Securities for this purpose, so the offer prohibition is not triggered. If it is not prescribed as exempt, the person remains within the scope of the general prohibition unless another exception under the Regulations applies.

question: When an Authorised Person is required to calculate its Leverage Ratio using a capital measure divided by an exposure measure, how must it determine the capital measure by calculating Tier 1 capital, and what components must be included in that Tier 1 capital calculation?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must calculate its Leverage Ratio using the stated methodology of Capital Measure divided by Exposure Measure, and it must ensure that the Capital Measure it uses is the Authorised Person’s Tier 1 Capital calculated in accordance with the referenced requirements [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b]. In determining that Tier 1 capital amount for purposes of the Leverage Ratio, Tier 1 capital must be calculated as the total of two specified components: Common Equity Tier 1 capital (CET1 Capital) and Additional Tier 1 capital (AT1 Capital) [#TGT:a2ce8a2e-9188-4d44-8582-42abbadc4f11]. Accordingly, the capital measure in the Leverage Ratio numerator is not a standalone figure or a discretionary capital concept; it is explicitly anchored to Tier 1 capital and, in turn, Tier 1 capital is explicitly defined as the sum of CET1 Capital and AT1 Capital. The Authorised Person must therefore identify and total its CET1 Capital and its AT1 Capital to arrive at Tier 1 capital, and then use that Tier 1 capital amount as the Capital Measure in the Leverage Ratio calculation, alongside an Exposure Measure based on the value of its Exposures.

question: If an Authorised Person must work out its Leverage Ratio as capital divided by exposures, what exactly must it add up to get the Tier 1 capital figure used for the capital part of that ratio?
gold_answer: To calculate its Leverage Ratio, an Authorised Person must use the required formula of Capital Measure divided by Exposure Measure, and the Capital Measure must be the Authorised Person’s Tier 1 Capital calculated under the specified methodology [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b]. The Tier 1 capital figure used for that capital measure is not a single label without content; it must be calculated as the total of two defined building blocks: Common Equity Tier 1 capital (called CET1 Capital) plus Additional Tier 1 capital (called AT1 Capital) [#TGT:a2ce8a2e-9188-4d44-8582-42abbadc4f11]. So, when the Authorised Person prepares the numerator for the Leverage Ratio, it must first determine its CET1 Capital and its AT1 Capital and then add them together to produce Tier 1 capital. That resulting Tier 1 capital total is the Capital Measure that goes into the Leverage Ratio calculation, which is then divided by the Exposure Measure representing the value of the Authorised Person’s Exposures calculated under the referenced exposure rules.

question: Where a person fails to comply with a requirement under Part 17 of FSMR and is certified in default, under what conditions may the Court of First Instance treat the Defaulter as if in contempt, and who else may be proceeded against if the Defaulter is a Body Corporate?
gold_answer: A person who fails to comply with a requirement under Part 17 of FSMR can be certified in default, which establishes the procedural posture for the matter to be brought before the Court of First Instance for consideration [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf]. The Court of First Instance is permitted to deal with the Defaulter as if he were in contempt only if it is satisfied that the Defaulter failed, without reasonable excuse, to comply with the requirement [#TGT:91865998-c73a-45ec-8cec-23c36750808a]. This means the Court’s power to proceed on a contempt-like basis is conditional both on the existence of a failure to comply and on the Court’s satisfaction regarding the absence of a reasonable excuse. In addition, where the Defaulter is a Body Corporate, the Court’s permission extends beyond the entity itself: it may also deal with any Director or other Officer as if he were in contempt, reflecting that the enforcement consequence can attach to relevant individuals connected to the Body Corporate [#TGT:91865998-c73a-45ec-8cec-23c36750808a].

question: If someone does not follow a requirement under Part 17 of FSMR and is certified in default, when can the Court of First Instance treat the Defaulter like they are in contempt, and can it also act against people at a Body Corporate?
gold_answer: If a person fails to comply with a requirement under Part 17 of FSMR, that person can be certified in default, which is the step that frames the non-compliance for potential court handling [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf]. The Court of First Instance may then deal with the Defaulter as if he were in contempt only where the Court is satisfied that the Defaulter failed without reasonable excuse to comply with the requirement [#TGT:91865998-c73a-45ec-8cec-23c36750808a]. So it is not automatic: the Court must be satisfied both that there was a failure to comply and that there was no reasonable excuse for that failure. If the Defaulter is a Body Corporate, the Court’s permission is broader, because it may also deal with any Director or other Officer as if he were in contempt, not just the Body Corporate itself [#TGT:91865998-c73a-45ec-8cec-23c36750808a]. Separately, the same failure to comply may also be treated as a contravention of FSMR, which is an additional consequence described alongside the certification-in-default pathway [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf].

question: For a Petroleum Reporting Entity preparing a Summary of Reserves and Resources, when must it include the prescribed table and what is the applicability boundary if the entity is required to file SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports annually with the SEC?
