In effect, the Resolution Pack is a defined subset of records that must be included, while the six-year obligation governs retention and completeness across all activities and functions.

question: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business has to keep a Resolution Pack and also keep records for at least six years. What kinds of client-related records must be kept so both requirements are met?
gold_answer: To meet both requirements, an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must keep the specific records that must appear in the Resolution Pack and also retain sufficient records for each activity and function for a minimum of six years. On the Resolution Pack side, the Authorised Person must include records of Client classification and Client agreements, master lists of all Client Accounts for Client Money and Client investments, records and the Client’s written permission relating to the use of Client Investments, assessments of the appropriateness of Third-Party Agents and related acknowledgements (covering both Client Money and Client Investments), and the most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. On the six-year recordkeeping side, the Authorised Person must maintain sufficient records and, where applicable, include documents regarding Client classification and a record of each Client Agreement (including later amendments agreed with the Client), as well as other records such as Marketing Material, records of Financial Instruments or Regulated Activities for Clients and related advice/recommendations, suitability assessment records, inducements and Soft Dollar Agreement details, financial promotions, and other disclosures made to Clients [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2].

question: If the Resolution Pack must include Third-Party Agent assessments and acknowledgements for Client Money and Client Investments, how does that fit with the rule that an Authorised Person must keep sufficient records for each activity and function for at least six years?
gold_answer: The Resolution Pack requirement and the six-year recordkeeping requirement work together: the Authorised Person must include certain Third-Party Agent documentation in the Resolution Pack, and it must also ensure those records are part of a broader, sufficiently complete record set retained for at least six years. The Resolution Pack must include the assessment of appropriateness of a Third-Party Agent and the acknowledgement by the Third-Party Agent in respect of Client Money, and similarly the assessment of appropriateness of a Third Party Agent and acknowledgement by the Third-Party Agent in respect of Client Investments [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. Separately, the Authorised Person must, for a minimum of six years, maintain sufficient records in relation to each activity and function, including (where applicable) records tied to Client-facing activities such as Financial Instruments provided to or Regulated Activities carried out for the benefit of a Client, advice or recommendations, and core client documentation like Client classification documents and Client Agreement records (including amendments) [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2]. So, Third-Party Agent records should be kept both as required Resolution Pack contents and within the longer-term, activity-based recordkeeping framework.

question: Where an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission is required to pay an annual supervision fee to carry on Providing Credit, in what circumstances must that same Authorised Person also pay an additional annual supervision fee, and what are the respective fee amounts payable to the Regulator?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission must pay to the Regulator an annual supervision fee of $100,000 in order to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Credit (and likewise for Accepting Deposits) [#TGT:0265e5d0-471b-4c99-a867-be675e8e3f9d]. In addition to that annual supervision fee, an Authorised Person must pay to the Regulator an additional annual supervision fee of $10,000 where it carries on either (i) both of the Regulated Activities referenced in the Source, or (ii) the Regulated Activities of Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account and Providing Credit [#SRC:a71386ba-eb33-4dc9-9692-dc7fb9f02b13]. Read together, this means that if the Authorised Person is carrying on Providing Credit and also meets one of the Source conditions triggering the “additional” fee (for example, it carries on Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account alongside Providing Credit), it must pay both the $100,000 annual supervision fee for the relevant Regulated Activity and the separate $10,000 additional annual supervision fee to the Regulator, each applying on its stated basis [#TGT:0265e5d0-471b-4c99-a867-be675e8e3f9d] [#SRC:a71386ba-eb33-4dc9-9692-dc7fb9f02b13].

question: If an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission pays the annual supervision fee to carry on Providing Credit, when does it also have to pay an extra annual supervision fee, and how much are the two fees?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission must pay the Regulator an annual supervision fee of $100,000 to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Credit (and also to carry on Accepting Deposits) [#TGT:0265e5d0-471b-4c99-a867-be675e8e3f9d]. Separately, an Authorised Person must pay the Regulator an additional annual supervision fee of $10,000 if it carries on either (a) both of the Regulated Activities referenced in the Source, or (b) the Regulated Activities of Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account and Providing Credit [#SRC:a71386ba-eb33-4dc9-9692-dc7fb9f02b13]. Putting these together, if the Authorised Person is carrying on Providing Credit and it also falls into one of the Source situations that triggers the “additional” fee (for example, it carries on Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account as well as Providing Credit), then it must pay both amounts to the Regulator: the $100,000 annual supervision fee for carrying on Providing Credit and the extra $10,000 annual supervision fee that applies because it carries on the specified combination of Regulated Activities [#TGT:0265e5d0-471b-4c99-a867-be675e8e3f9d] [#SRC:a71386ba-eb33-4dc9-9692-dc7fb9f02b13].

question: When deciding whether to admit Securities to the Official List, to what extent is the Regulator permitted to exercise discretion over which Securities are admitted, and what governing requirements must that decision comply with given that admission is only to an Official List maintained by the Regulator?
gold_answer: Across the two provisions, the Regulator is permitted to admit Securities to the Official List, but that permission is bounded by both a discretion element and compliance constraints. The TARGET establishes that the Regulator may admit to the Official List such Securities as it considers appropriate, indicating that the Regulator has evaluative discretion over which Securities are admitted, provided the admission is carried out in accordance with the relevant Part [#TGT:507cd713-ca86-4535-8687-25f1305317c6]. The SOURCE adds that the Regulator may only grant admission of Securities to an Official List maintained by it, and that any such admission must be in accordance with the requirements in the FSMR and this Rulebook, which frames the discretion as exercisable only within those governing requirements and within the context of the Regulator’s own maintained Official List [#SRC:0bb34f72-20bd-464f-abe6-89c6c9ad7967]. Read together, the Regulator can choose which Securities to admit as appropriate, but it can do so only by granting admission to its maintained Official List and only where the admission process and outcome comply with the applicable requirements in the FSMR, this Rulebook, and the relevant Part.

question: Can the Regulator choose which Securities to admit to the Official List, and what rules must it follow when it grants that admission to the Official List it maintains?
gold_answer: Yes, the Regulator is permitted to admit Securities to the Official List and has discretion over which Securities it admits, because it may admit such Securities as it considers appropriate, but only when acting in accordance with the relevant Part [#TGT:507cd713-ca86-4535-8687-25f1305317c6]. At the same time, that discretion is not open-ended: the Regulator may only grant admission of Securities to an Official List maintained by it, and the act of granting admission must be carried out in accordance with the requirements in the FSMR and this Rulebook [#SRC:0bb34f72-20bd-464f-abe6-89c6c9ad7967]. Putting both statements together, the Regulator can decide whether particular Securities are appropriate for admission, but it must do so within the framework set by the Part referenced in the TARGET and within the additional constraints that admission is only to the Regulator’s own maintained Official List and must meet the FSMR and Rulebook requirements. In practice, the permission to admit is therefore conditional on following those governing requirements while applying the Regulator’s judgment about appropriateness.

question: When we exercise the Own Initiative Requirement Power under the procedure for applications for recognition, and we proceed without giving an affected person advance notice or a prior opportunity to make representations before the action takes effect, what sequencing must we follow to ensure the affected person is still given a post-decision right to make representations and that we consider them within the required period?
gold_answer: Under the procedure context of “Applications for recognition” and the “Exercise of Own Initiative Requirement Power” [#TGT:f7674119-c840-498b-af18-02db0720ccb5], if we act in circumstances where we do not have to give an affected person advance notice of our proposed action or the chance to make prior representations before the action takes effect, we must still build a post-decision representation step into the sequence. Specifically, once the decision is made and communicated to the affected person, we are obliged to give that affected person a right of representation within a specified period running from the date of that decision and communication [#SRC:3a93267e-e3d8-4106-bfea-1af4b7310f4c]. The procedure should therefore ensure (i) the decision is made, (ii) it is communicated to the affected person, (iii) the affected person is informed of and afforded the right to make representations within the specified period, and (iv) we consider any representations made by, or on behalf of, the affected person during that period before finalising our position. This obligation applies even where the initial action takes effect without prior representations, including where the action is the exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers [#SRC:3a93267e-e3d8-4106-bfea-1af4b7310f4c].

question: If we use the Own Initiative Requirement Power procedure for applications for recognition and we do not give an affected person advance notice or a chance to respond before the action starts, what must we do after we make and tell them the decision so they still get a right to respond?
gold_answer: In the “Applications for recognition” context, where the “Exercise of Own Initiative Requirement Power” procedure is being used [#TGT:f7674119-c840-498b-af18-02db0720ccb5], there are situations where we do not have to give an affected person advance notice of our proposed action or the chance to make representations before the action takes effect. Even in those situations, we must still provide a structured opportunity to respond after the decision. Once the decision is made and communicated to the affected person, we are obliged to give the affected person a right of representation within a specified period that runs from the date the decision is made and communicated [#SRC:3a93267e-e3d8-4106-bfea-1af4b7310f4c]. We must also consider any representations made by, or on behalf of, the affected person during that period [#SRC:3a93267e-e3d8-4106-bfea-1af4b7310f4c]. So, the practical sequence is: make the decision, communicate it, give the affected person the right to make representations within the specified period, and then review and consider anything they submit within that period as part of how we handle the matter under the procedure [#TGT:f7674119-c840-498b-af18-02db0720ccb5].

question: In a Takeover or Merger, when may the Regulator consent to the release of a holding lock so that holders of Restricted Securities can accept an offer or otherwise transfer or cancel Securities, and what preconditions must be satisfied before the Regulator will provide that consent (including any requirements about offer scope, acceptance levels by non-restricted holders, and written re-imposition arrangements if the transaction does not proceed or securities are not acquired)?
gold_answer: The Regulator may consent to a party that is managing a holding lock in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 releasing the holding lock to enable holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer, or to transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover [#TGT:12178c65-d1b6-440a-91e1-c670c7d9ab67]. However, the Regulator will not provide its consent unless, to the extent applicable, specified conditions are met [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd]. Where there is an offer for Securities, the offer must cover all of the Ordinary Securities or, if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities, all Securities in the same class as the Restricted Securities; holders of at least half of the Securities that are not Restricted Securities to which the offer relates must have accepted; and if the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder must agree in writing that the holding lock be immediately re-imposed for each Security not bought by the offeror. Where the offer is conducted by way of a scheme, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity in which the Restricted Securities are held must agree in writing that the holding lock be immediately re-imposed if the Takeover does not take effect.

question: When can the Regulator allow a holding lock to be released so Restricted Securities holders can take part in a Takeover (accept an offer, or transfer or cancel Securities), and what must be true before the Regulator will give that consent?
gold_answer: The Regulator may consent to a party that is managing a holding lock in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 releasing the holding lock so holders of Restricted Securities can accept an offer, or transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover [#TGT:12178c65-d1b6-440a-91e1-c670c7d9ab67]. But the Regulator will not provide its consent unless the relevant requirements are met, to the extent they apply [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd]. If there is an offer for Securities, the offer must be for all of the Ordinary Securities, or (if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities) for all Securities in the same class as the Restricted Securities. Also, holders of at least half of the Securities that are not Restricted Securities covered by the offer must have accepted. If the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder must agree in writing that the holding lock will be immediately re-imposed for each Security the offeror does not buy. If the offer is done as a scheme, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity where the Restricted Securities are held must agree in writing that the holding lock will be immediately re-imposed if the Takeover does not take effect.

question: For the first type of Behaviour, how should a firm determine whether an Insider’s dealing or attempted dealing in a Financial Instrument, Related Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity is carried out on the required informational basis, specifically where the Inside Information is the reason for, or a material influence on, the decision to deal?
gold_answer: The first type of Behaviour is triggered where an Insider deals, or attempts to deal, in a Financial Instrument, Related Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity on the basis of Inside Information relating to the instrument or commodity in question [#TGT:da3ba0b9-ff62-4830-a771-93c35b02af25]. To assess whether the dealing (or attempted dealing) is “on the basis of” that Inside Information, the relevant factors focus on the causal role the Inside Information plays in the decision-making process: it is necessary that the Insider’s decision to deal or attempt to deal is driven by the Inside Information in the sense that the Inside Information is the reason for the decision, or at least a material influence on it [#SRC:09923519-864f-48a7-a123-52dfa0a02c05]. Read together, the definition of the Behaviour sets the scope of instruments and requires that the Inside Information relates to those instruments, while the “reason for or material influence” test provides the practical indicator for when the informational basis requirement is met. Accordingly, if the Inside Information materially influences the decision to transact in the relevant instrument or commodity, that points to the Behaviour being present.

question: When does an Insider’s trade (or attempted trade) count as the first type of Behaviour, and how do you tell if the Inside Information was the real driver for the decision to deal?
gold_answer: It counts as the first type of Behaviour when an Insider deals, or attempts to deal, in a Financial Instrument, Related Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity, and the dealing is done on the basis of Inside Information that relates to the particular instrument or commodity being traded [#TGT:da3ba0b9-ff62-4830-a771-93c35b02af25]. The key practical question is what “on the basis of” means in deciding whether the Insider’s conduct meets that definition. The relevant factors focus on whether the Inside Information actually drove the decision: if the Inside Information is the reason for the decision to deal or attempt to deal, or if it is a material influence on that decision, that indicates the dealing (or attempted dealing) is on the basis of the Inside Information [#SRC:09923519-864f-48a7-a123-52dfa0a02c05]. Putting both pieces together, you must confirm (1) the transaction involves one of the specified instruments or commodities and (2) the Inside Information relates to that item, then assess whether the Inside Information was a reason for, or materially influenced, the decision to trade. If it was, the definition is met.

question: Where a person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator is treated as liable for a Prospectus and an investor claims compensation for loss arising from an untrue or misleading statement or a material omission, what must that prescribed person demonstrate or have done to avoid incurring civil liability, including any steps required before the Securities were acquired in reliance on the Prospectus?
gold_answer: Under the compensation regime, any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to a person who acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and suffered loss or damage arising from an untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission of a material matter required to be included [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac]. However, that person does not incur civil liability if they can show one of the specified bases: that the statement was true and not false, misleading, or deceptive, or that the matter whose omission caused the loss was properly omitted; or that they made all enquiries that were reasonable in the circumstances and believed there was no false, misleading, or deceptive statement or omission in the Prospectus; or that, before the Securities were acquired by any person in reliance on the Prospectus, they took all steps reasonable for them to take to secure that a correction was promptly made and brought to the attention of persons likely to acquire the Securities [#SRC:4ce33793-6bb5-4bc3-a65f-675a4ac19554].

question: If a person is listed in the Regulator’s Rules as liable for a Prospectus and must pay compensation when an investor loses money because the Prospectus had a misleading statement or left out an important required matter, what can that person show or do so they do not incur civil liability—especially if they fixed the issue before anyone bought the Securities relying on the Prospectus?
gold_answer: A person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to someone who acquired the Securities covered by that Prospectus and suffered loss or damage because the Prospectus contained an untrue or misleading statement or omitted a material matter that was required to be included [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac]. Even so, that person does not incur civil liability if they can demonstrate one of the permitted defenses: (a) the statement was true and not false, misleading, or deceptive, or the omitted matter that caused the loss was properly omitted; (b) they made all enquiries that were reasonable in the circumstances and believed there was no false, misleading, or deceptive statement or omission in the Prospectus; or (c) before the Securities were acquired by any person in reliance on the Prospectus, they took all steps that were reasonable for them to take to ensure a correction was promptly made and brought to the attention of persons likely to acquire the Securities [#SRC:4ce33793-6bb5-4bc3-a65f-675a4ac19554].

question: In what circumstances, and subject to what notification timing conditions, must a Payment Service Provider refund the amount of an unauthorised Payment Transaction to the Payer and (where applicable) restore the debited Payment Account?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider’s obligation to refund the amount of an unauthorised Payment Transaction to the Payer (and, where applicable, to restore the debited Payment Account to the position it would have been in had the transaction not occurred) is triggered where an executed Payment Transaction was not authorised in accordance with the relevant authorisation standard, and the obligation is expressly stated as mandatory for the Payment Service Provider [#SRC:49dd4b51-276a-406c-ab4c-17a9797a7a7a]. However, the availability of redress under the Chapter is limited by scope conditions that apply to the Payment Service User: the Payment Service User is entitled to redress only if it notifies its Payment Service Provider without undue delay after becoming aware of the unauthorised (or incorrectly executed) Payment Transaction, and in any event no later than twelve months after the debit date [#TGT:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd]. Read together, the refund-and-restoration duty operates within the Chapter’s redress framework, meaning the Payment Service User’s timely notification is a gating condition for entitlement to the redress that includes the refund to the Payer.

question: When does a Payment Service Provider have to pay back the amount of an unauthorised Payment Transaction to the Payer, and what deadline must the Payment Service User meet to be able to get that redress?
gold_answer: The Payment Service Provider must refund the amount of an unauthorised Payment Transaction to the Payer when an executed Payment Transaction was not authorised under the applicable authorisation requirement; and, if it applies, the Payment Service Provider must also restore the debited Payment Account to the state it would have been in if the unauthorised Payment Transaction had not happened [#SRC:49dd4b51-276a-406c-ab4c-17a9797a7a7a]. But the ability to obtain that outcome is not open-ended: the Payment Service User is entitled to redress under the Chapter only if it notifies its Payment Service Provider without undue delay after it becomes aware of the unauthorised (or incorrectly executed) Payment Transaction, and it must do so no later than twelve months after the debit date [#TGT:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd]. In practice, this means the refund obligation is tied to the Chapter’s redress scope—timely notification by the Payment Service User is a condition for entitlement to the redress that includes refunding the Payer and, where relevant, restoring the Payment Account.

question: When a Recognised Investment Exchange engages a Clearing Service and the provider is a party that is not a Recognised Clearing House or a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Clearing House, what must the Recognised Investment Exchange do to both ensure appropriate clearing and settlement arrangements and to evidence those arrangements to the Regulator?
gold_answer: In this scenario, the Recognised Investment Exchange has two linked obligations. First, when engaging a Clearing Service, it must ensure that satisfactory arrangements are in place to secure the timely discharge—by performance, compromise or otherwise—of the clearing and settlement rights and liabilities of the parties to transactions effected on the Recognised Investment Exchange, specifically insofar as those rights and liabilities relate to those transactions [#TGT:c56de460-9435-43a8-b170-bfe38c05a616]. Second, where the Recognised Investment Exchange engages a party that is not a Recognised Clearing House or a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Clearing House, it must confirm to the Regulator, in writing, the satisfactory arrangements it has made (i.e., the arrangements it is required to ensure exist for clearing and settlement) [#SRC:58de7c59-691a-427d-b34d-d7fd9baf874e]. Read together, the Recognised Investment Exchange must both implement arrangements that achieve timely clearing and settlement outcomes for transaction-related rights and liabilities and provide written confirmation of those arrangements to the Regulator when the clearing provider is outside the specified clearing house categories.

question: If a Recognised Investment Exchange uses a Clearing Service from a party that is not a Recognised Clearing House or a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Clearing House, what must it do to make sure clearing and settlement will happen on time, and what must it send to the Regulator?
gold_answer: The Recognised Investment Exchange must do two things that work together. It must ensure that satisfactory arrangements are made to secure the timely discharge—whether by performance, compromise or otherwise—of the clearing and settlement of the rights and liabilities of the parties to transactions effected on the Recognised Investment Exchange, meaning the rights and liabilities that relate to those transactions [#TGT:c56de460-9435-43a8-b170-bfe38c05a616]. In addition, if the Recognised Investment Exchange engages a party that is not a Recognised Clearing House or a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Clearing House, it must confirm to the Regulator, in writing, the satisfactory arrangements it has made [#SRC:58de7c59-691a-427d-b34d-d7fd9baf874e]. So, it is not enough to rely on the clearing provider’s processes: the Recognised Investment Exchange must ensure the arrangements exist and are satisfactory for timely clearing and settlement, and it must also provide written confirmation of those arrangements to the Regulator when the provider is outside the specified clearing house categories.

question: For the purposes of these Rules, how must a Person’s eligibility to be classified as a Professional Client be determined, and what are the two distinct routes by which that classification may be achieved?
gold_answer: For the purposes of these Rules, the determination of whether a Person meets the criteria to be classified as a Professional Client must be made by applying the specified criteria referenced for that classification in the Rules [#SRC:fcb1c541-c9fe-414d-b3a5-f50678fc40a3]. Within that overall framework, the classification outcome may be reached through two distinct routes: the Person may be treated as a “deemed” Professional Client, or the Person may be treated as an “assessed” Professional Client [#TGT:9a802537-4320-4c78-9b40-8bad9941e285]. Read together, the Source establishes that Professional Client status is not discretionary or ad hoc but is tied to defined criteria specified for the Rules’ purposes, while the Target clarifies that those criteria can be satisfied or applied via one of two routes. Accordingly, when documenting or implementing a Professional Client classification, the process should both (i) anchor the decision in the specified criteria for Professional Clients and (ii) identify whether the Person is being classified under the deemed route or the assessed route, as those are the only two routes described for achieving Professional Client classification [#SRC:fcb1c541-c9fe-414d-b3a5-f50678fc40a3] [#TGT:9a802537-4320-4c78-9b40-8bad9941e285].

question: If you need to classify a Person as a Professional Client under these Rules, where do the criteria come from, and what are the two ways the Person can be treated as a Professional Client?
gold_answer: Under these Rules, the criteria used to decide whether someone can be classified as a Professional Client are not informal; they are specified for the purposes of the Rules and must be taken from the stated source of criteria for Professional Client classification [#SRC:fcb1c541-c9fe-414d-b3a5-f50678fc40a3]. Once you are applying those specified criteria, the Target definition explains that there are exactly two routes through which a Person may be classified as a Professional Client: the Person can be a “deemed” Professional Client or an “assessed” Professional Client [#TGT:9a802537-4320-4c78-9b40-8bad9941e285]. Putting both passages together, you should (1) base the classification decision on the specified Professional Client criteria referenced in the Rules and (2) record which route you are using—deemed or assessed—because those are the two routes described for reaching Professional Client status. This combined approach ensures the classification is grounded in the Rules’ specified criteria while also aligning the outcome with the Target’s two-route structure for Professional Client classification [#SRC:fcb1c541-c9fe-414d-b3a5-f50678fc40a3] [#TGT:9a802537-4320-4c78-9b40-8bad9941e285].

question: When an Authorised Person is operating as a Virtual Asset Custodian and holds Accepted Virtual Assets under custody for Clients, what statement-delivery cadence must it apply for Retail Clients, and how does that requirement align with the broader obligation on an Authorised Person that provides Custody or otherwise holds or controls Safe Custody Assets to send regular statements to Clients?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person is operating as a Virtual Asset Custodian, it is required, in respect of the Accepted Virtual Assets it holds under custody for Clients, to send out statements of a Client’s Accepted Virtual Assets holdings to Retail Clients at least monthly [#SRC:0fb3a173-21f7-447a-9b86-6c07aede7c32]. This monthly cadence sits within, and is more frequent than, the general requirement that an Authorised Person which provides Custody or otherwise holds or controls any Safe Custody Assets for a Client must send a regular statement to its Client, with the minimum frequency for a Retail Client being at least every six months [#TGT:c8d90cd9-2076-4aad-a6ae-6d57990ba0f8]. Read together, the framework establishes a baseline statement obligation tied to custody or control of Safe Custody Assets for any Client, while also imposing a specific, heightened operational requirement for Virtual Asset Custodians in relation to Accepted Virtual Assets held under custody for Clients. Accordingly, for Retail Clients whose holdings are Accepted Virtual Assets under custody, the Authorised Person must meet the monthly statement requirement, which necessarily satisfies the broader “regular statement” duty applicable to Retail Clients.

question: If an Authorised Person is a Virtual Asset Custodian holding Accepted Virtual Assets for Clients, how often must it send statements to Retail Clients, and how does that compare to the general rule for an Authorised Person that provides Custody or otherwise holds or controls Safe Custody Assets?
gold_answer: If the Authorised Person is operating as a Virtual Asset Custodian, it has a specific requirement for the Accepted Virtual Assets it holds under custody for Clients: it must send out statements of a Client’s Accepted Virtual Assets holdings to Retail Clients at least monthly [#SRC:0fb3a173-21f7-447a-9b86-6c07aede7c32]. Separately, there is a broader obligation that applies whenever an Authorised Person provides Custody or otherwise holds or controls any Safe Custody Assets for a Client: it must send a regular statement to its Client, and for a Retail Client the minimum frequency is at least every six months [#TGT:c8d90cd9-2076-4aad-a6ae-6d57990ba0f8]. Putting these together, the monthly statement requirement for Retail Clients’ Accepted Virtual Assets is a more frequent, custody-specific statement cadence that operates alongside the general “regular statement” duty for Safe Custody Assets. In practice, where the same Retail Client relationship involves custody of Accepted Virtual Assets, meeting the monthly statement requirement will also meet (and exceed) the general six-month minimum for Retail Clients.

question: When a Relevant Person performs its business-wide risk assessment, how must it address risks arising from carrying on NFTF business and the use of eKYC Systems, and how must those considerations be integrated into the identification, assessment, and mitigation of money laundering risks across the firm’s activities?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person must take appropriate steps to identify and assess the money laundering risks to which its business is exposed, taking into consideration the nature, size and complexity of its activities, and it must recognise that those risks include terrorist financing, proliferation financing, the financing of unlawful organisations, and sanctions non-compliance (including non-compliance with Targeted Financial Sanctions) [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. In doing so, its business risk assessment should include an assessment of the risks associated with carrying on NFTF business, particularly where it uses eKYC Systems [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2]. The Relevant Person must also, to the extent relevant, take into account vulnerabilities relating to its customers, geographies, products and services, distribution channels and business partners, transaction complexity and volume, new products and business practices, and the use of new or developing technologies, which would encompass eKYC-enabled processes and NFTF-related activity profiles [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. Finally, it must take appropriate measures to ensure identified risks are reflected in day-to-day operations and mitigated, and the assessment should consider incorporating relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator and other relevant bodies [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2] [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851].

question: In identifying vulnerabilities linked to new or developing technologies, what must a Relevant Person do to ensure its assessment covers eKYC Systems used in NFTF business and reflects any relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator or other competent bodies, while also ensuring the resulting risks are mitigated in day-to-day operations?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person must identify and assess the money laundering risks to which its business is exposed and, when doing so, must take into account (to the extent relevant) vulnerabilities relating to the use of new or developing technologies for both new and pre-existing products and services [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. Consistent with that requirement, its business risk assessment should include an assessment of the risks associated with carrying on NFTF business, particularly the use of eKYC Systems, because those technology-enabled processes can form part of its products, services, activity profiles, and delivery mechanisms [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2] [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. The Relevant Person must also take into account that money laundering risks include terrorist financing, proliferation financing, the financing of unlawful organisations, and sanctions non-compliance, so the NFTF/eKYC analysis should be framed within that broader risk set [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. In addition, the assessment should consider incorporating any relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and other relevant bodies [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2]. Finally, it must take appropriate measures to ensure any identified risk is taken into account in day-to-day operations and is mitigated, including in relation to new products, new customers, and changes to its business profile [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851].

question: What must a Relevant Person do to assess and manage risks linked to NFTF business and the use of eKYC Systems as part of its overall money laundering risk assessment?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person must take appropriate steps to identify and assess the money laundering risks to which its business is exposed, taking into consideration the nature, size and complexity of its activities, and it must take into account that these risks include terrorist financing, proliferation financing, the financing of unlawful organisations, and sanctions non-compliance (including non-compliance with Targeted Financial Sanctions) [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. As part of that business-wide assessment, it should include an assessment of the risks associated with carrying on NFTF business, particularly where it uses eKYC Systems [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2]. When identifying and assessing risks, the Relevant Person must also consider (to the extent relevant) vulnerabilities tied to customers, countries/geographic areas, products and services, distribution channels and business partners, transaction complexity and volume, new products and business practices, and the use of new or developing technologies—areas that can be directly affected by eKYC and NFTF activity [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. It must then take appropriate measures to ensure any identified risk is reflected in day-to-day operations and mitigated, including for new products, new customers, and changes to its business profile [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. The assessment should also consider incorporating relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator and other relevant bodies [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2].

question: When a Relevant Person looks at risks from new or developing technologies, how should it treat eKYC Systems used in NFTF business, and what must it do with any risks it finds?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person must identify and assess the money laundering risks to which its business is exposed, and when doing that work it must take into account, to the extent relevant, vulnerabilities relating to the use of new or developing technologies for both new and pre-existing products and services [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. In that context, its business risk assessment should include an assessment of the risks associated with carrying on NFTF business, particularly the use of eKYC Systems, because eKYC is a technology-driven mechanism that can affect how customers are onboarded and how services are delivered [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2]. The Relevant Person must also keep in view that money laundering risks include terrorist financing, proliferation financing, the financing of unlawful organisations, and sanctions non-compliance, so the technology/NFTF analysis should be aligned to those risk types [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. The assessment should consider incorporating any relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and any other relevant bodies [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2]. After identifying risks, the Relevant Person must take appropriate measures to ensure they are taken into account in day-to-day operations and mitigated, including in relation to new products, new customers, and changes to its business profile [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851].

question: For purposes of identifying an Offer of Securities, how should a firm assess whether a message constitutes a communication to any person in any form or by any means that provides sufficient information for an investor to decide to buy or subscribe, and how do the exclusions for certain trading-related, reporting-related, or otherwise exempt communications affect that assessment?
gold_answer: Across both texts, an Offer of Securities is defined by the functional effect of the communication rather than its format: it is any communication to any person, in any form or by any means, that presents information about the Offer and the Securities (including the terms of the Offer) in a way that enables an investor to decide to buy or subscribe to those Securities [#SRC:b3c9bf5b-e0ac-4be7-badf-15646cde6e09] [#TGT:35fa228f-ac9c-4d5f-82af-61d001921310]. In practice, the firm should evaluate (i) the breadth of distribution (“any person”), (ii) the channel used (“any form or by any means”), and (iii) whether the content is decision-enabling for an investor (i.e., it presents information on the Offer and the Securities offered, including the Offer’s terms). The TARGET then narrows the scope by excluding certain communications even if they otherwise resemble an offer: communications connected with trading of Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, communications made to comply with the on going reporting requirements of the Regulator or a Recognised Investment Exchange, and any other communications prescribed in Rules as exempt communications [#TGT:35fa228f-ac9c-4d5f-82af-61d001921310].

question: When does a message count as an Offer of Securities because it is a communication to any person (in any form) that helps an investor decide to buy or subscribe, and when is it not treated as an offer because it is linked to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, ongoing reporting to the Regulator or a Recognised Investment Exchange, or another exempt communication in Rules?
gold_answer: Both passages describe an Offer of Securities as a very broad category of message: it covers any communication to any person, in any form or by any means, that presents information about the Offer and the Securities offered (including the terms of the Offer) in a way that enables an investor to decide to buy or subscribe to those Securities [#SRC:b3c9bf5b-e0ac-4be7-badf-15646cde6e09] [#TGT:35fa228f-ac9c-4d5f-82af-61d001921310]. So you look at what the message does: does it give enough information about the Offer and the Securities for an investor to make a buy/subscribe decision, regardless of whether it is an email, website, presentation, or other medium? The TARGET then adds important carve-outs: even if a communication looks like it could influence an investor, it is excluded if it is in connection with trading of Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, if it is made to comply with the on going reporting requirements of the Regulator or a Recognised Investment Exchange, or if it is another type of communication that Rules prescribe as exempt [#TGT:35fa228f-ac9c-4d5f-82af-61d001921310].

question: When an entity is seeking admission of Digital Securities to the Official List of Securities and is also an Applicant for a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services, what fees must it pay, to whom, and how are the amounts determined for each fee category?
gold_answer: Two distinct fee obligations apply in parallel, depending on the nature of the submission being made. First, for the capital markets step, the listing fee payable for an admission of Digital Securities to the Official List of Securities is a fixed amount of US$3,000, tied specifically to the admission of Digital Securities to the Official List of Securities [#SRC:e6bea365-9269-4a14-ac6b-2ccf805f85f9]. Separately, for the authorisation step, an Applicant for a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services must pay an application fee to the Regulator, and the amount is determined by the activity the Applicant will carry on [#TGT:6ba8367f-82df-4c72-a188-980f7efc3b1b]. Under the activity-based table, the application fee is $15,000 where the activity is Currency exchange or Money Remittance, and $25,000 where the activity is Payment Services [#TGT:6ba8367f-82df-4c72-a188-980f7efc3b1b]. Accordingly, an entity undertaking both processes should budget for the US$3,000 listing fee plus the relevant application fee based on its Providing Money Services activity.

question: If a firm is admitting Digital Securities to the Official List of Securities and is also applying for a Financial Services Permission to provide money services, what fees must it pay and how do the amounts differ?
gold_answer: The firm would face two separate fees, each triggered by a different action. For the admission of Digital Securities to the Official List of Securities, there is a specific listing fee of US$3,000 that applies to that admission [#SRC:e6bea365-9269-4a14-ac6b-2ccf805f85f9]. In addition, if the firm is an Applicant for a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services, it must pay an application fee to the Regulator, and the amount depends on which Providing Money Services activity it will carry on [#TGT:6ba8367f-82df-4c72-a188-980f7efc3b1b]. The table sets the application fee at $15,000 for Currency exchange or Money Remittance, and $25,000 for Payment Services [#TGT:6ba8367f-82df-4c72-a188-980f7efc3b1b]. So, the listing fee is a fixed US$3,000 for the Digital Securities admission, while the permission application fee varies by the money services activity and is paid to the Regulator.

question: Where an Authorised Person operates as a Cell Company and already holds a Financial Services Permission, what fees must it pay to the Regulator when it seeks to add each additional Cell, and what separate annual supervision fee applies if it has a Financial Services Permission to carry on either one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as Principal?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that operates as a Cell Company and has already received its Financial Services Permission must pay the Regulator an application fee of $1,000 for each Cell it wishes to add after receiving that permission [#SRC:31302f70-ed5e-4f1a-860f-140416c5d9e8]. Separately, if the same Authorised Person has a Financial Services Permission to carry on either one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as Principal, it must pay the Regulator an annual supervision fee of $50,000 for either or both Regulated Activities [#TGT:6fc382ee-caf4-4abd-b571-718512a89e96]. In practice, this means the per-Cell application fee is triggered by the act of adding Cells after permission is granted and is calculated on a “per Cell” basis, while the annual supervision fee is tied to holding permission for the specified insurance-related Regulated Activities and applies on an annual basis regardless of whether one or both of those activities are carried on.

question: If an Authorised Person operates as a Cell Company and wants to add new Cells after it already has its Financial Services Permission, what must it pay the Regulator per Cell, and what annual supervision fee must it also pay if it is permitted to do insurance business as Principal (Effecting Contracts of Insurance and/or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance)?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person operates as a Cell Company and it wishes to add Cells after it has received its Financial Services Permission, it must pay the Regulator an application fee of $1,000 for each Cell it wants to add [#SRC:31302f70-ed5e-4f1a-860f-140416c5d9e8]. In addition to that per-Cell application fee, an Authorised Person that has a Financial Services Permission to carry on either one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as Principal must pay the Regulator an annual supervision fee of $50,000 for either or both Regulated Activities [#TGT:6fc382ee-caf4-4abd-b571-718512a89e96]. So, the amounts and triggers differ: the $1,000 fee is charged each time a new Cell is added after permission is already in place, while the $50,000 fee is an annual charge linked to being authorised for the specified insurance-related activities as Principal, whether the Authorised Person carries on one or both of those activities.

question: When an Authorised Person is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets and is required to comply with COBS, Chapter 8, how must the Chapter 8 terminology be applied where it refers to Investments or Financial Instruments, and what is the resulting compliance obligation?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets must comply with the requirements set out in COBS, Chapter 8 [#TGT:7cf37a88-ab41-4ec4-a018-7d040a752c1f]. In applying those Chapter 8 requirements to this Virtual Asset context, the terminology must be read through the specified interpretive procedure: any references in COBS, Chapter 8 to “Investment” or “Investments” are to be treated as references to “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets,” as applicable, and any references to “Financial Instrument” or “Financial Instruments” (including those in MIR as incorporated into Chapter 8) are likewise to be treated as references to “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets,” as applicable [#SRC:a3736367-db02-465d-809f-1bc6cfd7bbcd]. Practically, this means the Authorised Person’s Chapter 8 compliance assessment, controls, and implementation steps for the Multilateral Trading Facility must be performed by mapping the Chapter 8 concepts that would ordinarily apply to Investments or Financial Instruments onto Virtual Assets, ensuring the Chapter 8 requirements are met on that substituted basis rather than by applying the original terms without adaptation.

question: If an Authorised Person is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility for Virtual Assets, what do they have to do under COBS, Chapter 8, and how should they read Chapter 8 when it talks about Investments or Financial Instruments?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets must comply with the requirements set out in COBS, Chapter 8 [#TGT:7cf37a88-ab41-4ec4-a018-7d040a752c1f]. To apply those Chapter 8 requirements correctly in this Virtual Asset setting, the Chapter 8 wording must be interpreted using the specified reading approach: where Chapter 8 refers to “Investment” or “Investments,” those references are to be read as “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets,” as applicable, and where Chapter 8 refers to “Financial Instrument” or “Financial Instruments” (including references in MIR that are incorporated into Chapter 8), those references are also to be read as “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets,” as applicable [#SRC:a3736367-db02-465d-809f-1bc6cfd7bbcd]. In effect, the compliance obligation is not reduced or optional; instead, the Authorised Person must meet Chapter 8 requirements by treating the key product and instrument terms in Chapter 8 as referring to Virtual Assets for the purposes of operating the Multilateral Trading Facility.

question: When executing an unsolicited Client order in Financial Instruments while in possession of Inside Information, in what circumstances is the person executing the order prohibited from proceeding because the Insider has disclosed Inside Information to another person outside the proper course of employment, profession or duties, and what related conduct toward the Client must also be absent?
gold_answer: A person executing an unsolicited Client order in Financial Instruments while in possession of Inside Information must treat the execution as prohibited where the relevant conduct includes an Insider disclosing Inside Information to another person otherwise than in the proper course of the exercise of his employment, profession or duties [#TGT:24c9495c-026d-446e-865a-9051fa94f13b]. In the execution context, the prohibition is framed around ensuring the executor has not engaged in disclosure-based misconduct connected to the Client order: the person executing the order must not have disclosed Inside Information to the Client or procured the Client to deal in the relevant Financial Instruments (or other covered instruments) for which the executor has Inside Information, and must not have otherwise advised or encouraged the Client in relation to the transaction [#SRC:b4c8c1af-0583-4e05-88c2-d600d800e579]. Read together, the restrictions mean that execution cannot be used as a vehicle to pass Inside Information improperly (including disclosures outside proper duties) or to influence the Client’s dealing; the order must remain unsolicited and unprompted by any disclosure, procurement, advice, or encouragement by the person executing it.

question: If someone is executing an unsolicited Client order in Financial Instruments while they have Inside Information, when must they not go ahead because an Insider has shared that Inside Information with someone else outside their normal job duties, and what must they not have done to the Client?
gold_answer: They must not treat the execution of the unsolicited Client order as acceptable if the situation involves an Insider disclosing Inside Information to another person otherwise than in the proper course of the exercise of his employment, profession or duties [#TGT:24c9495c-026d-446e-865a-9051fa94f13b]. In addition, the person executing the order must not have used the order process to pass on or leverage the Inside Information with the Client: they must not have disclosed the Inside Information to the Client or procured the Client to deal in the Financial Instruments (or other covered instruments) for which the executor has Inside Information, and they must not have otherwise advised or encouraged the Client about the transaction [#SRC:b4c8c1af-0583-4e05-88c2-d600d800e579]. Put simply, the order can only be executed in a way that avoids improper disclosure (including disclosure outside proper duties) and avoids any steering of the Client’s decision-making through disclosure, procurement, advice, or encouragement.

question: How must an Authorised Person align the frequency and timing of reconciliations of Client Accounts when it is conducting Investment Business and also conducts a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets and holds or controls Client Money—specifically, what minimum cadence applies and what additional deadlines apply to the relevant reconciliation steps?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must maintain adequate systems and controls that ensure accurate reconciliations of Client Accounts are performed as regularly as necessary and, in any event, no less frequently than every calendar month [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b]. Where the same Authorised Person also conducts a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets and holds or controls Client Money, the reconciliations of Client Accounts required under the referenced framework must be applied with more specific minimum timing: the reconciliation step corresponding to Rule 14.11.1 must be carried out at least every week, and the reconciliation step corresponding to Rule 14.11.4 must be completed within five days of the date to which the reconciliation relates [#SRC:3a1b6f65-bf51-4f78-840e-f64d67f67a52]. Practically, this means the systems and controls required for Investment Business must be designed to support at least monthly reconciliations overall, while also enabling weekly performance of the specified reconciliation activity and ensuring the specified follow-up reconciliation activity is completed within the five-day window when the Virtual Assets/Client Money condition applies.

question: If an Authorised Person is conducting Investment Business, what is the minimum schedule for reconciling Client Accounts, and how does that schedule change if it also conducts a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets and holds or controls Client Money?
gold_answer: For an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, it must have adequate systems and controls so that accurate reconciliations of Client Accounts happen as often as needed, but at least once every calendar month [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b]. If that same Authorised Person also conducts a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets and holds or controls Client Money, the reconciliations of Client Accounts are subject to additional minimum timing requirements for specific reconciliation steps: the activity described as Rule 14.11.1 must be performed at least every week, and the activity described as Rule 14.11.4 must be completed within five days after the date the reconciliation covers [#SRC:3a1b6f65-bf51-4f78-840e-f64d67f67a52]. In effect, the monthly minimum for Investment Business remains a baseline, but the Virtual Assets/Client Money condition requires the Authorised Person’s controls to support a weekly reconciliation cycle for the specified step and a five-day completion deadline for the specified follow-up step, so that both sets of obligations are met.

question: When the documents referenced in the earlier paragraphs have already been Disclosed, how does that affect whether an Issuer must make an additional announcement under the continuous disclosure regime, given that the regime is intended to operate alongside periodic/financial disclosures and broader legal disclosure duties (including prospectus-style offer materials and bidders’/targets’ statements)?
gold_answer: Where the documents referred to in the earlier paragraphs have already been Disclosed, the Listing Authority treats the information contained in those documents as having entered the market, so it is not expected to be the subject of a separate, additional disclosure under the continuous disclosure obligations. This is a scope boundary on when a further disclosure step is required: the trigger is not merely that information exists, but whether it has already been made available through the specified Disclosed documents such that it is regarded as “within the market” [#SRC:0bb0c147-7d66-4abf-b7a7-624b435bfba6]. This interaction is particularly relevant because the continuous disclosure obligations are designed to operate closely with other disclosure channels, including periodic/financial disclosure obligations and general disclosure obligations under FSMR, ADGM Commercial Laws (for Listed Entities incorporated in ADGM), and international commercial and corporate laws (for Listed Entities not incorporated in ADGM), which can include Prospectus Offer documents and bidders’ and targets’ statements [#TGT:05f69230-1c8e-4359-98fe-2f92e40b5e8f]. In practice, once disclosure has occurred through those documents, the continuous disclosure regime does not require duplicative disclosure of the same information solely because it also falls within the broader disclosure ecosystem.

question: If the documents mentioned earlier have already been Disclosed, do you still need to make a separate continuous disclosure update, even though continuous disclosure is meant to work alongside periodic financial reports and other legal disclosures like prospectus offer documents and bidders’/targets’ statements?
gold_answer: If the documents referred to in the earlier paragraphs have already been Disclosed, the Listing Authority will treat the information in those documents as already being in the market, meaning it does not need a separate, additional disclosure under the continuous disclosure obligations. The key point is the boundary of what the continuous disclosure obligation is meant to capture: it is not intended to force a second disclosure of information that has already been made public through the specified Disclosed documents and is therefore regarded as “within the market” [#SRC:0bb0c147-7d66-4abf-b7a7-624b435bfba6]. This matters because the continuous disclosure obligations are described as operating closely with other disclosure regimes, including periodic/financial disclosure obligations and general disclosure obligations under FSMR, ADGM Commercial Laws (for Listed Entities incorporated in ADGM), and international commercial and corporate laws (for Listed Entities not incorporated in ADGM), which can include Prospectus Offer documents and bidders’ and targets’ statements [#TGT:05f69230-1c8e-4359-98fe-2f92e40b5e8f]. So, where those other disclosure routes have already been used to disclose the information, the continuous disclosure obligation is not treated as requiring duplication.

question: For purposes of defining CET1 Capital, how must a firm determine what constitutes the sum of CET1 capital elements, and how does that sum interact with any later adjustments, deductions, or exemptions when identifying the eligible capital elements (including capital instruments and related IFRS-based reserves)?
gold_answer: CET1 Capital is determined by first identifying the CET1 capital elements that make up the sum and then applying any subsequent modifications required by the framework. The SOURCE establishes that CET1 Capital is the sum of CET1 capital elements, but that this sum is not necessarily the final figure because it is expressly subject to later adjustments, deductions, and exemptions within the same Part [#SRC:57c6772e-451b-4845-9fb7-2bc5d251fa50]. The TARGET specifies what those CET1 capital elements are for the purpose of forming that initial sum: capital instruments (only where the relevant conditions are fully met), the share premium accounts related to those instruments, retained earnings, accumulated other comprehensive income as defined in International Financial Reporting Standards, and other IFRS-disclosed reserves (excluding amounts already included in accumulated other comprehensive income or retained earnings) [#TGT:6ae8d23c-06f5-4f8c-b1b1-824cb6db43eb]. Read together, the definition requires a two-step approach: (1) compile the sum from the enumerated elements, ensuring the eligibility condition for capital instruments is satisfied, and (2) treat that sum as subject to later adjustments, deductions, and exemptions that may change the resulting CET1 Capital amount.

question: What exactly goes into CET1 Capital, and after you add up those items, do you still have to change the total because of later adjustments, deductions, or exemptions?
gold_answer: CET1 Capital is built by adding up specified CET1 capital elements, but the total you get from that addition may not be the final number because later changes can apply. The TARGET lists the items that make up the sum of capital elements: eligible capital instruments (only if the stated conditions are fully met), the share premium accounts linked to those instruments, retained earnings, accumulated other comprehensive income as defined in International Financial Reporting Standards, and other reserves that must be disclosed under International Financial Reporting Standards (but excluding any amounts already counted in accumulated other comprehensive income or retained earnings) [#TGT:6ae8d23c-06f5-4f8c-b1b1-824cb6db43eb]. The SOURCE then clarifies how to treat that sum: CET1 Capital “constitutes the sum” of the relevant CET1 capital elements, but it is explicitly subject to adjustments, deductions, and exemptions that are stipulated later in the same Part [#SRC:57c6772e-451b-4845-9fb7-2bc5d251fa50]. So, you first identify and add the listed elements to form the base sum, and then you must apply any later adjustments, deductions, or exemptions that the Part requires before treating the result as CET1 Capital.

question: Where a Prospectus includes a statement originating from a public official or an official public document, and that statement is reproduced accurately and fairly, how must a person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus assess whether it still has to pay compensation to an acquirer of Securities who claims loss from an untrue or misleading statement or a material omission in the Prospectus?
gold_answer: A person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus must start from the general position that it is liable to pay compensation to a person who acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and who suffered loss or damage arising from (i) any untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or (ii) the omission of any material matter required to be included [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac]. However, when the alleged problematic content is a statement made by a public official or contained in an official public document and included in the Prospectus, the liability analysis must incorporate the specific carve-out that a Person does not incur liability for loss resulting from that statement if it has been accurately and fairly reproduced [#SRC:4c5cd124-5d5b-497d-821c-877b1c83741f]. Practically, the prescribed liable person should verify the provenance of the statement (public official/official public document), confirm the reproduction is accurate and fair, and then distinguish claims tied to that reproduced statement (potentially excluded) from claims tied to other untrue or misleading statements or material omissions elsewhere in the Prospectus (potentially compensable).

question: If an investor alleges loss from a Prospectus because it contains an untrue or misleading statement, but the relevant wording was taken from an official public document and reproduced accurately and fairly, must a person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus pay compensation, or can it rely on the no-liability position for that reproduced statement?
gold_answer: The compensation obligation applies to any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus where another person acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and suffered loss or damage arising from an untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or from the omission of a material matter required to be included [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac]. At the same time, there is a specific limitation on liability where the Prospectus includes a statement made by a public official or contained in an official public document: a Person does not incur liability for any loss resulting from that statement if it is accurately and fairly reproduced [#SRC:4c5cd124-5d5b-497d-821c-877b1c83741f]. Read together, the prescribed liable person must determine whether the investor’s alleged loss is “resulting from” the reproduced official statement and whether the reproduction was accurate and fair; if so, the no-liability position can apply to that aspect. If the loss instead arises from other untrue or misleading statements or from a required material omission in the Prospectus, the compensation liability framework remains engaged.

question: If a Prospectus repeats a statement from a public official or an official public document, and it is copied accurately and fairly, does a person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus still have to pay compensation to someone who bought the Securities and says they suffered loss because the Prospectus was untrue or left out required information?
gold_answer: A person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is generally liable to pay compensation to a person who acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and who suffered loss or damage because the Prospectus contained an untrue or misleading statement or omitted a material matter that was required to be included [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac]. But there is an important exception for certain content: when the Prospectus includes a statement made by a public official or contained in an official public document, a Person does not incur liability for loss resulting from that statement if the statement is reproduced accurately and fairly [#SRC:4c5cd124-5d5b-497d-821c-877b1c83741f]. So the prescribed liable person must check (1) whether the challenged wording really comes from a public official or official public document, (2) whether it was reproduced accurately and fairly, and (3) whether the claimed loss is actually caused by that reproduced statement. If those conditions are met, the no-liability position can apply to that statement, while compensation exposure may still exist for other misleading statements or required omissions in the Prospectus.

question: When someone claims compensation because a Prospectus misled them, what should a person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus do if the disputed text came from an official public document and was copied correctly?
gold_answer: The person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus must evaluate the claim against two linked rules. First, the general rule is that the prescribed liable person is liable to pay compensation to a person who acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and suffered loss or damage arising from an untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or from leaving out a material matter that had to be included [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac]. Second, if the disputed text is a statement made by a public official or contained in an official public document and it was included in the Prospectus, a Person does not incur liability for loss resulting from that statement where it is accurately and fairly reproduced [#SRC:4c5cd124-5d5b-497d-821c-877b1c83741f]. In practice, the prescribed liable person should confirm the source is official, confirm the reproduction is accurate and fair, and then decide whether the alleged loss is tied to that reproduced statement (potentially excluded) or to other misleading content or required omissions (potentially compensable).

question: How must an Authorised Person determine the frequency for evaluating its Exposure to interest rate risk arising from its Non Trading Book activities, and what minimum cadence applies when those evaluations are part of the stress-testing evaluation framework?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must perform an evaluation of its Exposure to the interest rate risk arising from its Non Trading Book activities, and this obligation sits alongside the broader requirement to carry out the relevant evaluations as often as needed to maintain an adequate, continuous understanding of the degree and nature of its Exposure to the applicable risks [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3] [#SRC:79d37689-e1b6-4801-8b67-ba7d7bafd0ae]. Practically, the frequency is not fixed at a single interval; instead, the Authorised Person must set a cadence that is sufficient for it to be reasonably satisfied that it has, at all times, a sufficient understanding of its Exposure and the nature of that Exposure. However, even where the firm’s own assessment would suggest a less frequent schedule, it must not fall below the specified minimum frequency referenced for those evaluations. Accordingly, the Authorised Person should align its Non Trading Book interest rate risk evaluation schedule with a frequency that is responsive to its risk profile while also meeting the stated minimum floor for conducting the evaluations.

question: Where an Authorised Person has balance sheet positions in different currencies, how must it integrate per-currency measurement of material risk Exposures into the requirement to carry out evaluations as frequently as necessary and not below the minimum required frequency?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person with balance sheet positions in different currencies must measure its risk Exposures in each of the material currencies as part of its evaluation of Exposure to the interest rate risk arising from its Non Trading Book activities [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3]. The timing of these measurements and the associated evaluations must be set so that the Authorised Person can be reasonably satisfied that it has, at all times, a sufficient understanding of both the degree to which it is exposed to the relevant risks and the nature of that Exposure [#SRC:79d37689-e1b6-4801-8b67-ba7d7bafd0ae]. This means the firm should determine a frequency that is responsive to changes in its currency-specific positions and the materiality of the currencies involved, rather than relying on a static schedule that could leave gaps in understanding. At the same time, the firm must ensure that the evaluations (including the per-material-currency measurement work that supports them) are not conducted less frequently than the minimum frequency referenced for those evaluations. In effect, per-currency measurement is required, and the evaluation cycle must be frequent enough to sustain continuous understanding while meeting the minimum cadence.

question: How often does an Authorised Person have to evaluate its Exposure to interest rate risk from Non Trading Book activities, and what is the minimum frequency it must not go below when setting that schedule?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must carry out an evaluation of its Exposure to the interest rate risk arising from its Non Trading Book activities [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3]. The frequency is not a single fixed interval; instead, the Authorised Person must carry out the relevant evaluations as frequently as necessary for it to be reasonably satisfied that it has at all times a sufficient understanding of the degree to which it is exposed to the relevant risks and the nature of that Exposure [#SRC:79d37689-e1b6-4801-8b67-ba7d7bafd0ae]. This requires the firm to choose a schedule that keeps its understanding current and continuous, rather than only periodic. Even so, there is a minimum floor: the firm must not conduct those evaluations less often than the minimum frequency referenced for them. So, the firm must both (i) set a frequency that is “as often as needed” to maintain sufficient understanding at all times, and (ii) ensure it still meets the stated minimum frequency requirement.

question: If an Authorised Person has balance sheet positions in different currencies, what must it do for each material currency, and how does that affect how often it runs the evaluations?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person has balance sheet positions in different currencies, it must measure its risk Exposures in each of the material currencies as part of its evaluation of Exposure to the interest rate risk arising from its Non Trading Book activities [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3]. This per-material-currency measurement needs to be built into the firm’s evaluation process so that the firm can be reasonably satisfied it has, at all times, a sufficient understanding of the degree and nature of its Exposure to the relevant risks [#SRC:79d37689-e1b6-4801-8b67-ba7d7bafd0ae]. In practice, that means the firm should not treat currency measurement as a one-off exercise; it should be performed on a cadence that supports continuous understanding, especially where positions or material currencies change. At the same time, the firm must ensure the evaluations are not carried out less frequently than the minimum frequency referenced for those evaluations. So the currency-by-currency requirement affects the content of each evaluation, and the “as frequently as necessary” standard drives how often the firm repeats that work.

question: When determining its balance sheet position at the Solvency Reference Date, how must an Insurer recognise (i) the value of reinsurance and other recoveries expected to be received in respect of relevant claims and (ii) the premium liability for policies in force, and how do these required classifications interact in presenting assets versus liabilities?
gold_answer: An Insurer must apply two complementary recognition requirements when presenting its financial position at the Solvency Reference Date. First, it must recognise on the asset side the value of reinsurance and other recoveries that it expects to receive in respect of the relevant claims, and it must do so in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards [#SRC:e6345a04-a9de-4dbf-8085-91eee4cffec6]. Second, it must recognise on the liability side the premium liability for policies that are in force as at the Solvency Reference Date; this premium liability represents the value of future claim payments and the associated direct and indirect settlement costs arising from future insured events under those in-force policies [#TGT:3c34e221-794b-4399-b4bd-b38a5f2a10c6]. Read together, the framework requires the Insurer to distinguish expected inflows from reinsurance and other recoveries (assets) from the obligation to meet future claims and settlement costs under existing policies (liabilities), ensuring both sides of the balance sheet reflect expected recoveries and expected outflows under the specified measurement bases.

question: For an Insurer, what must be shown as an asset for expected reinsurance and other recoveries, and what must be shown as a liability for future claims and settlement costs on policies that are still in force at the Solvency Reference Date?
gold_answer: An Insurer must classify two different items on opposite sides of its financial position. On the asset side, it must treat as an asset the value of reinsurance and other recoveries that it expects to receive in respect of the relevant claims, and it must recognise that asset in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards [#SRC:e6345a04-a9de-4dbf-8085-91eee4cffec6]. On the liability side, it must treat as a liability the premium liability for policies that are in force as at the Solvency Reference Date [#TGT:3c34e221-794b-4399-b4bd-b38a5f2a10c6]. The premium liability is defined as the value of future claim payments plus associated direct and indirect settlement costs, where those payments and costs arise from future events insured under the in-force policies. Taken together, these requirements mean the Insurer must separately recognise expected recoveries (as assets) and expected future claim-related outflows (as liabilities) for the same portfolio context, without conflating the two classifications.

question: When a notifiable interest arises or changes, which Person must give notice to the other members of the Governing Body, by when must it be given, and what types of interests or involvement qualify as a notifiable interest for a member of the Governing Body of a Listed Fund?
