After the Exposure is categorised, the Authorised Person assigns an applicable Credit Quality Grade and then the risk weight for that Exposure under the applicable Rules, which together determine the CRW used in the calculation. It then calculates the risk-weighted amount for each Exposure using the formula RWA(CR) = E x CRW, and finally adds up the RWA amounts for all of its CR Exposures to produce the total RWA figure [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368].

question: In the context of an investigation, when may the Investigator compel attendance at an interview and questioning, and does that authority extend beyond the Person Under Investigation to other individuals regardless of any connection to that person, provided the requirement is issued by written notice?
gold_answer: Across the two provisions, the Investigator is permitted to compel a person to attend an interview and answer questions as part of an investigation, and the mechanism and scope are clarified. The SOURCE establishes the core investigative permission: the Investigator has the power to require a person (described as the interviewee) to attend an interview and answer questions for the purposes of an investigation [#SRC:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf]. The TARGET then specifies how and to whom that power may be directed: the Investigator may do so by written notice, and the notice may be addressed either to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, expressly including persons who are not connected to the Person Under Investigation [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. Read together, the Investigator’s permission is not limited to the subject of the investigation; it can reach third parties, and it is exercisable through a written notice that can require attendance at a specified time and place and answering questions. This combined reading supports compliance planning for both primary subjects and potential third-party interviewees.

question: Can the Investigator make someone come to an interview and answer questions during an investigation, and can that include people other than the Person Under Investigation if the Investigator sends a written notice?
gold_answer: Yes, taken together the two texts indicate that the Investigator is permitted to require interview attendance and questioning for investigative purposes, and that this can apply to more than just the Person Under Investigation. The SOURCE states that, for the purposes of an investigation, the Investigator has the power to require a person (the interviewee) to attend an interview and answer questions [#SRC:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf]. The TARGET adds important detail about both process and scope: the Investigator may do this by written notice, and the notice can be directed to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, even if that other person is not connected to the Person Under Investigation [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. The TARGET also makes clear that the notice can specify the time and place for the interview and that the person must answer questions at that interview. Combining these points, the Investigator’s permission covers compelling interviews for investigative purposes and extends to third parties, provided the requirement is issued through written notice.

question: For a Listed Entity that has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities, when must it apply the restriction in APP 7, and in what circumstances are specified APP 7 restriction categories treated as not applying unless the Regulator decides otherwise?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity that has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities is required to apply the restriction in APP 7, or comply with such other restrictions as the Regulator decides in its discretion [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f]. However, the scope of that obligation is qualified by an express carve-out: unless the Regulator decides otherwise, the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply in relation to a Listed Entity that meets any of the stated conditions [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]. Those conditions are that the Listed Entity (1) qualifies for admission to the Official List pursuant to the specified admission basis, (2) has a track record of profitability or revenue acceptable to the Regulator, or (3) in the opinion of the Regulator has tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value that constitute a substantial proportion of the total value of its assets [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]. Accordingly, the Listed Entity must look to both the general requirement to apply APP 7 restrictions and the Regulator-dependent exceptions that can remove certain APP 7 categories from application.

question: If a Listed Entity has issued or plans to issue Restricted Securities, does it always have to apply the APP 7 restriction, or are there cases where some APP 7 restriction categories do not apply unless the Regulator says they do?
gold_answer: When a Listed Entity has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities, it must apply the restriction in APP 7, or follow other restrictions the Regulator chooses to impose in its discretion [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f]. But the Target text narrows when certain APP 7 restrictions apply: unless the Regulator decides otherwise, the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply in relation to a Listed Entity that meets at least one of three criteria [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]. Those criteria are: the Listed Entity qualifies for admission to the Official List under the stated admission route; it has a profitability or revenue track record that is acceptable to the Regulator; or, in the Regulator’s opinion, it has tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value that make up a substantial proportion of its total asset value [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]. So, the general “must apply” obligation exists, but whether particular APP 7 categories apply depends on these conditions and on whether the Regulator decides otherwise.

question: When an Authorised Person identifies that it does not hold, or is likely not to hold, the capital needed to meet its ongoing Tier 1 Capital and minimum Leverage Ratio requirement, what notification must it provide to the Regulator, in what form, and how quickly must it be made?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person has two linked obligations: it must continuously maintain sufficient Tier 1 Capital so that, at all times, it meets a minimum Leverage Ratio of 3% (or a different level if the Regulator sets one) [#TGT:e9e2bf18-6110-4e9f-8060-c59b85e5cd8e]. If, at any time, the Authorised Person does not hold, or is likely not to hold, the amount and quality of capital necessary to comply with that capital requirement, it must notify the Regulator immediately and the notification must be in writing [#SRC:cb563a7f-d8cf-4245-afdb-e5c995f3df81]. Practically, this means the trigger for notification is not limited to an actual breach of the leverage ratio; it also includes a forward-looking likelihood that the Authorised Person will not have the required capital to sustain the minimum leverage ratio on an ongoing basis. The required action is a written notice to the Regulator, and the timing standard is immediate once the Authorised Person becomes aware of the shortfall or likely shortfall.

question: How should an Authorised Person reconcile its duty to maintain a minimum Leverage Ratio through sufficient Tier 1 Capital with its duty to alert the Regulator where its capital position may no longer support that requirement, including the timing and medium of any alert?
gold_answer: The framework imposes an ongoing prudential maintenance duty and a separate escalation duty. First, an Authorised Person must hold sufficient Tier 1 Capital to ensure it maintains, at all times, a minimum Leverage Ratio of 3%, unless the Regulator sets a different minimum [#TGT:e9e2bf18-6110-4e9f-8060-c59b85e5cd8e]. Second, if at any time the Authorised Person does not hold, or is likely not to hold, the amount and quality of capital necessary to comply with that requirement, it must notify the Regulator immediately in writing [#SRC:cb563a7f-d8cf-4245-afdb-e5c995f3df81]. Read together, the Authorised Person must monitor its capital position against the leverage ratio standard on a continuous basis and treat both an actual inability and a likely future inability to maintain sufficient Tier 1 Capital as a reportable event. The notification obligation is not discretionary and is not delayed until the ratio is actually missed; it is triggered by the existence of a shortfall or the likelihood of one, and it must be communicated promptly and in written form to the Regulator.

question: If an Authorised Person thinks it may not have enough Tier 1 Capital to keep meeting the minimum Leverage Ratio at all times, what must it do to inform the Regulator, and how fast and in what format must it do it?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must always hold enough Tier 1 Capital to keep a minimum Leverage Ratio of 3%, unless the Regulator sets a different minimum [#TGT:e9e2bf18-6110-4e9f-8060-c59b85e5cd8e]. If, at any time, the Authorised Person does not have, or is likely not to have, the amount and quality of capital needed to comply with that requirement, it has to tell the Regulator right away and it must do so in writing [#SRC:cb563a7f-d8cf-4245-afdb-e5c995f3df81]. This means the duty to notify is triggered not only when the leverage ratio requirement is already being missed, but also when the Authorised Person expects it may not be able to keep enough capital to meet the requirement going forward. The required action is a written notification, and the timing is immediate once the issue (or likely issue) exists.

question: What are the two connected duties for an Authorised Person about (1) keeping its leverage ratio through Tier 1 Capital and (2) telling the Regulator when it cannot, or may soon not be able to, meet that capital need?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person has an ongoing duty to maintain its leverage standard and a separate duty to report problems quickly. On the maintenance side, it must hold sufficient Tier 1 Capital so that it maintains, at all times, a minimum Leverage Ratio of 3% (or another minimum if the Regulator sets one) [#TGT:e9e2bf18-6110-4e9f-8060-c59b85e5cd8e]. On the reporting side, if at any time it does not hold, or is likely not to hold, the amount and quality of capital needed to comply with that requirement, it must notify the Regulator immediately in writing [#SRC:cb563a7f-d8cf-4245-afdb-e5c995f3df81]. Put simply, the first duty is to keep enough Tier 1 Capital to meet the leverage ratio continuously, and the second duty is to send a written, immediate notice to the Regulator as soon as there is an actual or likely capital shortfall against that requirement.

question: When conducting an investigation, in what circumstances may the Investigator compel the Person Under Investigation or another person (including someone not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to provide information, and what kinds of material can fall within the scope of “information” for that purpose?
gold_answer: The Investigator is permitted to compel information by issuing a written notice to the person who is the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, whether or not connected to the Person Under Investigation, requiring that person to provide such information as the Investigator may require [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. This permission aligns with the Investigator’s power to require a person to give, or procure the giving of, information [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. For scope, “information” is to be interpreted broadly in its ordinary meaning and can include multiple forms of content, not limited to formal documents. It may encompass knowledge communicated or received about a matter, fact, or circumstance; knowledge gained through work, commerce, study, communication, research, or instruction; and data produced or handled by a computer at any stage of processing, including input, output, storage, or transmission data [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. It can also include an explanation or statement about a matter, identification of a person/matter/thing, and a response to a question, which complements the ability to require answers in an interview setting [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046].

question: How may the Investigator use a written notice to require a person to answer questions or otherwise provide information, and how should a regulated party assess whether the requested content qualifies as “information” rather than only “Documents”?
gold_answer: The Investigator may, by written notice, require the Person Under Investigation or any other person (even if not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to attend an interview at a specified time and place and answer questions, and may also require that person to provide such information as the Investigator may require [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. This sits alongside the Investigator’s power to require a person to give, or procure the giving of, information [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. In assessing whether a request is properly treated as “information” (as distinct from a request to “produce… Documents”), the key is that “information” is intended to be broad and not confined to documentary production. It can include knowledge about facts or circumstances, knowledge gained through professional or other activities, and computer-related data at any stage of processing (including stored or transmitted data) [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. It also includes explanations or statements, identification details, and responses to questions—meaning that oral or written answers, clarifications, and identifications can fall within “information” even where no specific document is being produced [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046].

question: Can the Investigator make someone give information during an investigation, and does this apply only to the Person Under Investigation or also to other people? What does “information” cover?
gold_answer: Yes. The Investigator may use a written notice to require the person who is the Person Under Investigation, or any other person (even if not connected to the Person Under Investigation), to provide such information as the Investigator may require [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. This matches the Investigator’s power to require a person to give, or procure the giving of, information [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. The term “information” is meant to be read broadly in its ordinary sense, so it is not limited to formal records. It can include knowledge communicated or received about a matter, fact, or circumstance, and knowledge gained through work, commerce, study, communication, research, or instruction [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. It can also include computer-related data at any stage of processing, including input, output, storage, or transmission data. In addition, “information” can be an explanation or statement about a matter, the identification of a person/matter/thing, or simply a response to a question—consistent with the Investigator’s ability to require a person to answer questions (for example, at an interview) [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32].

question: If the Investigator asks for “information” in a written notice, does that mean only documents, or can it include answers and computer data too? How does this fit with the Investigator’s ability to require interviews and questions?
gold_answer: A written notice can require more than just documents. The Investigator may require the Person Under Investigation or any other person (whether or not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to provide such information as the Investigator may require, and may also require the person to attend an interview at a specified time and place and answer questions [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. The Investigator’s power to require a person to give, or procure the giving of, information is intended to be broad [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. “Information” can include knowledge about a matter, fact, or circumstance, and knowledge gained through work or study. It also includes data obtained as output from a computer through processing, and any data at any stage of processing, including input, output, storage, or transmission data [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. Beyond data, it can include an explanation or statement, identification details, and a response to a question. That means the Investigator’s interview-and-questions power and the information-request power work together: the “information” requested can be provided as answers, explanations, identifications, or relevant computer data, not only as produced documents [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32].

question: When an Authorised Person has Non Trading Book assets or liabilities denominated in multiple currencies, how must it determine which currencies are treated as material for purposes of measuring interest rate risk Exposure, and what evaluation and measurement steps must follow for those currencies?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person has balance sheet positions in different currencies, it must first identify which currencies qualify as “material currencies” by applying the threshold that each currency accounting for 5% or more of its Non Trading Book assets or Non Trading Book liabilities should be treated as a material currency Exposure [#SRC:fa74198b-0ce3-4a0c-a1a1-e2a3e719df28]. Using that definition to set the scope, the Authorised Person must then carry out an evaluation of its Exposure to the interest rate risk arising from its Non Trading Book activities [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3]. In addition, because it has positions in different currencies, it must measure its risk Exposures in each of the currencies that meet the materiality criterion, rather than only on an aggregated basis [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3]. Practically, this means the evaluation of interest rate risk must be supported by currency-by-currency measurement for every currency that reaches or exceeds the 5% share of Non Trading Book assets or liabilities, ensuring the assessment captures the relevant exposures in those material currencies [#SRC:fa74198b-0ce3-4a0c-a1a1-e2a3e719df28].

question: If an Authorised Person’s Non Trading Book includes more than one currency, which currencies must it treat as “material,” and what must it do next to assess interest rate risk in those currencies?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person has balance sheet positions in different currencies, it must decide which currencies are “material” by using the criterion that any currency making up 5% or more of its Non Trading Book assets or its Non Trading Book liabilities should be considered a material currency Exposure [#SRC:fa74198b-0ce3-4a0c-a1a1-e2a3e719df28]. Once those material currencies are identified, the Authorised Person must carry out an evaluation of its Exposure to the interest rate risk arising from its Non Trading Book activities [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3]. Because the positions are in different currencies, it also must measure its risk Exposures separately in each of the material currencies, rather than treating all currencies as one combined exposure [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3]. In effect, the 5% threshold determines which currencies trigger the more detailed, currency-specific measurement that supports the required interest rate risk evaluation for the Non Trading Book [#SRC:fa74198b-0ce3-4a0c-a1a1-e2a3e719df28].

question: When a Third Party Provider refuses a Third Party Transaction, how must it deliver the refusal notification to the Customer, and what must the Governing Contract include to evidence the agreed means of communication for transmitting such notifications (including any technical requirements)?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider is required to notify of a refusal and must deliver that refusal notification in the manner that has been agreed for such communications [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575]. To ensure that this “agreed manner” is clear and operational for the Customer, the Governing Contract between the Third Party Provider and their Customers must, unless otherwise agreed in writing between the Third Party Provider and their Customer, set out the means of communication agreed between the parties for transmitting information or notifications, including any relevant technical requirements for the Customer’s equipment and software to receive them [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. In practice, this links the delivery obligation for refusal notifications to the contractually documented communication channel(s) and any prerequisites for receipt. The contract must also address the manner and frequency with which information under the relevant chapter is to be provided or made available, supporting consistent delivery of refusal notifications through the agreed communication arrangements [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49].

question: If a Third Party Provider intends to reserve the right to stop or prevent a Third Party Transaction from being executed, what must it do when it refuses a Third Party Transaction, and how must the Governing Contract address both the reservation of that right and the agreed notification method?
gold_answer: Where a Third Party Provider refuses a Third Party Transaction, it must provide a notification of the refusal and must do so using the agreed manner for delivering that notification [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575]. Separately, if the Third Party Provider proposes to reserve the right to stop or prevent a Third Party Transaction from being executed, the Governing Contract must include the conditions under which it proposes to reserve that right, unless otherwise agreed in writing between the Third Party Provider and their Customer [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. The same Governing Contract must also document the means of communication agreed between the parties for transmitting information or notifications (and any relevant technical requirements), which provides the contractual basis for what constitutes the “agreed manner” for refusal notifications [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. Together, these obligations require that the refusal event is both contractually anticipated (through stated conditions for stopping/preventing execution) and operationally communicated to the Customer through the contractually agreed notification channel [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575] [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49].

question: If a Third Party Provider refuses a Third Party Transaction, how does it have to send the refusal notice, and where should the agreed way of sending notices be written down for the Customer?
gold_answer: When a Third Party Provider refuses a Third Party Transaction, it must send a notification of that refusal, and it must send it using the agreed manner for providing the notification [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575]. The place where that “agreed manner” should be clearly set out for the Customer is the Governing Contract between the Third Party Provider and their Customers, unless the Third Party Provider and their Customer otherwise agree in writing [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. The Governing Contract must include the means of communication agreed between the parties for transmitting information or notifications, and it must also cover any relevant technical requirements for the Customer’s equipment and software to receive those notifications [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. This ensures the Customer knows exactly how refusal notifications will be delivered (for example, via the agreed communication channel) and what is needed to receive them, so the Third Party Provider can meet its obligation to notify in the agreed manner when a refusal occurs [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575] [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49].

question: If the contract says the Third Party Provider can stop or prevent a Third Party Transaction, what must the Third Party Provider do when it actually refuses a transaction, and what contract details support that?
gold_answer: If a Third Party Provider actually refuses a Third Party Transaction, it must provide a refusal notification and must provide that notification in the agreed manner [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575]. The Governing Contract supports this in two key ways (unless the Third Party Provider and their Customer otherwise agree in writing). First, it must include the conditions under which the Third Party Provider proposes to reserve the right to stop or prevent a Third Party Transaction from being executed, so the Customer can understand when a refusal may happen [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. Second, it must include the agreed means of communication for sending information or notifications (and any relevant technical requirements for the Customer’s equipment and software), which defines how the refusal notification will be delivered in practice [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. Taken together, the contract explains both the basis for stopping/preventing execution and the agreed channel for communicating the refusal to the Customer [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575] [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49].

question: When an Authorised Person has a CR Exposure to a qualifying multilateral development bank, what risk weight must be applied, and in what way may guarantees from MDBs be recognised as eligible credit risk mitigation in relation to that exposure?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person has a CR Exposure to a qualifying multilateral development bank, the Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to that exposure, provided the MDB is one of the listed qualifying MDBs (including, for example, members of The World Bank Group such as IBRD, MIGA, and IFC, as well as ADB, AfDB, EBRD, IADB, EIB, EIF, NIB, CDB, IDB, and CEDB) [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4]. In parallel, the Authorised Person is permitted to recognise guarantees as credit risk mitigation where the guarantee is provided by an eligible guarantor, and the eligible guarantor categories expressly include the MDBs referenced for this purpose [#SRC:bedaa8b8-4488-4156-9886-a8e1e2edd6b8]. Accordingly, for exposures involving qualifying MDBs, the compliance outcome combines (i) the mandatory application of the 0% risk weight to CR Exposures to the qualifying MDBs and (ii) the discretionary ability to recognise guarantees when they are provided by eligible guarantors that include the relevant MDB category, subject to the Authorised Person’s decision to use that recognition as part of its credit risk mitigation approach.

question: If an Authorised Person has a credit exposure to one of the listed MDBs, what risk weight must be used, and can the Authorised Person also treat an MDB-provided guarantee as an eligible guarantee for credit risk mitigation?
gold_answer: For a CR Exposure to an MDB that is on the qualifying list, an Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to that exposure [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4]. The qualifying list includes specific MDBs such as The World Bank Group (IBRD, MIGA, and IFC), ADB, AfDB, EBRD, IADB, EIB, EIF, NIB, CDB, IDB, and CEDB. Separately, the Authorised Person may recognise guarantees as a form of credit risk mitigation when the guarantee is provided by an eligible guarantor, and the eligible guarantor categories include MDBs for this purpose [#SRC:bedaa8b8-4488-4156-9886-a8e1e2edd6b8]. Putting these together, the rule set requires the 0% risk weight outcome for exposures to the qualifying MDBs, while also allowing (but not requiring) the Authorised Person to recognise an MDB-provided guarantee as eligible credit risk mitigation where it chooses to rely on that guarantee and the guarantor falls within the eligible MDB category.

question: When a Fund Manager proposes to remove and replace the Trustee of an Investment Trust, what independence condition must the replacement Trustee satisfy in relation to the Fund Manager, and what submissions must be provided so the Regulator may grant approval for the replacement?
gold_answer: In seeking to replace a Trustee, the Fund Manager must ensure the proposed replacement Trustee satisfies the independence requirement applicable to a Trustee of an Investment Trust, meaning the Trustee must be independent of the Fund Manager and must not fall within any of the specified non-independence relationships (including cross-shareholdings or voting rights, common holding company arrangements, overlapping Directors on the Governing Body, shared individuals performing Controlled Functions, or professional/material business dealings within the previous two years other than acting in their respective roles) [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c]. The Regulator is permitted to grant approval for the replacement only after it has received a written notice from the Fund Manager stating its intention to remove the Trustee, together with either a certification that the removal will not adversely affect Unitholders’ interests and the Fund Manager’s ability to comply with its obligations, or a Special Resolution of Unitholders approving the removal and replacement [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2]. In addition, the Regulator must receive the written consent of the person agreeing to act as the replacement Trustee, and that person must meet the applicable requirements to be able to act as the replacement Trustee [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2].

question: If the Regulator is asked to approve a replacement of a Trustee, how must the Fund Manager demonstrate that the incoming Trustee will be independent of the Fund Manager, and what alternative Unitholder or certification pathway can support the approval request?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager must structure the replacement so that the incoming Trustee is independent of the Fund Manager of that Investment Trust, and therefore does not have any of the disqualifying connections that make a Trustee not independent—such as either party holding Shares or exercising voting rights in the other, having a common holding company or common ultimate holding company, sharing Directors across their Governing Bodies, sharing individuals performing Controlled Functions, or having had professional or material business dealings in the previous two years other than acting as Fund Manager or Trustee respectively [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c]. For the Regulator to be able to grant approval, the Fund Manager must submit a written notice of its intention to remove the Trustee and then satisfy one of two alternative pathways: either provide a certification addressing adverse impact on Unitholders’ interests and the Fund Manager’s ability to comply with its obligations, or obtain and provide a Special Resolution of Unitholders approving the removal and replacement [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2]. The approval request must also include the written consent of the proposed replacement Trustee, and the proposed replacement must meet the applicable requirements to be able to act in that role [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2].

question: If a Fund Manager wants to replace the Trustee, what must be true about the new Trustee’s independence from the Fund Manager, and what documents must the Regulator receive before it can approve the replacement?
gold_answer: The replacement Trustee must be independent of the Fund Manager of the Investment Trust, meaning the Trustee cannot have certain close links with the Fund Manager. In particular, independence is not met if the Fund Manager or the Trustee holds Shares or voting rights in the other, if they share a common holding company or common ultimate holding company, if they have Directors who sit on both Governing Bodies, if they share individuals performing Controlled Functions, or if they have had professional or material business dealings in the previous two years other than acting as Fund Manager or Trustee respectively [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c]. Separately, the Regulator may approve the replacement only after receiving specific submissions: a written notice from the Fund Manager stating its intention to remove the Trustee, plus either (i) a certification that the removal will not adversely affect Unitholders’ interests and the Fund Manager’s ability to comply with its obligations, or (ii) a Special Resolution of Unitholders approving the removal and replacement [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2]. The Regulator must also receive the written consent of the person who will be the replacement Trustee, and that person must meet the applicable requirements to be able to act as replacement Trustee [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2].

question: When changing a Trustee, what must the Fund Manager check to avoid a non-independent Trustee relationship, and what are the two ways (certification or Unitholder vote) to support the Regulator’s approval?
gold_answer: Before proposing a replacement, the Fund Manager must check that the incoming Trustee will be independent of the Fund Manager for that Investment Trust. The Trustee will not be independent if there are cross-holdings of Shares or voting rights, a common holding company or common ultimate holding company, overlapping Directors on each other’s Governing Bodies, shared individuals performing Controlled Functions, or professional/material business dealings in the last two years other than acting as Fund Manager or Trustee respectively [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c]. To obtain the Regulator’s approval to replace the Trustee, the Fund Manager must give the Regulator a written notice of its intention to remove the Trustee and then follow one of two routes: provide a certification that the change will not adversely affect Unitholders’ interests and the Fund Manager’s ability to comply with its obligations, or provide a Special Resolution of Unitholders approving the removal and replacement [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2]. In all cases, the Regulator must also receive the written consent of the proposed replacement Trustee, and the proposed replacement must meet the applicable requirements to be able to act as replacement Trustee [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2].

question: When an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business is permitted to pay, or permit to be paid, Client Money to a Third-Party Agent, what specific record relating to that permission must be included in the Authorised Person’s Resolution Pack, and what condition must be satisfied before the payment is allowed?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may pay, or permit to be paid, Client Money to a Third-Party Agent only if it has first carried out a prior assessment of the suitability of that Third-Party Agent and, on reasonable grounds, concluded that the Third-Party Agent is suitable to hold Client Money in a Client Account [#TGT:7ec4ca22-df40-4fb5-ae3b-c48036500143]. In parallel, because the Authorised Person is conducting Investment Business, it must ensure its Resolution Pack includes the records evidencing the assessment of appropriateness of the Third-Party Agent (and the related acknowledgement by the Third-Party Agent in respect of Client Money) so that the basis for using the Third-Party Agent is documented and retrievable as part of the Resolution Pack contents [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. Read together, the permission to transfer Client Money is conditional on completing and documenting the prior suitability assessment, and the Resolution Pack obligation requires that the assessment record (and associated acknowledgement record) is maintained within the specified pack to support oversight and resolution readiness.

question: If an Authorised Person wants to send Client Money to a Third-Party Agent, what must it do first, and what paperwork about that step has to be kept in the Resolution Pack?
gold_answer: Before an Authorised Person may pay, or permit to be paid, Client Money to a Third-Party Agent, it must complete a prior assessment of the suitability of that Third-Party Agent and reach a reasonable, evidence-based conclusion that the Third-Party Agent is suitable to hold Client Money in a Client Account [#TGT:7ec4ca22-df40-4fb5-ae3b-c48036500143]. Separately, because the Authorised Person is conducting Investment Business, it must include in its Resolution Pack the records that relate to the assessment of appropriateness of the Third-Party Agent and the Third-Party Agent’s acknowledgement in respect of Client Money [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. Putting these together, the “can pay Client Money to a Third-Party Agent” permission depends on doing the assessment first, and the “must include records in the Resolution Pack” requirement means the Authorised Person needs to keep the assessment record (and the related acknowledgement record) in the Resolution Pack so there is a clear audit trail showing why the Third-Party Agent was considered suitable.

question: When an Exposure is only partially guaranteed by an Authorised Person’s Parent Financial Institution and the guaranteed portion would attract a lower risk weight, how must the Authorised Person apply the prohibition on incurring a Large Exposure above the Tier 1 percentage cap after recognising eligible CRM—specifically, is it prohibited to treat the entire Exposure as exempt, or only the guaranteed portion?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is prohibited from incurring any Large Exposure in its Non Trading Book (and, subject to the stated conditions, its Trading Book) that exceeds 25% of its Tier 1 after taking into account the effect of any eligible CRM [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f]. Where an Exposure is partially guaranteed by the Authorised Person’s Parent Financial Institution and the guaranteed portion would be assigned a lower risk weight, the exemption is limited: only the part of the Exposure that is subject to the guarantee is exempt from the Large Exposure limit, not the unguaranteed remainder [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3]. Accordingly, it would be inconsistent with the prohibition to exclude the full Exposure from the Large Exposures calculation merely because a parental guarantee exists; the Authorised Person must separate the guaranteed and unguaranteed portions, apply the exemption only to the guaranteed portion, and then assess whether the remaining exposure (after recognising eligible CRM effects) would breach the 25% Tier 1 cap. The Authorised Person may also consider other permitted exemptions relating to parental guarantees when determining the final treatment [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3].

question: If an Exposure is partly covered by a guarantee from an Authorised Person’s Parent Financial Institution, is the Authorised Person prohibited from ignoring the whole Exposure when checking whether it has a Large Exposure above the Tier 1 limit, or can it ignore only the guaranteed part after factoring in eligible CRM?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must not incur a Large Exposure in its Non Trading Book (and, subject to the stated conditions, its Trading Book) that exceeds 25% of its Tier 1 once it has taken into account the effect of any eligible CRM [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f]. The definition of exempt treatment for a partial parental guarantee is narrow: if an Exposure is only partially guaranteed by the Authorised Person’s Parent Financial Institution and the guaranteed portion would receive a lower risk weight, only that guaranteed portion is exempt from the Large Exposure limit; the rest of the Exposure remains subject to the limit [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3]. So, it is not permitted to treat the entire Exposure as exempt just because there is some parental guarantee. Instead, the Authorised Person should carve out the guaranteed part as exempt, then apply the Large Exposures prohibition to the remaining part (after eligible CRM effects) to confirm it does not exceed the Tier 1 percentage cap. The Authorised Person may also consider other exemptions permitted for parental guarantees when applying this treatment [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3].

question: How must an Authorised Person operationalise daily monitoring and control of its Exposures so that it remains within the applicable Large Exposures limits, including the requirement to keep the aggregate of its Large Exposures within the Tier 1-based cap?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must implement a daily process that both (i) monitors and controls its Exposures within the Large Exposures limits and (ii) ensures the sum of its Large Exposures stays within the Tier 1-based ceiling. Practically, this requires the Authorised Person to identify its Exposures and Counterparties (including whether any are Closely Related or Connected), measure and establish Exposure values, and determine Exposure size as a proportion of Tier 1, so that daily monitoring is anchored to current Tier 1 and Exposure metrics [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675]. It must also aggregate Exposures to the same Counterparty or relevant groupings, and identify any Exposures subject to CRM requirements or exempt from the limits, so that the daily control framework reflects the correct perimeter of constrained Exposures [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675]. In parallel, the Authorised Person must ensure that the sum of its Large Exposures does not exceed 800% of its Tier 1, which functions as the quantitative cap that the daily monitoring and control must be designed to enforce [#TGT:342299bc-1d26-4555-9104-cf3347054697].

question: What must an Authorised Person do each day to track and manage its Exposures so it stays within the Large Exposures limits, and how does this link to the rule that caps the total of its Large Exposures as a percentage of Tier 1?
gold_answer: Each day, an Authorised Person must run controls that let it monitor and control its Exposures within the Large Exposures limits while also keeping the total of its Large Exposures within the Tier 1-based cap. To do that, it must first identify its Exposures and identify its Counterparties, including checking whether any Counterparties are Closely Related to each other or Connected to the Authorised Person, because those relationships affect how Exposures must be grouped and managed [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675]. It must measure and establish the value of Exposures and determine their size as a proportion of Tier 1, then aggregate Exposures to the same Counterparty or to groups of Closely Related or Connected Counterparties, so the daily view reflects the correct combined risk position [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675]. It must also identify Exposures subject to CRM requirements and any Exposures that are exempt from the limits, so daily monitoring focuses on the right set of constrained Exposures [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675]. Finally, it must ensure the sum of its Large Exposures does not exceed 800% of its Tier 1, which is the overall quantitative limit the daily controls must enforce [#TGT:342299bc-1d26-4555-9104-cf3347054697].

question: When a Recognised Investment Exchange engages a Clearing Service, what must it do to ensure timely discharge and clearing and settlement of parties’ rights and liabilities, and in what circumstances can the engagement of a Recognised Clearing House or Remote Clearing House be treated as sufficient to meet that requirement?
gold_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange, when engaging a Clearing Service, must ensure that satisfactory arrangements are in place to secure the timely discharge (including by performance, compromise or otherwise) and the clearing and settlement of the rights and liabilities of the parties to transactions effected on the Recognised Investment Exchange, insofar as those rights and liabilities relate to those transactions [#TGT:c56de460-9435-43a8-b170-bfe38c05a616]. In assessing whether this obligation is met, the framework also recognises that the engagement of a Recognised Clearing House or a Remote Clearing House can be treated as sufficient to satisfy the relevant standard referenced in the source provision [#SRC:9217cc24-dbcc-43e5-8884-f398ee26b820]. Read together, this means the Recognised Investment Exchange must still focus on the outcome—satisfactory arrangements that secure timely discharge and clearing and settlement—while it may rely on engaging a Recognised Clearing House or Remote Clearing House as a deemed-sufficient way of meeting that standard in the context of its Clearing Service engagement [#SRC:9217cc24-dbcc-43e5-8884-f398ee26b820] [#TGT:c56de460-9435-43a8-b170-bfe38c05a616].

question: If a Recognised Investment Exchange uses a Clearing Service, what does it have to make sure happens for clearing and settlement, and can it rely on engaging a Recognised Clearing House or Remote Clearing House as enough to meet that standard?
gold_answer: When a Recognised Investment Exchange engages a Clearing Service, it must ensure that satisfactory arrangements are made to secure the timely discharge of obligations (including by performance, compromise or otherwise) and the clearing and settlement of the rights and liabilities of the parties to transactions effected on the Recognised Investment Exchange, where those rights and liabilities relate to those transactions [#TGT:c56de460-9435-43a8-b170-bfe38c05a616]. Alongside that obligation, the source provision indicates that engaging a Recognised Clearing House or a Remote Clearing House is treated as sufficient to satisfy the referenced requirement [#SRC:9217cc24-dbcc-43e5-8884-f398ee26b820]. Putting both together, the Recognised Investment Exchange still has the duty to ensure the arrangements are satisfactory and achieve timely discharge and clearing and settlement, but it can treat the engagement of a Recognised Clearing House or Remote Clearing House as a deemed-sufficient way of meeting that requirement in the context of its Clearing Service engagement [#SRC:9217cc24-dbcc-43e5-8884-f398ee26b820] [#TGT:c56de460-9435-43a8-b170-bfe38c05a616].

question: When the Rules distinguish between an Authorised Person operating as a Branch versus operating as a Domestic Firm, what capital-resources obligations must be met by the Authorised Person that falls within the Domestic Firm category, and how does that scope boundary affect the applicability of those obligations?
gold_answer: The scope provision differentiates which requirements apply depending on how an Authorised Person is operating: one set applies when the Authorised Person is operating as a Branch, while a different set applies when the Authorised Person is operating as a Domestic Firm [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6]. Where the Authorised Person is a Domestic Firm, it must comply with the capital-resources obligations specified for Domestic Firms. Specifically, the Authorised Person must have and maintain, at all times, Capital Resources of the types and amounts specified in, and calculated in accordance with, the Rules, and it must also ensure it maintains capital and liquid assets in addition to that baseline requirement that are adequate for the nature, size, and complexity of its business so there is no significant risk it cannot meet liabilities as they fall due [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56]. The scope boundary matters because these capital and liquidity maintenance duties are framed to apply to an Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm, rather than to an Authorised Person operating as a Branch, so classification as a Domestic Firm is the trigger for these ongoing “at all times” requirements.

question: If an Authorised Person is operating as a Domestic Firm (not as a Branch), what must it do to maintain capital resources and liquidity, and why does the operating category matter for which Rules apply?
gold_answer: The Rules first set the boundary for applicability by stating that different requirements apply depending on whether an Authorised Person is operating as a Branch or operating as a Domestic Firm [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6]. Once the Authorised Person falls into the Domestic Firm category, it has specific ongoing obligations on capital resources and liquidity. It must have and maintain, at all times, Capital Resources of the types and amounts specified in the Rules and calculated in accordance with those Rules [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56]. In addition, it must ensure it maintains extra capital and liquid assets beyond that baseline, and those additional resources must be adequate for the nature, size, and complexity of its business so there is no significant risk that it cannot meet its liabilities as they fall due [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56]. The operating category matters because the scope text makes clear that the Domestic Firm set of requirements applies to an Authorised Person operating as a Domestic Firm, while a different set applies to an Authorised Person operating as a Branch [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6].

question: When a Trading Halt is imposed, what must be observed about the maximum duration of a Trading Halt of the relevant type, and in what circumstances is the Regulator permitted to impose a suspension in connection with that Trading Halt?
gold_answer: Where the Trading Halt is of the type imposed pursuant to Rule 7.8.1, it must not run for more than two Business Days, unless the Regulator agrees to a shorter period; this duration cap is a binding constraint on how long that Trading Halt can remain in effect [#TGT:88d53574-f94b-4da4-8a47-2afa2fd511db]. In parallel, the Regulator is permitted to impose a suspension in accordance with Rule 2.6 in relation to Trading Halts, including the ability to do so at any time during a Trading Halt established under Rule 7.8.1, and also upon completion of the duration of a Trading Halt established under Rule 7.8.2 [#SRC:dd30220a-9ed3-4f7f-98aa-99f1bd8dd3da]. Read together, this means that for a Rule 7.8.1 Trading Halt, the Trading Halt itself is time-limited as described, while the Regulator retains discretion to impose a suspension during that Trading Halt (and, for the other Trading Halt type, after its duration completes).

question: If there is a Trading Halt of the kind covered here, how long can it last at most, and when can the Regulator impose a suspension linked to that Trading Halt?
gold_answer: For a Trading Halt imposed pursuant to Rule 7.8.1, the Trading Halt cannot last longer than two Business Days, unless the Regulator agrees it will be shorter; that limit sets the outer boundary for the Trading Halt’s duration [#TGT:88d53574-f94b-4da4-8a47-2afa2fd511db]. Separately, the Regulator has permission to impose a suspension in accordance with Rule 2.6 in connection with Trading Halts: it may impose that suspension at any time during a Trading Halt established under Rule 7.8.1, and it may also impose a suspension upon completion of the duration of a Trading Halt established under Rule 7.8.2 [#SRC:dd30220a-9ed3-4f7f-98aa-99f1bd8dd3da]. Putting both points together, you should treat the Trading Halt’s maximum length (for the Rule 7.8.1 type) as fixed by the two-Business-Day cap, while also recognizing that the Regulator can decide to move from a Trading Halt to a suspension during that same Trading Halt period (and, for the other Trading Halt type, after it ends).

question: When calculating CET1 Capital, what exclusions must an Authorised Person apply, and how must it ensure those required exclusions are implemented without making prohibited fair-value adjustments to remove unrealised gains or losses from its Capital Resources (other than the limited carve-out referenced in the prohibition)?
gold_answer: In calculating CET1 Capital, an Authorised Person must apply specific exclusions, including (i) certain increases in equity under the International Financial Reporting Standards (notably where linked to future margin income that produces a gain on sale, and—where the Authorised Person is the Originator of a securitisation—net gains from capitalising future income from securitised assets that provide Credit Enhancement), (ii) the cash flow hedge reserve amount related to gains or losses on cash flow hedges of Financial Instruments that are not valued at fair value (including projected cash flows), and (iii) unrealised gains or losses on the Authorised Person’s fair-valued liabilities that arise from changes in its own credit quality, subject to an exception where those gains or losses are offset by a corresponding fair-value change in another fair-valued Financial Instrument driven by the same own-credit-quality changes [#TGT:6e1d64e5-60c2-4627-af1c-f05e612f92bc]. At the same time, outside the limited carve-out referenced in the prohibition, the Authorised Person must not make adjustments whose purpose is to remove from its Capital Resources unrealised gains or losses on assets or liabilities measured at fair value [#SRC:977b51e8-a945-4729-87fb-0845f5319ed6]. Practically, this means implementing the mandated CET1 exclusions while avoiding any additional, discretionary fair-value “removal” adjustments beyond what is expressly contemplated.

question: For CET1 Capital, what items must an Authorised Person leave out, and what does it mean that it generally must not adjust its Capital Resources just to strip out unrealised fair-value gains or losses (apart from the limited carve-out mentioned)?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must exclude several specified items when it calculates CET1 Capital. These include certain increases in equity under the International Financial Reporting Standards—especially increases tied to future margin income that creates a gain on sale, and (if the Authorised Person is the Originator of a securitisation) net gains from capitalising future income from securitised assets that provide Credit Enhancement. It must also exclude the cash flow hedge reserve amount relating to gains or losses on cash flow hedges of Financial Instruments that are not valued at fair value (including projected cash flows). In addition, it must exclude unrealised gains or losses on its own liabilities that are valued at fair value when those gains or losses come from changes in the Authorised Person’s own credit quality, except to the extent they are offset by a corresponding own-credit-quality-driven fair-value change in another fair-valued Financial Instrument [#TGT:6e1d64e5-60c2-4627-af1c-f05e612f92bc]. Alongside these required CET1 exclusions, the Authorised Person is generally prohibited from making adjustments that remove from its Capital Resources unrealised gains or losses on fair-valued assets or liabilities, other than the limited carve-out referenced in the prohibition [#SRC:977b51e8-a945-4729-87fb-0845f5319ed6].

question: When an Authorised Person has an Exposure to a Client that is guaranteed by a third party, in what circumstances is the Authorised Person prohibited from treating the guaranteed portion as an Exposure to the third party for purposes of assessing whether it would exceed the applicable Large Exposures threshold, and what conditions must be satisfied for such treatment to be permitted?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is prohibited from structuring or recognising a guaranteed portion in a way that would allow it to incur a Large Exposure in its Non Trading Book (and, subject to the stated Trading Book qualification) that exceeds 25% of its Tier 1 after taking into account the effect of any eligible CRM; the Large Exposures limit applies on that post-CRM basis and must not be breached [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f]. However, where an Exposure to a Client is guaranteed by a third party, the Authorised Person is permitted to treat the portion of the Exposure that is guaranteed as an Exposure to the third party (rather than to the Client) for the purpose of considering the relevant limits, but only if the guarantee meets the CRM requirements and would be assigned a lower risk weight, and the Authorised Person must treat the guaranteed portion as having been incurred to the third party on that basis [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e]. In addition, the guarantee analysis must not involve any Maturity Mismatch between the guarantee and the underlying Exposure; if there is a mismatch, the permitted treatment cannot be relied upon for limit assessment [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e].

question: If an Authorised Person seeks to re-allocate part of an Exposure to a third party because it is secured by third-party Collateral, how does the prohibition on exceeding the Large Exposures cap apply after eligible CRM effects are recognised, and what prerequisites govern whether the secured portion may be treated as incurred to the third party rather than the Client?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must not incur any Large Exposures in its Non Trading Book (and, subject to the stated Trading Book qualification) that exceed 25% of its Tier 1 once it has taken into account the effect of any eligible CRM; accordingly, any re-allocation of exposure via collateral recognition cannot be used to justify a position that still exceeds the cap on that post-CRM basis [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f]. At the same time, where Exposures to a Client are secured by Collateral issued by a third party, the Authorised Person is permitted to treat the portion of the Exposure secured by that Collateral as an Exposure to the third party, and it must treat that secured portion as having been incurred to the third party providing the Collateral rather than to the Client for purposes of considering the relevant limits [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e]. This permission is conditional: the Collateral must meet the CRM requirements and must be of a type that would be assigned a lower risk weight. If those prerequisites are not met, the secured portion cannot be treated as exposure to the third party for limit assessment, and the Large Exposures prohibition continues to apply to the exposure as incurred [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e].

question: If a Client exposure is guaranteed by a third party, when must an Authorised Person not end up with a Large Exposure above the limit, and when is it allowed to count the guaranteed part as exposure to the third party instead of the Client?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must not incur a Large Exposure in its Non Trading Book (and, subject to the stated Trading Book qualification) that exceeds 25% of its Tier 1 after it has taken into account the effect of any eligible CRM; so even with CRM recognition, the exposure position must not breach that cap [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f]. Where the Exposure to the Client is guaranteed by a third party, the Authorised Person is allowed to treat the portion that is guaranteed as an Exposure to the third party (not the Client) for the purpose of considering the applicable limits, but only if the guarantee meets the CRM requirements and would be assigned a lower risk weight [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e]. The Authorised Person must also treat that guaranteed portion as having been incurred to the third party on that basis when assessing the limits. In addition, there must not be any Maturity Mismatch between the guarantee and the underlying Exposure; if there is a mismatch, the guarantee cannot be relied on in the way described for limit assessment [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e].

question: If a Client exposure is secured by Collateral issued by a third party, what is the rule that says an Authorised Person must not go over the Large Exposures cap, and what has to be true before the secured part can be treated as exposure to the third party?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must not incur any Large Exposures in its Non Trading Book (and, subject to the stated Trading Book qualification) that exceed 25% of its Tier 1 after taking into account the effect of any eligible CRM; the limit is applied after recognising eligible CRM effects and must not be exceeded [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f]. Separately, if the Exposure to the Client is secured by Collateral issued by a third party, the Authorised Person may treat the portion of the Exposure that is secured by that Collateral as an Exposure to the third party, and it must treat that secured portion as incurred to the third party providing the Collateral rather than to the Client for purposes of considering the relevant limits [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e]. This is only allowed if the Collateral meets the CRM requirements and would be assigned a lower risk weight. If those conditions are not met, the secured portion cannot be shifted to the third party for limit assessment, and the Large Exposures cap still constrains what the Authorised Person may incur [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e].

question: Where a Listed Entity qualifies for admission to the Official List and meets the Regulator’s profitability/revenue or tangible-asset criteria so that APP 7 category restrictions are disapplied unless the Regulator decides otherwise, may a Controller also be treated as not needing to be a party to the relevant Restriction Agreement, and on what bases?
gold_answer: Yes, these provisions can operate together, but they address different compliance outcomes. Under the TARGET, unless the Regulator decides otherwise, the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply in relation to a Listed Entity that qualifies for admission to the Official List and either has a track record of profitability or revenue acceptable to the Regulator, or (in the Regulator’s opinion) has tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value forming a substantial proportion of total assets [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]. Separately, under the SOURCE, a Controller need not be a party to the Restriction Agreement if any specified condition applies, including where the value of the Restricted Security is less than 10% of the total value of the assets of the holder of the Restricted Securities or an intermediate entity through which the Controller has its interests; where the holder or such intermediate entity is a Listed Entity (or listed on an exchange that is a full member of the World Federation of Exchanges) or is a trustee, custodian or nominee; or where the holder is a Person whose Securities are Restricted Securities due to category 2, 4 or 6 of APP 7 [#SRC:afb239cd-ac67-4702-8e1d-e5293bccd010].

question: If the Regulator treats a Listed Entity as not subject to certain APP 7 restriction categories because it qualifies for admission and meets the profitability/revenue or tangible-asset test, can the Controller still avoid signing the Restriction Agreement, and when is that allowed?
gold_answer: It can be allowed, but you need to apply both tests to the right issue. The TARGET says that, unless the Regulator decides otherwise, the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply in relation to a Listed Entity that qualifies for admission to the Official List and either has a track record of profitability or revenue acceptable to the Regulator, or (in the Regulator’s opinion) has tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value that make up a substantial proportion of its total assets [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]. The SOURCE separately permits a Controller not to be a party to the Restriction Agreement if any listed condition applies: the Restricted Security is under 10% of the total asset value of the holder or an intermediate entity through which the Controller has its interests; or the holder/intermediate entity is a Listed Entity (or listed on a qualifying exchange) or is a trustee, custodian or nominee; or the holder is a Person whose Securities are Restricted Securities due to category 2, 4 or 6 of APP 7 [#SRC:afb239cd-ac67-4702-8e1d-e5293bccd010].

question: What must a Listed Entity ensure is built into its constitution to support enforceability of Restriction Agreements, and how does this obligation align with the requirement that an Applicant operate in conformity with its constitution as part of being validly established under the laws of its place of incorporation or establishment?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity must ensure that its constitution contains provisions that allow Restriction Agreements to be enforced, meaning the constitutional framework must expressly support enforceability rather than leaving it uncertain or dependent on external arrangements [#SRC:e54d518f-d9f5-40da-a031-b346bfca2a53]. In parallel, an Applicant is required to be duly incorporated or otherwise validly established under the relevant laws of its place of incorporation or establishment and to operate in conformity with its constitution, so the constitution is not merely a formal document but a binding set of rules the Applicant must follow in practice [#TGT:0011b198-f2c8-4274-b104-904e8a80b9d0]. Read together, the compliance expectation is twofold: (i) the constitution must include the necessary enabling provisions to permit enforcement of Restriction Agreements for Listed Entities, and (ii) the entity’s ongoing operations must conform to that constitution as part of maintaining its valid establishment status as an Applicant. Accordingly, constitutional drafting and operational adherence must be consistent so that enforcement mechanisms contemplated by Restriction Agreements are both permitted by the constitution and implemented through compliant conduct.

question: What do Listed Entities need to put in their constitution so Restriction Agreements can be enforced, and what does an Applicant have to do to show it is properly set up and following its constitution?
gold_answer: Listed Entities must make sure their constitution includes provisions that allow Restriction Agreements to be enforced, so the constitution itself supports taking action under those agreements when needed [#SRC:e54d518f-d9f5-40da-a031-b346bfca2a53]. Separately, an Applicant must be duly incorporated or otherwise validly established under the laws that apply where it is incorporated or established, and it must operate in conformity with its constitution, meaning its day-to-day conduct must match what the constitution requires [#TGT:0011b198-f2c8-4274-b104-904e8a80b9d0]. Putting these together, the constitution matters in two ways: it must contain the right enabling language (so Restriction Agreements are enforceable for Listed Entities), and the entity must actually follow that constitution in operation (as required for an Applicant’s valid establishment and ongoing compliance). In practice, this means the entity should both draft the constitution to permit enforcement and ensure its operations do not contradict those constitutional provisions.

question: For an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5 that is also an Authorised Person Managing a PSIA which is an Unrestricted PSIA, what exposures are prohibited when considering (i) Financial Group Large Exposure (including the Financial Group's PSIAus) relative to the Group’s Tier 1 and (ii) Exposure to a Counterparty or related counterparty group relative to Capital Resources, including where the exposure is financed by Capital Resources and/or Unrestricted PSIAs?
gold_answer: The prohibitions operate in parallel and require the Authorised Person to monitor both group-level and counterparty-level concentration limits. First, where the Authorised Person is in Category 1, 2 or 5, it must not incur any Financial Group Large Exposure (including the Financial Group’s PSIAus) that exceeds 25% of its Group’s Tier 1, so any Financial Group Large Exposure above that threshold is prohibited [#SRC:daaa6de1-3ef9-4148-ae13-789a1bb8a600]. Second, where the Authorised Person is Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA, it must not have an Exposure to a Counterparty, Connected Counterparty, group of Closely Related Counterparties, or group of Connected Counterparties that exceeds specified percentages of its Capital Resources, with the applicable cap depending on how the exposure is financed [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f]. Specifically, an exposure is prohibited if it exceeds 25% when financed by its Capital Resources or Unrestricted PSIAs, or exceeds 40% when financed by an aggregate of its own Capital Resources and Unrestricted PSIAs [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f].

question: If an Authorised Person is in Category 1, 2 or 5 and also manages an Unrestricted PSIA, what must it not do regarding (1) Financial Group Large Exposure (including the Financial Group’s PSIAus) and (2) exposure to a counterparty or related counterparty group, and what percentage limits apply in each case?
gold_answer: It must avoid breaching two separate exposure prohibitions that apply in different ways. At the financial group level, an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5 must not incur any Financial Group Large Exposure, including the Financial Group’s PSIAus, if that Financial Group Large Exposure exceeds 25% of its Group’s Tier 1; any amount above that 25% threshold is prohibited [#SRC:daaa6de1-3ef9-4148-ae13-789a1bb8a600]. Separately, when the same Authorised Person is Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA, it must not have an Exposure to a Counterparty, Connected Counterparty, group of Closely Related Counterparties, or group of Connected Counterparties that exceeds the applicable percentage of its Capital Resources [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f]. The prohibited level depends on financing: the exposure must not exceed 25% if it is financed by its Capital Resources or Unrestricted PSIAs, and it must not exceed 40% if it is financed by an aggregate of its own Capital Resources and Unrestricted PSIAs [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f].

question: When the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, may the Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User agree in writing that the regime governing charges for information will not apply, and how does that interact with their ability to agree charges for information requested by the Payment Service User that is extra, more frequent, or sent via a different communication method than the Framework Contract specifies?
gold_answer: Yes. Where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider are permitted to agree in writing that the specific Rules dealing with charges for information do not apply, meaning they can contract out of that default rule set for this topic [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]. Separately, the framework also permits the Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User to agree on charges for information provided at the Payment Service User’s request when the information falls into defined categories: it is additional to what must otherwise be provided or made available, it is provided more frequently than specified, or it is transmitted using a means of communication other than those specified in the Framework Contract [#TGT:18f42ca0-235a-47ac-9e8c-47bd6dd631d7]. Read together, the parties can (i) rely on the permission to agree charges for these types of requested information, and (ii) if the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, additionally agree in writing that the default Rules on charges for information are disapplied, leaving the charging approach to their written agreement within the overall contractual arrangement.

question: If the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, can the Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User put in writing that the usual rules about charging for information won’t apply, and can they still agree to charge for information the Payment Service User asks for that is extra, more frequent, or sent in a different way than the Framework Contract says?
gold_answer: Yes. The texts work in tandem. First, when the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider are allowed to agree in writing that the Rules on charges for information do not apply, which is an explicit permission to disapply that default rule set by written agreement [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]. Second, there is also a general permission for the Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User to agree on charges for information that is provided at the request of the Payment Service User, but only where the information is (a) additional to what must otherwise be provided or made available, (b) provided more frequently than specified, or (c) transmitted using a communication method other than those specified in the Framework Contract [#TGT:18f42ca0-235a-47ac-9e8c-47bd6dd631d7]. Putting these together, the parties can agree charges for those categories of requested information, and—if the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person—can also document in writing that the default information-charging Rules are switched off, so the written agreement governs instead.

question: When a substantial additional regulatory burden arises for FSRA and the Regulator expects substantial additional costs or effort in handling an application, authorisation, filing, or ongoing supervision, may the Regulator require a Person (including an Applicant/Authorised Person) to pay supplementary or additional fees, and what practical step is recommended to manage the fee implications?
gold_answer: Yes. The SOURCE establishes that FSRA reserves the right to impose additional fees where a “substantial additional” regulatory burden is imposed on FSRA, and it highlights that such circumstances can include a migration of an MTF to become a conventional “Securities” Recognised Investment Exchange, indicating that fee impacts may arise from increased regulatory work [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc]. The TARGET complements this by permitting the Regulator to require a Person to pay a supplementary fee when it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing, or when conducting on-going supervision, which aligns with the SOURCE’s concept of additional burden translating into additional fee recovery [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]. Taken together, the framework supports the Regulator’s ability to levy extra charges in high-effort or high-cost cases affecting Applicants/Authorised Persons. As a practical compliance step, FSRA recommends that the Applicant/Authorised Person discuss fee implications with FSRA as early as practicable, so potential supplementary/additional fees can be anticipated and managed in advance [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc].

question: If extra work is expected for FSRA/the Regulator—like when an application or ongoing supervision needs substantial additional effort—can the Regulator charge extra fees, and what should the Applicant/Authorised Person do to avoid surprises?
gold_answer: Yes. The SOURCE explains that FSRA reserves its right to impose additional fees when a “substantial additional” regulatory burden is imposed on FSRA, and it gives an example where this may occur, such as the migration of an MTF to become a conventional “Securities” Recognised Investment Exchange [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc]. The TARGET sets out a closely related permission: the Regulator may require a Person to pay a supplementary fee when it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing, or when conducting on-going supervision [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]. Reading both together, the common trigger is substantial additional burden/cost/effort, and the outcome is that extra fees (described as additional or supplementary) may be imposed or required from the relevant Person, including an Applicant/Authorised Person. To reduce uncertainty and manage budgeting and planning, FSRA recommends that the Applicant/Authorised Person discuss the fee implications with FSRA as early as practicable, particularly where the matter is likely to increase regulatory workload [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc].

question: When assessing whether a Digital Settlement Facility has satisfactory arrangements for timely discharge of parties’ rights and liabilities, how may the FSRA take into account the DSF’s clearing and settlement framework, and what is the scope of any regulatory tolerance where a Recognised Clearing House cannot arrange settlement of a particular transaction?
gold_answer: In determining whether there are satisfactory arrangements for securing the timely discharge of the rights and liabilities of the parties to transactions, the FSRA is permitted to have regard to a Digital Settlement Facility’s operational and governance arrangements across the settlement lifecycle, including its rules and practices for clearing and settlement (and any arrangements with another Person to provide those services), trade matching processes to ensure agreement on trade details, delivery and payment arrangements in relevant jurisdictions, and procedures and monitoring to detect, manage, and respond to a Member’s (or participant’s) failure to settle, including taking action to settle a trade and, where appropriate, applying Default Rules and default procedures [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36]. At the same time, the scope of non-compliance for a Recognised Clearing House is limited in that it will not be regarded as failing to comply with the Recognition Requirement merely because it is unable to arrange for a specific transaction to be settled [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e]. Read together, this means the FSRA’s assessment can focus on the DSF’s overall arrangements and controls, while recognising that an isolated inability to settle a particular transaction, by itself, does not automatically constitute a Recognition Requirement breach for a Recognised Clearing House.

question: If the FSRA is checking whether a Digital Settlement Facility has good arrangements to make sure trades settle on time, what parts of the DSF’s processes can the FSRA look at, and does a Recognised Clearing House automatically fail its Recognition Requirement if one specific transaction cannot be settled?
gold_answer: When the FSRA assesses whether there are satisfactory arrangements to secure the timely discharge of the parties’ rights and liabilities in transactions, it may look across a Digital Settlement Facility’s end-to-end clearing and settlement setup.
